headline: ESTONIA, FOR RUSSIANS, IS A WINDOW LOOKING WEST
abstract: In its 800-year history, Tallinn has survived fire, sacking, civil strife, war and occupation and yet has remained among the most charming and well-preserved of Europe's medieval towns.   Along with awe-inspiring walls and mighty towers with names like Peep- in-the-Kitchen, Stout Margaret or Tall Hermann, some 1,500 medieval buildings remain in the ancient heart of this capital of Estonia, one of the Soviet Union's 15 republics, or states.   A general restoration was completed in time for the 1980 Olympic Games, during which Tallinn served as host for sailing events. Since then this Baltic city has set about restoring each building to its original state, a project that may take generations.

headline: Closing by Inland
abstract: The Inland Steel Company said it is restructuring its raw materials operations by closing the Jackson County Iron Company in Black River Falls, Wis., its smallest iron ore mining operation. Inland, based in Chicago, said the closing of the operation, along with other lesser restructuring steps, will result in an extraordinary charge against fourth-quarter earnings of $15 million. The restructuring, attributed to lower demand for steel, will reduce Inland's work force by 330 employees.

headline: Acquisitions in U.S. Are Sweet for Finn
abstract: Today is not a holiday in Finland, but at the home of Erkki E. Railo of Helsinki, there will undoubtedly be a thanksgiving of sorts. Mr. Railo, an executive vice president of the Finland-based Huhtamaki Group, flew home from the United States earlier this week for a reunion with his family after seven months of negotiating with investment bankers and and living in hotels.   On Monday, he will return to Chicago as president and chief executive officer of his company's United States operations, a newly created position. Almost all of the United States holdings were acquired under Mr. Railo's supervision since April.

headline: SOVIET SAYS U.S. PLANS HUGE ATTACK IN LEBANON
abstract: The Soviet press agency Tass said today that the United States was planning a ''massive attack'' on ''national-patriotic forces'' in Lebanon.   ''In the leading circles of the Soviet Union it is deemed necessary to warn the United States Government with all seriousness about this, in connection with the plans to expand the armed interference in the affairs of Lebanon that are being harbored in Washington,'' the agency said.   The warning was issued as a ''Tass statement,'' which carries the weight of an official Government statement.    The agency said it was basing its warning on statements made by President Reagan, Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, as well as an unspecified ''information coming from various sources.''

headline: Military Link Charged In Aquino Slaying
abstract: The blue airport uniform worn by the purported assassin of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. came from a wardrobe of disguises maintained by the military, a lawyer for the accused man's family said today.

headline: S.E.C. Cites Touche Ross
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today censured Touche Ross & Company, a major accounting concern, for its audits of a defense contractor that was involved in a dispute with the Navy over millions of dollars in cost overruns on shipbuilding contracts.   The commission charged in an administrative proceeding that Touche Ross failed to use ''generally accepted auditing standards'' in its examinations from 1972 through 1977 of the financial statements of the contractor, Litton Industries Inc.

headline: CONE MILLS PLANNING TO GO PRIVATE
abstract: The Cone Mills Corporation, a textile company that has been the target of a takeover attempt by Western Pacific Industries, yesterday announced an agreement for Cone to be bought by management, employees and institutional investors.    Cone said holders of its 5.5 million outstanding shares would receive $70 a share, or a total of $385 million.   The stock closed yesterday at $66.75, up $3.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Its price has risen more than $20 since Western Pacific disclosed its takeover attempt early this month.

headline: BROOKLYN MAN TELLS OF ORDEAL IN GRENADA PRISON
abstract: On Aug. 15, 1979, Antonio Langdon was making repairs at his mother's home, three miles from St. George's, Grenada. His 5-year-old daughter, Shauna, was playing at his feet.    Almost casually, as he recalls it, a car stopped and two men got out. ''Come along,'' one said, ''the boss wants to ask you a few questions.''   ''Who is your boss?'' Mr. Langdon asked.

headline: Baldwin-United Sells Unit
abstract: The Baldwin-United Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Baldwin Life Insurance Company, which operates in New York State, to the Transamerica Insurance Corporation of California, a unit of the Transamerica Corporation, for about $5.4 million in cash.

headline: Vauxhall Strike Ends
abstract: Engineers and assembly workers at the Vauxhall Motor Company's plant here voted today to end their strike following a similar vote by workers at plants in Dunstable and Luton. The strike began last Friday. Union leaders here said they still reject the company's 7.75 percent pay offer and the fight for a better wage would continue inside the plant.

headline: I.B.M. WIDENS PERSONAL COMPUTER LINE
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced two new, more powerful versions of its personal computer that will enable programmers, scientists and business professionals to hook up to large I.B.M. mainframe computers from their desks.   The giant computer maker did not, however, introduce its widely anticipated home computer, once code- named the Peanut. Company officials refused to comment on this machine, which will be called the ''PC Junior,'' a less expensive version of the Personal Computer. But analysts said they expect the PC Junior, a $600 to $1,200 computer, to be announced in a few weeks.

headline: CSX Application
abstract: The CSX Corporation said that it had filed an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission to assume control of American Commercial Liners Inc., one of the largest marine transportation companies serving the inland waterways. American Commercial Lines is a former subsidiary of the Texas Gas Resources Corporation, which CSX acquired last August. Current law prohibits ownership of a barge line by a railroad, a point used by opponents of the original Texas Gas-CSX merger.

headline: BARRIER TO PHONE FEE IS VOTED
abstract: The House of Representatives tonight approved by a voice vote legislation that would block the telephone industry from charging a monthly fee for household and business phones to be linked to long-distance networks.    Earlier in the evening, the House rejected, 264 to 142, a Republican version of the bill that would have postponed the monthly fee until 1985 rather than kill it entirely.   The Federal Communications Commission has authorized the nation's local phone companies to begin on April 3 to charge $2 a month for residential phones and up to $6 a month for business telephones for access to long-distance networks. These fees would rise in subsequent years.

headline: CRAFTING A CREATIVE TAKEOVER
abstract: LONDON ALONG with its growing international reputation for creativity,    British advertising in recent years has acquired a disdain for the work done on Madison Avenue. One of the admen here who leads in creativity - and contempt for American advertising - is Frank Lowe, whose advertisements for Benson & Hedges cigarettes and Heineken beer have become industry standards. In fact, a lot about America, from its gargantuan salads to its tedious television commercials, ''appalls,'' ''shocks'' and ''frightens'' the 40-year-old Mr. Lowe.   Despite such prejudices, Mr. Lowe has just gone into business with an American partner. In September, he agreed to merge his two-year-old company, Lowe Howard-Spink, with Wasey Campbell-Ewald, the British subsidiary of Marschalk Campbell- Ewald Worldwide. Marschalk, in turn, is part of the behemoth Interpublic Group in the United States, which had billings last year of $3.6 billion.

headline: KN Rejects Mesa's Bid
abstract: The board of KN Energy Inc., an oil and natural gas producer, has rejected an acquisition proposal by the Mesa Petroleum Company, which would have been carried out by an exchange of shares.   Instead, KN Energy said yesterday, it planned to spin off a ''substantial portion'' of its producing properties and transfer them to its shareholders.

headline: The U.N. Today; Oct. 12, 1983
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 3 P.M.   Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M.

headline: NEW YORK C.D. RATES RANKED HIGHEST IN U.S.
abstract: New York financial institutions are paying at least a percentage point more than banks in other parts of the country to attract customers to newly deregulated certificates of deposit, according to a nationwide survey released yesterday.   According to The Bank Rate Monitor's survey of five major markets, the first since C.D.'s were deregulated last Saturday, the average introductory rate offered in New York City was 10.45 percent.   The next highest rate, offered in Detroit, was 9.37 percent, followed by 9.33 percent in Los Angeles, 9.21 in Chicago and 9.17 percent in Philadelphia. Nationwide, The Monitor said, the average rate was 9.48 percent.

headline: Bulgarians End Inquiry Into Turkish Gunman
abstract: Two Bulgarian magistrates returned home tonight after conducting an investigation here into a criminal case opened by Bulgaria against Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turk convicted of shooting Pope John Paul II in 1981.   Meanwhile, Giuseppe Consolo, a defense lawyer for Sergei I. Antonov, a Bulgarian airline official imprisoned here because Mr. Agca accused him of complicity in the attempt on the Pope's life, said he would formally move next week to have his client freed.

headline: CAROLINA UTILITY STOPS A-PLANT
abstract: The Carolina Power and Light Company said today that it was cancelling construction of a nuclear generating unit that was due to be completed in 1990 and instead speeding up construction of a coal-fired generator.   The utility said it would halt work on the 900,000-kilowatt Shearon Harris Nuclear Unit 2 in Wake County, which was 4 percent complete. The company said its investment so far has been $315 million.

headline: Macy's Sales Rise; Profit Gains Seen
abstract: R. H. Macy & Company said that November sales for its stores open more than a year are running 16 to 17 percent ahead of last November, and that new stores are contributing another 3 to 4 percent to the total corporate sales gain. Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman and chief executive, said before the company's annual meeting that if the sales trend continued, profits in the second quarter, ending Jan. 28, would improve ''significantly'' from the year before.   He said at the meeting that Macy's first Florida store, in North Miami Beach, will have first-year sales of about $55 million, ''well above our plan,'' and that the company will proceed with its program of opening 10 stores in Florida and Texas by the end of the decade.

headline: PRETORIA STARTS NEW DRIVE ON NAMIBIA REBELS
abstract: South Africa has begun a new offensive in Angola against guerrillas fighting for the independence of South-West Africa, according to defense officials.   The officials said military actions were continuing in Angola today.   The offensive, in which five South African soldiers have been killed and one is reported missing, was first disclosed by South Africa Friday. The military officials said no further details would be released at present.

headline: APPLE SEES FLAT PROFIT OUTLOOK
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. said yesterday that its earnings in the next two quarters probably would not improve from the 8 cents a share reported for its fiscal fourth quarter, ended Sept. 30. That was down sharply from 32 cents a share a year earlier.   John Sculley, the president of Apple, made this earnings forecast in an address to securities analysts. After two quarters, he said, Apple expects a ''gradual return of margins to our traditional level about a year from now.''

headline: Rockwell Closings
abstract: The Rockwell International Corporation said it might close plants in Battle Creek, Mich., and Wellington, Ohio, because of declining production.

headline: GREEK CYPRIOTS SATISFIED WITH U.N.'S VOTE, BUT TURKS DENOUNCE IT
abstract: Greek Cypriots expressed satisfaction today over the condemnation by the United Nations Security Council of the Turkish Cypriots' declaration of their third of the island as an independent republic.    Turkish Cypriot leaders on this Mediterranean island rejected the Security Council's resolution, which was passed Friday night, requesting a withdrawal of their proclamation of independence.   Both sides expressed hope that the crisis would give the necessary impetus for a solution to the Cyprus problem through the United Nations.

headline: Columbia Gas Sells Affiliate
abstract: Columbia Gas System Inc. said it had accepted an offer to sell its West Virginia natural gas distribution affiliate for about $60 million to the Allegheny and Western Energy Corporation.   Columbia Gas of West Virginia Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Columbia Gas System, which is based in Wilmington, Del., serves about 207,000 customers and 11 smaller utilities in West Virginia. The company said in July that it was considering selling the affiliate because of its history of operating losses.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  Allied Corp., Morris Township, N.J., has appointed Charles F. Bischoff, Robert J. Geiger and Russell W. Hawkins staff vice presidents.     *  Amax Inc., Greenwich, Conn., has named Martin V. Alonzo, executive vice president, to chief financial officer.

headline: FROM A GRENADIAN DIPLOMAT: HOW PARTY WRANGLE LED TO PREMIER'S DEATH
abstract: A Grenadian Embassy official here says the events that led to the death of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop on Oct. 19 began at a secret meeting in Grenada the month before when the Central Committee of Mr. Bishop's party told him he would have to share leadership of the country with his Deputy Prime Minister, Bernard Coard.    The official, in an interview here Friday, said that by a vote of 9 to 1 with 3 abstentions, the committee voted on Sept. 14 to allow Mr. Bishop to continue as head of state but to have Mr. Coard privately assume control of the economy and take charge of party matters.   The events following this meeting, the official said, ended in tragedy after Mr. Bishop tried to float a rumor in Grenada, where he was very popular, that Mr. Coard and his wife, Phyllis, who was a Central Committee member, were trying to kill him.   Details of the party struggle, which at the outset were to be kept from the public, were provided by Donald McPhail, who is first secretary of the Grenadian Embassy and has been in charge of its affairs during the absence of Ambassador Leon Cornwall, who has been in Grenada since September.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: No Headline
abstract: Travelers Has Rise of 10.4%    The Travelers Corporation, one of the nation's largest investor-owned insurance companies, reported yesterday that operating income in the third quarter rose 10.4 percent, to $79.7 million, or 95 cents a share, from $72.2 million, or 86 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

headline: RULING FOR I.B.M. LEFT INTACT
abstract: The Supreme Court left intact today a ruling that cleared the International Business Machines Corporation of charges that it illegally prevented competitors from gaining a foothold in an important part of the computer market - the sale of computer accessory devices.   The Court, without comment, turned down an appeal by the Transamerica Corporation, which said that it had abandoned a $200 million investment in the computer business because I.B.M. illegally cut prices of computer equipment and engaged in other antitrust violations.   The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled last February that I.B.M. did not restrict competition illegally, even though 16 of 18 companies, including Transamerica, suffered huge losses and abandoned efforts to compete.

headline: Advertising; Meeting Highlights Print Ads
abstract: Regular adland convention-goers would not be surprised to hear that the 74th annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers began today with presentations of case studies of successful advertising campaigns.   What would surprise them, though, would be to learn that all of the campaigns were in print.   Ever since television began grabbing the big national advertising bucks and the imaginations of agency creative people with its sight, sound, color and motion, the print media have taken a back seat at advertising meetings.   But today, right after a panel of Newsweek editors and correspondents brought the membership up to date on the state of the world, four advertisers and/or their agencies brought them up to date on the power of print.

headline: E.E.C. Faces Lack of Cash
abstract: To help avoid running out of money this year, the European Economic Community today announced a 10-day freeze on some agriculture subsidies.

headline: HAVANA IS RESCHEDULING HALF ITS DEBT TO THE WEST
abstract: Cuba has rescheduled nearly half of its $3.5 billion debt to Western governments and banks, according to a research group that monitors the Cuban economy.   Recent studies by the group, the Cuban American National Foundation of Washington and Miami, also said that Cuba had been largely unsuccessful in diversifying what is still largely a one-crop economy based on sugar.   The studies have provided a a profile of the Cuban economy, which has been closely linked to the Soviet Union for that last two decades. The foundation is supported by a Cuban-American academics and business leaders, many of them former backers of Fidel Castro.

headline: U.S. UNITS RAID ISLAND HIDE-OUT
abstract: United States troops raided a house where six armed Grenadian soldiers were hiding, an Army spokesman said Friday.   One of the soldiers was captured, but the others escaped, the spokesman said.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD
abstract: Italian Jewelry Heiress Is Freed by Kidnappers    ROME, Dec. 24 (AP) - Kidnappers today freed an heiress of Italy's Bulgari jewelry company and her teen-age son, whose ear had been cut off in an attempt to force a ransom payment, the police said. They were kidnapped Nov. 19 by three masked men.

headline: New-Home Sales Fall By 5.1%
abstract: Sales of new single-family houses fell by 5.1 percent in August, the second consecutive monthly decline, the Government said today.   The report, from the Commerce Department and the Department of Housing and Urban Development, said new houses sold at an annual rate of 578,000 last month compared with a revised rate of 609,000 in July. Despite the decline, August sales were still 48.6 percent higher than the depressed levels of a year ago.

headline: ; INVISIBLE HAND
abstract: To the Business Editor:      In Professor Dorfman's article, Gerard Debreu's endeavor is to reinforce Smith's theory of the ''invisible hand'' without resorting to questionable assumptions or mathematical inconsistencies. However, Professor Dorfman notes that Professor Debreu's economy disregards uncertainty in investments and economy of scale. Professor Dorfman adds from his own point of view that not only will ''no one ever be able to prove conclusively Adam Smith's 'invisible hand' theory,'' but that ''Debreu has added to a common-sense view that no such simple dictum can be relied on in all circumstances.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1983    Companies Two A.T.& T. divisions want to cut 13,000 employees from their payrolls by offering them early retirement packages. The information systems and communications units expect to save $500 million a year through the move and become more competitive in the newly deregulated industry. (D1.)  I.B.M. introduced its long-awaited $700 home computer, the PCjr, but it will not be available for the Christmas shopping season. (D1.) Industry experts and I.B.M. agreed that the new product represents a fundamental change in marketing strategy and product design for I.B.M. that could propel the company to $100 billion in annual sales by 1990. (D4.)

headline: P.L.O. UNITS CLASH IN DAMASCUS
abstract: Gun battles, apparently between rival Palestinian factions, broke out in two areas of Damascus today.   Residents said gunfire echoed in the streets, and they believed the fighting, involving small arms, was between opponents and supporters of Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

headline: South African Rates Up
abstract: Nedbank, Barclays and Standard Bank said today that they are raising their prime rates to a record- equaling 20 percent, from 19.5 percent. The rise by Nedbank and Barclays is effective immediately and Standard Bank's new rate will be effective Tuesday. South African banks last raised their rates 10 days ago from 19 percent, and bankers said there has continued to be heavy pressure on short-term rates.

headline: BASTION REPORTED TO FALL; BATTLE GOES ON
abstract: Congressional criticism of the Grenada invasion mounted today as the House Foreign Affairs Committee, in a vote of 32 to 2, adopted legislation declaring that the War Powers Resolution pertained to events on the Caribbean island.   Senate Democrats want to attach similar legislation to a bill pending on the Senate floor that would raise the national debt limit. If adopted by Congress, the War Powers measure would require President Reagan to withdraw troops within 60 days unless Congress authorizes their continued presence.   Early in the day, the Senate approved an amendment to a supplementary spending bill commending the troops who had fought in Grenada.

headline: Government Securities Steady; Rally Erases Early Losses
abstract: The market in fixed-income securities stabilized yesterday after being battered earlier in the week. After a weak opening on carry-over selling from Tuesday, prices of Government securities rallied modestly, erasing the earlier losses and went on to close largely unchanged on the day, dealers said. But rates on Treasury bills declined.

headline: GREEK CYPRIOT VOWS TO REVERSE MOVE PEACEABLY
abstract: The President of Cyprus said today that his Government was determined to reverse, through peaceful means, Tuesday's declaration of independence by Turkish Cypriots.    The President, Spyros Kyprianou, said there were many ''effective, peaceful'' steps that could be taken. He cited Britain's actions in dealing with the former breakaway state of Rhodesia, implying that some form of economic blockade was under consideration.

headline: CONTINENTAL AIR FACING UNION BAN IN AUSTRALIA
abstract: Unions representing Australia's airline employees have voted to deny support services for Continental Air Lines' daily flight from Los Angeles to Sydney and Melbourne, an action that would effectively halt the service.  The action was taken Thursday night and is scheduled to go into effect next Wednesday. Union officials said the boycott was meant to bring pressure on Continental to resume talks with striking American unions and ''to honor existing collective agreements.''

headline: MEXICAN FACES MORE TESTS IN 2D YEAR
abstract: President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado completed his first year in office today, governing a Mexico that looks increasingly healthy to foreign financiers but increasingly troubled to people at home.   The 48-year-old President, who took office at the peak of Mexico's worst financial crisis in decades, is given wide credit for successfully imposing a stiff program of economic austerity while maintaining social stability.   Although results have been harder to see, Mr. de la Madrid also remains unswerving in his talk of ''moral renovation'' of the country - the national euphemism for his efforts to control Mexico's endemic corruption.   While some major corruption cases have been pursued - the former director of the national oil company, Petroleos Mexicanos, is now in jail awaiting trial for his role in a $34 million fraud - the more pervasive, everyday corruption in the police force and the bureaucracy appears to continue to flourish.

headline: PatentsStacy V. Jones Simulator Of Gravity For Space
abstract: WASHINGTON  A N astronaut who is a physician has invented a suit to simulate in space the effects of normal gravity on the human circulatory system. The invention allows normal movement in a spacecraft.

headline: DYNASTY WITHOUT TRADITION
abstract: Experts may view it as a naive Chinese muscatel, but Dynasty medium-dry white wine heralds China's emergence into the competitive world of budget-priced wines.   The wine was produced by a joint venture of the Chinese and Remy Martin Ltd. of France in the flat countryside a dozen miles north of this industrial city.   The 190,000 or so bottles produced this year have already sold out, with 90 percent of the batch exported to Southeast Asia, Australia, the United States and Western Europe.   Sales in New York    Nearly 17,000 bottles were consigned last month to a wine importer in New York. And Guillaume d'Avout, the managing director of Remy Martin's operations in Asia, said last spring that Dynasty was being introduced this year to the discriminating French market.

headline: President Resigns At Zurn Industries
abstract: David M. Zurn has resigned as president and chief executive of Zurn Industries to pursue other interests, the maker of antipollution equipment said yesterday.   The Erie, Pa., company said the board elected Oscar L. Dunn, 69 years old, to succeed Mr. Zurn, effective Jan. 1, until a permanent replacement can be found. Mr. Dunn is a board member.

headline: Jersey Resources Draws New Offer
abstract: South Jersey Industries said it had proposed to acquire the New Jersey Resources Corporation for a combination of cash and stock valued at about $100 million.

headline: T.W.A. CHIEF CALLS UNION PACTS CRUCIAL
abstract: C. E. Meyer, the president and chief executive officer of Trans World Airlines, said yesterday that $51 million in concessions that leaders of its pilot union had agreed to was an important first step in reaching the $197 million needed to make the airline profitable next year.    Speaking at the airlines headquarters here a day after the board of directors of the Trans World Corporation had decided to spin off the airline, he also said that without the support of the parent, the company would find it more difficult to raise credit.   The 55-year-old president, however, also saw some pluses. He said the move would help dispel the illusion among the airline's three major unions and employees that ''the parent is there to take care of us.''

headline: Pirelli Realignment
abstract: The Pirelli group has put its American and Canadian subsidiaries under the same senior managers, the company announced over the weekend. Marcello DeGiorgis, chairman and chief executive of Pirelli Cables Inc., Montreal, will hold the same offices at the Pirelli Cable Corporation, Union City, N.J. James E. Arnold, president and former chief executive of the New Jersey company, will become president and chief operating officer of both subsidiaries. Operations of the two companies were merged Oct. 24.

headline: SLOWLY AND HESITANTLY, INDIA ADOPTS BIRTH CONTROL
abstract: More often than in the past, there comes these days what one Government official calls ''a very philosophical moment'' for the couples who live in villages like this one in northern India when they decide not to have more children. The moment signifies to some who face it a radical break with centuries-old attitudes on life and birth.   For Phoolmati, a 35-year-old woman who works in the rice fields every day to feed her three sons and two daughters, the decision to undergo sterilization was matter-of-fact.   She decided, she later told a visitor, that if she had any more children she would not be able to properly feed, clothe and educate them.

headline: Shultz to Attend NATO Talks Due in Brussels Next Month
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will attend a meeting of foreign ministers of North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries in Brussels Dec. 8 and 9, the State Department announced today.   John Hughes, the department spokesman, said the 16 NATO foreign ministers would discuss ''matters of interest to the alliance, including East- West relations.''

headline: Mrs. Thatcher, in Ulster, Vows to Defeat I.R.A.
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher visited Northern Ireland for six hours today and said Britain and the Irish Republic were determined to beat the Irish Republican Army's ''bombs, bullets and terrorists.''   In London, the police for the third straight day questioned an unidentified I.R.A. sympathizer held in raids after the outlawed organization bombed Harrods department store last Saturday, killing 5 people and wounding 95.

headline: JOURNALISTS ATTACK LISBON PRESS LAW PROPOSAL LISBON, Dec. 17 (Reuters) - A draft press bill proposed by the Portuguese Government has sparked widespread criticism, including charges that parts of it go beyond the harsh laws of the right-wing dictatorship that was overthrown in 1974.
abstract: The Union of Journalists has denounced the 73-page bill as ''the most violent attack on the freedom of the press committed since the revolution.''    The draft was submitted to news organizations last month by Minister of State Antonio Almeida Santos, a Socialist. He acknowledged that some of its 83 articles were controversial.

headline: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Split View On Coleco Continues
abstract: COLECO INDUSTRIES, one of the market's most volatile stocks in the past two years, received mixed reviews yesterday from securities analysts who toured its plants in Amsterdam, N.Y., on Wednesday.   ''Most of us walked away with more of a comfort level after seeing the Adam home computer coming off the assembly line,'' said Barbara Russell of Prudential-Bache Securities.   While opinions about Coleco on Wall Street vary widely, there is general agreement on two points. First, past forecasts by the company have been unduly optimistic. Second, Coleco will rise or fall on the fate of Adam, which so far has suffered a series of production problems.

headline: TechnologyJohn Holusha New Methods To Paint Cars
abstract: DETROIT HENRY FORD's attitude toward painting cars was simple and efficient: You could have any color you wanted as long as it was black. And since the paint of the Model T era took a long time to dry, he simply shipped the cars to market and let them dry en route. In those days, no one seemed to mind if they picked up a few specks of dirt on the way.   Today's car buyers mind a great deal, though, and the superior finish of imported cars has become a symbol of their supposedly higher quality. It was the foreign auto companies that first adopted the old car customizers' trick of putting a clear coating over the pigmented paint to give it a deeper, more lustrous finish.

headline: WHITE HOUSE INSISTS; MILITARY IS DOUBTFUL
abstract: Americans back the invasion of Grenada and marines in Lebanon but are uneasy with President Reagan in a crisis, a poll shows. Page 9.           WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 - The White House said today that the Reagan Administration would withdraw American forces from Grenada in a matter of weeks ''at the outside,'' meeting its earlier estimate.   But American military officials offered a more pessimistic view, saying that 300 Cubans had retreated into northern and central mountain areas where militia camps were known to exist and where a guerrilla resistance would be feasible.

headline: BETHLEHEM AND LTV CUT LOSSES
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the LTV Corporation, the nation's second- and third- largest steel companies, yesterday reported narrower third-quarter losses than they had a year earlier. Analysts said the gradual pickup in steel orders had powered the improvement.   Bethlehem reported a loss of $59.7 million for the third quarter, less than one-third of its $208.9 million loss a year before. Analysts said Bethlehem had been held back by depressed demand and prices for heavy steel products used in capital goods, in which Bethlehem's output is concentrated.

headline: A SWITCH TO ALCOHOL AS AUTOMOBILE FUEL IS GAINING IN BRAZIL
abstract: A Brazilian who sets off for the weekend in the wrong kind of car is turned away from service stations all day Saturday. And when he is allowed at the pump, fuel costs $2.37 a gallon, nearly $1 more than for the driver of the right kind of car. To buy the wrong car, an auto loan carries stiffer terms, and to keep it, the owner pays a higher road tax.    The wrong car runs on gasoline and the right one on nearly pure alcohol. With policies like these, Brazil's military technocracy has bludgeoned the consumer into supporting its drive, begun eight years ago, to purge the automotive sector of imported oil.

headline: Iran Accuses Iraq Of Wrecking Own Town
abstract: Iran said today that Iraqi troops had started to destroy one of their own towns as a propaganda move in the face of an Iranian advance on the northern front in their war.   The offician Iranian press agency said Iran had suspected that the Iraqis were blowing up buildings in the border town of Penjwin some days ago when they heard explosions from the town.

headline: Zimbabwean Temperate On U.S. Aid Cut
abstract: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe gave a carefully worded reaction today to the announcement this week that the United States had cut this year's aid to Zimbabwe by $35 million.   Mr. Mugabe said Zimbabwe ''could not complain'' if the Reagan Administration had to reduce Zimbabwe's aid for budgetary reasons. Mr. Mugabe said, however, that he found it ''extremely objectionable'' that the United States might have cut the aid because of its disapproval of Zimbabwe's votes in the United Nations.   In his Government's first official reaction to the Reagan Administration's decision to cut Zimbabwe's aid for the current fiscal year from $75 million to $40 million, Mr. Mugabe said Zimbabwe valued its independence to make its own foreign policy more than it valued money.

headline: Money Fund Assets Rise
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose by $399 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.   The institute said that the assets reached $164.8 billion.

headline: Arafat Is Reported En Route To Saudi Port City of Jidda
abstract: Yasir Arafat, who was forced to flee Lebanon, is aboard a Greek ship en route to the Saudi port of Jidda, an official of the Palestine Liberation Organization said today.   A P.L.O. source in Cairo, where Mr. Arafat held a meeting with President Hosni Mubarak on Thursday, said Mr. Arafat wanted to meet with King Fahd.   But the P.L.O. official here would not say whether Mr. Arafat would leave the Greek ship, the Odysseus Elytis, or whether he would meet with Saudi officials.

headline: DRUSE SHUNS SITE FOR MEETING
abstract: Efforts to bring about negotiations among Lebanon's warring factions suffered a setback today when a key figure said he would not attend any meeting at the presidential palace outside Beirut.   Walid Jumblat, leader of the Druse, said the presidential palace was not suitable for the proposed meeting that is intended to reconcile differences among Lebanon's factions.

headline: Members of Cabinet Under Shamir Listed
abstract: Following is a list of Israeli Cabinet members with their party affiliations. They were approved today by Parliament:    Prime Minister and Foreign Minister -Yitzhak Shamir (Herut).

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 10, 1983
abstract: Markets Stock prices rose sharply in what analysts called a technical advance. The Dow Jones industrial average soared 17.58 points, to 1,233.52, its biggest daily gain since Oct. 6, when it was up 18.60 points. Turnover climbed to 83.1 million shares from 64.9 million shares during Tuesday's slow Election Day trading. (Page D1.)  Interest rates were stable to slightly lower for Treasury notes and bonds. (D10.) The dollar fell in foreign currency trading, while gold prices rose 50 cents an ounce, to $381.50, in New York. (D16.) Prices of stock index futures were sharply higher. (D16.)

headline: ITALY'S LEADER DISCUSSES THE COMING U.N. TRIP
abstract: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi, Italy's first Socialist head of government, will arrive in the United States Tuesday for talks with President Reagan and top American officials that are expected to center on economic and arms issues.    In an interview that consisted of an exchange of written questions and answers, Mr. Craxi discussed the subjects he intends to address.   On economic problems, which a senior aide to the Prime Minister said were the most pressing for Italy, Mr. Craxi said there were ''some imbalanced sectors'' in the two nations' ties.

headline: 3 PLEAD GUILTY IN BACHE CASE
abstract: Three men pleaded guilty in Manhattan yesterday to fraud charges involving the embezzlement of more than $18 million from Prudential- Bache Securities Inc.    All three waived their right to an indictment by a grand jury, pleaded guilty to the charges filed by Federal prosecutors and agreed to cooperate in the continuing investigation.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; A GOOD IDEA, BUT LET MANAGEMENT DO IT
abstract: THERE is a subtle irony about the   move by T. Boone Pickens Jr. to  break up the Gulf Oil Corporation. If Gulf's management had not done such an effective job during the past few years in changing the company into a sleek concern with good operations and respectable earnings, Gulf would not be such an attractive target for Mr. Pickens.  Gulf Oil's management, led by James E. Lee, has adjusted its strategic planning, sold or shut down losing operations, trimmed the fat from ongoing operations, disposed of nonproductive assets and done a creditable job of getting new oil and gas production onstream. On this basis, Gulf shareholders have reason to be satisfied with Mr. Lee and company.

headline: A STRUGGLE TO SURVIVE IN THE AIR
abstract: EVEN for the airline industry, where upheaval has    become endemic, the events of the last eight   days unraveled with startling force.   First, Continental Air Lines said it was filing for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code and would lay off its 12,000 workers. Then last Tuesday, it slashed its route structure and hired back a third of its employees, at about half their former salaries, to staff a much smaller airline.   Later that morning, Eastern Airlines moved. It showed its 37,500 employees a taped message from Frank Borman, its chairman, warning that unless they accepted wage and benefit concessions, Eastern may have to file for bankruptcy like Continental or shut down as Braniff Airways did in May 1982, when it, too, filed under Chapter 11.

headline: Bethlehem Steel
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, citing an increase in business, said it plans to reactivate two steelmaking furnaces at the Sparrows Point, Md., plant and recall about 200 workers. John G. Roberts, the plant's general manager, said one furnace will begin operation on Jan. 9 and the second one on Jan. 16. The furnaces have been closed since early this year.

headline: SHOWTIME-PARAMOUNT PACT Showtime/The Movie Channel, the nation's second-largest pay television service, has acquired exclusive rights to the films produced by the Paramount Pictures Corporation for the next five years, the two companies announced yesterday.
abstract: Industry officials estimated that the agreement would cost Showtime $500 million. It will begin in February with the presentation of the film, ''Flashdance.''

headline: AROUND THE WORLD
abstract: Humanitarian Panel Holds Its First Session    A new group that says it hopes to help create ''a new international humanitarian order'' held its first meeting in New York this weekend.   The 25-member group, which calls itself the Independent Commission on International Humanitarian Issues, said in a news conference Thursday that it would publish reports on specific humanitarian problems about once every six months for three years.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Alleghany Corporation   $16,300,000   x 52.3

headline: TechnologyAndrew Pollack The Speedy Disk Copier
abstract: T HE computer is often considered the pencil   and paper of the office of the future. Now a   device known as a floppy disk copier is vying to become the Xerox machine of the future.    These new copiers allow copies of a disk containing data or software to be made in as little as 20 seconds, far faster than such copies can be made on a personal computer.    Three companies - one has just gone public and another is about to - are fighting for dominance in the $20 million market for disk copying machines. Still other entrepreneurs have purchased the copiers and opened disk copying services that are somewhat analogous to print copy shops.

headline: JAPAN PUSHING HARDER ON AUTO PARTS
abstract: Although Japanese exports of assembled automobiles, limited by foreign restrictions, declined 8 percent last year and remain stagnant this year, exports of cars shipped as parts to be assembled overseas are rising rapidly.    Last year, during the recession, these so-called knock-down set exports advanced about 12 percent. And for the six-month period ended September, the number climbed almost 30 percent from the comparable period a year ago.   Typically, engines, transmissions and axles are the main components made in Japan and shipped overseas. The items purchased locally generally include glass, tires, seats, steel, air-conditioners and radios.

headline: U.S. Task Force Sets Sail
abstract: The Defense Department said tonight that a nine-ship task force headed by the 78,500-ton aircraft carrier America had sailed ''for the Central Atlantic'' on maneuvers.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * American Natural Resources Co.  announced that its Michigan Wisconsin Pipe Line Co. unit had filed a request with Federal regulators to reduce its wholesale natural gas prices by $50 million.     * Applied Data Research, Princeton, N.J., said it had received two Army contracts, valued at about $10 million, to supply software.     * Bell & Howell Co.  said it had completed the sale of its datatape division analog and digital tape recorder business to Eastman Kodak Co.

headline: Golden West Sale
abstract: Golden West Homes said its chairman emeritus, Jerry Golden, had sold his entire stake in the company to the William Lyon Company, and that as a result, Lyon's chairman and chief executive officer, William Lyon, had been elected chairman of Golden West. Mr. Golden's shares represented 19.2 percent of the company's approximately 3.4 milllion shares outstanding. In another transaction, Golden West's previous chairman, Dave Totten, also agreed to sell his stake in the company - totaling about 3.7 percent - to William Lyon, a residential home builder in California. Mr. Totten will remain on Golden West's board.

headline: TOURISM CONFERENCE IN INDIA CONDEMNS AIRLINER DOWNING
abstract: An international tourism conference condemned Moscow today for its destruction of a South Korean civilian airliner last month. The delegates adopted a resolution of censure that was presented by the United States and its supporters.   The resolution was approved 37 to 9. India, the host nation, and 26 others abstained, saying the World Tourism Organization was not the place for such a resolution.

headline: BANK OF AMERICA TO CUT 220 UNITS, 6,000 OF STAFF
abstract: In a move to streamline its operations and bolster sagging earnings, the Bank of America announced yesterday that it will reduce its staff by up to 6,000 people during 1984 - primarily through attrition - and close about 220 branches throughout California. Bank of America employs about 60,000 in California and has just over 1,000 branches in the state.   Samuel H. Armacost, president and chief executive, said the bank, the nation's largest, would depend more heavily on electronics to deliver banking services to consumers and small businesses. ''Evolving technology makes it no longer necessary to use conventional branches as extensively as before,'' he said.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: Fannie Mae Securities Set for Yield of 12.61%    The Federal National Mortgage Association sold $250 million of 12 1/2 percent mortgage-backed securities yesterday at a price of 98 1/2 to yield 12.61 percent. The securities were offered directly by Fannie Mae and through various dealers led by Salomon Brothers.

headline: GRENADA WAS TOLD OF INVASION PLAN
abstract: Prime Minister Edward Seaga of Jamaica said today after a meeting with President Reagan that Gen. Hudson Austin, the leader of Grenada before the United States-led invasion of the island, had been told of the invasion plan nearly 36 hours before it was carried out.    The disclosure was made by one of the Caribbean nations that participated in the decision, but it did not include the precise timetable, Mr. Seaga said.   ''Therefore,'' he said, ''the harm done turned out to be minimal.''

headline: COMPANY NEWS Eastern Air Defers Payout
abstract: Eastern Airlines, which suffered a large loss in the first nine months of 1983, said yesterday in Miami that its board had postponed the payment of the quarterly dividend on all three classes of preferred stock. The airline also said that it would not issue the transportation discounts in January that it had said would be offered to shareholders of common stock.

headline: Israel Trims Its Budget
abstract: The Israeli Government today cut the current budget by $2 billion and increased the cost to citizens of schools and health care in an effort to slow the inflation of 130 percent a year and to curb the growth of foreign debt.   The reduction to a $21.5 billion budget for the remaining five months of the fiscal year will mean more unemployment (now 4 percent of the work force) and less private consumption, Finance Minister Yigal Cohen-Orgad told reporters.   The actions are the latest in the Government's program of economic belt-tightening. Today's changes, Mr. Cohen-Organ said, reflect a policy of domestic credit restrictions, a lower foreign-exchange rate for the shekel - now 85 to the dollar - and a reduction in private consumption.

headline: DPCC FAILS TO GET DR PEPPER METTING
abstract: Dr Pepper said yesterday that it had turned down a request by the DPCC Acquisition Corporation, which has offered to buy Dr Pepper, to attend Dr Pepper's special board meeting today in Dallas.   A Dr Pepper spokesman, Jim Ball, said it is standard company policy to limit board meetings to directors and their advisers.

headline: MRS. GANDHI SAYS TERRORISM WILL END
abstract: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, facing new political violence in northwestern India, said today that terrorism ''is not going to succeed'' as a political weapon in the country.   Mrs. Gandhi, at her first news conference here in more than six months, also said that national elections would be held ''when they are due.''   Some politicians here had lately felt that Mrs. Gandhi would call elections for next February or March. They are scheduled to be held in January 1985. The Prime Minister's popularity has been rising recently, and some had thought she would schedule early elections to take advantage of that.

headline: Afghan Rebels Say Offensive Has Slowed
abstract: Afghan Army reinforcements and a Soviet bombing campaign have slowed a two-month guerrilla offensive against Communist strongholds in eastern Afghanistan, guerrilla sources based here said today.

headline: People
abstract: *  Roger L. Werner has been promoted to executive vice president, marketing, and  John S. Bonanni has been named vice president, advertising sales, at ESPN.     *  Hollis McLoughlin has been appointed vice president, marketing, for the Purolator Courier Corp.

headline: China's Unions Reported To Win Right to Strike
abstract: A Chinese labor convention adopted a new trade union constitution today. The official New China News Agency said it gave workers a limited right to strike against unsafe working conditions,   The constitution revises one adopted in 1978.

headline: ACORN COMPUTER MAKES U.S. DEBUT
abstract: Acorn Computers Ltd., which dominates the educational computer market in Britain, introduced its BBC microcomputer in the United States yesterday and said it had already received $21 million in orders from American schools.   The computer, which has a base price of $995, is expected by analysts to be a heavy contender in the increasingly competitive educational sales market.

headline: SYRIA THREATENS SUICIDE RAIDS
abstract: Syria's Defense Minister was quoted today as saying that his armed forces were prepared to launch suicide attacks against United States warships and had missiles that could hit anywhere in Israel.   In an interview with the pro-Libyan Beirut magazine Al Kifah Al Arabi, which means Arab Struggle, Maj. Gen. Mustafa Tlas said: ''When the Americans attack us we will respond with all suitable means. We have pilots who are ready to launch suicide missions over American warships.''

headline: POLES TRY A NEW TWIST ON PRICES
abstract: Poland unveiled two proposals for increases in food prices today and, in an effort to prevent protests, said the public could choose which proposal would be used.   Under one proposal, food prices would rise an average of $3 a person a week and subsidies would be maintained at their present level.

headline: JACKSON NOT SURE HE WILL VISIT SYRIA
abstract: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson said today that he might cancel plans to visit Syria to seek the release of a captured American flier if President Reagan asked him not to go.   While not objecting explicitly to Mr. Jackson's trip, Mr. Reagan indicated to reporters this morning that he had misgivings about it because, he said, such private missions ''can be counterproductive.''   Mr. Jackson, taking note of what he called Mr. Reagan's intervention, said he was pleased that the fate of the captured flier was now ''on the front burner.'' When asked if he would still go if the President asked him not to, Mr. Jackson, a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, replied:   ''At this point we would not be inclined to go in absolute defiance of him.''

headline: HOLLYWOOD GAMBLES ON VIDEO
abstract: Some of Hollywood's most important movies this Christmas may be playing on video cassette recorders.     With video cassette players proliferating and cassette prices falling, the home video industry's outlook this season is brighter than expected. Now Hollywood is hoping that hundreds of thousands of video cassettes will materialize under Christmas trees this year.   While consumers have not been overly resistant to the $29.95 price tag on video cassettes with music or children's programming, they have balked thus far at having to pay $60 or more for a recorded movie. As a result, the movie cassette business has largely evolved into a rental market, with dealers typically charging from $2.50 to $7.50 for an evening's entertainment.

headline: OPEC Price Outlook
abstract: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is likely to keep its benchmark price of $29 a barrel unchanged for most of 1984, assuming there is no serious worsening of political tensions in the Middle East, according to the HWWA Economic Institute. But the price could rise toward the end of the year if the recovery in Western economies continued, the institute said.

headline: Certificate Rates Slip;  Certificate Rates Slide
abstract: Interest rates on certificates of deposit slipped in New York and fell sharply elsewhere around the country last week, the Bank Rate Monitor said yesterday.   The Monitor's average of rates offered on six-month certificates by 10 major New York banks and thrift units dropped one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point, to 9.61 percent, from 9.62 percent last week.

headline: Isuzu Earnings Drop by 12.4%
abstract: Isuzu Motors Ltd. said today   that its profit for the fiscal year   ended Oct. 31 fell 12.4 percent   from the previous year and that   it expected to post a loss in the   current fiscal year. Isuzu said profit in the latest   year fell to $22.6 million from  $25.8 million the previous year,   while sales dropped 4.6 percent, to $2.93 billion, from $3.07   billion.

headline: Wrigley Net Rises 4%
abstract: The Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company, maker of chewing gum, today announced third- quarter consolidated net earnings of $10.3 million, or $1.35 a share, up 4 percent from $9.9 million, or $1.26 a share, a year earlier. Sales improved slightly, to $148.1 million.

headline: CONGRESS CRITICAL OF MIDEAST POLICY
abstract: The Reagan Administration held a briefing for Congressmen today on the situation in Lebanon, but the session apparently failed to placate many legislators who are increasingly critical of President Reagan's Middle East policy.   The Representatives said after the private session that the President's position was losing support on Capitol Hill and around the country, and they predicted Congress would renew the debate over the mission of the United States Marine Corps in Lebanon when Congress reconvenes next month.   ''If my colleagues are getting what I'm getting from my community,'' said Representative Barbara A. Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland, ''there's a growing disenchantment with this situation.''   Most of the critical comments today came from Democrats who have long opposed the President's Middle East policy. But some Republicans who have backed the President in the past have joined the chorus of concern and uneasiness. One of them was Representative Ed Zschau, a freshman from California who serves on the Foreign Affairs Committee.

headline: Treasury Resignation
abstract: Marc E. Leland, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, said today that he planned to resign in January. Mr. Leland, who joined the department three years ago, said he has no specific job plans. On Monday, the White House said W. Dennis Thomas, the Treasury's Assistant Secretary for Congressional Liasion, would become the deputy chief of Congressional relations. Also, a Treasury spokesman said Cora P. Beebe, Assistant Secretary for Administration, would be leaving soon for the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: U.N. HUMAN RIGHTS CHARTER: SIX NEW STAMPS OF APPROVAL
abstract: They rank among the shortest, briefest - and certainly the smallest - messages to be delivered at the United Nations.   There are six of them and they were delivered last week, not by politicians in conservative three-piece suits, but by an Austrian artist named Friedensreich Hundertwasser.   Mr. Hundertwasser's medium in this case was postage stamps. He designed the half-dozen stamps to mark the 35th anniversary of the signing of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: *  Beatrice Foods Co.  agreed to pay the state of Arizona $5 million in settlement of a lawsuit involving charges of bid-rigging in the sale of milk to school cafeterias. Arizona has settled identical claims against Borden Inc., Shamrock Foods Inc. Foremost-McKesson Inc. and the Carnation Co.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Kerr-McGee Net Off 30.1% The Kerr-McGee Corporation, a diversified Oklahoma   mineral resources conglomerate, yesterday reported a 30.1   percent drop in profits in the   third quarter ended Sept. 30.

headline: U.S. REPLACES PART OF FORCE; SENATE CHIEFS URGE INQUIRY
abstract: United States forces using helicopters searched today for up to 600 Cuban soldiers thought to be hiding in the heavily wooded hills of Grenada, military officials said.   As the search went on, teams from the United States Agency for International Development began flying in emergency food rations and drinking water for displaced civilians.   Marines captured Bernard Coard, the former Grenadian Deputy Prime Minister, and his wife Phyllis, a member of the Central Committee of the ruling New Jewel Movement. Mr. Coard headed a hard-line faction whose move to take power from Prime Minister Maurice Bishop led to the American-led invasion.  Reporters who toured Grenada today were told that Mr. and Mrs. Coard were seized this morning in a secluded house near the Governor General's mansion, and that American forces later had to protect them from angry citizens.    U.S. Names Embassy Chief    At the same time, the United States began preparations to establish an embassy on the island, even though there is no acting government.

headline: THE AIRLINE BATTLE AT O'HARE
abstract: United, American and Delta, three of the nation's largest and most financially secure airlines, are spending hundreds of millions of dollars in a battle to expand their already powerful positions at O'Hare International Airport, the world's busiest.   At stake are the 82 million passengers who are expected to use the airport by 1995, more than double the 38 million who passed through O'Hare last year.   All three airlines may be winners in this contest. Industry analysts predict that the strongest and largest airlines will be able to profitably divide the growth at O'Hare. The losers are expected to be the smaller carriers that must find a market niche or move their operations to other airports.

headline: REGAN SEES CONTINGENCY TAX PLAN
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that President Reagan, to reduce future budget deficits, will include a tax increase proposal in the 1985 budget that he will send to Congress in January.     Mr. Regan added that the tax rise would be contingent on first achieving spending cuts that will also be included in the budget, which is tentatively scheduled to be submitted to the lawmakers on Jan. 30.    In answer to questions after a speech here, Mr. Regan's comments became the first official statement that there would be such a proposal in the budget for the 1985 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, 1984. Over the weekend, Administration officials said they expected such a contingency proposal in the budget.

headline: AFTER THE ARMS TALKS
abstract: NewsAnalysis     GENEVA, Oct. 12 - Many NATO governments are assuming that the Soviet Union will withdraw from arms negotiations in Geneva, leaving Moscow with few tactics in dealing with the West other than making threats and creating the appearance of crisis.  Officials in the foreign ministries of the larger European countries are considering what kind of pressure the Soviet Union might exert in a harder, more tense international climate and the range of potential Soviet actions once new NATO missiles are deployed in Europe. They are also considering possible Western responses.   The wide acceptance of the idea that the talks will be halted is essentially based on statements of Soviet officials who have insisted that the negotiations will be robbed of sense once the stationing of Pershing 2 and cruise missiles begins at the end of the year.

headline: Inflation Rate Rises in Britain
abstract: Britain's annual inflation rate rose to 5.1 percent in September, up from 4.6 percent in August and the highest level in seven months, the Government reported today.

headline: PRICES INCREASED
abstract: The new Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir moved swiftly on the economic front today, devaluing the Israeli shekel by a total of 23 percent from its value Friday, raising prices of subsidized foods and offering a plan to protect investors in commercial bank stocks.    The measures, to take effect Wednesday, were announced at dawn after an all-night Cabinet meeting that was convened hours after Mr. Shamir was sworn in.   But the steps, taken in the face of panicky selling of Israeli currency, also thrust the Government into a new round of political and labor problems.   Rush Depletes Supplies    The Government halved food subsidies, pushing up the prices of bread and dairy products by 50 percent and frozen meat by 40 percent. Gasoline prices were to go up 23 percent.

headline: U.S. REPORTS SENDING 9 NAVY SHIPS INTO ATLANTIC ON MANEUVERS
abstract: The Navy announced today that nine combat ships, including the carrier America, had been ordered to put to sea immediately from East Coast ports to conduct a training exercise in the Atlantic.   The exercise, a so-called ''no-notice'' drill because the ships involved were given less than a week's advance word to prepare themselves, was said to be unrelated to the recent United States invasion of the Caribbean island of Grenada or to reported threats of Cuban retaliation.   Navy sources reported, however, that the ships would conduct some of their drills in the Caribbean area. They noted too, that the exercise was called just as the carrier Independence and other ships supporting the Grenada invasion were being pulled out and directed to the Mediterranean.

headline: BEIRUT TRUCE HOLDS AS WARNING GROUPS PREPARE FOR PARLEY
abstract: Guns fell silent today in Beirut as leaders of the warring factions gathered in Switzerland to open talks on a national reconciliation.   United States Marine patrollers secluded themselves in their airport compound after an exhausting week of digging out comrades killed by a terrorist bomb attack.

headline: PATENTS
abstract: Christmas Tree Device   With appropriate timing, a patent was issued this week for a decorative stand in the form of a Christmas tree. Patent 4,421,801 went to Harald Wahlfahrt of West Germany. As described in a published abstract, a metal support has a number of branches with needles extending from them and limbs that can display articles, presumably Christmas presents.

headline: Metal Box Widens Role Of U.S. Unit President
abstract: Metal Box P.L.C., the world's third-largest packaging manufacturer, has begun a worldwide reorganization that will give Peter J. Hewett, president and chief executive of its United States unit, broader responsibilities for all the Americas.   Mr. Hewett, who is 47, established the American unit - Metal Box America Inc. - with headquarters in Westport, Conn., in 1979. ''Although we did a number of small things,'' he said, ''we were consolidating our position and looking around to find out what we wanted to do.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: Banks Curbed In Philippines MANILA, Oct. 27 (AP) -   The Philippines central bank   today ordered the nation's   banks to sell it 80 percent of   their foreign exchange receipts. The move, designed to   raise dollars to pay for imported oil and installments on   its foreign debt, will also have   the effect of choking off imports by depriving banks of dollars to pay for them.

headline: Turkey Jails 27 Iranians
abstract: An Istanbul civil court today sentenced 27 Iranian students to six years in jail for attacking the Iranian Consulate two years ago, court officials said. The students said they had been protesting Iran's clerical leadership.

headline: POLICY MAY CURTAIL STUDENT LOANS
abstract: Some college students may find next year that Government-guaranteed student loans are less available because of a new policy at the United States Department of Education that makes it more difficult for state authorities to help finance such loans.     About two dozen state authorities are waiting for the department to approve their plans to sell about $1 billion of tax-exempt bonds. The money from these bonds would be used to buy Government-guaranteed student loans from colleges and local banks. By purchasing the loans, the state authorities maintain, they encourage banks and other lenders to make the loans more readily available.

headline: Dynamics Award
abstract: The General Dynamics Corporation's Electric Boat Division won an $82.4 million Navy contract for Trident submarine material, the Defense Department said. It also said that a Logicon Inc. division had received a $29.4 million Air Force award for the MX missile program.

headline: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: REAGAN'S VISIT IS A TOUR DE FORCE FOR THE IMAGE MAKERS
abstract: If all the world's a stage, then President Reagan has just played the palace and the troops in the trenches in the same week.   He changed from his diplomatic pin stripes at Japan's Imperial Palace to his olive-drab battle parka along the demilitarized zone near here as fast as fresh video cassettes could be fed into the television cameras that whirred with him across northeast Asia.   The Administration's commitment to news access was readily apparent: at the DMZ there was a Government helicopter waiting to rush out, for transmission to the United States, the footage of the President worshiping with front-line troops, cheering them on in a speech and glowering across the zone at the North Korean outposts.     In this same week the President managed to refine the state of the art by which the world stage can be adapted for domestic politicking by mutually reliant principals.

headline: ICAHN SEEKS ACF IN $337 MILLION DEAL
abstract: Carl Icahn, the Wall Street investor, who owns 27.2 percent of ACF Industries, offered yesterday to buy the rest of the company for $337 million in cash and stock. ACF, which makes oilfield equipment, railcars and auto parts, said it would study the offer.     Under the proposal, each share of ACF would be exchanged for $31 in cash. In addition, Mr. Icahn said, ACF's W-K-M oilfield equipment division would be set up as a separate company, with each shareholder of ACF getting one share of W-K-M for each share they hold in ACF. Mr. Icahn valued W-K-M shares at a minimum of $25 each.

headline: PHILIPPINE OPPOSITION LISTS ITS TERMS ON ELECTION
abstract: A coalition of 12 opposition parties announced today that it would take part in parliamentary elections scheduled for next May only if President Ferdinand E. Marcos gave up the power to legislate by decree and agreed to seven other demands.    Former Senator Salvador H. Laurel, the president of the coalition, called the United Nationalist Democratic Organization, said in a statement that the proposals were being offered ''as an alternative to imminent violence and as a solution to the serious political and economic crisis that we face today.''   The statement was issued as thousands of women, led by the widow of the slain opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr., marched through some of Manila's busiest streets to protest against the President's 18-year-old rule. The procession ended with a program of speeches by women's leaders at a grandstand in Rizal Pari, the usual site of patriotic functions staged by the Government.

headline: Reagan Hails Venezuelan
abstract: (UPI) - President Reagan has sent a congratulatory telegram to Jaime Lusinchi, the newly elected President of Venezuela, the White House spokesman said today. The spokesman, Larry Speakes, said that in his message ''the President notes with pleasure the Venezuelan democratic process has once again demonstrated its vitality.''

headline: Moderate in Guatemala Will Quit the Cabinet
abstract: A leading moderate in Guatemala's military Government has resigned as part of a Cabinet shake-up by the head of state, Brig. Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores.   Labor Minister Otto Palma Figueroa, appointed under the deposed President Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, has handed in a letter of resignation, a Government spokesman, Ramon Zelada Carillo, said today.

headline: CASTLE & COOKE GROUP RAISES DR PEPPER BID
abstract: In an effort to meet objections from the Dr Pepper Company, an investor group headed by Castle & Cooke Inc., the big West Coast food producer, last night raised its offer for Dr Pepper by $21 million, to $581 million in cash.     The offer was hand delivered last night to Dr Pepper directors at their homes.    The investor group, known as the DPCC Acquisition Corporation, had originally offered to pay $24 a share, or $560 million, for Dr. Pepper. but the company turned the offer down last Saturday, accepting a previous one of $22 a share, or $512.5 million, from Forstmann Little & Company, a New York investment house.

headline: Advertising; Olympics Insurance Campaign
abstract: HOW far will the gang at Della Femina, Travisano & Partners go for a client?   Why, to the ends of the earth, if the client pays for the trip.   This they proved only recently in behalf of one of their newest clients, Transamerica, for which they have done the corporate campaign.   In order to dramatize the San Francisco-based company's involvment in the Olympics as the official insurance company, the agency people took their creative team and cameras to London, Bavaria, Venice, a Greek island, and, yes, even to the Great Wall of China, where they assembled the local folk in colorful native costume and had them act out the festivities of giant farewell parties for local athletic heros off to compete in Los Angeles.

headline: Washington Watch; Toyota-G.M. Doubts Grow
abstract: THE Federal Trade Commission is rapidly losing patience with the Toyota Motor Corporation for failing to supply additional information about the Toyota-General Motors plan for joint production of a subcompact car in California.   The venture, announced last February, needs antitrust blessing from the commission before it can get under way, but Toyota has still not produced all documents the commission says it needs to make a decision. G.M. complied some time ago.   During the summer there were reports that the delay was due to translation problems. Then there was speculation that the delay was tactical, with Toyota waiting until the term of a commissioner, David A. Clanton, expired at the end of September. Mr. Clanton was thought to be inclined to vote against approval.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Correction    The Personal Finance column on Oct. 23 misstated the effect of a new law on taxation of Social Security benefits. For those with incomes over the threshold, tax is due on half of their Social Security benefits or on half of their income in excess of the threshold, whichever is less.

headline: THE CIVILIAN CALLED TO COMMAND ARGENTINA
abstract: During his more than 30 years in politics, Raul Alfonsin, the successful candidate in Argentina's presidential election, has been an outsider and, at crucial moments, a loser. But his image as a maverick served him well when Argentina, after seven years of military rule, began looking for leaders not associated with the failures of the past.  In his campaign, Mr.  Alfonsin proved to be a master of consensus and a vigorous advocate for democracy and social justice. He pledged to wipe out illiteracy and malnutrition, increase the money spent on education to 30 percent of the total budget and suspend the purchase of arms.    ''I honestly believe that Argentines at this moment are not divided by deep ideological differences,'' Mr. Alfonsin said in an interview in Buenos Aires a few weeks ago. ''What we face is the need to address the problems of the unemployed, of child care, of school dropouts and the destruction of the national economy.''

headline: Turks Urged to Vote For Continuity of Regime
abstract: President Kenan Evren urged tonight that all Turks take part in elections for Parliament scheduled for Sunday and that they support the party that represents a continuity of the military regime's policies.   General Evren's call appeared to be an endorsement of the Nationalist Democracy Party, led by Turgut Sunalp, a retired general.

headline: Bangladesh Said to Ask Soviet to Cut Embassy
abstract: The newspaper Ittafaq said today that the Government had asked the Soviet Union to cut its diplomatic staff by half and had ordered the closing of the Soviet cultural center here.   A Foreign Ministry spokesman refused to comment on the report, which came two days after clashes between security forces and protesters in which 4 people died and 238 policemen were wounded.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.  announced that it would extend through the close of business on Friday its offer to buy below-market- rate home mortgages from thrift and institutional mortgage lenders. Freddie Mac has offered to buy mortgages with coupons as low as 7.5 percent, with the $50 million cap on each lender's aggregate offer removed for the special offer.     *  Gibraltar Financial Corp. of California's $40 million issue of 9 1/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2008 was priced at par, convertible to capital stock at $12.50 a share, through Salomon Brothers.

headline: HONDURANS DISAPPOINTED BY LEVEL OF U.S. AID
abstract: Government and military officials here say they are increasingly disappointed with the joint military maneuvers with the United States, which they had hoped would be accompanied by new economic aid or guarantees of military security.   The exercises, called Big Pine II, involve an average of 3,500 United States troops and several battalions of Honduran soldiers. They began in August and are scheduled to continue until March.

headline: Peruvian Police Seize More Than 100
abstract: The police arrested more than 100 people in connection with weekend bombing attacks that killed five people, but the key suspect - a woman guerrilla - was still at large, a Civil Guard spokesman said today.   The spokesman said many of those picked up in the sweep by 20,000 policemen in the capital were questioned and released.

headline: Data Bank; December 4, 1983
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: CAROLINA BANK GETS HIGHER BID
abstract: Bankers Trust of South Carolina, which has no relationship with Bankers Trust in New York, said yesterday that it is offering a package valued at $69.20 a share for the First Bankshares Corporation of South Carolina, or a total of $173 million for all the stock. The merger would unite two banks in Columbia, S.C., that are about the same size in terms of deposits.   The offer includes $60 in cash and the remainder in the form of two- tenths of a share of Bankers Trust of South Carolina stock for each share of First Bankshares, based on current prices for the companies' shares.

headline: United Delays Boeing Order
abstract: United Airlines said it had   agreed with the Boeing Company and United Technologies   Inc.'s Pratt & Whitney unit to   postpone the delivery of 20   previously ordered Boeing 767   airplanes and engines. Under the original plan,   United was to receive five   deliveries in 1985 and another   five in 1986.

headline: Fiat Unit and PPG
abstract: PPG Industries said it had agreed to purchase 65 percent of the stock of Industrie Vernici Italiane S.p.A., a subsidiary of Fiat S.p.A. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: TUBE PRICE CASE ENDS IN ACQUITTAL
abstract: A Federal jury yesterday found three companies and six executives not guilty of conspiring to fix copper tubing prices over a six-year period from 1975 to mid-1981. The verdict came at the end of a nine-week trial before Judge Daniel Huyett in United States District Court in Philadelphia.     The case was the biggest price-fixing suit brought by the Reagan Administration and one of the biggest ever brought by the Department of Justice. According to the department, total sales of the tubing by the defendant companies amounted to more than $360 million in 1980.

headline: MOTHERS OF MISSING WON'T GIVE UP IN ARGENTINA
abstract: The dictatorship ended nearly three weeks ago when the military stepped down from power, but the mothers who represent some of the thousands of people who disappeared under the military continue their vigil.   On Thursday, as they have every Thursday for nearly seven years, several hundred joined in a march of sadness among the flower beds and water fountains of the Plaza de Mayo, in the lee of the pink presidential palace here.   Despite the sweltering heat of the Argentine summer, they wore their same white headscarves with the same names of missing children scrawled in ink for all the world to read.   ''We will not give up the battle until all the guilty are judged, until we reach the truth about where are our disappeared ones,'' Hebe Bonafini, president of the mothers' group, said in an interview.

headline: U.S. SEES PROSPECT FOR MIDEAST TALKS
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that the deepening rebellion in the Palestine Liberation Organization could provide an opportunity to renew efforts to bring King Hussein of Jordan and West Bank Palestinians into negotiations with Israel.   The officials said that as far as they knew, Yasir Arafat, the titular head of the P.L.O., was still in Tripoli, leading his supporters in defense against stepped-up attacks from Syrian-backed P.L.O. rebels. But they said Mr. Arafat, if he survived, was likely to be forced to move to Tunis or some other place far from the West Bank of the Jordan.   Once that happens, the officials said, it will raise the question of who is authorized to speak for the 1.5 million Palestinians in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, which Israel has controlled since 1967. American officials said it was too soon to know what would happen.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; DON'T FAVOR TEEN-AGERS OVER ADULTS
abstract: EARLIER this year, the Administration proposed legislation that would allow employers, without prior certification by the Secretary of Labor, to hire teen-agers at a wage less than the current Federal minimum.  The most likely discount from the $3.35 per hour Federal standard would be 15 percent, and after a specified period of time (three months to a year, depending on circumstances), such a law wouuld probably require that a worker receive at least the full minimum wage.  This proposal strongly appeals to many people who believe that a legislated wage floor has seriously reduced employment opportunities for the young.  However, like practically everthing else in life, the benefits of a youth subminimum wage would not come without costs. In order to weigh the pros and cons of this important proposal, it is necessary to place it in the context of the overall effects of the minimum wage itself.

headline: PENTAGON'S INQUIRY BLAMES MAJOR MARINE COMMANDERS AND FAULTY POLICY IN BEIRUT
abstract: A special Defense Department commission that investigated the bombing of the Marine headquarters in Lebanon concluded in a report published today that major failures of command, intelligence and policy contributed to the vulnerability of Marine defenses.    The report is the Government's definitive inquiry into the Oct. 23 terrorist attack that killed 241 American servicemen. The five-member commission, appointed by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger last month, was charged with investigating the circumstances surrounding the attack and reporting its findings and opinions on the adequacy of security measures. The commission was headed by Adm. Robert L.J. Long, retired.   The report, submitted to Mr. Weinberger last week, was made public by the Defense Department with an indeterminate number of passages deleted for security reasons. The report said the policy of stepping up American military involvement in Lebanon endangered the marines' safety, and it also found intelligence inadequate.
