Its discussion of accountability, however, was of most immediate concern to Administration officials because the conclusions, they said, might raise questions about President Reagan's assertion that blame should rest with him.

headline: TOYOTA AND G.M. GET A GREEN LIGHT
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission decided in a three-to-two vote that the General Motors-Toyota joint venture to produce subcompact cars does not violate antitrust laws and the two companies can proceed with their production plans. Thus, the F.T.C. ended an investigation that had dragged on for 15 months. The final approval came only after the two big companies agreed to a consent decree that limits production to 200,000 subcompacts a year. Even so, the the five-man commission was split, with the three Reagan appointees pitted against the two appointed during the Carter Administration. ''A plain and unambiguous violation of the antitrust laws,'' said Michael Pertschuk, who was chairman of the F.T.C. under President Carter and voted against the Toyota-G.M. deal. The venture was also opposed by the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation, which argued that because of their size, G.M. and Toyota could use their venture to dominate the subcompact market. The consent decree is intended to prevent such domination.

headline: KILLINGS DOMINATE TALK ON SOUTH PHILIPPINE ISLAND
abstract: In this centuries-old seaport on the southern island of Mindanao, a large ''crime chart'' with red lettering is mounted over the entrance to the gray stone city hall.    The chart, placed there by Mayor Cesar Climaco, a fiery 61-year-old who sometimes rides to work on a motorcycle, shows that 723 murders were committed between Jan. 1, 1981, and the end of August this year in this city of 377,000 people.   The theme of violent death has come up in virtually every conversation during an eight-day tour of Mindanao, the second largest island in the Philippine group, after Luzon.

headline: Growth for E.E.C.
abstract: The European Commission forecast growth of 1.5 percent in the 10-nation European Economic Community in 1984 after a growth of five-tenths of 1 percent this year as the ''hesitant and patchy recovery'' continues. In its annual economic report to member governments today, the commission said recovery remains slow and is vulnerable to any renewed turbulence in the international environment.

headline: CHARGES FILED ON 33 FILIPINOS
abstract: The Government filed criminal charges of smuggling and other offenses today against 33 executives and employees of eight leading textile and garment companies.    The purported violations were said to have cost the country's ailing economy tens of millions of dollars in lost revenue.   A Government statement said the Commissioner of Customs, Ramon J. Farolan, filed the charges today on the orders of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

headline: PENN CENTRAL FINDS BUYERS FOR ARVIDA
abstract: A management group in the Arvida Corporation and Fort Worth's Bass brothers have agreed jointly to buy Arvida from the Penn Central Corporation, Penn Central said yesterday. Arvida is a Florida-based real estate and resort hotel subsidiary that Penn Central has been trying to sell.

headline: New Force Not a Topic With Allies, France Says
abstract: Defense Minister Charles Hernu denied today that France was discussing the use of its new Rapid Action Force with Western allies.   It was reported this week that a senior French Army commander began talks with the allies last month on?logistical support that NATO armies would offer the Rapid Action Force if used in Central Europe.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Angeles Corp.  announced that it would file for an offering of $30 million of senior subordinated debentures, to be offered in units with five- year warrants to purchase common stock.     *  Casablanca Industries Inc. , Milwaukee, filed for an offering of $11 million of subordinated capital debentures due in 1993.     *  Citicorp said an average rate of 9.331 percent was set at the weekly auction of its 91-day paper, down from 9.347 percent at last week's auction. A rate of 9.314 percent was set for its 182-day paper, down from 9.357 percent.

headline: DOW JUMPS TO RECORD 1,287.20
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average surged 17.38 points yesterday to a record closing high of 1,287.20. Analysts said heavy volume - 100.5 million shares traded, up from 78.2 million the day before - indicated that many cash-laden institutions had returned to the market.   The best gainers were some of the blue-chip and technology issues.   The market's overall advance, however, was not as sharp as the Dow's; winners outnumbered losers by about a 5-to-3 ratio. The performance of the two more broadly based market indicators yesterday was also more moderate. The New York Stock Exchange composite index of 1,500 common stocks rose 0.75, to 96.94, while Standard & Poor's index of 500 equities added 1.37, to 167.91. Both indexes are still below their record highs, set in October.

headline: President's Role In Courts-Martial
abstract: By saying today that no military officers should be punished for security lapses at the Marine compound in Beirut, President Reagan was apparently acting within his capacity as Commander in Chief.   The United States Uniform Code of Military Justice does not provide specifically that the President can order that a court-martial not be held, but that is presumably inherent in his power as Commander in Chief.

headline: CNCP Requests Low-Cost Service
abstract: -Television and Telecommunications Commission to allow it to provide a low-cost, long- distance telephone service similar to that offered in the United States by companies such as MCI Communications.   Strong opposition is expected from both Bell Canada, which provides services to 90 percent of all households in Ontario, Quebec and the British Columbia Telephone Company.

headline: Phone Stocks: Special Listing
abstract: In a box with the New York   Stock Exchange listings, The   New York Times will list separately the prices of the American Telephone and Telegraph   Company and the regional operating units. The listing will   run through April 1, when the   divestiture of A.T.& T. and the   local companies is to be completed.

headline: WHEN IT COMES TO HIGHWAY CHAOS, INDIA IS NO. 1
abstract: The Grand Trunk Road, one of India's historic thoroughfares, is a major national highway as important to the northern part of the country as, say, Interstate 95 is to the eastern United States. The Grand Trunk, however, carries a daily traffic chaos that dramatizes the clash between the old traditional India and the new modern nation.    On one particularly lethal stretch near this capital's northern outskirts, normal traffic involves passenger cars whizzing along past bicycles, which in turn dodge around carts pulled by smartly trotting horses, which must somehow get around more slowly moving tricycle rickshaws, which must in turn contend with rubber-wheeled carts pulled by plodding bullocks.   Three-wheeled motorized rickshaws, two-wheeled motor scooters, motorcycles and mopeds dart in and out of the parade. Pedestrians cross the highway at will, often seeming not to look. Occasionally a cow wanders into the traffic.

headline: SLUGGING IT OUT ON THE SOFTWARE FRONT
abstract: When 32-year-old Mitchell L. Kapor took his fledgling computer software company, the Lotus Development Corporation, public less than two weeks ago, he made a fortune - roughly $70 million in fact. That this former radio disc jockey and teacher of transcendental meditation turned to computer programming only a few years ago simply adds to the feat. It is the stuff of which legends are made, especially in the personal computer software business.    Throughout the land, other young and ambitious entrepreneurs are toiling away late into the night struggling to write that next great piece of software - a set of instructions, usually embedded in a gray disk, that allows the nation's computers to perform useful tasks. These lone programmers working in their basements are also dreaming of creating the next Lotus.   But such visions may be unrealistic - for Mr. Kapor's accomplishment, dramatic as it may be, is no rags-to- riches success story. Mr. Kapor was amply backed by nearly $5 million in venture capital. To introduce its personal computer program, called simply ''1-2-3,'' Lotus spent more than $1 million in advertising in a three- month period - an unprecedented level for the industry.

headline: DOW UP BY 12.50, TO 1,284.65
abstract: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday in quiet holiday trading with all three major market indicators ending at record highs.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which had closed at record levels last Thursday and Friday, finished with a rise of 12.50 points, to 1,284.65. In the last five trading sessions, the average has soared more than 53 points, partly on the expectation of strong corporate profits as the economic recovery continues.   William G. Hieber Jr., president of Shoenberg, Hieber Inc., said the market's strength stemmed from the belief that many corporations ''will issue improved third-quarter earnings reports in the next few weeks and from investors' growing convictions that interest rates will decline and that inflation is under control.''

headline: SANDINISTAS URGING NICARAGUA TO RALLY AROUND REVOLUTION
abstract: The Sandinista Government has used the United States invasion of Grenada as a rallying point for its own revolution.    The Government has been issuing communiques calling for discipline and loyalty to the revolution, and characterizing the invasion as just another example of ''Yankee imperialism.''

headline: TELEVISION DOS AND DON'TS
abstract: Don't wear a checkered suit. You'll look fat, and the lines in the cloth will appear to undulate on the television screen.   For an executive making his or her first television appearance, on a news or interview program or even in a video teleconference with other executives, many of the dos and don'ts of life before the lens can seem confusing.

headline: PRESS OFFICIALS ARE CRITICIZED OVER ID CARDS ISSUE
abstract: The two top officials of an international press group that has long defended press freedoms gave tentative approval last month to a proposal that would require identification cards for journalists working in war zones.   North American members of the group, the International Press Institute, have criticized the officials, saying such a proposal is an invitation to government licensing of the press.   The proposal was made at a Sept. 5 meeting in Geneva that had been arranged by the two officials, Max Snijders, the chairman of the board of I.P.I., and Peter Galliner, the executive director. They had invited four other press groups, including the International Organization of Journalists, a Communist organization based in Prague, to meet and discuss ways to protect journalists working in war zones and other areas of danger.

headline: Egypt Seeks to Extend Its State of Emergency
abstract: The Government of Egypt asked Parliament today to extend special emergency laws for another year, saying that 13 attempts had been made over the past year to overthrow President Hosni Mubarak.   The attempts were made ''by rightist and leftist armed terrorist groups who tried to undermine the security of the state,'' Interior Minister Hassan Abu Basha told Parliament.

headline: IRAN, IN U.N., WARNS OF FURTHER 'RETALIATIONS'
abstract: Iran's delegate to the United Nations warned today that the United States involvement in Lebanon would lead to ''further retaliations'' against its forces there.   In a strongly worded statement delivered at a session today of the General Assembly, the delegate, Said Rajaie Khorassani, said that France and the United States were the only two governments fully involved in the escalation of the military conflict in Lebanon and had ''lost whatever claim they had to maintaining peace and order there.''   The United States, Mr. Khorassani said, had ''openly become a party to the conflict.'' He added, ''It must prepare itself for further punishment from the Lebanese Moslem masses and further retaliations.''

headline: Soviet Calls DMZ Visit By Reagan Provocative
abstract: The Soviet Union accused President Reagan today of making a provocative trip to the Korean demilitarized zone and said the visit was meant to help ''intensify military preparations'' in Asia.   The accusations came in sharply critical commentaries on Mr. Reagan's Asian tour distributed by the official press agency Tass and other state- run information outlets.

headline: Pioneer Posts Profit for Year
abstract: The Pioneer Electronic Corporation, a leading maker of audio equipment, said today that its consolidated profit for the year ended Sept. 30 totaled $9.55 million, compared with a $13.1 million loss in the previous year.

headline: Economic Scene; Reaganomics Report Card
abstract: IS Reaganomics a winner or a loser? The 1984 Presidential election is more likely to turn on that issue than on any other, unless the Administration's conduct of foreign policy - in El Salvador, Nicaragua, Lebanon, Grenada and perhaps other theaters still to come - becomes the main issue.   Herbert Stein, professor of economics at the University of Virginia, senior fellow of the American Enterprise Institute and former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Richard M. Nixon, still considers it highly probable that, whatever else happens, economics will remain a strong factor in the election.   Writing in current issue of The A.E.I. Economist, which he edits, Professor Stein says one can already tell with great confidence what the economic platforms of both parties will be. ''The platforms,'' he says, ''will be the same, and they can be summed up in one word: 'See!' ''     But the two parties will ask the electorate to look at different things. The Republicans, according to Mr. Stein, will say: ''See how good things are under our management of the economy. Inflation is way down, taxes are down, interest rates are down and unemployment is falling.''

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Miles Laboratories Names a New Chief    Dr. Klaus Heinz Risse was named vice chairman and chief executive officer-elect of Miles Laboratories Inc. yesterday, succeeding Dr. Franz J. Geks, chairman and chief executive, effective July 1. Miles, a leading health-care products maker, is a subsidiary of Bayer A.G., the giant chemical company based in Leverkusen, West Germany.   Dr. Geks, who is 64 years old, is retiring under the Bayer mandatory retirement policy at age 65. In a statement yesterday, Dr. Geks observed, ''This action by the board recognizes that I will be reaching retirement age next year and assures that the appointment of my successor is known as early as possible. It also assures that Dr. Risse is given full opportunity to become familiar with the people, the business and most importantly the spirit of this company.''

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: Amerada Hess   $75,100,000   - 6.2

headline: MARINE COMMANDER TESTIFIES ON BEIRUT BOMBING
abstract: -The Commandant of the Marine Corps, Gen. Paul X. Kelley, said today that the bombing that killed at least 230 marines, sailors and soldiers in Beirut involved more than twice the amount of explosives as had been previously believed.   General Kelley told the Senate Armed Services Committee that the Defense Intelligence Agency had estimated that the truck that sped into the Marine headquarters in Beirut carried 5,000 pounds of explosives, not 2,000 pounds, as had been reported earlier.   At the same hearing, the commander of United States forces in Europe, Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, took responsibility for the security precautions arranged by the Marines in Beirut, since they are within his theater of operation.   ''I am responsible,'' General Rogers told the committee. ''Anything that happens or fails to happen in that theater is my responsibility.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: Justice Dept.  Backs Jet Plan    WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) - The Justice Department's antitrust division has decided not to challenge a joint venture by seven American, European and Japanese companies to develop and manufacture a more fuel-efficient jet engine for commercial aircraft.

headline: HEROIN ADDICTION SAID TO BE INCREASING IN EUROPE
abstract: The number of people addicted to heroin is increasing rapidly in Western Europe, and officials say the problem is spreading into areas where it had been previously unknown.    In Ireland, according to the police in Dublin, there are an estimated 6,000 heroin users today in a country where hard drugs were difficult to obtain before 1979.   In the Netherlands, where drug trafficking had been confined for some time to drifters and maritime workers in international centers like Amsterdam and Rotterdam, officials say hard drugs are finding their way to middle class youth in outlying areas. Similarly, Swedish authorities report that heroin use is no longer the problem of just a few cities.

headline: ESTONIA, FOR RUSSIANS, IS A WINDOW LOOKING WEST
abstract: In its 800-year history, Tallinn has survived fire, sacking, civil strife, war and occupation and yet has remained among the most charming and well-preserved of Europe's medieval towns.   Along with awe-inspiring walls and mighty towers with names like Peep- in-the-Kitchen, Stout Margaret or Tall Hermann, some 1,500 medieval buildings remain in the ancient heart of this capital of Estonia, one of the Soviet Union's 15 republics, or states.   A general restoration was completed in time for the 1980 Olympic Games, during which Tallinn served as host for sailing events. Since then this Baltic city has set about restoring each building to its original state, a project that may take generations.

headline: Closing by Inland
abstract: The Inland Steel Company said it is restructuring its raw materials operations by closing the Jackson County Iron Company in Black River Falls, Wis., its smallest iron ore mining operation. Inland, based in Chicago, said the closing of the operation, along with other lesser restructuring steps, will result in an extraordinary charge against fourth-quarter earnings of $15 million. The restructuring, attributed to lower demand for steel, will reduce Inland's work force by 330 employees.

headline: Acquisitions in U.S. Are Sweet for Finn
abstract: Today is not a holiday in Finland, but at the home of Erkki E. Railo of Helsinki, there will undoubtedly be a thanksgiving of sorts. Mr. Railo, an executive vice president of the Finland-based Huhtamaki Group, flew home from the United States earlier this week for a reunion with his family after seven months of negotiating with investment bankers and and living in hotels.   On Monday, he will return to Chicago as president and chief executive officer of his company's United States operations, a newly created position. Almost all of the United States holdings were acquired under Mr. Railo's supervision since April.

headline: SOVIET SAYS U.S. PLANS HUGE ATTACK IN LEBANON
abstract: The Soviet press agency Tass said today that the United States was planning a ''massive attack'' on ''national-patriotic forces'' in Lebanon.   ''In the leading circles of the Soviet Union it is deemed necessary to warn the United States Government with all seriousness about this, in connection with the plans to expand the armed interference in the affairs of Lebanon that are being harbored in Washington,'' the agency said.   The warning was issued as a ''Tass statement,'' which carries the weight of an official Government statement.    The agency said it was basing its warning on statements made by President Reagan, Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, as well as an unspecified ''information coming from various sources.''

headline: Military Link Charged In Aquino Slaying
abstract: The blue airport uniform worn by the purported assassin of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. came from a wardrobe of disguises maintained by the military, a lawyer for the accused man's family said today.

headline: S.E.C. Cites Touche Ross
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today censured Touche Ross & Company, a major accounting concern, for its audits of a defense contractor that was involved in a dispute with the Navy over millions of dollars in cost overruns on shipbuilding contracts.   The commission charged in an administrative proceeding that Touche Ross failed to use ''generally accepted auditing standards'' in its examinations from 1972 through 1977 of the financial statements of the contractor, Litton Industries Inc.

headline: CONE MILLS PLANNING TO GO PRIVATE
abstract: The Cone Mills Corporation, a textile company that has been the target of a takeover attempt by Western Pacific Industries, yesterday announced an agreement for Cone to be bought by management, employees and institutional investors.    Cone said holders of its 5.5 million outstanding shares would receive $70 a share, or a total of $385 million.   The stock closed yesterday at $66.75, up $3.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Its price has risen more than $20 since Western Pacific disclosed its takeover attempt early this month.

headline: BROOKLYN MAN TELLS OF ORDEAL IN GRENADA PRISON
abstract: On Aug. 15, 1979, Antonio Langdon was making repairs at his mother's home, three miles from St. George's, Grenada. His 5-year-old daughter, Shauna, was playing at his feet.    Almost casually, as he recalls it, a car stopped and two men got out. ''Come along,'' one said, ''the boss wants to ask you a few questions.''   ''Who is your boss?'' Mr. Langdon asked.

headline: Baldwin-United Sells Unit
abstract: The Baldwin-United Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Baldwin Life Insurance Company, which operates in New York State, to the Transamerica Insurance Corporation of California, a unit of the Transamerica Corporation, for about $5.4 million in cash.

headline: Vauxhall Strike Ends
abstract: Engineers and assembly workers at the Vauxhall Motor Company's plant here voted today to end their strike following a similar vote by workers at plants in Dunstable and Luton. The strike began last Friday. Union leaders here said they still reject the company's 7.75 percent pay offer and the fight for a better wage would continue inside the plant.

headline: GOLD DROPS $11 TO FALL BELOW $400
abstract: The price of gold closed below $400 yesterday for the first time in more than a year, touching off widespread selling, much of it forced by margin calls over the weekend.    In New York, bullion, as reflected by the spot October Commodity Exchange futures, closed down $11 an ounce, to $390.90, after being down as low as $387 earlier in the day. At Republic National Bank, gold was bid at $390.50 at 4 P.M., also down $11 from late Friday.   Among the factors that led to the sharp drop in prices were competitive yields on other investments, fears that more poor countries would be forced to sell their central bank gold reserves to finance debts and imports and the weakness in silver prices last week.

headline: A WRENCHING WEEK AT AIRLINE
abstract: Eastern Airlines reported a wider loss but also some headway with three of its unions. Page 38.             Continental Air Lines began running newspaper ads in nine cities yesterday to recruit pilots as it neared the end of the first week of a pilots' walkout. And the airline not only failed to expand its scaled-down operations as planned, but it also canceled 8 percent of its scheduled flights.

headline: DAMASCUS ORDERS MILITARY CALL-UP
abstract: Syria put its armed forces on alert and declared a general military mobilization today.   Sources in Damascus said the move was prompted by fears of a United States retaliation for the suicide bombing attack of the Marines headquarters in Beirut.   The state-run Damascus radio repeated messages to Syrian reservists to report at once to active duty with the 220,000-man army. One source in the Syrian capital said the Government of President Hafez al-Assad has ''decreed a status of full mobilization'' throughout the country without officially announcing it.

headline: PATENTS ; Device Alerts Doctors To Heartbeat Dangers
abstract: An electrocardiograph instrument designed to alert doctors to patients who, after heart attacks, are subject to life-threatening periods of excessively rapid heartbeats, has been invented by Dr. Michael B. Simson, director of the intensive care unit at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia.

headline: Visa Energy
abstract: The Visa Energy Corporation said it had filed to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code after talks for an equity infusion ended without agreement. Visa, an oil and gas company based in Denver, said talks were continuing with outside investors. Visa also said that litigation with the Marshall Exploration Company of Marshall, Tex., had been settled by Visa's sale of certain Texas properties to Marshall for $4.8 million and by a $1 million production payment.

headline: Soviet Atom Blast Detected
abstract: The Department of Energy said today that its system for detecting underground nuclear explosions had picked up seismic signals from the Soviet testing grounds northwest of Semipalatinsk, in eastern Kazakhstan. The signals were detected at 9:55 P.M. Tuesday.

headline: Reagan Urges Chile To Restore Democracy
abstract: The Reagan Administration urged the Chilean Government and its democratic opposition to resume talks today intended to return Chile to democratic government, and it sent a high State Department official to Santiago to stress Washington's interest directly.   The State Department official, Edward J. Derwinski, the department counselor, will tell Chilean leaders they risk being the ''odd-man out'' in relations with Washington after Argentina's elections on Sunday, according to one United States official. Mr. Derwinski will be in Santiago on Wednesday and Thursday.

headline: No Ferries to Greek Islands
abstract: Ferryboat sailings to the Greek islands have been canceled for Sunday so seamen may spend Christmas with their families. It will be the first time that the Greek Merchant Navy's ferryboats will not serve the islands on Christmas Day.

headline: Qantas-Boeing Pact
abstract: Qantas, Australia's national airline, said it received Government approval to spend $640 million on nine new Boeing airliners. It will buy six 200-seater B767 extended-range aircraft and three 300-seater 747's.

headline: Continental Group
abstract: The Continental Group said it had completed its sale of its containerboard, kraft paper and certain other units to the Stone Container Corporation for about $510 milllion.

headline: 39.2% DROP AT PAINE WEBBER
abstract: Paine Webber Inc., reporting a drop in net income similar to that of other major brokerage firms, said yesterday that earnings for its fiscal fourth quarter fell 39.2 percent, to $12.4 million, or 74 cents a share, from $20.4 million, or $1.34 a share, in the year-earlier period.    The decline came despite a 13.3 percent increase in revenue, to $372.5 million, from $328.8 million.   For the 1983 fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30, earnings jumped to a record $90.6 million, or $5.53 a share, from $35.9 million, or $2.37 a share, in fiscal 1982. Revenue increased 29.4 percent, to $1.54 billion, from $1.19 billion.

headline: SENATE UNIT CUTS MONEY FOR JORDAN STRIKE FORCE
abstract: The Reagan Administration's effort to obtain $220 million in secret funding for a Jordanian strike force in the Middle East was dealt a major setback today when the Senate Appropriations Committee deleted the money for Jordan from the 1984 military spending bill.   Congressional sources said the unexpected defeat for the Administration occurred when the Appropriations Committee met behind closed doors to hear objections to the Jordanian force that were raised by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, and Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii.   After discussing the plan to provide transport planes and modern infantry equipment to equip an 8,000-man elite Jordan force for use in the Persian Gulf, Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, chairman of the committee, decided that there were enough votes to defeat the inclusion of the funding for Jordan in the bill.

headline: Bahamian Crew Is Rescued From Blazing Ship Off France
abstract: French frogmen and naval helicopters rescued 29 crewmen from a burning Bahamian freighter off the coast of northwest France today, the maritime police said.

headline: U.S. AIDES SAY SOME IN INVASION DIED IN ACCIDENTS
abstract: Accidents caused some of the casualties among United States troops in the invasion of Grenada, Pentagon officials said today.   In the worst accident in which American servicemen were the victims, four Navy commandos died when their landing craft tipped over in heavy surf near the capital of St. George's on the day of the invasion, Pentagon officials said.   In other accidents, a dozen men were wounded when a Navy jet inadvertently dropped a bomb on their position, and two men were injured when a helicopter disabled by enemy fire collided with another helicopter.

headline: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Spinoff Tests Fund Manager
abstract: C AN an independent unit of a big bank find happiness - and superior market performance - in managing assets for institutional investors? That's the challenge facing 39-year-old Samson Wang as president of the Beacon Capital Management Company.    Created earlier this year as a subsidiary of the Bank of New York Company, Beacon manages $900 million for 20 corporate pension funds and foundations. Before the spinoff, these accounts came under the investment wing of the Bank of New York, where Mr. Wang was an executive. Meanwhile, the bank itself continues to manage another $6 billion for both individuals and institutions.

headline: 36 Die in India Train Blast
abstract: Two railroad tank cars loaded with gasoline exploded today at a station in Dhulwari, in northeast India, killing 36 people and injuring more than 100, the United News of India reported.

headline: Advertising; A Print Campaign For Rolls
abstract: AS long as the dedicated British workers that carefully construct the Rolls-Royce have the support of such creative American geniuses as Jerry Della Femina, Ron Travisano and Frank DiGiacomo, sales of that splendid motor car need never suffer in the Colonies. Perhaps.   The three are the team at Della Femina, Travisano & Partners that has put together the print campaign for the account won last April. It is due to break Nov. 18 with headlines and graphics by Mr. Travisano, the vice chairman, and Mr. DiGiacomo, a senior vice president, and body copy by Mr. Della Femina, the chairman.   In the agency conference room Monday morning, Mr. Della Femina mused at what a challenge it was to be writing Rolls advertising - returning it to the theme of quality construction from a status approach - and following in the footsteps of such an advertising great as David Ogilvy.

headline: BRAZIL ANTICIPATES EMERGENCY
abstract: President Joao Baptista Figueiredo invoked emergency powers tonight to calm a tumultuous debate over his Government's attempt to force down Brazilian wages. The action came on the eve of a scheduled congressional vote on the wage legislation.    The Government's intentions were still unclear, but diplomats in Brasilia said the powers appeared to apply only to that city and probably only to the chambers of the National Congress. ''Congress has been packed with people lobbying against the wage law,'' said a Western diplomat in Brasilia, ''and this now means people will be able to concentrate and listen to the debate.''

headline: Sanyo Computers
abstract: The Sanyo Electric Company said it would begin marketing personal computers in the United States next year that will be able to use software designed for the International Business Machines Corporation small business models. The Sanyo models, the MBC- 550 and MBC-555, will retail for between $1,000 and $1,400, Sanyo said.

headline: Indictment Asserts Bulgarian Paid $300 for Secret Papers
abstract: A Federal indictment brought Friday in New York said that Penyu B. Kostadinov, a suspected Bulgarian spy, paid an American graduate student $300 for secret United States nuclear documents.

headline: CALVIN KLEIN IS OFFERING $60 MILLION FOR PURITAN
abstract: Calvin Klein, the fashion designer, said yesterday that he and his business partner, Barry Schwartz, had offered to acquire the Puritan Fashions Corporation for about $60 million.   The $16.50 a share offer, if accepted, would give Calvin Klein control of a major manufacturer and distributor of clothing bearing his name. He and Mr.  Schwartz now own about 10 percent of Puritan's 3.65 million shares, and over the past few years Puritan has transformed its business from the production of women's dresses to become one of Calvin Klein's more important licensees.    Production and distribution of Calvin Klein jeans and jean-related products accounted for about 95 percent of Puritan's $246 million in sales in 1982, according to Mr. Schwartz. Of this, Mr. Klein was paid $15.6 million in royalties.

headline: Holiday Closings
abstract: Because of Veterans Day yesterday, most Federal, state and municipal government offices were closed and there was limited trading of Government securities. Most banks were also closed, and foreign exchange trading in the United States was limited. The weekly money supply report, usually released Friday, was postponed until 4:15 P.M. Monday.

headline: B.B.D.& O. Is Chosen For HBO Account
abstract: Home Box Office Inc., it was learned late yesterday, has selected Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn as its new ad agency for HBO, which had been at Ted Bates for four years.

headline: 78 KILLED AND 21 HURT IN A MADRID DISCOTH EQUE FIRE
abstract: Seventy-eight people died and at least 21 were injured and hospitalized early today when a fire spewed thick fumes in a popular basement discoth eque with hundreds of young people.    The police and survivors said most of the victims were asphyxiated as they fought to reach the street-floor exits of the dance hall, called the Alcala 20 and situated in the central business district here.   The crowd stampeded up narrow staircases. An employee said one of the doors on an upper floor was locked, and others noted that a major exit shared with the lobby of a theater in the same building had been closed by an iron grill. It was smashed during the fire, and scores of screaming young people poured out onto the street.

headline: CHRISTIANS START TO GIVE UP ON BEIRUT
abstract: Adnan Kassar has replaced the windows of his home six times. Mr. Kassar, a wealthy banker and president of the Chamber of Commerce here, vows to go on replacing the glass until the fighting here stops and peace is restored to his country.    ''I believe in Lebanon,'' said Mr. Kassar, whose windows were blown out last Sunday when two bombs ripped through the compounds of the French and American forces.   ''I don't want to be a millionaire refugee in Paris or New York,'' he said.   For eight years of fighting in which more than 100,000 people have died, many Lebanese, like Mr. Kassar, have hung on.   But this week, many of his friends, especially the Christians, have begun finally to despair. The attacks on the multinational forces, in which around 230 Americans and 58 French soldiers were killed, have led many to conclude there is no hope of reconciliation in Lebanon. Even if the leaders of warring factions resolved their differences at the talks in Geneva, which are scheduled to open this week, any truce would only be temporary, said those who despair of a settlement.

headline: RATE DROP SPURS RISE IN STOCKS
abstract: After almost daily declines over the past month, stock prices rose sharply yesterday, reacting in part to a drop in interest rates.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout the session, rose 17.58 points, to 1,232.52, its biggest daily since Oct. 6, when it soared 18.60 points. Since closing at a record 1,284.65 on Oct. 10, the average had tumbled more than 60 points.   The advance was broadly based, with stocks gaining in price on the New York Stock Exchange outscoring losers by a 5-to-3 ratio. Turnover climbed to 83.1 million shares, from 64.9 million on Tuesday, when volume was slowed because of Election Day.

headline: 5 SWORN IN TO GOVERNING COUNCIL FOR GRENADA
abstract: Grenada's Governor General swore in five members of an interim governing council today. The council promised to hold elections ''as soon as practical'' and to review the detention of citizens on the island.    At the same time, the council's legal adviser announced that a state of emergency imposed in Grenada after the United States invasion had been lifted. He did not elaborate on the meaning of the change.

headline: RAIL LINK S CLEARED BY I.C.C.
abstract: Santa Fe Industries and the Southern Pacific Company merged into a new holding company yesterday afternoon, hours after the Interstate Commerce Commission lifted an order blocking the combination.    The order was imposed last week, in response to protests by three other railroads, to allow the commission further time to review competitive implications.    The commission now has 31 months to decide if the two railroads owned by the merged companies can combine as well, producing the nation's third-largest rail system, after Burlington Northern and CSX.

headline: AMERICAN EXPRESS SEES NET OFF 10%
abstract: The American Express Company announced yesterday that its earnings for 1983 would be 10 percent below the 1982 level, because it had added $230 million to the reserves of the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company, its insurance subsidiary. In 1982, the company earned $581 million, or $3.02 a share.    American Express also said that it was replacing Edwin F. Cutler, 59 years old, who has been chairman and chief executive of Fireman's Fund since last Jan. 1.

headline: West German Orders
abstract: Domestic demand for West German construction equipment has recovered markedly from depressed levels at the turn of the year, but foreign orders have declined drastically.

headline: MEMBERS OF THE PENTAGON'S COMMISSION
abstract: Following is the section of the report on the Oct. 23 attack on the Marine barracks that describes the commission's members:    Adm. Robert L. J. Long    U.S. Navy, retired Chairman     Admiral Long retired as the commander in chief Pacific in July 1983, after 40 years of commissioned service which included combat duty in World War II and the Vietnam conflict. He has commanded the U.S.S. Sea Leopard; U.S.S. Patrick Henry; U.S.S. Casimir Pulaski; the Submarine Force, U.S. Atlantic fleet; Submarines, Allied Command; and Submarine Force, Western Atlantic area. Admiral Long has served as executive assistant and naval aide to the Under Secretary of the Navy; Deputy Chief of Naval Operations (Submarine Warfare), and Vice Chief of Naval Operations.

headline: WESTINGHOUSE UNIT RETREATS
abstract: A decision by Westinghouse S.A., a subsidiary of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, to suspend outlays while it reorganizes under the Spanish equivalent of bankruptcy law illustrates the difficulties that American businesses can have operating in a depressed economy under foreign restrictions.    According to company and Government sources, Westinghouse, Spain's largest manufacturer of heavy electrical and transport equipment, has been hurt by the worldwide recession in the construction industry and a reduction in demand for this type of equipment, which plunged 40 percent in 1982 and 45 percent so far this year.   In addition, the company was damaged by the new Government's austerity policies, which include drastic cutbacks in spending. The Government, for example, has recently approved the cancellation of five nuclear energy plants whose electrical equipment was to have been provided by Westinghouse.

headline: SHULTZ ASKS SOVIET TO PRESS SYRIA NOT TO WIDEN CONFLICT IN LEBANON
abstract: News session excerpts, page A20.           WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 - Secretary of State George P. Shultz called on the Soviet Union today to use its influence with Syria ''to look at the Lebanon problem in a sensible way'' and not widen the conflict there.   At a press conference in which virtually all questions were related to the American air attack on Syrian positions in Lebanon, Mr. Shultz was blunt in saying that ''we will defend ourselves'' if American reconnaissance planes are attacked again. But he said the American goal was to promote peace, not to enlarge the war.

headline: photo of Syrian soldiers; SYRIA SAID TO PASS EGYPT AS A POWER
abstract: Syria is rapidly eclipsing Egypt as the predominant Arab military power in the Middle East, according to Israeli and United States military analysts.    The officials attribute this to Syria's mobilization of manpower and to continued increases in the number and quality of Soviet weapons reaching Syrian forces.  The Israeli and United States sources who take this view also say the presence of 5,000 to 7,000 Soviet soldiers in the country has strengthened Syria's defensive position.   Syria's present tactical deployments, intelligence officials said, make it virtually certain that any deep penetration of Syrian airspace by Israeli fighters and bombers would meet heavy antiaircraft fire, both from missiles and guns, that are largely manned by Soviet personnel. Only one of the four major surface-to-air missile bases in Syria is now said to be operated by Syrians.

headline: CONSUMER CREDIT UP $2.38 BILLION
abstract: Outstanding consumer installment credit in the United States increased by $2.38 billion in September, seasonally adjusted, the Federal Reserve Board said today.   The rise from August was less than the increase in that month, when debt outstanding expanded by $3.39 billion.

headline: TALKS ON STRATEGIC ARMS RENEWED IN GENEVA
abstract: President Reagan's new proposals for cutbacks in intercontinental nuclear weapons were presented here today at the opening of a new round of American-Soviet talks.   There was no immediate indication of the reaction by Viktor P. Karpov, the Soviet delegate, to the proposals outlined by Edward L. Rowny, the United States negotiator. These urged principally that any deployment of new nuclear warheads by either side be accompanied by the destruction of a greater number of old warheads.

headline: Burroughs, Telex Venture DETROIT, Dec. 12 (AP) - The Burroughs Corporation and Telex Computer Products Inc. said today that they are planning a joint venture to build and sell flat panel display screens for computers.
abstract: The first product of the new company, which will be called the Plasma Graphics Corporation, would be a 1 1/2- inch thick, 4-inch-by-7-inch screen that can display the same quantity of information as a 25-line, 80-character cathode ray tube, the companies said. Burroughs, based in Detroit, manufactures business machines; Telex Computer Products, a Telex Corporation subsidiary, is in Tulsa, Okla.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: 2 Fannie Mae Issues    WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (Reuters) - The Federal National Mortgage Association set an 11.15 percent interest rate on its offering Wednesday of $600 million of three-year, one-month debentures, and an 11.75 percent interest rate on a $400 million five-year debenture offering.

headline: NEW VENTURE FOR BELL CANADA
abstract: When Bell Canada reorganized last April into Bell Canada Enterprises, investors bid up its stock on the expectation that the big utility was preparing to follow its distant cousin, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, into a future of unregulated growth in high technology.    This week, however, the big Montreal-based company confounded those expectations by making a surprise offer for Canada's biggest pipeline company.   Bell announced that it had agreed to pay $167 million (Canadian), or $31.50 a share, to acquire the 11.8 percent interest in TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. that is held by Dome Canada. It then offered the same price for all of TransCanada's 45 million shares, or an indicated $1.42 billion.

headline: Citicorp Notes To Yield 11.91%
abstract: A $250 million issue of 11 7/8 percent Citicorp notes due Nov. 1, 1988, is offered at a price of 99 7/8 to yield 11.91 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.    The notes, rated Aa-1, were part of a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The five-year issue yields about 70 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than comparable Treasury notes.

headline: 2 IN BULGARI FAMILY SEIZED BY GUNMEN AT AN ESTATE IN ITALY
abstract: Two members of Italy's millionaire Bulgari jewelry family were seized by gunmen posing as paramilitary officers, and hundreds of policemen searched today for the kidnappers, the authorities said.   Three gunmen burst into a villa south of Rome Saturday night and overpowered nine servants and farmworkers before seizing Anna Bulgari Calissoni, 56 years old, and her son, Giorgio, 17.

headline: NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS OFFER PROFITABLE WORK
abstract: ANGELA M. ANGEROSA moved from her home in upstate New York to Washington, in 1979, armed with what she called a ''generic'' college degree but not knowing quite what she wanted to do with her life. One of her first stops was at an employment agency, and, she said, ''they really opened my eyes to the opportunities in associations.'' The agency led her to a staff position with a small trade association, and thus she became one of more than a million people working for the more than 40,000 nonprofit national and local trade associations and professional societies in the United States.   Once placed, Miss Angerosa found a network of opportunities and challenges in Washington, which is the capital of associations as well as of the nation. It was not long before she learned of an opening at the American Society of Association Executives, which is known as the association of associations. That led to her current position of assistant to the public relations director in a newly formed division of the A.S.A.E.

headline: 55 in Tanzania Reported Dead As Lake Victoria Ferry Sinks
abstract: An overloaded ferryboat on Lake Victoria capsized and sank in a storm this week, killing at least 55 people, the Tanzania radio said today.

headline: BAILOUT PLAN FOR GERMAN BANK
abstract: Amid mounting concern about financial problems at Schr"oder M"unchmeyer, Hengst & Company, a prestigious private bank, a group of other West German banks acted today to rescue the institution.    In making the announcement, the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, indicated that the problems stemmed from losses at Schr"oder M"unchmeyer's nonbanking affiliates. Unlike in the United States, German banks may own shares in industrial companies and underwrite corporate stocks.   Schr"oder M"unchmeyer, which is headed by Count Ferdinand von Galen, president of the Frankfurt Stock Exchange, is one of Germany's leading international stockbrokers.

headline: TEXTS OF SUMMARY OF INVESTIGATION INTO ATTACK ON MARINES AND OF DISSENT
abstract: Following are the texts of the summary of findings and conclusions issued Monday night by the Investigations Subcommittee of the House Armed Services Committee on the Oct. 23 bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut and a statement of panel members' dissenting views, issued today, that are to be incorporated into the subcommittee's report: The Summary    (1)    There were inadequate security measures taken to protect the Marine unit from the full spectrum of threats. The truck bomb that transited and exploded on the Battalion Landing Team (B.L.T.) headquarters building, with the loss of 240 lives, rolled through a concertina wire fence that was primarily a personnel barrier; it went between guard posts where the guards had their guns unloaded and had no opportunity to fire before the truck got past them; it went through a gate that was generally left open and was almost assuredly open that morning; iron pipes in front of the building were not large enough to stop the vehicle and had an opening the vehicle could drive through. It is by no means certain that defenses protecting the B.L.T. building would have been adequate to repel a car bomb attack.

headline: Mrs. Kirkpatrick Hints At Arms to Argentina
abstract: The United States sees no reason to maintain its ban on arms sales to Argentina despite British opposition, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the American delegate the United Nations, said today.   Interviewed on British television, Mrs. Kirkpatrick did not say whether a decision had been made on lifting the ban, imposed by President Carter.

headline: Cincinnati Bell By Reuters
abstract: Cincinnati Bell Inc. has agreed to repurchase the 33 percent of its stock held by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for an average price of $38 a share, the two companies said.

headline: NEW BONDS: 88% APPROVED
abstract: Voters approved in Tuesday's elections about $3.5 billion in new bond issues that will be floated by state and local governments, according to preliminary data compiled yesterday by The Bond Buyer, a trade newspaper specializing in tax-exempt securities.   Of the 170 bond proposals up for voter approval, 122 were approved, representing more than 88 percent of the total debt before the voters. The approval rate was the highest since 1960, when voters approved more than 90 percent of all bond issues.

headline: NICARAGUAN LEADER SAYS 2,000 CUBANS HAVE ALREADY LEFT
abstract: Daniel Ortega Saavedra, coordinator of Nicaragua's ruling junta, said here today that 2,000 Cubans had left his country, but he said that Cuban military personnel would remain until foreign troops are withdrawn from other Central American nations.   Mr. Ortega said most of the 2,000 Cubans who left - out of an estimated 8,000 Cubans who have been working in the country - were teachers returning home after the end of a school term.

headline: Initial Tribune Issue Raised
abstract: Demand for the first public offering of the Tribune Company was so strong yesterday that the company decided to sell more shares than it originally planned. The company, which publishes The Chicago Tribune and The Daily News, in New York, offered 7.7 million shares of common stock, up from the 7 million that it said yesterday it would offer, at $26.75 each.

headline: Ramada's Net Leaps
abstract: Ramada Inns Inc., citing gains from property sales and higher gaming income, said today that its third-quarter net income climbed to $22 million, or 62 cents a share, from $1.76 million, or 7 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 8.3 percent, to $162.4 million, from $150 million.

headline: SCIENTISTS URGED BY POPE TO SAY NO TO WAR RESEARCH
abstract: Excerpts from address, page 36.         ROME, Nov. 12 - Pope John Paul II called today on the scientists of the world to abandon their ''laboratories and factories of death'' and replace them with ''laboratories of life.''   In a discourse that is could cause anguish for some Roman Catholics and others engaged in military research, the Pope urged scientists to insure that ''the discoveries of science are not placed at the service of war, tyranny and terror.''   The Pope stopped just short of explicitly urging all military researchers to quit their jobs. But a source close to the Pope, who asked not to be named and said he had contributed some of the ideas for the speech, said that the Pope strongly implied that military research should be abandoned. He said the Pope had never publicly expressed such strong sentiments on the issue.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE Longstreth, a Democrat, To Leave S.E.C. Early Bevis Longstreth, a Democratic member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has informed President Reagan that he will leave the commission on Jan. 13, nearly five months before his term expires. The announcement yesterday by Mr. Longstreth came as no surprise because he has been telling associates that he would leave early.
abstract: The vacancy will mean that the President has two non-Republican appointments to make to the five-member panel. By law, no more than three members may come from one party, and there are three Republican incumbents.   Mr. Longstreth, 49, was appointed to the commission by President Reagan in June 1982, and his term expires June 5, 1984. However, Mr. Longstreth said in his letter of resignation, he had served on the commission without being able to have his wife and three children join him in Washington. ''The burdens that this arrangement imposed on my family have grown to the point where I feel compelled to rejoin them in New York,'' he wrote.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  American Agronomics Corp., a Tampa, Fla., citrus company, has named William C. Rousse president and chief operating officer.     *  American Savings Bank has named Stephen Fuzesi Jr. first senior vice president, general counsel and secretary.     *  Fingermatrix Inc., North White Plains, a developer and manufacturer of electronic fingerprint identification and verification systems, has elected Mark A. Meyer chairman.

headline: SUBSIDIARY IMPERILS HARVESTER PACKAGE
abstract: International Harvester's tractor and parts subsidiary in France is in ''critical'' condition and could undermine the company's latest financial restructuring package, Harvester said in a statement mailed today to stockholders.   The statement said that the subsidiary had defaulted in October on agreements with its lenders, which could ''trigger cross-defaults'' in West Germany, Britain and the United States.   IH France, which makes and sells tractors and combines, fell below the minimum net worth specified by Harvester's dealers, who are also substantial creditors, at the end of Harvester's 1983 fiscal year on Oct. 31. Harvester refused to disclose the French unit's current net worth or to say what was allowed under the lending agreements.

headline: Splitting Gulf
abstract: To the Business Editor:   Dillard Spriggs, in complaining about the possibility that T. Boone Pickens might succeed in taking control of the Gulf Oil Corporation, expressed the fear that ''it will be hard for other major oil companies to escape the same fate'' (''Breaking Up Gulf,'' Business Forum, Nov. 13).    Such a fate, however, would be of great benefit to those companies' stockholders, the oil industry itself, competition and consumers. De-integration, or divestiture, will:     * Increase the value of oil company stocks and improve overall efficiency.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Claremont Associates announced the offering of $344,859,750 of serial zero coupon notes due from 1984 to 2007, through E. F. Hutton & Co. The notes are priced from 6.39 percent to 12.40 percent of par with yields ranging from 10.20 percent to 12.40 percent and will be payable from lease rentals guaranteed by the Security Pacific National Bank.     *  Doskocil Cos.  said its offering of 35,000 units, each consisting of an 8 1/2 percent subordinated note due in 1993 and 125 common shares, was priced at $998.29 a unit, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The debt portion is valued at 685.79, giving a stripped yield of 14.75 percent. The issue is rated B2 by Moody's Investors Service and B- by the Standard & Poor's Corp.

headline: Publishers Cite Abuses Of Press in 23 Nations
abstract: United States and Latin American newspaper publishers and editors said today that journalists were arrested, harassed, silenced or subjected to other violations of press liberties in 23 Western Hemisphere nations last year.   ''Attacks against freedom of the press are coming with more frequency and with greater rage,'' Andres Garcia Lavin, president of the Inter-American Press Association, said at the opening of the group's 39th annual general assembly.   The group said journalists had been kidnapped, jailed, wounded or killed in Argentina, Grenada, Chile, Haiti, Guatemala and El Salvador.

headline: CHIEF OF F.A.A. QUITS TO RETURN TO HIS BUSINESS
abstract: J. Lynn Helms, the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, submitted his resignation today, saying he wanted to resume his business consulting work.    President Reagan accepted the resignation expressing regret and thanked Mr. Helms for a ''job well done.''   Mr. Helms's handling of the 1981 air traffic controller's strike was, as President Reagan said in his brief letter of acceptance today, his best-known accomplishment. Mr. Helms, with the backing of the President, dismissed 11,400 strikers of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization and kept the nation's airports open, though at a reduced level.   The exchange of letters between Mr. Helms and President Reagan made no mention of reports that Mr. Helms's private business dealings had been under investigation.

headline: Afghan Rebels Reported To Down 2 Soviet Planes
abstract: Afghan guerrillas fighting the Soviet-backed Government have shot down two Soviet transport planes trying to resupply a besieged town in eastern Afghanistan, Western diplomats said today.   The guerrillas downed the planes, light aircraft identified as either AN- 26's or AN-32's, about two weeks ago at Matun, one of three towns under guerrilla siege, the diplomats said, quoting reports from their embassies in the Afghan capital.

headline: Soviet Search Appears Over
abstract: Soviet ships appear to have ended their search for wreckage from the South Korean airliner shot down over the Sea of Japan in September, Japanese Coast Guard officers said today.

headline: BROKERED DEPOSITS FACE TIGHTER RULES
abstract: In a move to reduce losses to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Federal agency ruled today that troubled banks may not accept deposits from brokers without its approval.   Until now, banks that could not get funds elsewhere have been able to stay afloat by ''buying'' them from money brokers. These brokers package relatively small deposits from around the country and place them with banks willing to pay high interest rates and broker fees.   Brokered deposits have played an important role in numerous bank failures. They were a key element, for example, in the failure last year of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Ever hear of a ''prestigious marketer of cough drops?''    That's how MacNamara, Clapp & Klein describes its new client, Laboratoires Valda, a French company that is only now entering the American market.

headline: PALESTINIAN URGES FACTIONS TO MEET
abstract: A Palestinian leader said here today that he and other prominent Palestinians were trying to organize an emergency meeting of all factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization to prevent the 19-year-old group from disintegrating.    The statement was made in an interview by Khaled Fahum, chairman of the Palestine National Council, the organization's parliament, which is based here.   He said that unless the factions reconciled their differences, ''there will be two P.L.O.'s, and two P.L.O.'s mean there will be no P.L.O.''   ''Two P.L.O.'s mean the end,'' he said.   No Formal Split in the P.L.O He spoke as Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the P.L.O. and head of Al Fatah, the largest faction, was being evacuated from the Lebanese city of Tripoli with 4,000 loyalists. The Arafat force, Mr. Fahum noted, has lost its military battle against Syrian- supported Palestinian rebels, but the organization has not been formally split.

headline: ISRAELI ARABS: SCORNED, ASHAMED AND '20TH CLASS'
abstract: The Arabs of Israel are torn between their country and their people.   As much as Jews, they are citizens of the state, with the rights to vote, to equality before the law, to the economic benefits of an extensive social welfare system. Many say they would serve in the Israeli Army if the army would have them, and would stay in Israel even if a Palestinian state were formed elsewhere.   In practice, however, they are aliens in their own land. As Moslems or Christians, they cannot feel wholly part of a nation conceived as a Jewish state.  As an Arab minority in a country threatened by an Arab majority in the region, they are the objects of suspicion, surveillance and official discrimination. For security purposes they are stopped often by policemen on the streets, summoned for interrogation, searched thoroughly at border stations and denied employment in the extensive military industries.

headline: E.E.C. Near Steel Accord BRUSSELS, Dec. 14 (AP) - Industry ministers of the European Economic Community agreed today on most new emergency measures to rescue their troubled steel industry.
abstract: The most controversial point at the meeting was a proposal for a system of certification aimed at monitoring the flow of steel trade within the Common Market.   Agreement was reached on that point late today, making it likely that a final agreement will be reached next week at a special ministerial meeting.

headline: THE GIVE AND TAKE OF SOCIAL SECURITY
abstract: SOME retirees who draw Social Security benefits and many workers who make payroll contributions will be paying more taxes next year as a result of a host of changes designed to restore fiscal solvency to the nation's retirement system. The major provisions of the Social Security Amendments of 1983 that take effect next week, as well as automatic changes mandated by earlier laws, are summarized below.    * Contributions by Workers.  Many employees will pay more FICA (Federal Insurance Contributions Act) tax next year. The Social Security Administration recently announced that the maximum wage on which the tax is imposed will rise to $37,800 from $35,700. The wage base is linked to benefit increases, which in turn are tied to rises in the Consumer Price Index. The wage base has increased every year since 1971, when it was $7,800.

headline: Zimbabwe Says Bishop Has Ended His Fast
abstract: A Government spokesman said today that Bishop Abel Muzorewa, under detention, had ended a weeklong hunger strike. But officials of Bishop Muzorewa's opposition party were unable to confirm the statement.

headline: Industry Aid Bank Urged
abstract: Fourteen House Democrats, in sharp conflict with the Reagan Administration, are proposing an $8.5 billion Government bank to help revive aging industries and help new high- technology companies in competition with Japan and other nations.   The Democrats, members of a House Banking subcommittee, said today that the nation's current general economic recovery is inadequate to ensure the survival of crucial industries such as steel and computers that must compete with well-organized foreign industries.

headline: MAJIK MARKET SHOPPERS TOLD OF MESA-GULF ISSUE
abstract: The struggle between the Mesa Petroleum Company and the Gulf Oil Corporation was carried on last week not only in boardrooms but also in convenience stores, courtesy of Dillard Munford, an Atlanta businessman.   Mr. Munford, chairman of Munford Inc., a major chain of such stores, had 250,000 leaflets printed urging Gulf stockholders to side with their company's management in Mesa's bid to restructure Gulf. He distributed the leaflets through the 980 Majik Market stores that his company operates.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Steel Output Down in Week     By The Associated Press   Steel production fell to 1.69 million tons last week, down 2.4 percent from the previous week's 1.73 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

headline: Gas Producer Plea Denied WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) - Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today refused to block a Federal court order expected to lead to refunds to natural gas consumers nationwide.
abstract: The Chief Justice left intact a Federal appeals court ruling that natural gas prices since 1978 have been illegally higher than they should be.   He turned down emergency requests from natural gas producers and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.

headline: U.N. ASSEMBLY HEAD LOSES POST IN PANAMA
abstract: Jorge Illueca, president of the United Nations General Assembly, was dismissed today as Vice President of Panama after a disagreement with Panama's powerful National Guard, the Government announced.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1983   International    G.M. is willing to sign an antitrust consent order to secure approval from the Federal Trade Commission of its joint venture with Toyota, the company said. Toyota officials also said an agreement is near. The vote by the commission is expected tomorrow, and commission aides said approval would be given. (Page D1.)   A Korean steel plant should be blocked from receiving a $100 million Export-Import Bank loan for equipment, the Commerce Department says, because ''increased Korean exports would be aimed primarily at the U.S.'' (D1.)

headline: REDESIGNED BUSINESS PLANES
abstract: The companies that make aircraft for business use and individuals are finishing their worst year since 1952. But the industry is spending hundreds of millions of dollars developing new planes in the hope that the market is beginning to recover.   Most major companies are designing or have already introduced high- performance planes that they hope will capture new sales to corporate buyers.   In the next two years, an entirely new generation of aircraft will be introduced, from large trans-Atlantic corporate jets to small single-engine turboprop airplanes that will be 40 percent to 50 percent more fuel efficient and will fly faster and higher than most of the planes now in service.

headline: Heller Liquidation
abstract: The Walter E. Heller International Corporation said its shareholders approved a plan of liquidation and the previously announced sale of its American National Bank subsidiary to the First Chicago Corporation for $275 million.

headline: THOUSANDS HONOR SLAIN FOE OF MARCOS
abstract: Tens of thousands of Filipinos took to the streets here today to mark the birthday of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the slain opposition leader who would have been 51 years old.     There were several minor clashes between rock-throwing demonstrators and the police. Those thought to have attacked the police were dispersed by officers who used clubs and fire hoses, Eight people were injured and 17 arrested.    The crowds carried signs demanding the resignation of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, whose Government is suspected of having played a role in Mr. Aquino's death last Aug. 21. The former Philippine Senator was shot dead as he stepped from an airliner that had brought him home after three years in the United States.

headline: ISRAEL MAY AID SHARES OF BANKS
abstract: Israeli authorities closed the stock exchange today to confer with banking officials in Jerusalem on whether the Government should intervene to help the country's banks from heavy losses after a run on their shares.   Speculators sold shares in order to raise cash to buy dollars in anticipation of a major devaluation of the Israeli shekel, which has not occurred.   While industrial shares were also heavily hit during the run, the banks propped up their shares by borrowing tens of millions of dollars abroad. But toward the end of the week, the banks indicated they could not keep it up and asked the Government to help.

headline: THE DEBUT OF I.B.M.'S JUNIOR
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced its first computer designed specifically for use in the home, but said the $700 machine would not be available for the upcoming holiday buying season.    Consumers will not be able to buy the long anticipated computer, called the PCjr (pronounced PC Junior), until early next year and it will be in limited supply even then, the company said. The delay is expected to slow holiday season computer sales in general because many consumers, already confused by a rapidly changing market, may delay their purchases until they can see and test the PCjr.   The home computer industry has been characterized by severe price cutting, which helped lead to last week's announcement by the Texas Instruments Corporation that it was quitting the business. There is also a growing disenchantment among consumers who are finding that the machines, many of which carry base prices of $200 and less, can do little more than play games.

headline: Advertising; Executive Change at Rosenfeld
abstract: STEPHEN E. HUMPHREY, whose father, Champ Humphrey, was once chairman of Gardner Advertising, St. Louis, is the new president of the New York office of Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson and the chief operating officer of the whole organization.   In the year and a half since he joined the agency, Stephen Humphrey, who is 41 years old, has been executive vice president and director of account services. Like Thomas E. Lawson, the president and chief executive, he came from Ogilvy & Mather. And he has something else in common with the boss: both their wives are executives on the account side at Kenyon & Eckhardt. They are Nina Lawson and Mary Lou Humphrey.

headline: U.N. Chief Says Plight Of Cambodia Is Worse
abstract: The situation in Cambodia is deteriorating in the absence of progress toward a peaceful settlement of the Vietnamese occupation, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today.   In a report to the General Assembly, Mr. Perez de Cuellar said the interest of the Cambodian people would be ''best served by a peaceful solution reached through a process of negotiations.

headline: SEOUL CONDEMNS BOMBING AS PLOT BY NORTH KOREA
abstract: The Government stepped up its war of words against North Korea today, blaming it for the ''barbarous'' bombing in Burma Sunday that killed 19 people, including some of South Korea's highest-ranking officials.   President Chun Doo Hwan, who apparently escaped harm only because a traffic delay kept him from the scene of the explosion, said upon his return to Seoul this morning that the incident was a ''carefully premeditated plot against the life of your President.''   'Not Talking From Evidence'    However, Government officials acknowledged they had no evidence that North Korea was behind the bombing, in which 47 people were wounded, many of them seriously. A principal Government spokesman, Choi Tae Soon, said, ''We are not talking from evidence but from the past record of the North Korean conspiracy.''

abstract: Storage Technology LOUISVILLE, Colo., Oct. 19   (AP) - The Storage Technology Corporation said today   that it expects to post a $6 million loss for the third quarter. It   would be the first loss for Storage Technology, a leading   maker of systems for storing   computer data, since it went   public in 1971.

headline: S.& P. INDEX ADDS A.T.& T. SPINOFFS
abstract: Surprising many on Wall Street, the Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday added to its 500-stock index all seven of the regional companies being spun off by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.   The slimmed-down ''new'' A.T.& T. will also be listed, replacing the ''old'' parent company in the index. The changes go into effect today.
