headline: BULGARIAN FREED FROM ITALIAN JAIL
abstract: A Bulgarian charged with complicity in the shooting of Pope John Paul II was released from jail by Rome magistrates today and placed under house arrest because of health problems said to require medical treatment.   Accompanied by Bulgarian consular officials and defense lawyers, Sergei Ivanov Antonov, the 36-year-old former head of the Rome office of the Bulgarian national airline, was taken by car from Rebibbia Prison to a private apartment owned by the Bulgarian Embassy in the Tor di Quinto neighborhood of Rome where he will be kept under heavy guard and receive medical treatment.   His release comes less than a week before the Pope is to visit the prison, where he is expected to meet another inmate, Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turkish national who is charged with the shooting.

headline: Dow Climbs 3.35, to 1,251.32
abstract: Stock prices rose modestly yesterday, with several of the technology issues scoring impressive gains.   The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow price range throughout the session, closed up 3.35 points, to 1,251.32. In the general market, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered decliners by almost a 3-to-2 ratio.

headline: RHODESIA'S WANDERING WHITES: HEARTSICK FOR THE PAST
abstract: In the catalogue of white self-perceptions in Africa, there are, by way of social distinction, many categories.   There is, for instance, the ''Kenya cowboy,'' a roguish, raffish figure set against a backdrop of sunlit safaris, pink gins and polo, and possibly dubious deals in an East African playground, whose roots might be traced to the minority of white settlers in the 1930's.   Then there is the ''two-year wonder.'' The label is affixed by settlers of long standing to fellow whites of briefer tenure in a continent of adoption - technicians or businessmen who come to Africa on a contract and amass a little wealth to warm their fortunes back home, usually in Western Europe, Britain in particular. The two-year wonder is a figure of some derision, without the faded glamor of the Kenya cowboy.

headline: CHRYSLER: NEW VAN AND PLANT
abstract: When Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, drives a minivan off an assembly line here next Wednesday, it will mark the start of full production at a plant that has been completely rebuilt in an attempt to match Japanese production efficiencies.    Chrysler officials have high hopes for both the new product and the new facility, which cost $660 million. With a new production system that reduces inventory in the plant, they expect an increase in efficiency that will help pay for the $1 billion labor contract recently signed with the United Automobile Workers Union.   The vans, to be marketed as the Plymouth Voyager and the Dodge Caravan, are intended to woo buyers away from conventional station wagons and larger vans.

headline: MARINES' SECURITY RAISES QUESTIONS
abstract: After a car bomb blew up the United States Embassy in Beirut on April 18, killing 63 people, the Marine force at the Beirut airport took steps to strengthen security measures against a similar incident, Marine Corps officers said today.    The embassy bombing, and at least seven other serious car bombings this year in Beirut, gave warning of a common tactic. But a determined terrorist overwhelmed the new airport defenses, raising questions about why the security measures were inadequate.    Larry Speakes, the chief White House spokesman, said tonight that President Reagan had ordered the Marine Commandant, Gen. P. X. Kelly, to go to Beirut to determine what security measures could be taken to improve protection for the marines in Lebanon.    'Unbelievable,' Kennedy Says    Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, a member of the Armed Services Commitee, asked for an investitation by the committee into what he called the ''unbelievable breakdown in security that allowed it to happen.''

headline: ECUADOR REBOUNDING FROM ECONOMIC PLIGHT
abstract: Ecuador, which with other Latin American countries has teetered on the brink of financial disaster for years, rebounded into economic ''recuperation'' three months ago. Its President, Osvaldo Hurtado, said the recovery could speed up next year.   President Hurtado, a 44-year-old former economics professor, conceded in an interview Friday that Ecuador, which has a foreign debt of more than $6 billion, was far from solving its payments problems.   He said that with a combination of austerity measures undertaken two years ago and increased petroleum production that ''we have been able to resolve our immediate problems'' and that Ecuador was headed toward eventual economic recovery.

headline: GARTNER AND I.B.M. IN ACCORD
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation and a small Connecticut-based research company, The Gartner Group Inc., have reached an agreement under which the latter has agreed not to disclose any of I.B.M.'s trade secrets.      Gartner, founded in 1979, enjoys a reputation on Wall Street for the aggressive manner in which it reports on I.B.M. for Gartner's clients - primarily users of I.B.M. computers and services.   ''I don't think we're terribly popular with I.B.M.,'' David L. R. Stein, Gartner's executive vice president said recently.

headline: FRENCH SOLDIER ON PATROL KILLED BY BEIRUT GUNMAN
abstract: A French soldier was killed today when his patrol was fired on by an unidentified gunman, a spokesman for the French force here said.   The spokesman, Lieut. Col. Phillipe de Longeaux, said the patrol came under small-arms fire at 5:50 A.M. as it drove through the Tayuneh neighborhood on the southern edge of Beirut.   The patrol returned fire, he said. He did not say if the assailant was hit.

headline: Ford to Upgrade Spain Motor Plant
abstract: The Ford Motor Company said it would invest $42 million to upgrade an auto plant in Valencia, Spain, to produce a new line of 1.3- liter engines.   Ford's chairman, Philip Caldwell, said the investment would increase the plant's engine capacity by 195,000 units a year, to about 635,000. The new engines are to be used in Ford Escorts that are sold in Europe.

headline: Axia Holdings
abstract: Axia Inc. said the financier Victor Posner, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said he plans to increase his holdings in the company to more than 25 percent, from 16.1 percent.

headline: IRAQIS FACING NEED TO WIN IN GULF SOON
abstract: Senior military analysts and diplomats say they believe that Iraq, fearful of losing a war of economic attrition with Iran, may try to widen the war by forcing Iran to take military action to close the Persian Gulf.  A senior official of the Baghdad Government said recently that Iraq had already fired Soviet-made surface-to-surface missiles at Kharg Island, the Iranian oil terminal at the head of the gulf, and neutral military analysts believe that there will be further attacks from missile sites in Iraq.   The type of missile supplied by the Soviet Union to Iraq, known as SCUD B in the West, has a range of 187 miles and is capable of hitting Kharg Island and other targets in Iran from sites deep in Iraq. Recently these missiles have hit cities 125 miles into Iran. However the SCUD B, which can carry either a nuclear or a non-nuclear warhead, is not an accurate missile and informed opinion in London is that the Iraqis might fire as many as 10 without hitting the Kharg Island terminal.

headline: P.L.O. TRUCE PACT CALLED COMPLETE
abstract: Yasir Arafat and the rebel Palestinians who have been besieging him and his guerrilla supporters here were reported today to have agreed on the final details of their mutual withdrawal from Tripoli within the next two weeks.   Meanwhile, Mr. Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, relocated his headquarters here and dispersed his senior staff throughout the city in an attempt to escape any retaliaory Israeli air strike in response to the bomb explosion set off by guerrillas on a city bus in Jerusalem on Tuesday.   Mr. Arafat avoided reporters and an aide said the P.L.O. leader was temporarily going ''underground'' out of concern that retaliation for the bus bombing might also include an assassination attempt.   Negotiations for the evacuation of the guerrillas were continuing in Damascus, where former Prime Minister Rashid Karami reported that final touches were being put on the accord. All that remained was said to be for Mr. Karami to conclude aqrrangements for the security force that is to oversee the withdrawal.

headline: 4 ALLIES PLEDGE TO KEEP FORCES IN BEIRUT AREA
abstract: The United States and the three other countries in the multinational force in Lebanon said today that they would remain there indefinitely to press for a broadly based Lebanese Government and the withdrawal of Israeli and Syrian forces.   The Americans appeared relieved at the allied show of support because the tactics worked out last week with Israel and with the Lebanese Government were conditioned in part on a firm Western presence in Lebanon.   In Washington, the Marine Corps Commandant, Gen. Paul X. Kelley, said he was ''optimistic'' that the Marine unit could be withdrawn early next year. But a Marine spokesman and Government officials said no decisions had been made. (Page A14.)

headline: FORD POSTS A PROFIT IN QUARTER
abstract: The Ford Motor Company, continuing the series of better-than-expected third-quarter earnings reports in the automobile industry, today reported a profit of $333 million, or $1.83 a share, compared to a loss of $325 million a year earlier. Analysts had been estimating that Ford would earn about $250 million.    The four domestically based auto companies thus had a combined profit of $1.16 billion for the quarter, against a combined loss of $218 million in the comparable 1982 period. Earlier this week, the General Motors Corporation reported a profit of $737 million and the Chrysler Corporation reported one of $100 million. Only the American Motors Corporation, by far the smallest company in the group, had a loss, of $9.1 million.

headline: INTERFIRST REASSURES BANKERS
abstract: The big third-quarter loss reported late Friday by the Interfirst Corporation of Dallas surprised many of the 11,000 bankers here for the annual convention of the American Bankers Association.   But it evidently did not surprise top officers at the bank holding company. They indicated in an interview here that they had spent the days before the announcement assuring their colleagues in the industry that Interfirst was sound.   Not only was the $194 million net operating loss the biggest ever reported among American banks, but Interfirst long had been considered to have been one of the best run and most profitable banking organizations in the United States.

headline: Mesa Retracts Offer for KN
abstract: The Mesa Petroleum Company said it had decided to withdraw its offer to acquire all of KN Energy Inc.'s shares outstanding.   Mesa said that it may increase or decrease its investment in the shares or may propose another transaction with KN.

headline: 500,000 JOIN DUTCH ANTIMISSILE RALLY
abstract: An estimated 500,000 people turned out here today for a peaceful mass rally to protest NATO's scheduled deployment of intermediate-range missiles.    A member of the Dutch Royal Family, Princess Irene, the 44-year-old younger sister of Queen Beatrix, told the rally that she refused to go on living under the shadow of nuclear threat.   By addressing the rally she broke with a custom that keeps members of the House of Orange from speaking out on sensitive political issues in this constitutional monarchy.

headline: 82D AIRBORNE MOVES IN TO REPLACE THE MARINES
abstract: Elements of the United States 82d Airborne Division replaced United States marines in all positions in Grenada today, then fanned out through the island in an effort to secure it against continued sniping.    At the Point Salines airport, the United States military headquarters five miles southwest of this capital, a spokesman for the division, Maj. Douglas Frey, said, ''Our mission is to secure the island and capture whatever leaders of the army remain.''   On Sunday, a unit of the 82d Airborne captured Gen. Hudson Austin, commander of the Grenadian Army and head of what had been the ruling revolutionary military council. The general was captured at Wetherhaven Point, a small peninsula in the southeast.

headline: U.S. Invasion Said to Harden Opposition to New Missiles
abstract: The United States invasion of Grenada has hardened opposition in Europe to deployment of new medium-range American nuclear missiles there, the European Parliament President Pieter Dankert says.   Mr. Dankert, who held talks with Reagan Administration officials last week, also said he believes that a United States-European trade war is a ''real possibility.''

headline: Preparations Start For Stockholm Meeting
abstract: Preparations for a European disarmament conference began today, with all sides calling for discussions that would ease East-West tensions. The conference is to open in Stockholm Jan. 17.

headline: AT LEJEUNE, CHILD GETS AN EXTRA HUG
abstract: Like so many wives here, Linda Bates has spent the last two days waiting to hear from her husband, to learn that he is alive in Beirut.   ''I know that if he is O.K. he will try to reach me somehow,'' said Lieutenant Bates, a 35-year-old Navy nurse stationed at the base hospital at Camp Lejeune. ''I can't lie down without imagining things, without straining to hear the telephone. Sometimes I think it's ringing even when it isn't.''

headline: KN Energy Plans Oil-Gas Spinoff
abstract: KN Energy Inc., as it said it would do last month after rejecting an acquisition proposal from the Mesa Petroleum Company, said it plans to spin off its oil and gas exploration and production operations to two new companies. KN said its board had authorized the formation of a new corporation, the Midlands Energy Company, which will own KN's exploration and production units, the Midlands Gas Corporation and the Excelsior Oil corporation.

headline: COMMONWEALTH CRITICIZES U.S. OVER NAMIBIA
abstract: Leaders of the 44-nation Commonwealth said today that efforts to win independence for South- West Africa were being obstructed by United States insistence that there should be a parallel withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola.   This position was supported by Britain and Canada, which together with the United States, France and West Germany belong to a United Nations contact group that has been trying since 1977 to find a way to end South African rule over South-West Africa, also known as Namibia.    According to Patsy Robertson, a spokesman for the Commonwealth conference here, the heads of Government and other delegates expressed ''sadness, puzzlement and a certain amount of dismay'' over what they perceived to be ''mistaken American policies based on misconceptions of the real principles at stake.''

headline: 'RE-REGULATIN' WOULD AID COMPETITION
abstract: A panel headed by Vice President Bush is looking into a pro- posal to consolidate most of the Government's regulation of com- mercial banks in a new, single Federal banking commission. Under the draft plan, the new agency would supplant the Comp- troller of the Currency, abolish the Federal Reserve Board's juris- diction over most banks and holding companies and assume many of the noninsurance functions of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The plan also would expand the powers of the Fed- eral Home Loan Bank Board to include regulation of smaller com- mercial banks in addition to savings and loan associations.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1983
abstract: Companies    An inquiry into whether crimes were committed during an S.E.C. investigation of possible insider trading violations by Paul N. Thayer, Deputy Secretary of Defense, is planned by Federal prosecutors in New York and Washington, officials said. The questions about Mr. Thayer's activities while he was chairman of the LTV Corporation constitute a potential source of extreme embarrassment to the Administration. (Page A1.)   Chris-Craft Industries and Warner Communications announced a deal whereby Chris-Craft will acquire more than 25 percent of Warner and Warner will acquire a 42.5 percent stake in Chris- Craft's television subsidiary, BHC. The transaction is being seen as an attempt by Warner to fend off Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher whose holding company recently acquired 7 percent of Warner, making it the largest shareholder. (D1.)

headline: Export Curbs Are Extended
abstract: Declaring that a national economic emergency exists, President Reagan signed an executive order last week that indefinitely extends export controls and other provisions of the Export Administration Act.   Mr. Reagan acted under the 1979 International Emergency Economic Powers Act because the Export Administration Act, extended by Congress beyond its Sept. 30 expiration date, lapsed at midnight Friday.

headline: SUCCESSION PLAN STIRRING NEW ATTACKS ON MARCOS
abstract: Many businessmen and political opponents say a plan by President Ferdinand E. Marcos's ruling party to restore the vice presidency, abolished 10 years ago, will not end their demands that Mr. Marcos resign.    Calls for the President's resigation were heard daily this week in demonstrations leading to a memorial ceremony Sunday for the slain opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr. Another demonstration, involving about 25,000 people, took place today in Manila's financial district. Mr. Aquino, who was shot to death as he stepped from an airplane here Aug. 21, would have been 51 years old.   Political unrest after the slaying has been accompanied by a sharp economic decline traced to doubts abroad of the stability of the Marcos Government. Most of the the demonstrations have been peaceful.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: WHT Shifts to Ogilvy    WHT, a pay-TV broadcast company, is moving its advertising account to Ogilvy & Mather Partners from Lansdowne Advertising, a J. Walter Thompson division, on Jan. 1. WHT, which stands for Wometco Home Theater, is a unit of Wometco Enterprises, which is in the process of being acquired by a group of investors headed by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company. Billings on the account are about $4 million, 80 percent of which are earmarked for television.

headline: TREASURY UNEASY ON SOVIET TRADE
abstract: An unexpected recommendation by a subordinate to Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan to bar the importation of some Soviet goods said to be made with the help of forced labor has put the Treasury chief in what aides say is an awkward position.    In September, William von Raab, the 41-year-old Commissioner of Customs, said in a letter to Mr. Regan that he had information that ''reasonably indicates'' that some three dozen products imported from the Soviet Union in 1982 were manufactured with the help of prisoners or other forced labor.   The Customs Service is an arm of the Treasury Department. Under the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930, the Secretary of the Treasury is empowered to deny entry to foreign goods made with ''convict labor'' or ''forced labor.''

headline: INDIA IS SLOWLY WINNING ITS WAR ON ILLITERACY
abstract: At one end of the open veranda of a crumbling building that once served as the village council hall, nine elementary school- aged children sat cross-legged on burlap mats following their teacher in unison, counting in Hindi.   Other children wrote numbers and letters with brushes on black slates in white ink. Inside the building, older children worked at arithmetic.   The school and others like it are playing a key role in a gradual transformation that is taking place in rural India.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Glick & Lorwin    Creamer Inc. has acquired 30-year- old Glick & Lorwin, an educational and professional relations firm that specializes in corporate and association-sponsored curriculum materials and teaching aids. Glick & Lorwin, which will retain its name, has become a part of Creamer Dickson Basford, Creamer's public relations subsidiary. Ira Glick and Bordis Lorwin will continue as its managers.

headline: Brazil Strike Continuing
abstract: Metalworkers voted today to continue a week-long strike that has paralyzed much of Brazil's auto industry. They are seeking pay increases above a Government limit that was designed to curb inflation. The stoppage started last Monday at the Ford plant at Sao Bernardo, on the city's outskirts, and spread to Volkswagen and other factories.

headline: Thailand and Malaysia Attack Border Rebels
abstract: Thailand and Malaysia have begun major coordinated military assaults on Communist guerrillas based along their common border, a Thai military officer said today.

headline: Quake Strikes Yugoslavia
abstract: An earthquake that registered 3.7 on the open-ended Richter scale struck the southern Adriatic coast early today, sending residents fleeing from their homes. The police said the earthquake caused no damage or casualties.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: G.M. Board Backs Nigeria Truck Tie
abstract: The General Motors Corporation's board has approved an agreement with the Nigerian Government to begin assembling Isuzu light commercial trucks at a new plant near the Chad border starting in late 1985.   W. C. Mott, executive vice president of G.M.'s overseas operations, said the truck-making venture will be capitalized in excess of $25 million. G.M. will have a 15 percent equity interest and will retain management control in the venture. The venture will include 15 local investors and three other foreign investors including Isuzu Motors Ltd. of Japan with about 15 percent equity interest.

headline: 200 Extremists Attack The Jerusalem Mayor
abstract: About 200 Orthodox Jewish extremists assaulted Jerusalem's Mayor, Teddy Kollek, with sticks and bottles today, knocking him down in a street brawl.   Mr. Kollek's spokesman, Rafi Davara, said that the Mayor received a scratch on his face and a bruise on his knee and his trousers were torn but that he did not need medical attention.

headline: POLAND SHOWING 'DAY AFTER'
abstract: ''The Day After,'' the ABC-TV film about the aftermath of nuclear war, is scheduled to be broadcast on national television in Poland tonight - the first time the film has been shown in a Soviet-bloc country - the film's distributor said yesterday.    Eddie Kalish, senior vice president of worldwide marketing for Producers Sales Organization, distributors of the film for ABC, said that TVP, the Polish Government-owned television network, had bought the film and that it was to be shown this evening.

headline: BANKERS SAY MARCOS MUST ACT SOOM
abstract: The Government has been assuring Filipinos that the country's economic crisis is under control. Foreign bankers do not agree.    Many believe, in fact, that President Ferdinand E. Marcos - through his failure to mollify his political critics - is making his country a less attractive candidate to be bailed out of its suddenly overwhelming $19 billion debt to foreign commercial banks and governments.   ''I don't understand why Marcos doesn't do something,'' said an exasperated senior executive of a major American bank who declined to be identified. ''He's supposed to be such an astute thinker and politician. There are going to have to be some gestures made, and he's not making them.''

headline: SELLING VIEWERS A PACKAGE PLAN
abstract: One way the cable industry is fighting ''disconnects'' is by packaging, or bundling together one or more pay services with basic cable. Package buyers are less likely to drop a pay service, operators say, because they might actually end up paying more for fewer separate parts.  As a result, ''packaging has swept the cable industry in recent months,'' said Dennis Leibowitz, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

headline: U.S. REPLACES HEAD OF LATIN AID FUND
abstract: The head of a Government agency that makes grants to Latin American civic organizations and other groups that sponsor self-help projects for the needy has been dismissed by board members appointed by the Reagan Administration.    The directors of the agency, the Inter-American Foundation, voted, 4 to 2, on Monday night to replace Peter D. Bell as its president. The two negative votes were cast by Carter Administration holdovers.

headline: CommoditiesH. J. Maidenberg Year-End Futures Accounts
abstract: T HE margin accounts of futures   traders have always been   ''marked to the market'' at the end of every business day. At that time, any profits of the day are credited to accounts, while losses not covered by surplus funds often result in margin calls.   But next Friday, the last business day of the year, marking to the market will again mean something else. On that day, for every open futures account, profits and losses must be marked to the market for tax as well as margin purposes.

headline: ARGENTINE RIPPLES TOUCH NEIGHBORS
abstract: When Wilson Ferreyra Aldunate, an exiled Uruguayan opposition leader, came here as a specially invited guest for the inauguration Saturday of President Raul Alfonsin, he was interviewed by a leading Uruguayan newspaper.   The interview, in which he extolled democracy and asked for respect from the military rulers in his own country to allow him to return home, was published Sunday inconspicuously on page 4 of the newspaper, El Dia.   Today, the Uruguayan military issued a decree closing the newspaper for three days. The interview, the decree said, was with someone who has ''no national rights.''

headline: Unesco Chief Regrets U.S. Withdrawal Move
abstract: The head of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization expressed regret today at the decision of the United States to withdraw from the agency, which is based here.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: City Rejects Bond Bid    New York City officials rejected a proposal by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and other securities firms to buy $25 million of city bonds due in 1 to 10 years. The new bonds would have been in additon to the $125 million of city bonds bought by the securities dealers on Wednesday and reoffered to the public with yields ranging from 6 percent in 1985 to 9 percent in 1993 and 9.91 percent in 2007-08.

headline: U.S. REPORTS EVIDENCE OF ISLAND HOSTAGE PLAN
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that United States invasion forces in Grenada had found evidence that the Grenadian Government, in conjunction with Cuban advisers, had been considering a plan to hold United States citizens hostage in the near future.    The officials said the evidence included documents that were found at a Cuban military installation in the village of Frequente, which was overrun by invading American forces.   ''It is clear from these documents and other information we now have that serious consideration was being given to seizing Americans as hostages and holding them for reasons that are not entirely clear, but seem to involve an effort to embarrass the United States and, more immediately, to forestall American military action in Grenada,'' one senior official said.   Another senior official said, ''It appears we got there just in time to prevent a tragedy.'' The officials declined to describe the documents in detail or to discuss specific information about the potential seizure of hostages.

headline: GROUP BEHIND BOMBING IN RANGOON IS MYSTERY
abstract: The bomb that killed 19 people and wounded 48 in Rangoon on Sunday could have been planted either by Burmese dissidents or by North Korean terrorists, diplomatic sources in the Burmese capital said tonight.   ''No one here seems to know,'' one ranking official said in a telephone interview. ''The city is full of speculation, but the Government has so far issued no statement assigning blame, and no one has claimed responsibility.   ''It seems obvious, though,'' he said, ''that it was largely fortuitous that more Koreans than Burmese were killed. Whoever planned the attack could not have known where the two groups of people would be when it went off.''

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Public Relations Assist    One area of communications in which ad agency chiefs generally need help is public relations, especially when it has to do with their own company. The American Association of Advertising Agencies, at long last, has come to the rescue with an excellent booklet entitled ''How to Handle Public Relations for Your Advertising Agency,'' written by Joyce Harrington, who does just that for Foote, Cone & Belding. The booklet is free for member agencies and $10 for nonmembers.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: $318 Million of Bonds Priced for Puerto Rico    Citibank tentatively priced two bond issues for Puerto Rico yesterday. Both issues were backed by Federal Home Administration insured mortgages and Section 8 assisted projects.

headline: Advertising; Y.& R.'s Focus on Cable TV
abstract: YOUNG & Rubicam, which always thinks of itself as a total marketing communications company, has established a new unit so that it can lead its clients into the new world of electronic technologies. That meant expanding the New Electronic Media group and bringing Timothy V. Conner from Burson-Marsteller, Y.& R.'s public relations company, to run it.   Actually he will be succeeding William Donnelly, the agency's resident guru and thinker on new technology, who has left to write a book on the subject.

headline: SPEAKES'S TONE ANGERS REAGAN, OFFICIAL REPORTS
abstract: Several former heads of the Council of Economic Advisers indicated that the current chairman had been too outspoken. Page 29.           WASHINGTON. Dec. 2 - A senior White House official said today that President Reagan had been angered by the tone taken by Larry Speakes, his spokesman, in commenting on Wednesday about Martin S. Feldstein, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.   The official said Mr. Reagan objected to the manner, but not the substance, of Mr. Speakes's repeated criticism of Mr. Feldstein for his public insistence on the need to reduce the Federal deficit through tax increases.

headline: Regina Still Restrained On Consumer Reports
abstract: Federal Judge Henry F. Walker of the Southern District of New York on Friday continued the temporary restraining order that prevents the Regina Company of Rahway, N.J., from mentioning Consumer Reports evaluations in TV commercials.   Consumers Union, parent company of the monthly magazine, which already has a suit pending against Miller Brewing for the use of its material, filed suit against Regina on Sept. 30.   The maker of floor care products said that it respected the wishes of Consumer Reports to remain independent of any commercial interest, but felt it had protected that interest by stating in its commercials that Consumer Reports does not sponsor Regina products.

headline: AMERICAN RANCHER IN HONDURAS FUROR
abstract: Temistocles Ramirez de Arellano came to this remote corner of Honduras from his native Puerto Rico 23 years ago and has been working hard ever since to build out of jungle land and seacoast a $13 million meat and shrimp packing business. For the last six months he has been fighting to save his land and livelihood from an encroaching American- built military base.   ''There were ocelots and jaguars and black panthers in the jungle that this was then,'' Mr. Ramirez recalled as he showed a visitor a well-tended part of his 14,000 acres of ranch and coastal land. ''It took me 20 hours to walk through it, stopping overnight to sleep on the ground. The same trip, on the road here now, takes an hour by car.''

headline: SPREAD OUT METALS RISK
abstract: MOST investors in precious metals believe the bullion will outperform such ''paper investments'' as securities and money market instruments. Precious metals usually do so in inflationary or turbulent conditions.    In the first 10 months of 1983, however, the price of gold declined more than $100 an ounce; those who made money were those who sold the metal short.

headline: MGM/UA, Begelman Settled for $732,000 An automobile and $732,000 - that's what David Begelman got from the MGM/UA Entertainment Company to settle his contract after he was dismissed in 1982 as head of the United Artists unit.
abstract: The terms of the settlement were disclosed in a proxy statement for the annual meeting Jan. 14. The statement also reported settlements with two other former top executives, Joseph A. Fischer and Donald Sipes.

headline: Washington WatchRobert D. Hershey Jr. The Next Issue Is Natural Gas
abstract: -slurry pipelines last   week, Congress positioned itself to take action   of some kind on natural gas, the knottiest and most highly charged energy issue of all. Nobody knows, even as the heating season gets under way, whether there will be more deregulation or just the opposite, what some are calling reregulation.   The Senate will have before it this month a bill reported without recommendation - that is, without enthusiasm - by an 11-9 vote of the Energy Committee. The main provision is a decontrol device under which gas selling above the presumed free-market price of about $2.90 per thousand cubic feet would be ''ramped'' down over a 12- month period, while gas selling below $2.90 would be ''ramped'' up over 36 months. In the end there would be deregulation that includes ''old,'' or pre- 1977, gas.

headline: Thousands in UruguayProtest Military Rule
abstract: Thousands of Uruguayans celebrated Christmas with noisy protests and peaceful street demonstrations against 10 years of military rule, witnesses said today.   They said that in a now traditional form of protest thousands of people in this capital of 1.2 million banged saucepans at midnight Saturday night while hundreds of others took to the streets to press for a return to democracy.   Tension rose last week over growing press censorship and demands for an amnesty for the country's 900 political prisoners.

headline: SUPPORT PLAZA GETS BLUE CHIP TENANTS
abstract: When United States Aviation Underwriters Inc. agreed last week to lease 60,000 square feet at One Seaport Plaza, which is nearing completion at 199 Water Street, the deal represented more than just the renting of two more floors - at least to the developer of the building, Jack Resnick & Sons Inc.   ''We now have the three major industries of Wall Street - banking, investment and insurance - represented in the Seaport building,'' said Burton P. Resnick, president of the company. ''The leases signed recently in our building and in others shows the commitment to the neighborhood, not only as an important historic area but as a financial center.''   The building, which has a million square feet of space on 35 floors, is on the block bordered by John, Fulton and Front Streets and it flanks that part of the Seaport project containing Schermerhorn Row.

headline: Self-Employed Czechs to Get More Government Benefits
abstract: In a move apparently designed to encourage private enterprise, the Czechoslovak Parliament approved legislation today expanding social security benefits for self-employed people providing services.   In addition to family allowances already extended, the new law will grant private operators sickness and maternity benefits, free spa treatment, contributions to funeral expenses and reimbursement of lost income during military service.   Dressmaking, hairdressing, decorating and carpentry are among the services most frequently run privately.

headline: Kenilworth Investigation
abstract: Trustees of the Kenilworth Realty Liquidating Trust are sending a letter to its beneficiaries today in which they deny behaving contrary to their fiduciary obligations.   The trustees pledge in the letter to turn over any profits on the purchase of 415,000 units of the trust from the American Financial Corporation and its affiliates, but they deny any wrongdoing in connection with that purchase.

headline: Unit of IBH Given Credit
abstract: Hanomag, the Hanover-based subsidiary of the IBH construction group that sought court protection from its creditors on Nov. 4, has received a bridging credit the equivalent of between $760,000 and $1.1 million to keep production going at least through part of next week, according to a company spokesman.   The spokesman said the credit was provided by the group's principal bankers, Schr"oder M"unchmeyer, Hengst & Company, whose near-collapse precipitated the IBH crisis.   Hanomag's supervisory board adjourned a meeting last Wednesday without reaching any decision on the future of the company.

headline: SICK CHILDREN REFLECT BRAZIL'S DASHED HOPES
abstract: In the little Catholic hospital for children here, a 2-year-old girl in a printed blue dress sits in the center of her crib, motionless. Her brother, about 4, stands beside the crib. He has a large distended belly.    At the end of the ward, one boy, showing the first traces of a beard, is propped up on a cart, the lower half of his body shriveled and deformed.

headline: SOCIALIST GOVERNMENTS IN EUROPE FIND INTELLECTUALS' ARDOR FOR LEFT COOLING
abstract: In 1936, when France of the Popular Front and Republican Spain exemplified the ideals of democracy and Socialism, the names of their men of culture were Malraux, Picasso, Garcia Lorca, and Gide - artists, combatants, supporters of their struggling Governments.  Today, with Socialists in power everywhere in southern Europe, there are no more great symbolic intellectuals of the left, offering their transcendental reputations, both as artists and militants, to a political cause. Not only are the resounding names gone, but many intellectuals feel that caution, for the most part, has replaced passion and involvement as the theme dominating the relationship between intellectual life and the Socialist experience of the five countries.  A series of interviews and conversations in the three central countries of the group, France, Spain and Italy, often found intellectuals split between their own definitions of themselves as ''people of the left,'' and their notions of how their Governments should perform.   A Badge of Legitimacy   The Governments from Portugal to Greece spend more money on culture, talk more about it, and insist they care more deeply about culture than any of their non-Socialist predecessors. For each of them, the approval of intellectuals and the Government's involvement in cultural affairs seem to be unusually important elements in establishing their legitimacy, shaping public opinion, and sinking Socialist roots.

headline: Moroccan Debt Talks
abstract: A committee of 10 international banks made progress in talks here last Friday on a Moroccan request to reschedule $500 million of debt, financial sources said today.

headline: Fatah Factions Fight Battle Over an Office in Damascus
abstract: Rival factions of Al Fatah fought a 30-minute gun battle in central Damascus early today, and residents said several people were wounded.

headline: Rights Panel Scoffs At the Aquino Inquiry
abstract: A delegation of lawyers just back from the Philippines said today that the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos was guilty of continuing human rights violations and that the commission investigating the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was not credible.   Marvin E. Frankel, chairman of the group, the Lawyers Committee for International Human Rights, said that ''more than six weeks after Benigno Aquino's assassination, there is no serious effort to investigate this crime.''

headline: SOVIET COMMENT ON LEFTIST INROADS IN AMERICAS FOUND IN GRENADA
abstract: Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, the Soviet Chief of Staff, reportedly told the Grenadian Chief of Staff in Moscow last March that, while two decades ago ''there was only Cuba in Latin America, today there are Nicaragua, Grenada, and a serious battle is going on in El Salvador.''   The remark is contained in what appears to be a photocopy of a memorandum prepared on the letterhead of the Grenadian Embassy in Moscow. The document was made public by the State Department today.   It was one of 21 more documents that the department says were captured after the invasion of Grenada last month. An initial packet was made public Nov. 4. There are, according to department officials, thousands of documents still being processed.

headline: Correction
abstract: A chart last week accompanying an article about the American Telephone and Telegraph Company misstated the age of Morris Tanenbaum, the company's executive vice president. He is 55.

headline: U.S. SAID TO THINK IRAN HAD KEY ROLE IN BEIRUT ATTACKS
abstract: The Reagan Administration is now assuming that the Iranian Government played the key role in the bombing attacks on the American marines and French troops last Sunday and will retaliate once conclusive information is collected, Administration officials said today.   In another Middle East development, several officials said Donald H. Rumsfeld, who was Defense Secretary in the Ford Administration and is a friend of Secretary of State George P. Shultz, had been approached about becoming the next special envoy to the region.   Another name under consideration is that of Alfred L. Atherton Jr., the departing Ambassador to Egypt. It is possible, one official said, that they might divide the task, with Mr. Rumsfeld concentrating on Lebanon and Mr. Atherton on broader peace issues.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA WHITES APPROVE A LIMITED SHARING OF POWER
abstract: The South African Prime Minister, P. W. Botha, has won a mandate from the country's all-white electorate to go ahead with a program of limited and ambiguous political liberalization. The program will offer brown minorities - but not the black majority - a voice in national life alongside whites for the first time in almost 30 years.    Over two million whites, representing 76 percent of the 2.7 million eligible voters, passed judgment on the program in a referendum Wednesday. Of those voters, according to results announced here today, 1,360,223, almost 66 percent, approved proposals for a new constitution. The ''no'' vote was 691,577. Both the turnout and the outcome reversed the forecasts of pundits who had expected a narrower margin of success.

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: MCI Seeks Tests Of European Calls    WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) - The MCI Communications Corporation today asked for permission to begin tests of overseas, direct-dial phone circuits to Belgium and Greece in what would represent a challenge to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's monopoly over handling calls to and from Europe.   The request was contained in a filing with the Federal Communications Commission.

headline: Southern Union To Sell Utility
abstract: The Southern Union Company said it plans to sell its New Mexico utility operations for their book value, estimated at $225 million, at the end of last year to the Robert O. Anderson School of Management Foundation at the University of New Mexico.   Southern Union, which has been trying to sell the operations for nearly two years, said that it selected the foundation's offer from a number of bids for the properties and that a letter of intent was being drafted. It said the New Mexico utility operations account for 60 percent of its utility assets and $350 million of its total annual revenues of $1.10 billion, but have been only marginally profitable.

headline: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT REAGAN'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON THE ATTACK IN BEIRUT;
abstract: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT    Good afternoon. And given what has happened in Lebanon, I've put aside the remarks that I was prepared to give here today and I'd like to read you this statement.   Yesterday's acts of terrorism in Beirut, which killed so many young American and French servicemen, were a horrifying reminder of the type of enemy that we face in many critical areas of the world today - vicious, cowardly and ruthless.   Words can never convey the depth of compassion that we feel for those brave men and for their loved ones.   Many Americans are wondering why we must keep our forces in Lebanon.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  American Hoist & Derrick Co., St. Paul, has elected Robert H. Hassau chief executive officer, succeeding Robert P. Fox, who will continue as chairman.     *  Bankers Trust Co.  has appointed Jan R. Brumm senior commercial banking officer for Europe, based in London.

headline: No Headline
abstract: G.E. Account to Chiat   Chiat/Day, New York, has won a major corporate advertising assignment from the General Electric Company. Chiat is to create an all-print, business-to-business campaign on which G.E. will spend at least $5 million, according to the agency. The Chiat shop is already working on a campaign for the General Electric Information Services Company, which is based in Rockville, Md.

headline: Kodak-Mead Pact
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company said it agreed to acquire Mead Digital Systems, a producer of ink-jet printing equipment, from the Mead Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. In Dayton, Ohio, Mead said it is trying to sell technology developed by Mead Office Systems, its remaining ink-jet business, and is scaling down operations there as part of a plan to withdraw from ink-jet development and concentrate on the company's electronic publishing and forest products businesses.

headline: I.B.M.-NEW LIFE FOR A BLUE CHIP
abstract: PROFESSIONAL money managers are experiencing a touch of dej a vu these days, but it's not just because the 15-month-old bull market resembles one of those long, glorious rallies of the 1960's. Rather, I.B.M., their favorite growth stock, is back.    The stock of International Business Machines has nearly tripled in price since late 1981. And, this year alone, it has advanced 40 percent, compared with a 25 percent gain for the Dow Jones industrial average, of which I.B.M. is a significant part. On Oct. 10, the stock hit a record high of $134.25 a share. Not since the late 1960's and early 1970's has I.B.M. been on such a roll.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1983
abstract: The Economy The House opens debate today on a measure that could have a broad impact on telephone rates. The fate of the bill, opposed by A.T. &T. but supported by consumer groups, is considered too close to call. It would repeal an F.C.C. order requiring phone users to begin paying a new monthly fee for ''access'' to long-distance networks. (Page D1.) The S.E.C. is expected to issue a ban today on premature trading in stock of the streamlined A.T.& T. and the seven regional companies that it is spinning off. (D1.)  State and local governments may not regulate television programming distributed via satellite to private homes, the F.C.C. ruled. The decision involved a small but growing service that many communities regard as a threat to cable TV service. (D10.)

headline: CONSUMER PRICES RISE 0.4%
abstract: Despite stepped-up inflation in food prices, the Consumer Price Index rose only four-tenths of 1 percent last month, helped by a decline in gasoline and other energy costs, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.   Prices in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area also rose by just four-tenths of 1 percent. (Page D2.)    With the moderate October increase, inflation nationwide so far this year is running at a 3.9 percent annual rate. That matches the increase in all of 1982, a recession year that saw the slowest pace of price increases since the 3.4 percent registered in 1972, when price controls were in effect. In 1981, prices rose 8.9 percent; in 1980, they increased 12.4 percent.

headline: TWO AFRIKANERS ON TRIAL FOR TREASON
abstract: Two young Afrikaners, members of South Africa's dominant white group, went on trial here this week accused of supporting the most prominent of the outlawed, black nationalist movement opposed to the system of racial separation that has become synonymous with Afrikanerdom in general. They are charged with high treason, an offense that carries a possible death sentence.    The hearings in the Rand Supreme Court have provided a rare glimpse into the world of South Africa's secret police and its operations against foes of apartheid.    Moreover, the disclosures at the trial seemed designed to create suspicion and mistrust among South African dissidents because they have highlighted the authorities' ability to undermine the nationalist movement by planting spies and informers in its ranks.

headline: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Trust Concern Looks Abroad
abstract: T HE Bessemer Trust Company, which manages $3.3 billion for wealthy individuals and   60 pension funds and foundations, is cutting back its holdings of United States equities while increasing commitments in foreign stocks.   ''We are less certain today of the sure opportunities of making money for our clients in the United States stock market, so we are also raising some cash reserves,'' said John R. Whitmore, president and chief executive officer. As a result, slightly less than half of all assets under management will remain in a core portfolio of American stocks, while the allocation to overseas issues will almost double, reaching 15 percent of total assets.   ''There are two key reasons for this decision,'' Mr. Whitmore said. ''First, we believe that European economies and markets that have lagged behind the United States, along with those in the Pacific Basin, now look attractive. Second, we expect foreign currencies to improve against the dollar as the economies abroad pick up.''

headline: ARAFAT PLEDGES HE'LL TRY TO AVERT A 'BLOOD BATH' IN LEBANESE CITY
abstract: The Mayor of Tripoli and other local leaders, fearful that fighting between Palestinian factions will sweep into their city, met today with Yasir Arafat, who promised he would do ''everything in my power to avert a blood bath.''    The police said the shelling here today was the lightest since dawn Thursday, when the attack on positions held by supporters of Mr. Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, began.    The city officials formed a committee to try to negotiate a cease-fire and sent a message to Hafez al-Assad, the President of Syria, urging him to help end the fighting. Mr. Arafat has been contending that without strong support from Syria it would have been impossible for rebel Palestinians to begin their attack against his last remaining strongholds just north of here.   Meeting With Rebel Chief Sought    The officials said they hoped to have a similar meeting with Col. Saeed Musa, the leader of the rebel group opposing Mr. Arafat.   (In Washington, Reagan Administration officials said the crisis in the P.L.O. could provide an opportunity for renewing efforts to bring King Hussein of Jordan and West Bank Palestinians into negotiations with Israel. Page A17.)

headline: 3D-QUARTER EARNINGS UP SHARPLY
abstract: Earnings of the nation's leading corporations in the third quarter appear, at first glance, to have exceeded the expectations of even the most optimistic shareholder.    But many analysts express disappointment that the stock market has not responded to the gains with the same vigor that earnings have responded to the economic recovery.   A compilation of 284 industrial companies shows that, by and large, performances were strong in the three months ended Sept. 30, with dozens of companies doubling and tripling their net incomes and many others turning red ink into black. (Details of the reports appear on page D13.)

headline: Storer-Loews
abstract: The Loews Corporation has acquired a 4.8 percent interest in Storer Communications Inc. and has warrants to buy more stock that would increase its stake to 5.1 percent, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Storer closed unchanged today, at $34.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Waste Disposal Bonds In 2 Florida Offerings
abstract: Two separate bond issues to finance waste disposal facilities in Florida are being offered this week. One is from Pinellas County, the other from Palm Beach County.

headline: Swiss Wholesale Prices
abstract: The Swiss wholesale price index rose four-tenths of 1 percent in September after a rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Department for Industry, Trade and Labor said today. The index, with a 1963 base of 100, stood at 171.5 at the end of September, compared with 170.8 in the previous month. The increase from the period last year was eight-tenths of 1 percent.

headline: Spanish Advertising Merging With Robles
abstract: Spanish Advertising and Marketing Services is becoming independent once again and, since it is also merging with Frank Robles Communications, will be known as Robles Rodriguez/Spanish American Marketing Systems.

headline: Jury Fines Northwest Industries CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) - A Federal jury today found Northwest Industries guilty of violating Federal securities law and awarded $18.1 million to current and former stockholders of the company.
abstract: The jury determined that Northwest had violated securities law by withholding word that it planned to sell its beverage division while it was buying back stock from shareholders.   In a class action suit filed in 1981, shareholders charged that shares would have increased in value if they had known of Northwest's plans.

headline: COPING WITH NEW COMPUTERS
abstract: Marlene Lassberg, an account executive for Merrill Lynch in Dallas, keeps two computers on her desk: her old Radio Shack machine and her new I.B.M. She still cannot make the new machine do everything the old one did.   Hod Caulkins, an investment officer in White Plains, has been translating computer programs since July so that they can run on his new computer, also an I.B.M. ''Its a royal pain in the neck,'' he complains.    Mrs. Lassberg and Mr. Caulkins are both struggling with perhaps the single most important change in personal computers this year: the rapid emergence of the International Business Machines Personal Computer as an industry standard.   While few doubt that over the long run ''I.B.M. compatibility'' will make it much easier to use personal computers, hundreds of companies and thousands of office workers are discovering that abandoning their first desktop computers - either voluntarily or because of a company mandate - can be a technical nightmare.    Different Languages Used    The chief problem is that nearly every brand of personal computer sold before 1982 used a different language. While the Apples, Commodores and Radio Shacks that seeped into offices across the country increased productivity, they also stored letters and notes, statistics and financial statements in their own unique code. That meant information stored on a memory disk in Apple code could not be used in a Commodore, which had a code of its own.

headline: Denmark Prices Up
abstract: Consumer prices in Denmark rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in November from October and 5.4 percent from November 1982, the Government's Bureau of Statistics said. It was the second consecutive month that consumer prices rose on an annual basis by less than 6 percent.

headline: MARCOS OPPOSES SUCCESSION ACT
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos has rejected moves in Parliament to restore the office of vice president, saying the country has more serious problems than establishing a line of succession.   ''We are too deeply concerned with too many problems to be changing the concept of government right now,'' Mr. Marcos said in an interview shown on Government television Sunday.   He faces political and economic unrest after the assassination in August of his chief opponent, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., a former senator.

headline: ACCORD REPORTED IN P.L.O. FIGHTING BUT DOUBTS ARISE
abstract: The Foreign Ministers of Syria and Saudi Arabia announced today that rival Palestinian factions had agreed to stop fighting here and withdraw from the area within two weeks. But the Palestinians later cast doubt on whether the agreement would be put into effect.   At a news conference here, Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said the forces opposing him had sent in reinforcements overnight and that ''we expect tomorrow they will try another big attempt.'' Saturday is the day that rebels in the P.L.O. have threatened to begin fighting Mr. Arafat in the streets of Tripoli.   In Damascus, the Syrian capital, Col. Abu Khaled al-Omlah, the chief of staff of the rebels, indicated that his faction was unwilling to comply with a provision of the agreement that requires the withdrawal of all Palestinian guerrillas from Tripoli and its environs.   'We Will Never Leave'    ''We will never leave these camps,'' Colonel Omlah said of the Beddawi and Nahr al Bared refugee settlements near Tripoli. ''They are our camps. We are the only ones who can insure the protection of our people in these camps.'' At his news conference, Mr. Arafat seemed not to have seen the full text of the agreement, which was announced in Damascus, and possibly had not given his final endorsement.

headline: Mechanical Failures Blamed In 2 Jet Crashes Off Lebanon
abstract: Two F-14 Tomcat fighters crashed into the Mediterranean in separate incidents last week because of mechanical failures, the Navy said today.   Reports over the weekend said both planes had come under antiaircraft fire from Lebanon, but Navy spokesmen denied this and said the crashes occurred near the planes' ship, the Kennedy, during routine flight operations.

headline: IRAN REPORTS TWO RAIDS BY REBELS IN BAGHDAD, BUT IRAQ ISSUES DENIAL
abstract: Iran's official press agency said Iraqi ''revolutionaries'' had detonated an explosives-laden truck at the headquarters of Iraq's intelligence services in Baghdad, killing more than 100 Iraqi officials. It added that a second bombing at an Iraqi military headquarters had killed ''tens'' of military personnel.   Iraq denied the report. The official Iraqi press agency, INA, quoted an Iraqi spokesman as having said ''such events did not take place in Baghad today.''

headline: FILIPINO MOSLEM REVOLT SEEMS TO EBB
abstract: Moslem separatist guerrillas still lurk in the wilderness outside cities like Zamboanga, occasionally kidnapping travelers for ransom and committing other acts of terrorism. But their war for independence on Mindanao and other southern Philippine islands with large Islamic populations, once a major security threat, seems to have declined drastically in intensity.    The Moslem uprising, and another of longer standing led by Communists, has added to the political problems faced by President Ferdinand E. Marcos as a result of widespread opposition to his stern policies, reinforced by martial law from 1972 to 1981. These intensified after the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the opposition leader, last month.

headline: Rebels in Peru Launch Bomb Attacks in Lima
abstract: Leftist guerrillas detonated more than a dozen bombs in Lima tonight, killing at least 2 people and wounding more than 20 in attacks on an office of the ruling Popular Action Party, a police station and a bank, officials reported.   Utility poles also were blasted, causing sporadic blackouts in the capital.

headline: ARGENTINA ASKS DELAY ON ITS DEBT
abstract: Argentina's newly elected Government, seeking breathing space to repay the developing world's third-largest foreign debt, asked its foreign creditors today if it could defer for six months payment of the more than $12 billion that is due in that period.   The Government of President Raul Alfonsin, which inherited a $40 billion foreign debt when it took over five days ago, asked a steering committee that represents more than 300 international banks to defer until June 30 the refinancing of nearly $9 billion in debt that was due today.   In meetings with bank representatives here and in a telex to the 12- member steering committee in New York, Economics Minister Bernardo Grinspun also asked to put off the payment of nearly $3.5 billion in both overdue interest and new interest that will be due by then.    Reactions Mixed    The reactions of representatives of the steering committee of American, European and Japanese banks was mixed. They said in interviews that the committee would likely recommend that Argentina's creditors put off the refinancing that was due today but not put off all the interest payments.  ''The new Government is being responsible and realistic,'' said one of the representatives. ''It's clear they cannot pay all the interest, but we can't waive it all for six months.''

headline: Market PlacePamela G. Hollie Klein's Bid for Puritan
abstract: FOLLOWING the death last summer of Carl Rosen, the chairman of the Puritan Fashions Corporation, Puritan's stock on the New York Stock Exchange rose to a high of 26 7/8 on rumors of a takeover. Last Friday it reached a low of 12 1/4, after the company reported a 60 percent drop in third-quarter earnings.    This week a takeover offer came from Calvin Klein, the fashion designer, and the stock climbed to 16 7/8. Mr. Klein offered $16.50 a share for Puritan, a maker of Calvin Klein jeans, which amounted to a premium of about 35 percent on the market price the day of the offer, and was 65 percent over the book value of the shares.   Several factors have made Puritan particularly susceptible to these wide stock swings. It is still a family-run company, with Mr. Rosen's 27-year- old son, Andrew, as president; Puritan depends on one customer, and that customer, Calvin Klein, is operating in a weak jeans market and an even weaker designer jeans segment.

headline: INVASION OF GRENADA WINS SOME ALLIED SUPPORTERS
abstract: After strong initial disapproval by United States allies, several politicians and commentators in Western Europe are saying they now understand the invasion of Grenada better and in some cases approve of it.    The most forthright statements have come from conservative and moderate politicians in France. Le Monde, which is widely regarded as the country's most influential newspaper, said today in an editorial that the events in Grenada were ''a failure for Cuba.'' The Christian Democratic-led Government in West Germany has also softened its earlier criticism a degree.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1983    Companies A.T.& T. stockholders will get slightly higher dividends as a result of the breakup of the giant company, according to documents filed with the S.E.C. The anticipated annual dividends for the eight companies together are $5.46 a share, compared with the $5.40 that A.T.& T. now pays. The bulky filing consisted of more than 20,000 pages in 58 documents weighing a half-ton. (Page A1.)  PSA, a low-cost California-based airline, has ordered 20 new short-haul jets from British Aerospace for $300 million. The company said the plane will strengthen its position in the highly competitive West Coast market. Its engines are considered among the quietest and most fuel-efficient on commercial airliners. (D1.)

headline: New Ahmanson Chief
abstract: H. F. Ahmanson & Company said today that William H. Ahmanson had asked to be relieved of his post as chief executive officer but agreed to remain chairman. Ahmanson said its board had elected Richard H. Deihl president and chief executive. Mr. Deihl is now president and chief executive of Home Savings of America, the main unit of Ahmanson, a financial holding company.

headline: Australian Resigns After Agents' Hotel Raid
abstract: A raid on a hotel by men wearing clown masks may have toppled the head of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service.

headline: Caterpillar Patent
abstract: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said that a Federal appellate court had upheld a lower court ruling that Berco S.p.A., an Italian undercarriage manufacturer, infringed on Caterpillar's United States patent involving sealed and lubricated track. Caterpillar sued Berco and the Wortham Machinery Company, Berco's dealer in Cheyenne, Wyo., in 1980. The suit charged that Berco was making and selling crawler undercarriages with a specially designed seal that is a critical component of Caterpillar's sealed and lubricated track.

headline: Bonn to Seek Bank Curbs
abstract: The West German Government, prodded by the near collapse earlier this month of one of the nation's largest private banks, said today it will seek to enact by January changes in banking law to consolidate foreign affiliates in banks' balance sheets.

headline: ATHENS AREA TRYING ANEW ON LAND USE
abstract: ''Now I can sleep easily at night because my home is legalized,'' said Constantine Carlosze ropoulos, the owner of a three-room wooden house in suburban Loutsa, 15 miles to the north.    It took Mr. Carloszeropoulos seven years to build his house. Since he had no building permit, he worked on it only in the evenings to escape inspection by officials. Now he has registered the house with the authorities and paid a legalization fee of 10,000 drachmas, a little more than $100.

headline: U.S. STEEL MAY KEEP PLANT OPEN
abstract: After months of reports that the United States Steel Corporation was going to shut its South Works in Chicago, company officials now say they will probably build a new rail mill there and keep the plant open.   William E. Lewellen, U.S. Steel's senior vice president for finance, said today that, because of cooperation from the union and municipal, state and Federal officials, the company would probably continue operating the plant.   ''We haven't decided we will keep it open, but we probably will,'' Mr. Lewellen said in an interview. Mr. Lewellen and Thomas C. Graham, vice chairman in charge of steel and related resources for the company, which is based in Pittsburgh, are scheduled to make an announcement about the mill in a press conference in Chicago on Thursday.

headline: First Boston Sells Commercial Paper
abstract: First Boston Inc., the holding company for the First Boston Corporation, an investment banking firm, said it has begun selling commercial paper. Proceeds will be used as a source of short-term financing.   The firm said it will issue up to $400 million of paper, which has been assigned the highest P-1 rating by Moody's Investors Service and A-1 by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

headline: Ally & Gargano Is Still on a Roll
abstract: Continuing its hot streak, Ally & Gargano, on the verge of going public, yesterday was named the agency for the SFN Electronic Publishing Company, a recently formed subsidiary of the SFN Companies of Glenview, Ill. It is the third piece of new business in November for the agency.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: Guam Bonds Sell Briskly A $450 million bond sale by   the Guam Economic Development Authority has been substantially sold with $150 million   of 10 1/8 percent bonds due in 20-   years and $300 million of 10 1/4   percent bonds due in 30 years,   according to underwriters led   by Kidder, Peabody & Company.  The bonds, which are rated   triple A by major rating agencies, are backed by an escrow   account of Treasury securities.

headline: MIDEAST CONFERENCE IN ATLANTA DRAWS ARAB AND U.S. OFFICIALS
abstract: For Jimmy Carter's new center for policy studies at Emory University, the four-day conference on the Middle East this week marks an auspicious beginning.   Not only did Mr. Carter persuade another former President, Gerald R. Ford, to help him chair his inaugural conference, but he has also drawn an impressive roster of participants to join the discussions.   There are high-ranking officials from the Governments of Syria, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Egypt, as well as a roster of former United States officials that reads like a Who's Who in foreign affairs.   ''It's quite a reunion,'' said Cyrus R. Vance, Mr. Carter's Secretary of State, as he sat in the audience Sunday alongside Philip C. Habib, who until last spring served as President Reagan's special envoy to the Middle East, and Joseph J. Sisco, a diplomat who worked under several Presidents.

headline: STUDY FINDS INCREASE IN WORLD PRESS CONTROLS
abstract: Government control of the press has increased significantly in most areas of the world in the past year, according to a new study presented to an international conference of representatives of independent news outlets that is taking place here this weekend.    The study, drawn up by the London- based International Press Institute, an organization representing more than 2,000 newspapers and news organizations around the world, says journalists and broadcasters face reduced freedom and increased government harassment in Latin America, Asia, Africa and Eastern Europe.   ''There can be no doubt that in most parts of the world, press freedom became significantly more limited over the last year,'' the institute's president, Max L. Snijders, a Dutch editor, told the meeting, which has brought together nearly 90 editors and publishers from 25 countries.

headline: 4TH REACTOR IS DOWN IN CANADA TORONTO, Oct. 31 (UPI) - The fourth nuclear reactor in two weeks was shut down in Canada today after a leak that released radioactive water into Lake Ontario, officials of Ontario Hydro said.
abstract: Officials said the No. 5 unit at the Pickering station near Toronto tripped off without explanation as technicians searched for the source of the leak in the 2,500 heat exchange coils that remove heat from the reactor.   It was the fourth nuclear reactor incident in two weeks, following problems with reactors at the Bruce and Douglas Point stations on Lake Huron and at a small demonstration plant at Rolphton, Ont.

headline: GREEK CYPRIOTS ARE WORRIED BUT EXPECT NO DRASTIC STEPS
abstract: Daily life has changed little for Greek Cypriots on this Mediterranean island since Tuesday's declaration of independence by the Turkish Cypriot minority.    For example, there has been no move to cut the water, electricity or sewage lines between the Greek Cypriots and the breakaway Turkish Cypriots in the north. People say they generally do not expect such drastic steps because both sides would be hurt.

headline: Japan Takes Lead in Tools
abstract: Japan took over world leadership from the United States last year in the $22 billion machine tool industry - a standard for measuring a country's wealth, according to a United States Government report issued today.   The United States International Trade Commission said the Japanese have some better and more efficiently made products, improved service, quicker delivery and lower prices.

headline: 2-YEAR NOTES TO BE SOLD THIS WEEK
abstract: The first sale of Treasury notes in three weeks is scheduled for Wednesday, when $8 billion of new two-year notes are to be auctioned.    Elsewhere in the capital markets, analysts expect high interest rates to continue to deter corporate issuers but not state and local governments, which have scheduled about $1.2 billion of new long-term issues this week.   While the sale of two-year notes will raise $3.2 billion of cash for the Treasury, the Monday auction of three- and six-month bills will pay off $450 million of Treasury debt, since only $12 billion of bills are to be sold while $12.45 billion will mature.

headline: Bangladesh Leader Promises 1984 Elections
abstract: Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, the military leader of Bangladesh, said today that he would call elections in the Asian nation next year.

headline: Helioscience Deal By Reuters
abstract: Helioscience General, a joint venture of Helioscience Inc. and General Ener-Tech Inc., said it had recieved a 30-year, $900 million contract to provide electricity to the Navy from geothermal sources. Under the agreement, Helioscience General will construct a 75-megawatt geothermal power plant at the Navy's air weapons training complex at Fallon, Nev., at a cost of more than $100 million.

headline: Argentina in Plea on Debt BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 14 (Reuters) - Argentina has asked its steering committee of foreign banks to extend a Dec. 15 deadline for refinancing $9 billion worth of public sector external debt, the Economy Minister, Bernardo Grinspun, said today. Mr. Grinspun told reporters after his first meeting with representatives of the steering committee in Buenos Aires that the banks would reply by Thursday.
abstract: He did not say how long a period he had sought to complete the refinancing.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Venture Capital Partner Is Doing Fine, Thanks     Benjamin M. Rosen ventured into the venture capital business two years ago and has been making a success of it since.   Mr. Rosen, 50, was a securities analyst and, later, the publisher of a newsletter before he teamed up with L. J. Sevin, the founder of Mostek, a semiconductor company, to form Sevin Rosen Partners.   The fund was the lead investor in a computer software company that just went public, the Lotus Development Corporation, and in Compaq Computer, which plans to go public.

headline: ARGENTINA MOVES TO CLEAR BARRIER TO TALKS ON LOANS
abstract: A federal appeals court today removed a major obstacle to the resumption of the international negotiations needed to refinance Argentina's huge foreign debt and to keep fresh loans flowing into the country.   The court stripped a local judge of jurisdiction over a case that had effectively blocked the signing of refinancing agreements for the $40 billion debt. Without those agreements, foreign banks have been unwilling for the past week to pay out new loans needed by Argentina to keep up with interest payments. More than $500 million in loans have been held up.

headline: PATENTS; NATIONS TO SHARE THEIR DATA
abstract: -day conference this week, the heads of patent offices in Europe, Japan and the United States signed an agreement to cooperate in research and operations.  Under the agreement, there will be exchanges of technical personnel, documents, microfilm and electronic data, as well as cooperation in automating offices, classifying and indexing documents and sharing information on patent grants.

headline: USERS, PROVIDERS FACE ADJUSTMENTS
abstract: Q. What effect will the breakup    of A.T.& T. have on the telecommunications business?     A. The breakup should stimulate a new burst of competition in all phases of the telecommunications business and in such closely related businesses as computers. The breakup is, after all, the settlement of a Federal suit charging A.T.& T. with monopolizing the telephone business.    Q. Why will the agreement promote competition, and in which   businesses?     A. The Justice Department charged A.T.& T. with using its control of local telephone service to monopolize three segments of the telecommunications business.

headline: T.I. Introduces Portable Model
abstract: In a move analysts said indicated that Texas Instruments plans to remain in the higher-priced end of the personal computer market, the company introduced a portable version of its Professional Computer. Like the current Professional Computer, the new portable is compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's Personal Computer, which is emerging as an industry standard. T.I.'s portable, which comes with a black-and-white display screen and 64,000 characters of internal memory, is the first new computer entry by the Dallas-based company since it announced last month that it was discontinuing production of its 99/4A computer and withdrawing from the low end of the market.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  Del Monte Corp., San Francisco, has named R. Edward Glover vice president and regional director in charge of European and African operations for Del Monte International Inc.     *  California Federal Savings, Los Angeles, has elected George P. Rutland president and chief executive officer.     *  Kidder Peabody & Co.  announced that C. M. Butler 3d, recently retired chairman of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, is joining the company as a vice president in the natural gas division.

headline: CommoditiesH. J. Maidenberg Taxing Futures Options
abstract: EVER since trading in options based on futures contracts resumed on Oct. 1, 1982, after a hiatus of 40 years, investors, their accountants and the Internal Revenue Service have faced an unusual problem: how should the profits on these options be treated?   Confusion has reigned, with the I.R.S. offering no guidelines. For its part, the options and futures industry has strongly urged that profits on options be treated the same way as gains on futures have been since June 1981 - 60 percent as long term and 40 percent as short term, which works out to a maximum tax bite of 32 percent. Unlike the securities markets, no tax holding periods are involved in futures trading.

headline: Angolan Rebels Report Capture of 17 Europeans
abstract: Pro- Western rebels in Angola said today that they captured 5 British and 12 Portuguese citizens in attacks on Government positions in eastern Angola on Sunday.   A communique from the rebel group, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, said the 17 had been seized in raids on Kazombo and Kavungu and on a bridge over the Zambezi River in the Moxico Province.

headline: Toys 'R' Us
abstract: Toys ''R'' Us Inc. said it expects net income in the third quarter to exceed the $4.7 million, or 8 cents a share, earned in 1982's third period. Charles Lazarus, chairman of the company, said that while sales of video games and home computers continue strong this year, they represented 13 percent of total volume for the first 10 weeks of the third quarter, ending Oct. 31, compared with 19 percent of the volume a year before.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM SOVIET-BLOC PACTS WITH GRENADA
abstract: Following are excerpts from the documents found in Grenada by American forces and made public by the State Department on Friday:        Military Cooperation Agreement Between Grenada and Cuba.     (Undated)   ''SECRET''    Protocol of the Military Collalboration Between the Government of the Republic of Cuba and    the People's Revolutionary Government of Grenada    The Government of the Republic of Cuba and People's Revolutionary Government of Grenada, in full exercise of their sovereign right as free and independent States, based on the fraternal relations existing between both countries with the aim of making a contribution to the strengthening of the defensive capacity of Grenada, have agreed upon the following:     ARTICLE I    The Government of the Republic of Cuba in agreement with the request formulated by the People's Revolutionary Government of Grenada, will maintain Cuban Military specialists in that country in quantities and specialists established in Annex No. 1 of this document. (Protocol).

headline: O'NEILL CONSIDERS BACKING A CHANGE IN MARINE MISSION
abstract: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., is reconsidering his support for the 18-month limit that Congress set for the Marine deployment in Beirut, an aide said today.    The reassessment by Mr. O'Neill, a Massachusetts Democrat, coupled with remarks earlier this week by the House minority leader, Robert H. Michel, an Illinois Republican, appeared to reflect a shift in Congressional sentiment away from Reagan Administration policy in Lebanon.
