Other Democratic and Republican legislative leaders, including several who have supported the policy in Lebanon, suggested today that Congress would move to force a change in the Marine mission in Beirut if President Reagan does not do so by the end of January.   6-Month Limit 'Much Wiser'    While declining to comment in person, Mr. O'Neill authorized the aide to say, ''It would be fair to say the Speaker now thinks a six-month limit would be much wiser.''

headline: Advertising; D'Arcy's Electricity Account
abstract: In shopping malls in 20 markets scattered about the country, selected consumers these days are being asked about the communications quality and convincing nature of four rough commercials that D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, New York, has prepared for the Edison Electric Institute, a trade group of 200 investor- owned electric utilities.   When the agency has collected about 900 interviews, it will report to the institute's marketing task force, headed by John J. Russell, a vice president of Long Island Lighting. The task force has already decided on a logotype: a finger on a light switch with the statement, ''It's the power of choice.''

headline: REAGAN PREDICTS ROLE TILL BEIRUT STANDS OR FALLS
abstract: News session transcript, Page B12.           WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 - President Reagan said today that the United States would not withdraw its marines from Beirut until the Government of Lebanon took control of its territory or there was ''such a collapse of order'' that no peaceful resolution of the Lebanese conflict was possible.   At a news conference, Mr. Reagan defended recent United States naval bombardment and air strikes against Syrian positions outside Beirut. He said that ''we want no conflict with Syria'' and that the retaliation had been limited to ''those who have actually done the attacking'' on United States forces.

headline: '83 Eurobonds: $44.2 Billion
abstract: Eurobond issues in 1983   totaled $44.2 billion, up 1.3 percent from last year, although   the number of issues dropped to   481, from 544, Kredietbank S.A.   said in a study issued today. The dollar accounted for 292   issues, totaling $35.2 billion,   and represented 79.5 percent of   the overall volume, down from   82.1 percent in 1982. Next came the West German   mark, with 79 issues totaling  $4.1 billion, or 9.3 percent of the   total (9.9 percent in 1982); the   European Currency Unity, 44   issues, $1.7 billion and 3.9 percent (1.6 percent); sterling, 23   issues, $1.6 billion and 3.5 percent (1.8 percent); the Canadian dollar, 26 issues, $1.1 billion and 2.4 percent (3 percent),   and the yen, 4 issues, $295.9   million and seven-tenths of 1   percent (1.1 percent).

headline: MARCOS CRITICIZES BUSINESS LEADERS
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos reacted angrily today to a public appeal from business and industrial leaders for political changes to restore what they described as domestic and international confidence in the Philippine economy.    He accused them of contributing to economic ills through tax evasion, hoarding of foreign exchange, overpricing, smuggling, dealing in stolen goods and other illegal practices.   Mr. Marcos spoke at a televised meeting of 350 business leaders at the Presidential Palace after they had handed him a report that said there should be free elections and an unfettered press.   The report also called for ''an independent and honest judiciary, the restoration of public constitutional rights,'' relief from ''pervasive militarism'' and clear legal provisions for a successor to the President.

headline: Prince Sees 'Slim Chance' Of Cambodia Accord
abstract: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the leader of the anti-Vietnamese Cambodian coalition, said today that there was a ''slim chance'' of working out a political solution to the conflict in Cambodia.   ''We may one day have the agreement of Vietnam and the Soviet Union to have a conference, an international conference,'' Prince Sihanouk said, referring to a proposal that all sides in the Cambodian war meet to work out a political accord.   The General Assembly is preparing to consider a resolution sponsored by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations that calls for a withdrawal of Vietnamese forces from Cambodia.

headline: Prudential Eurobonds Linked to Phone Stocks
abstract: The Prudential Funding Corporation, a subsidiary of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, is selling $150 million of 10 1/8 percent Eurobonds, with warrants attached to buy the stock of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the seven new regional telephone companies to be spun off Jan. 1.   The lead underwriter for the offering, which is not available to United States investors, is Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Wakefern Hires Grey    The Wakefern Food Corporation, which is a cooperative that purchases, warehouses and ships products for 200 Shoprite supermarkets owned by 30 companies in this area, is now moving into communications as well and has retained Grey Advertising and its Grey & Davis public relations subsidiary for a corporate advertising and public relations effort. The talk is of a budget in ''the millions.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: The U.N. Today Oct. 17, 1983 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Political and Security Committee - 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD
abstract: Soviet Denies Directing Microwaves at Embassy    MOSCOW, Nov. 12 (Reuters) - The Foreign Ministry today denied American charges that the United States Embassy here had been bombarded with microwaves.

headline: BUYING FOR LESS
abstract: To the Business Editor:      The article contained a very common error concerning retailers' methods of pricing and computing gross profits. This is due, I believe, to the lack of standardized terms among retailers and confusion between ''markup on cost'' and ''markup on selling price.''   The article states that ''. . . department stores generally operate at a 50 percent markup over wholesale prices.'' This is not true. Department stores usually try to operate at a 100 percent markup over wholesale prices. This gives them a 50 percent gross profit on sales. It also said that ''. . . traditional stores . . . have started promoting merchandise at reduced prices - with markdowns sometimes as high as 50 percent.'' A 50 percent markup on cost followed by a 50 percent markdown on selling price? Who could afford that for very long or at all?

headline: SOVIET AIDE IMPLIES SAKHAROV IS MENTALLY ILL
abstract: A prominent Soviet official implied at a news conference today that Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and human rights campaigner, was mentally disturbed.   The official, Vitaly P. Ruben, who is chairman of one of the two houses of the Supreme Soviet, the nominal Parliament, called Dr. Sakharov ''a talented but sick man'' and said an article the physicist published in the West earlier this year had invited an American nuclear strike on the Soviet Union.   ''A sane person would not say such things,'' Mr. Ruben said, tapping his head with his forefinger in a gesture suggesting mental trouble.

headline: Boys Club Campaign Completed by SSC&B
abstract: SSC&B has completed a volunteer effort for the Boys Clubs of America that resulted in a multi-media advertising campaign with the theme, ''The club that beats the streets.''   In that line, ''streets'' is a metaphor for all the problems that beset today's underprivileged youth, Walter Weis, senior vice president of the agency, explained last week.

headline: CHILDREN OF MIXED ANCESTRY: ORPHANS OF ARARTHEID
abstract: Eileen Gyani is a 10-year-old girl with bushy hair and a chocolate skin. The characteristics have been her downfall.    She and her brother Ian used to go to a school in the sprawling black satellite township of Soweto, but the other children taunted her because she was not as black as they. She was, they said, a ''colored'' - the word from South Africa's catalogue of racial classification that denotes people of mixed racial descent.

headline: Grey Reports Gains In Britain and U.S.
abstract: Grey Advertising made news yesterday on two counts, by acquiring more business in this country and by acquiring an agency in Britain.   The new business is from an existing client, the 3M Company, which is now assigning the Third Avenue giant a line of skin care products with the Buf brand name.

headline: Foes of Marcos Schedule Parley to Plan Strategy
abstract: A national convention of the many opposition political parties and citizens' groups throughout the country has been scheduled here next month to work out a coordinated strategy against President Ferdinand E. Marcos.   Planning for the gathering is being directed by Agapito Aquino, the younger brother of the assassinated opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. He said d the convention would be held Jan. 7 and 8 at a university here.

headline: FOUR MARINES WOUNDED BY A CAR BOMB IN BEIRUT
abstract: Four United States marines were slightly wounded today by the explosion of a car bomb as a convoy of four American military vehicles moved along a road near Palestinian refugee camps in Beirut's southern suburbs.   The explosion came on a day of increased violence here in violation of a cease-fire agreed to on Sept. 26. The police said two Lebanese soldiers and six civilians were killed and 27 people were wounded as Lebanese Army troops exchanged artillery and rocket fire through much of the day with Druse militiamen in the Suk al Gharb area, nine miles southeast of the center of this capital, and with Shiite Moslem gunmen in shantytowns just south of the city.

headline: British Pensions Get Rampac Stake
abstract: Two pension plans of the National Coal Board of Britain have purchased a 10.4 percent interest in Rampac, a California real estate investment trust, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.   The pension plans bought a total of 333,800 shares as an investment, the document said.

headline: Train Derailment in Pakistan Halts All North-South Traffic
abstract: All rail traffic between northern and southern Pakistan was halted for several hours after a 10-car freight train derailed en route to the capital, the police said today.

headline: BOMB KILLS 19, INCLUDING 6 KEY KOREANS
abstract: At least 19 people, including two leading advisers to President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea and four of his Cabinet ministers, were killed Sunday when a bomb exploded as they prepared for a wreath-laying ceremony in Rangoon, Burma. Forty-seven people were wounded, many seriously.    President Chun, who was on an official visit to Burma, escaped harm because his car was delayed in traffic. He arrived five minutes late at the site of the ceremony.    By this morning no group had taken responsibility for the bombing. But President Chun blamed North Korea after returning to Seoul early this morning, cutting short what was to have been an 18-day trip to six Asian and Pacific countries. He arrived in Rangoon from Seoul on Saturday.

headline: 2-MONTH U.S. STAY ON GRENADA SEEN
abstract: The head of the first Congressional delegation to visit Grenada since the American invasion said today that it was possible that American troops might be needed on the Caribbean island ''into the next year.''   Earlier in the day, the leader of the 14-member delegation, Representative Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, had said that all United States troops were expected to leave ''within weeks.''   Mr. Foley made his comment about the longer stay after meeting Grenadian and other Caribbean officials who urged that the United States keep troops here over the next few months while Grenada forms a constitutional government and plans national elections.   Two Republican members of the delegation, William S. Broomfield of Michigan and Dick Cheney of Wyoming, echoed Mr. Foley's comments that it might be necessary for United States forces to stay on longer than expected. ''I think we'll have a contingent force at least for a few months,'' Mr. Cheney said.

headline: G.S.A. Chief Shifting Jobs
abstract: Gerald Carmen, chief of the General Services Administration, is leaving his position and is likely to be named the United States delegate to the United Nations office in Geneva, a White House official said today. Mr. Carmen, 53 years old, played a key role in President Reagan's 1980 Presidential campaign victory in New Hampshire. The G.S.A. is the Federal agency that provides Government supplies and operates Federal buildings.

headline: RUMANIAN APPEALS FOR HALT ON MISSILES
abstract: President Nicolae Ceausescu, saying that he fears ''nuclear destruction,'' has reiterated a call to both the United States and the Soviet Union to stop deploying nuclear missiles and to resume arms control negotiations.    ''The deployment of the new missiles and development of the ones in place will not bring extra security to either side, least of all to European countries,'' the Rumanian leader said in an interview on Thursday. ''On the contrary, they will increase insecurity and the nuclear war threat.''   Instead, he called on both sides to agree on a balance of forces at the lowest possible level.

headline: HOPE ON THIRD-WORLD DEBT
abstract: Developing countries now have a reasonable chance of borrowing from private banks the $20 billion in new loans they need this year to pay for their imports and sustain world economic recovery, according to a report by the Bank for International Settlements on international bank lending during the second quarter.    The institution, which helps regulate the international banking market in behalf of the central banks of many major industrial countries, thus took a cautiously optimistic view of the international debt crisis - a significant turnabout from its assessment of a few months ago. While this somewhat brighter outlook is generally shared by American bankers, many in Europe remain deeply skeptical that the third world's liquidity needs will be met.   A major underlying question, however, is what would happen should the I.M.F. cut back drastically on new lending to the developing world, as it has threatened to do if Congress refuses to approve legislation increasing the Fund's resources.

headline: MCDOWELL CHIEF QUITS; CHARTER SOUGHT OUSTER
abstract: Floyd W. Kephart Jr. has resigned as chairman and chief executive officer of McDowell Enterprises, a Nashville construction company.   The Charter Company, a Jacksonville, Fla., oil and insurance concern, earlier this month increased its stake in McDowell to 48.9 percent, from 41 percent.

headline: NCR Sees Gain
abstract: The NCR Corporation said it expects to have record revenues and earnings in the 1983 fourth quarter. In last year's final period, the company earned $94 million, or $3.47 a share, on revenues of $1.06 billion. NCR, which makes business information processing systems, expects a strong performance in 1984, reflecting an improved economy, further announcements in its next generation of products and the positive acceptance of new products released to date.

headline: Microsoft Displays Window Program
abstract: The Microsoft Corporation, a leading personal computer software company, introduced a new program to allow computer screens to be divided into several windows, each displaying different tasks that can be performed with the aid of a handheld device called a mouse.

headline: COLORFUL COUSIN OF THE JEEP KEEPS MANILA MOVING
abstract: When a major union of jeepney drivers voiced support recently for President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda, the action was viewed as a political development of considerable importance.    There are 385,100 jeepneys, or minibuses, whizzing around Philippine cities and towns, large numbers of them with more than one driver taking turns behind the wheel.   Jeepneys take their name from the military vehicle that was converted by enterprising Filipinos at the end of World War II to transport six people in the back, but the latest models are specially manufactured and much larger, with room for 12 to 18.   What is more, jeepneys are probably the most imaginatively decorated public conveyance in the world.

headline: U.S. AND ISRAELI INTERESTS
abstract: News  Analysis        WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 - The suicide attacks on American, French and Israeli forces over the last 12 days have quickened Washington's determination to alter its policy in Lebanon by forging a closer strategic bond with the Israelis, American officials said today.   They said they hoped to create such a bond now to take advantage of what they regard as a growing convergence of American interests with Israel's.    By coincidence, Under Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger was in Israel winding up a mission aimed at reducing the misunderstandings and distrust of the last two years when the terrorist explosion occurred at an Israeli compound in Tyre. A goal of his trip was to persuade the new Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, to make an early trip to Washington for discussions on how the two countries can collaborate in these tense times in Lebanon and the Middle East.   A Major Shift for U.S.     This represents a major shift in American thinking about Lebanon, a shift caused both by the diplomatic stalemate over the country's future and a major buildup of Syrian forces. Ever since Israel pulled its troops back from the Shuf Mountains against the advice of the American and Lebanese Governments in early September, the Administration has feared that the Syrians may be under the impression that they can force Israel and the United States out of Lebanon without making any concessions themselves.

headline: BRITISH PRINTERS ARE ORDERED TO CALL OFF STRIKE
abstract: A judge ordered the country's largest printers' union today to call off a nationwide 24-hour strike that the union had set for Wednesday.   The judge, Philip Otton, handed down the order in response to a request from seven London-based national newspapers and a regional newspaper company.   The 132,000-member National Graphical Association responded with a plea to other unions for full backing of its strike call.

headline: Tamco Purchase
abstract: Tamco Enterprises Inc. said a subsidiary had acquired the 3,541,100 shares of the Imperial Corporation of America owned by a Reliance Group unit for $15 a share.

headline: No Headline
abstract: People     *  Neil Kraft appointed director of advertising for Barney's.     *  William Wendt has been appointed vice president-marketing for the Zayre Stores division of the Zayre Corporation, Framingham, Mass.     *  Lewis Dorf has joined Comart Aniforms, a division of Comart Associates, as vice president of marketing.

headline: SPECIAL OPEC MEETING IS FORESEEN
abstract: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that because demand for their crude oil was expected to fluctuate widely in the first half of 1984, an emergency meeting of the group would probably be necessary in coming months to realign its fragile production-sharing agreement.     Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, oil minister of the United Arab Emirates and outgoing president of OPEC, said that a cold winter and the economic recovery is expected to lift demand for the group's crude to 18.4 million barrels a day in the first quarter.    In the first half of 1983, demand for OPEC oil averaged a rock-bottom 14.9 million barrels a day, depressed by mild weather and a worldwide recession.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Banks Review C.D. Impact The first results of the deregulation of interest rates on bank   certificates of deposit, which   took effect Saturday, are not   expected to be known for at   least a week, according to officers of several major New   York banks. ''At this time we don't even   know how Saturday's rainy   weather affected the inflow of   money into the C.D.'s,'' said an   officer of the Chemical Bank.

headline: Status of U.S. Officers Mentioned in Report
abstract: Following are the whereabouts and assignments of the officers mentioned in the Defense Department report on the Marine bombing in Beirut, issued Wednesday:   Lieut. Col. Howard L. Gerlach, battalion commander for the unit stationed in Beirut Oct. 23, is at Bethesda Naval Hospital outside Washington, recovering from wounds suffered in the bombing.   Col. Timothy J. Geraghty, commander of the 24th Marine Amphibious Unit in Beirut at the time of the bombing, is now stationed at Camp LeJeune, N.C. assigned to the Second Marine Division's staff.

headline: MARINES RELEASE DIAGRAM ON BLAST
abstract: United States Marine spokesmen issued a diagram today detailing exactly how the driver of an explosives-laden truck penetrated their security perimeter and blew up his vehicle inside their headquarters. But the document raised as many questions as it answered.   There has been much uncertainty about how the suicide driver was able to burst into the heart of the Marine Battalion Landing Team building without being deterred by either gunfire or barrier defenses.   Meanwhile, more bodies were excavated from the ruins of the devastated Marine compound, and a Pentagon spokesman in Washington announced that the death toll from the blast was now 225 men. A French spokesmen in Beirut said the bodies of 56 French paratroopers have been recovered from the wreckage of their bomb-ravaged barracks.

headline: JEWS MIGHT BE KEY IN PRETORIA CHARTER VOTE
abstract: Voting alignments among whites are being drastically altered in the fight over the Government's constitutional proposals, which would give some nonwhites a subordinate role in the national Government. Nowhere does this seem more evident than among Jews, whose votes in a referendum next month are conspicuously up for grabs.   Until now, few Jews had been willing to identify themselves with the governing National Party of Prime Minister P. W. Botha or the party's racial policies. In part, their reluctance stemmed from memories of the anti-Semitic tendencies that surfaced in World War II when important elements among Afrikaners, the dominant white group, sympathized with the Nazis.

headline: Westinghouse
abstract: The Westinghouse Electric Corporatioin said its surveillance radar division had been awarded a $480.5 million contract by the Federal Aviation Administration for 137 radar systems that will be delivered over a five-year period beginning in 1986. The company said 23 of the radars are for Department of Defense installations. The airport radars, which are designed to operate 24 hours a day without full-time maintenance personnel, are part of a $10 billion program to modernize the United States air traffic control and air navigation system.

headline: RATH SEEKS CHAPTER 11 PROTECTION
abstract: The Rath Packing Company, an employee-owned meatpacker hailed as a leader in a new era of industrial democracy, filed yesterday for protection and reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.    In 1980, employees bought the company to try to keep it from failing. At noon yesterday, many of those same employees were told by Lyle Taylor, a former butcher and union leader who was elected president of Rath in March, that the company was seeking protection from its creditors.

headline: 50 MARINES LAND AT BARBADOS FIELD
abstract: About 50 United States marines arrived here today in a naval transport plane and flew off in three helicopters. An American Embassy spokesman suggested that they might help evacuate Americans from Grenada, whose Prime Minister was slain last week.   Diplomats here said up to 300 of the 1,000 Americans on Grenada wanted to leave. The Grenadian airport remained closed to most planes today, but a United States Government plane took some diplomats in and brought out three United States citizens.

headline: THE FOE IN LEBANON: DIVIDED BUT STRONG
abstract: Military   Analysis    WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 - The composition of the hostile forces facing the Marine Corps, other Western troops and the Lebanese Army in Lebanon ranges from a depleted but aggressive battalion of Iranian Revolutionary Guards to bands from the Druse and Amal guerrilla forces, according to Pentagon officials.  The number of men in these irregular forces engaged in operations varies from day to day, these sources said. There are, however, two constants. Between 6,000 and 7,000 Syrians serve with the guerrillas as officers, noncommissioned officers and technicians. In addition the Pentagon estimates that 100 Soviet officers tour the area of operations each day to check on troop dispositions, training and the use and maintenance of Russian weapons supplied to the guerrillas by Syria. Those Soviet officers disappear at sundown, the Pentagon sources say.   The basic weakness of the irregular forces is the absence of an effective command and control structure. A band may decide on an operation and carry it out without telling other groups or the Syrian high command. The Syrian influence was described as pervasive, but it is clear, these sources said, that the Syrians do not have operational control of all their clients.

headline: EXOTIC NEW EXPLOSIVE IN ARSENAL?
abstract: Terrorists in the Middle East may be increasing the destructive force of their bombs by using exotic, hard- to-obtain explosives in conjunction with dynamite or TNT, according to private security experts and sources close to a recent Congressional investigation of the bombing at the Marine compound in Beirut.    The explosive is referred to as hexogen, according to Fred Smith, a spokesman in Washington, D.C., for the Institute of Makers of Explosives. The term RDX is more common in the United States, he said, adding that it is primarily a military explosive with a few specialty applications in the oil industry.   RDX was developed in World War II and is one of the most powerful conventional explosives. A white powder in its pure form, it is more effective than TNT and contains almost the theoretical limit of stored energy for a chemical of its type.

headline: SOVIET TO BOLSTER NUCLEAR ARSENAL AT SEA AGAINST U.S.
abstract: Statement by Andropov, page A18.         MOSCOW, Nov. 24 - Yuri V. Andropov said today that the Soviet Union would deploy seaborne nuclear missiles against the United States to counter the threat to his country that he said was posed by new American missiles to be based in Western Europe.   In addition, the Soviet leader announced the abrogation of a voluntary Soviet moratorium on the deployment of SS-20 medium-range missiles in European areas of the Soviet Union. The moratorium was declared by Leonid I. Brezhnev in March 1982.  The Reagan Administration has said the moratorium was never actually observed.

headline: MGM FALLS
abstract: The ITT Corporation reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income slipped 10.9 percent compared with the period last year, largely because of a one-time gain last year of $33 million.    The 1982 benefit came from the favorable settlement of an antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. ITT said that, excluding the extraordinary item, earnings in the third quarter would have risen 23.5 percent.

headline: Jacobs Purchases Shares in RCA
abstract: The Minneapolis financier Irwin L. Jacobs said he had purchased shares of the RCA Corporation, but would not disclose the amount. ''My holdings are under 5 percent,'' he said, declining to say whether he intended to purchase more.

headline: CITY IN ARGENTINA LIVES UP TO ITS REBELLIOUS IMAGE
abstract: Argentines call it el Cordobazo, the big Cordoba blow, accenting how this interior city is known as the nation's center of revolt.   It was in Cordoba, the country's second largest city, where popular uprisings in 1955 and 1969 led to the overthrow of two Governments; where three years ago local military garrisons went on the march in a failed mutiny, and where the revolutionary Ernesto (Che) Guevara was raised.   It was also in Cordoba in late October that Raul Alfonsin, now the President- elect, led a civic revolution, handing the long dominant Peronist party its first election defeat in nearly 40 years. Peronists here conceded just two hours after the polls closed; it was the first sign that a major political upset was in the making. Mr. Alfonsin went on to win 52 percent of the nation's vote and 60 percent of Cordoba's.

headline: Two Arrested in I.R.S. Bribe Case
abstract: The Justice Department and the Internal Revenue Service today announced the arrest of two men accused of offering $548,000 in cash and promissory notes to a revenue agent to protect a tax-shelter program.   Commissioner Roscoe L. Egger Jr. of the I.R.S. said at a news conference that the reported bribe was the largest ever offered to an agent.

headline: FOOTBALL'S TV RATINGS LAG
abstract: It may seem that every television set in America is tuned to N.F.L. games on Sunday afternoon and Monday evening, but in fact football ratings have been depressed this season for all three networks.    One result is that disgruntled advertisers, complaining that they are not getting the audience for commercials that they expected, have been banging on the networks' doors, looking for restitution. And in many cases it looks like they will be successful.   Another result is that TV sales people are worried that unless the rest of the season picks up steam, they may not command the sort of rate increases for next year that they have become accustomed to.

headline: TREASURY SALES TIED TO DEBT ACTION
abstract: Treasury auctions will dominate credit market activity this week, assuming that Congress reaches a compromise on increasing the national debt ceiling above the current maximum of $1,389 billion.    As soon as they can, Treasury officials are expected to announce a new date for the auction of $7.75 billion of one-year bills that was canceled last Thursday.    In view of the debt ceiling's unresolved status, a Treasury spokesman said last night, all matters relating to sales of Treasury securities will be reviewed early this morning. Thus it remained unclear whether today's scheduled auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills totaling $12 billion would actually be held.  Outstanding three- month bills were bid late Friday at a rate of 8.60 percent, while six-month bills were at 8.82 percent and one- year bills were about 9 percent.

headline: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Smaller Stocks Struggle Along
abstract: THE Dow Jones industrial average, which is   doing far better than the general run of   stocks these days, closed last Tuesday at a record high of 1,287.20. Thereafter the blue-chip indicator headed downhill. It finished Friday at 1,265.24, off 12.20 points for the week, as worries again swept Wall Street about the possibility that interest rates might move higher and depress stock prices.   On the surface, the Dow's performance to date would seem to indicate an abundance of bull-market riches, inasmuch as the average soared 510.28 points, or 65.7 percent, between its closing on Aug. 12, 1982, at 776.92 and Tuesday's record reading.

headline: U.S. HAS BONN STOP SOVIET-BOUND COMPUTER
abstract: West German authorities seized a highly sophisticated American-built computer just seven minutes before it was to leave for the Soviet Union via Sweden, the Treasury Department reported today.    John M. Walker Jr., Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Enforcement and Operations, said the seizure was made on Friday ''in the nick of time.''    He said Customs officials stationed in West Germany had told the Germans about the planned shipment after receiving word that the complex minicomputer made in the United States by the Digital Equipment Corporation would be smuggled into the Soviet Union.    The Commerce Department has banned its shipment to nations of the Eastern bloc to keep them from acquiring high technology equipment that could be used for military purposes. The Soviet Union lacks the technology to manufacture this type of computer, Customs officials maintain.

headline: No Headline
abstract: American Brands Bids for Insurer    In a move that will take it more deeply into the financial services area, American Brands Inc., a highly diversified company based in New York, announced yesterday that it plans to acquire the Southland Life Insurance Company from the Southland Financial Corporation for $352 million in cash.   Edward W. Whittemore, chairman and chief executive officer of American Brands, which also owns the Franklin Life Insurance Company, said, ''This acquisition gives us a much larger stake in financial services, in which we are already well represented.''

headline: Soviet Denies Jamaica Plot
abstract: The Soviet Embassy today denied Jamaican accusations that four diplomats had plotted to murder a Foreign Embassy employee because she had learned that a colleague was passing information to the Russians. The four diplomats are being expelled and are planning to leave Friday.

headline: Greek Leftist Balks At Visiting Berlin Wall
abstract: Ioannis Alevras, President of the Greek Parliament, refused to visit the Berlin wall during his current official visit to West Germany.   A West German Embassy official here said today that the incident constituted the first time that a senior Western politician had refused to do so, and added that his Government was ''quite displeased.''   Mr. Alevras, a senior member of the ruling Socialist Party, is visiting West Germany at the head of a six-member group made up of deputies from all three Greek parties, at the invitation of his West German counterpart.

headline: SHULTZ AND PRESIDENT DEFEND AID FOR REBELS FIGHTING SANDINISTAS
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz appealed to the House of Representatives today to continue United States aid to rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government.   The Secretary warned that a cutoff of assistance ''would virtually destroy'' prospects for getting the Nicaraguan Government to stop assisting leftist guerrillas in El Salvador.   At his news conference tonight, President Reagan defended covert backing by the United States for Nicaraguan rebels. But he refused to be drawn into the Central Intelligence Agency's involvement in planning or helping mount recent sabotage attacks in Nicaragua.

headline: BANKERS TO CONFER ON BRAZIL
abstract: The president of Brazil's central bank is to meet here Tuesday with scores of American bankers in an effort to convince them to participate in a restructuring of Brazil's foreign debt.   The official, Affonso Celso Pastore, is coming here because this is where the bankers are this week, at the annual convention of the American Bankers Association, and the athmosphere for agreement seems positive.   Under the plan, approved in principle last week, the banks would lend Brazil $6.5 billion in new funds on which the country would not make principal payments for five years. In addition, the banks would postpone for five years the $5.5 billion in principal on old loans that is due next year.

headline: TANDY COMPUTER'S HARD TEST
abstract: The Tandy Corporation, the world's largest retailer of consumer electronic products and one of the most profitable, got that way emphasizing price, distribution and service.   It owns and operates more electronics stores than anyone with its worldwide Radio Shack chain. Its employees are generally knowledgeable; its products are widely regarded as inexpensive and reliable.   ''We consider ourselves a distribution system for the products of technology,'' says its chairman, John V. Roach.

headline: El Salvador Sued in Death
abstract: The mother and sister of Michael Kline, 21 years old, who was shot to death in El Salvador a year ago, sued the Government of El Salvador and six United States officials today for $15 million in damages in United States District Court. Renate Kline, the mother, and Julie-Anne Kline, the sister, say soldiers killed Mr. Kline on Oct. 13 after hauling him from a bus. They say the Salvadoran authorities made no reasonable effort to investigate the killing and the State Department failed to insure a proper inquiry.

headline: LEAR SET TO BUY 20% OF BANGOR STOCK
abstract: Lear Siegler Inc. announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy 20 percent of the common stock of the Bangor Punta Corporation and that it was interested in acquiring all the stock if further agreement could be reached.    The 20 percent holding, 1.5 million shares, is to be bought for $26 a share, or $39 million, from James E. Stewart, a Bangor director and the chairman and chief executive of Lone Star Industries, a cement producer.   Robert T. Campion, chairman and chief executive officer of Lear, said that ''we hope to obtain representation on the Bangor board and exercise some influence over that company's future course.'' Lear, a producer of electronics and communications equipment, vehicle components and flight-control systems, is based in Santa Monica, Calif.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Boat Magazine To Accept Ads Advertising trade circles,    where a cost-per-thousand advertising rate of $30 is considered high, are really going to   rock when they hear about the   plans of Nautical Quarterly, a   six-year-old hard-cover publication that is going to start accepting advertising with its   spring issue out next February. The advertising page rate for   both four-color and black and   white will be $10,000, and since   its circulation is only 20,000,   that brings the CPM, as it is   called, to $500. Bingo.

headline: Data Bank; October 23, 1983
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: Businessman and Ex-Official Sentenced and Fined in Seoul
abstract: A business executive and a former Cabinet Minister were fined and sentenced to prison here today in a bribery case.   Yoon Ja Joong, 54 years old, a former Transportation Minister and retired air force chief of staff, was sentenced to seven years and fined $102,000, the amount he reputedly received in bribes from a key defendant in return for favors.

headline: THREE HIT OR MISS STORES OPENING IN MANHATTAN
abstract: The Zayre Corporation's Hit or Miss subsidiary, one of the discount industry's largest apparel retailers, will open its first Manhattan stores next week: two in the Wall Street area and one on upper Broadway.    Maurice Segall, president and chief executive officer of Zayre, said in a telephone interview that the decision to open stores in Manhattan was a result of successful ventures in the downtown areas of other large cities.   Hit or Miss, which sells brand- name apparel at 20 to 50 percent off regular prices, operates seven stores within a 20-block area in downtown Chicago. It has three stores in Boston and two in Philadelphia, as well as in other cities.

headline: COMMODITIES Common Themes Link Three Falling Metals
abstract: During the past week, gold, silver and copper prices have been acting like three parachutists in a team jump.   Gold, which is at a 14-month low in Europe, has fallen despite the crises in Grenada and Lebanon. Silver, dropping more than a dollar an ounce this week, has plummeted to its lowest level in a year.  And just when people said copper could not fall any further, it has continued to slide.

headline: Bethlehem to Alter Accounting System
abstract: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it is changing some of its accounting practices in a move that will reduce its 1983 net loss by about $250 million.   The moves generally will make Bethlehem's reported earnings larger but will not affect its taxable earnings.

headline: U.S. CALLED ILL-EQUIPPED TO FIGHT 'ON THE CHEAP' WAR BY TERRORISTS
abstract: MilitaryAnalysis     American and Atlantic alliance sources appear surprised that the President and the Pentagon consider terrorism to be a new form of warfare. A NATO officer notes that the British have been fighting Irish Republican Army terrorism in Northern Ireland for years and that the French have recently encountered terrorism in Corsica.   President Reagan on Tuesday and the Long Commission report issued yesterday by the Pentagon both said terrorism posed a new military problem for which, in Mr. Reagan's words, the services are ''inadequately equipped.'' To operations and intelligence officers in the United States and the NATO alliance, this has suggested a need to recast American tactics in Lebanon and, perhaps, in other places where the United States might face terrorist attacks.

headline: The U.N. Today; Nov. 15, 1983
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Special Political Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Legal Committee - 3 P.M.   Ad Hoc Committee on Indian Ocean - 3 P.M.

headline: ADVERTISING ; Carnation's Dog Food Alters Disputed Claim
abstract: When you make taste preference claims on behalf of consumers who cannot articulate their own, you are skating on thin ice. And last month, the Carnation Company, maker of New Breed Dog Food, found that out.

headline: REAGAN ISSUES WARNING; ; 8 MARINES KILLED
abstract: Fighting in Lebanon increased sharply today, beginning with an early morning American air strike on Syrian targets east of here in which two United States carrier jets were shot down.   Later in the day, eight marines were reported killed and two wounded during an intense artillery attack by Syrian-backed militiamen. Sixth Fleet warships then opened fire on the militia positions.   In Washington, President Reagan said the American attack was in response to Syrian antiaircraft attacks on unarmed reconnaissance aircraft on Saturday and warned that he was determined to defend American forces in Lebanon.   The air raid, which followed an Israeli aerial strike in the same area 24 hours earlier, was directed against Syrian antiaircraft batteries and involved 28 American fighter-bombers.

headline: Coleco Denies Soaring Debt
abstract: Coleco Industries Inc., responding to published reports that its short- term debt had soared as the company gears up to produce its Adam computer system in volume, said it has stayed ''well within'' its credit lines. The company, based in West Hartford, Conn., also denied reports that retailers can return unsold machines for credit, even if they are not defective, and said that early indications show that customers are satisfied with the Adam system.

headline: AID TO JORDAN FROM ARAB NATIONS SAID TO FALL
abstract: Aid to Jordan from oil-producing Arab countries is expected to total $750 million this year, reportedly the lowest figure since the program was begun in 1978.    However, for Jordan, a land of 2.4 million people whose gross national product in 1982 was $4.5 billion, this aid figure is a large amount, and the Government is heavily dependent on it. The aid this year is said to have come from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates.   Western diplomats here say this Jordanian dependence contributes to King Hussein's cautious attitude toward taking part in Middle East peace efforts that might offend the contributing governments.

headline: POLAND CALLS SANCTION MOVE INADEQUATE
abstract: The Polish Government denounced as inadequate today the United States' announcement on Wednesday of ''two limited steps'' toward easing economic sanctions imposed after the 1981 declaration of martial law.    The protest came in a note handed to the United States charge d'affaires and immediately made public. The Government said the United States move, which was accompanied by a sharp attack on what Washington called the continuing abuse of human rights here, constituted an ''unfriendly and unlawful act'' and an ''inadmissible interference in the affairs of our country.''   The American envoy, John R. Davis Jr., was summoned to the Foreign Ministry to receive the long note, which denounced the two steps as being ''merely of an illusory nature.'' The note said that unless economic and financial restrictions ''and other unfriendly actions'' were ended, ''further deterioration of relations may become inevitable.''

headline: ANDROPOV'S SITUATION: AILING, BUT POLITCALLY STORNG
abstract: The Supreme Soviet ended its winter session here today with Yuri V. Andropov's empty seat on the podium symbolizing the political uncertainty that has enveloped the country in the face of his prolonged absence.  Mr. Andropov has been out of public view for four months, among the longest absences of a Soviet leader since Lenin suffered a stroke in 1923 and moved to the mansion at Gorki, south of Moscow, where he died.   Two meetings this week - of the Communist Party's Central Committee and of the Supreme Soviet, the nominal legislature - were accompanied by vigorous efforts to offset the impact of Mr. Andropov's absence.   Assertive Speech on Economy    An assertive speech on the economy was read to the Central Committee in Mr. Andropov's name, four men considered loyal to him were promoted to positions on the top top party bodies, the Politburo and the Secretariat, and the press lavished praise on him in the context of his nomination as a candidate in the single-slate elections of the new Supreme Soviet in March, in other circumstances a routine event.   At the same time, officials were busy in lounges off the Supreme Soviet chamber assuring diplomats and Western reporters that Mr. Andropov's illness was more a matter of age - he is 69 - than of a critical ailment. One official denied, in particular, that the party leader's problem is with his kidneys, as has been reported.

headline: D.D.B. Creativity Split; Bernbach Art Honor
abstract: From 1979 to last August, Roy Grace, now chairman of Doyle Dane Bernbach-U.S., was creative director of the whole show. In August, the responsibility for the main office here in New York was divided between him and Marvin I. Honig, vice chairman, D.D.B./N.Y.   Now it is going to be a four-way split, with the other two members of the team being Michael J. Mangano and John R. Noble, both executive vice presidents.   Four current or former art director heavyweights from the agency - George Lois, Bob Gage, Helmut Krone and Bill Taubin - presented a special award Friday night from the Art Directors Club of New York to Evelyn Bernbach honoring her late husband, William, who was a great copywriter and co-founder of D.D.B. The award was given at the Pierre Hotel at the club's annual Hall of Fame Banquet.

headline: ADVERTISING ; BBDO Direct Is Picked For Hasbro Toy Work
abstract: Hasbro Industries, the Providence, R.I., toy company that has its regular advertising done by Griffin Bacal Inc., has brought in BBDO Direct to work up a plan for using direct marketing techniques to sell its products.   The agency is a subsidiary of BBDO International, which is also the parent of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn.   Hasbro's well-advertised products include G.I. Joe, Charmkins, My Little Pony and more, so much more.

headline: TOP U.S. OFFICIAL QUOTED AS RIDICULING TRUDEAU
abstract: Canadian newspapers reported today that Lawrence S.  Eagleburger, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, told a meeting of some 100 people three weeks ago that Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's attempts to spur arms reduction talks were ''akin to pot-induced behavior by an erratic leftist.''   In Washington, John Hughes, the State Department spokesman, said that Mr. Eagleburger had asked him to say that the reports of his comments ''were grossly distorted.''   Mr. Hughes added that he had been authorized to say that Mr. Eagleburger ''regrets the report and that he has the highest regard and respect for Prime Minister Trudeau.''   The account in the Canadian papers was given prominent coverage. It was written by a Canadian wire service reporter in Washington who earlier wrote that he had been told of Mr. Eagleburger's remarks by Canadian officials, was issued at a time when Canadian diplomats and journalists are expressing dismay over the scant attention the Trudeau peace initiative has drawn in the United States, particularly in comparison to the enthusiastic coverage it has been accorded here.

headline: BUILDING OUTLAYS UP IN AUGUST
abstract: Spending for new construction rose 2.4 percent in August, the fifth consecutive monthly gain, the Commerce Department reported today.   The report said the value of new construction put in place during the month was at an annual rate of $276.1 billion, compared with a rate of $269.5 billion in July.   The increase followed gains of 2 percent in July and 3.7 percent in June, according to revised figures announced today, and brought construction spending to 19.2 percent above August of last year. The July and June advances had previously been reported at 1.7 percent and 4 percent, respectively.

headline: Tektronix Settles
abstract: The Justice Department said it had reached a settlement with Tektronix Inc. over charges that the company failed to disclose complete information to the Government when negotiating contracts for the years 1977 to 1983. Under the settlement, the Beaverton, Ore., electronics concern will pay the Government $5 million.

headline: B.B.D.O. Changes Staff At Its Detroit Office
abstract: James H. Berline, 37, once the No. 2 executive at the Detroit office of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, is being brought back to run the place.   He will succeed Ronald W. Mitchell, 51, executive vice president and general manager, who formerly was on the Chevrolet business at Campbell-Ewald.

headline: Union Pacific
abstract: An antitrust challenge brought by the Union Pacific Corporation to the planned combination of the holding companies that own the Southern Pacific and Santa Fe railroads was rejected by a United States District judge here and a panel of the United States Court of Appeals. In dismissing the complaint from his court, District Judge Thomas H. Flannery said the issue belonged before the Interstate Commerce Commission. Stockholders of Santa Fe and Southern Pacific are to vote today on whether to form a combined Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation.

headline: Ford Car Imports
abstract: The Ford Motor Company plans to import 20,000 to 30,000 of its European-made Sierra model cars into the United States each year, starting in the fall of 1984, a Ford official said. Robert Lutz, executive vice president-overseas automotive operations of Ford, said that Kharmann G.m.b.h. of West Germany would complete assembly of the units before shipment to the United States.

headline: Electronic Associates Stake
abstract: Electronic Associates Inc., a West Long Branch, N.J., manufacturer of computer-based simulation systems, said that a group led by investor Howard Benedek had acquired 5.1 percent of the company's stock and that the group had requested a meeting with management. Electronic Associates said it has no further knowledge of the group's plans.   Electronic Associates, which has about 2.8 million shares outstanding, closed yesterday at $7.75, down 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Market PlaceRobert J. Cole Arbitragers' Exciting Day
abstract: WALL STREET professionals devised a simple formula yesterday for the start of trading in the new A.T.& T. and its seven regional spinoffs: Buy the old and sell the new. Their basic assumption, which turned out to be correct, was that the Bell System's parts would be worth more than the whole.   ''We're going to buy old and sell new all day long, until our fingers get bloody,'' said T. Brett Haire, arbitrager for the First Boston Corporation.   The one thing that stood out yesterday, Mr. Haire said, was the new A.T.& T. stock. Some 8.2 million shares changed hands, partly because of its relatively low market price. For much of the day it traded around 18 points a share. ''To be able to buy Telephone below $20 a share will attract enormous attention,'' Mr. Haire said.

headline: SALVADORAN TROOPS REPORTED TO KILL 100 REBEL SUPPORTERS
abstract: Army troops rounded up and killed more than 100 leftist sympathizers, including women and children, in three small towns in northern El Salvador, residents told foreign journalists who visited the area. The journalists said today that they saw 20 bodies being buried.   The reports matched claims made by two clandestine leftist radio stations earlier in the week.

headline: Malaysian Airliner Crashes
abstract: A Malaysian Airlines jet believed to be carrying 233 people crash-landed in heavy monsoon rains a half-mile short of the Kuala Lumpur airport today, airline officials said.

headline: AUTO SALES SURGE 45% IN PERIOD
abstract: The nation's six major auto manufacturers opened the 1984 model year on a high note, reporting today that sales in the first 10 days of October rose 45 percent from the same period a year earlier.   The producers said sales in the period were 191,695 units, up from 132,386 in the 1982 period. The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for the period rose to 6.7 million units, from 4.9 million units in the 1982 period and 6.4 million in the last 10 days of September.

headline: AMEX OPTIONS SUIT BY GOLDEN NUGGET
abstract: Attorneys for Golden Nugget Inc. have sued the American Stock Exchange and the Options Clearing Corporation in an action they say could set a precedent for all companies with options trading on a securities exchange.    The suit charges that the two defendants issued and listed put and call options without the permission of the company. Golden Nugget owns and operates hotel-casino complexes in Las Vegas and Atlantic City.

headline: Economic Scene; Some Clouds Beyond 1984
abstract: THE economic outlook for 1984 is good here at home and in the world economy generally.   But there are clouds on the horizon.    The Center for Business Cycle Research at Columbia University reports that the leading indexes of business activity are rising at annual rates of 19 percent in Canada, 16 percent in the United States and 13 percent in Japan and France. They are rising at a more moderate 8 percent rate in West Germany, 5 percent in Italy and 3 percent in Britain.

headline: CURB ON DEVELOPMENT BONDS IS STALLED
abstract: Representative Martin Frost, the point man in an intense campaign, now at the showdown stage, to keep Congress from restricting the sale of industrial development bonds, began to get the word last summer.    As the Democrat from the Oak Cliffs section of Dallas recalls it, a meeting with the Mayor of Dallas, a call from Gov. Mark White of Texas, a fellow Democrat, and entreaties from the supporters of the new Dallas Mass Transit Authority, all conveyed adamant opposition to curbing these tax-exempt, low-interest bonds.   This type of lobbying, repeated across the country by supporters ranging from local governments to underwriters, has now effectively stalled a measure to slow the proliferation of these bonds.   And that is endangering the chances for a $4 billion to $5 billion tax increase that was approved in the Ways and Means Committee and includes the measure to curb these bonds. With the Congress seeking to adjourn on Nov. 18, there is a possibility the tax bill will not get to the floor.

headline: NEW NICARAGUA ISSUE: SOCIALIST LINKS
abstract: A document reportedly discovered during the invasion of Grenada shows that left-wing Latin American and Caribbean parties sought ways to ''neutralize'' forces within the Socialist International opposed to them, Jamaican and United States government officials say.    The document appears to outline an attempt to respond to growing criticism of Nicaragua in particular from some West European members of the Socialist organization.   According to the document, a meeting was held in Managua, the Nicaraguan capital, on Jan. 6 and 7 to consider ''the balance of forces'' in the Socialist International and to propose ''initiatives to be taken to strengthen the position of progressive forces of Latin America and the Caribbean.''   The meeting was presided over by a member of Nicaragua's ruling Sandinista party and included representatives of the National Revolutionary Movement of El Salvador, the People's National Party of Jamaica, the Radical Party of Chile, the New Jewel Movement of Grenada and the Communist Party of Cuba, the document says.

headline: ; THE DEFICIT
abstract: To the Editor:      Mr. Wojnilower's statement that ''a cut in military spending would be the most effective way to promote a redirection of resources toward private investment'' is certainly accurate, but I question his dismissal of another deficit-cutting measure's effectiveness.   He says that ''the odds'' favor a tax increase's falling on consumption.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Cronus Industries, Dallas, which makes metal buildings and agriculture-related equipment, said its board had approved the divestiture of its agricultural equipment business, resulting in a ''modest'' charge to fully diluted earnings per share for 1983.     *  Ellis Banking Corp., Bradenton, Fla., said its shareholders had approved the merger of Ellis into a subsidiary of NCNB Corp.     *  First Interstate Bancorp said the state banking commission of South Dakota had approved a previously announced agreement to acquire the Big Stone State Bank in Big Stone, N.D.     *  Holiday Inns Inc.  said it had signed a definitive agreement to buy Granada Royale Hometels, which owns 21 hotels, from its chairman, Robert E. Woolley, for $44 million in cash and $67 million in long-term notes.

headline: ANDROPOV IS SPOTTED BEING DRIVEN TO WORK
abstract: American officials said today that Western diplomats had spotted Yuri V. Andropov being driven to work in the Kremlin after an absence since mid-August.    The Soviet leader's limousine and security convoy were first observed going into the Kremlin one afternoon in the middle of last week, officials said.   On Monday and Tuesday, they said, Mr. Andropov's convoy was again seen going in the mornings from his apartment to the Kremlin through the Borovitsky Gate, and returning home in late afternoon. Not only was the convoy seen, but Mr. Andropov was personally identified as being in the Kremlin.

headline: Advertising; Challenge To Nielsen From AGB
abstract: A.C. NIELSEN, the world's largest research company, could well be getting some domestic competition in an area in which it has reigned supreme: measuring network television audiences.   The potential challenger, AGB Research of Britain, has people over here now trying to drum up financial support for a United States test of its system.   Stephan Buck, group research director, and Richard Hallwood, a company representative, will be putting on presentations for small groups of broadcasters and cable operators, agency folk and advertisers at the Doral Hotel through the rest of the week.

headline: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON ATTACK ON MARINE BARRACKS;
abstract: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference today on the Long commission's report on the attack that killed 241 marines in Lebanon, as recorded by the White House: OPENING STATEMENT    I received the report of the Long commission last Friday and have reviewed it thoroughly. The report draws a conclusion that the United States and its military institutions are by tradition and training inadequately equipped to deal with the fundamentally new phenomenon of state-supported terrorism. I wholeheartedly agree.   The thrust of the history of this country is that we've recognized a clear distinction between being at peace with other states and being at war. We have never before faced a situation in which others routinely sponsor and facilitate acts of violence against us while hiding behind proxies and surrogates which claim - they claim they do not fully control.

headline: $150 Million Issue By Midland Unit
abstract: The Midland American Capital Corporation, a subsidiary of the Midland Bank Group in London, sold $150 million of 12 3/4 percent guaranteed notes, which are offered at 99 3/4 to yield 12.783 percent to maturity in 2003 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: Betting on Turbocharged Cars; Detroit Hoping To Sell 300,000
abstract: The 1984 model year is being seen as the year of the turbocharger for the American automobile industry.   The Big Three auto makers, betting that buyers will pay more to have extra power available on demand, are projecting combined sales of nearly 300,000 turbocharged cars for the model year, compared to just 15,700 in the 1983 model year.   To attain that goal, Detroit will have to overcome resistance to turbocharging that developed during the late 1970's, when the few domestic turbo models on the market proved to be unreliable and difficult.   And there will be price resistance to consider - turbochargers increase power without greatly reducing fuel economy, but they are a complicated, and expensive, accessory.

headline: TOOL ORDERS UP, BUT ARE STILL LOW
abstract: Machine tool orders, a guage of business plans to increase production, rose 70 percent in October over levels of a year earlier, an industry trade group reported yesterday.   In its monthly survey of orders, however, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association noted that the level of orders last month was still depressed, even though the increase indicates that the recovery is starting to help the capital goods sector.   ''In early 1980, monthly machine tool orders averaged over $500 million per month, versus $203 million in October,'' said James A. Gray, the association's president.

headline: Kohl Is Off on Mideast Tour
abstract: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany left today for Jordan on a seven-day tour of the Middle East to assess chances for resuming peace talks there. In addition to Jordan, Mr. Kohl will also visit Egypt and Saudi Arabia.

headline: LITTON ASKS PANEL ON LABOR
abstract: The chairman of Litton Industries has proposed that the company, a major military equipment contractor, attempt to resolve a series of escalating disputes with several employee unions in direct talks monitored by ''a neutral chairman.''   The surprisingly conciliatory announcement, made on Saturday by Fred W. O'Green during the company's annual meeting in Beverly Hills, came as four representatives of labor and religious groups were preparing to deride what they regard as Litton's concerted antilabor practices.   ''As I hastily change gears, it seems to me that we would welcome that proposal,'' said Howard D. Samuel, president of the industrial union department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations. ''Although I have not been able to consult with the other 12 unions, I will bring attention to it immediately.''

headline: A.T.&T. Stock Warrant Price
abstract: The exercise price for A.T.& T. stock warrants attached to a $150 million issue of Prudential Funding Corporation 10 1/8 percent Eurobonds due in 1993 was set on Friday at $75.25, according to Prudential- Bache Securities. Each warrant, which is good for five years, entitles the holder to buy 10 shares of the new A.T.& T. plus one share in   each of the seven new regional   phone companies.

headline: A HIGH-TECH BEER FROM SILICON VALLEY
abstract: Silicon Valley seems about to produce another entrepreneural breakthrough: high- tech beer.   The Palo Alto Brewery, which is really based in nearby Mountain View, is the latest of the ''micro- breweries'' that have sprung up over the past few years to produce a few thousand barrels of specialized beers each year for limited distribution.   Most have been founded out of simple love of the brew, and a thirst by connoisseurs for an alternative to what many say is the bland nature of popular American beers.   The West Coast has been especially active in spawning micro-breweries, likely inspired by the granddaddy of small California brewers - San Francisco's Anchor Steam Brewery, which produces 28,500 barrels a year. By comparison, the Anheuser-Busch Companies, the beer industry's largest, annually produces a bit more than 54 million barrels.

headline: INTEREST RATES DECLINE A BIT
abstract: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday, with much of the decline occurring in the afternoon after a Commerce Department announcement that housing starts declined in September.    Although the bellwether 12 percent Treasury bond due in 2013 remains well within the range of 102 to yield 11.75 percent and 105 5/8 to yield 11.32 percent that has prevailed since early September, the housing starts data added slightly to hopes that prices might rise in coming weeks.   Investor buying yesterday seemed to be concentrated on issues due in less than 10 years, but even so, prices rose modestly for longer-term issues. The 11 7/8 percent Treasury notes due in 1993, for example, were offered late in the day at 102 15/32, up almost 1/4 point, to yield 11.45 percent. The 12 percent bonds due in 2013, which are actively traded by speculators and are a benchmark for long-term corporate bond issues, were offered late in the day at 104, up almost 1/4 point, to yield 11.50 percent.

headline: INDIA, WITH BITTERSWEET MEMORIES, AWAITS QUEEN
abstract: Roughly 250 miles southeast of here, in the city of Lucknow, stand the ruined shells of a cluster of late 18th-century buildings. From them, the British once ruled a vast expanse of northern India.   The Lucknow Residency, as the compound was called, crumbles hollowly, grass growing from walls and towers scarred by thousands of cannonball and bullet holes made a century and a quarter ago.   More than 2,000 British men, women and children died there when Indian mutineers laid siege to the residency for 89 days during the 1857 Sepoy rebellion, the low point of the British adventure in India for both sides.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: *  CBS/Records Group has appointed Richard C. Wolter president of the Columbia House division.

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: U. S. Steel Warns Of Plant Closings    PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8 (AP) - The United States Steel Corporation is warning some 4,700 employees at plants in five states that their jobs could be eliminated if they do not agree to further contract concessions.   A company spokesman, David Higie, said today that, in letters to the workers, U.S. Steel said its competitive disadvantage on labor costs might result in shutdowns of all or parts of the Cuyahoga Works near Cleveland; South Works in Chicago; Fairfield Works near Birmingham, Ala.; Johnstown Works in Johnstown, Pa., and Trenton Works in Trenton.

headline: IN BRAZIL, AGREEMENT BUILDS TO FREEZE DEBT
abstract: Members of both Government and opposition political parties here are saying that a freeze on repayment of Brazil's $90 billion foreign debt is now the only way to solve the country's economic crisis.    These politicians stress that they do not favor a unilateral default, which is being proposed by a vocal minority here. Instead, they are urging a negotiated moratorium on debt repayments of between three and five years.   ''We need a moratorium of at least three years to resolve our internal problems,'' said Theodorico Ferra,co, a pivotal member of the Social Democrats, the Government party in the Chamber of Deputies. ''After three years we will be in a position to begin paying our debts.''

headline: FRENCH-LIBYAN RELATIONS WORSEN
abstract: Relations between France and Libya have worsened, with Libya keeping 37 French citizens from leaving the country and France telling the Libyan envoy here that the action was ''unacceptable.''    On Sunday, Libya kept 35 French citizens from boarding a flight from Tripoli to Paris and took their passports without explanation. Two more French citizens were stopped at the airport Monday.

headline: COPY/Dividend Meetings for Monday's paper/McCue/Fin News
abstract: Dividend Meetings

headline: Eurobonds Up Slightly
abstract: Eurobond trading was quiet today, with some prices showing slight gains, dealers said.

headline: Italian Airports Closed
abstract: All airports in Italy were closed today by a seven-hour firemen's strike. The firemen, who are negotiating a new contract, stopped work and the airports were closed to comply with safety regulations.

headline: Stix Talks Confirmed
abstract: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation of New York and Dillard Department Stores of Little Rock, Ark., have confirmed reports that they are negotiating the sale by Associated of its Stix, Baer & Fuller 12 department stores in St. Louis to Dillard's.

headline: Ford Credit Notes
abstract: The Ford Motor Credit Company filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $750 million of notes with maturities ranging from nine months to five years. The notes are to be offered continuously through Goldman, Sachs & Company and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets as agents, or directly by Ford Motor Credit. Interest rates on the notes will be announced later, and may be changed according to market conditions.

headline: Dow Rises by 2.14; Trading Moderate
abstract: Stock prices finished with minor changes yesterday in moderate trading, with International Business Machines, the market's bellwether stock, one of the bigger losers.    At the end of the session, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 2.14 points, to 1,263.52. I.B.M., one of the 30 major stocks that make up the average, tumbled 1 7/8 points, to 131 3/4, and was the second-most-active issue.   The weakness in I.B.M, the most widely held institutional stock, was fueled mainly by reports that John A. Mendelson, chief technical analyst of Morgan Stanley & Company, had recommended selling the stock yesterday morning, before the computer company issued its third-quarter earnings.   Although Mr. Mendelson could not be reached for comment, a spokesman for Morgan Stanley said that the chief analyst had advised the company's salesmen at a meeting yesterday morning that he was ''issuing an intermediate sell signal on I.B.M.''    At noon yesterday, I.B.M. reported that earnings rose to $2.14 a share, within the $2.10-to-$2.20-a-share range predicted by many analysts. In the period last year, it had earned $1.75 a share.

headline: Block Modeling
abstract: To the Editor:   Scott A. Boorman and and Paul R. Levitt (''Big Brother and Block Modeling,'' Nov. 20) flatter themselves and mislead their readers when they claim that their technique provides new and threatening tools for personnel management.

headline: WARSAW SELLS OIL BOUGHT ON CREDIT
abstract: Poland is so eager to earn hard currency to prop up its battered economy that the Government is taking a loss of as much as $9 million by reselling Libyan oil on the open market, according to industry sources.    The decision dramatically illustrates the plight of the Polish economy, which is heavily dependent on Western raw materials and spare parts and has been deeply affected by a cutoff of credit from Western nations.   In effect, Poland is increasing its overall debt to obtain dollars needed to buy Western materials. But viewed another way, Poland is converting a credit granted by Libya into hard currency at relatively low cost.

headline: South Africa Planning to Try Reporter for Foreign Papers
abstract: Allister Sparks, a South African journalist who writes for The Washington Post and The Observer of London, is to go on trial on charges under the Internal Security and Police Acts.   Lawyers said today that the Nov. 29 trial of Mr. Sparks was a test of how much the authorities could censor foreign correspondents operating from South Africa.

headline: Turk Is Told U.S. Opposes Cypriot Move
abstract: President Reagan told Foreign Minister Ilter Turkmen of Turkey today that the United States strongly opposed the proclamation of a Turkish Cypriot state in northern Cyprus last week.   ''We do have strong feelings, and the President did indicate them,'' the chief White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, told reporters in describing the 10-minute meeting between Mr. Reagan and Mr. Turkmen.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; A New Chief Executive For Cities Service Co.
abstract: David A. Hentschel was named chairman and chief executive of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's Cities Service subsidiary, Cities Service said yesterday in Tulsa.   Mr. Hentschel, 49, succeeds Charles J. Waidelich, 53, who announced last month that he would retire on Nov. 1.

headline: Trane Files Suit To Block IC Move
abstract: The Trane Company said it had asked a United States District Court in Wisconsin to restrain IC Industries from acquiring any more Trane shares and to require the company to divest itself of the Trane shares it owns.   Trane, primarily a maker of air conditioners, is based in La Crosse, Wis.

headline: GRENADIAN'S APPEAL TO YOUNG WAS THE PROMISE OF CHANGE
abstract: Maurice Bishop, the Marxist Prime Minister of Grenada who was killed Wednesday, was a London-trained lawyer influenced by the black civil-rights movement of the 1960's who came to believe that a revolutionary society would solve the problems of the poor Caribbean nation.    Tall and resonant-voiced, Mr. Bishop, who was 39 years old, said in an interview in August that he wanted to build a new kind of postcolonial society providing basic human needs.   ''But I don't think that can be done in the system we have got now,'' he said, ''which, as far as I am concerned, is inherently exploitive.''   Mr. Bishop's movement appealed to younger people because it held out the hope of change, and it came to have wide support in the years of Prime Minister Eric Gairy, who was not a popular leader.

headline: Geneva Arms Session Lasts 2 Hours 50 Minutes
abstract: The United States and Soviet delegations to the negotiations on the reduction of strategic nuclear arms held a two-hour-and-50- minute meeting today, the first formal session of their new round of talks.

headline: 25% STAKE IN AMFAC IS SOLD BY G. & W.
abstract: Gulf & Western Industries sold its 25 percent stake in Amfac Inc. yesterday for $110.5 million. The sale was part of a continuing effort to sell off some of the large portfolio that had been acquired by G.& W.'s former chairman, Charles G. Bluhdorn.

headline: Knight-Ridder
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission has granted Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. permission to purchase a 50 percent interest in a specialized mobile radio service system in Miami, part of a broad diversification effort by the newspaper holding company.

headline: Integrated Barter Debt-Equity Issue
abstract: Integrated Barter International Inc. said yesterday that it would file a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Comission for an offering of about $50 million, in a combination of debt and equity.   The company said it has already signed a letter of intent with a New York underwriter to manage the offering, but it would not identify the investment banking company.

headline: Puritan Fashions To Answer Klein
abstract: The directors of Puritan Fashions Corporation are expected to announce today their decision on a $60 million offer by designer Calvin Klein to purchase the company, which makes Calvin Klein jeans. Mr. Klein late last week said that if Puritan rejected his offer of $16.50 a share, he would begin a tender offer at $15.50 a share. The lower price, he said, reflects the cost of pursuing an unfriendly tender offer.

headline: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: BEIRUT'S ARTILLERY PARROT
abstract: Anything and anyone, it seems, can be bought here: information, hashish, cocaine, transit visas, passports, loyalty.    Law and order remains nonexistent, residents complain. No major crime has been solved in the last eight years. One survives here by luck and one's wits.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * Arrow Electronics Inc., Greenwich, Conn., said it had agreed to acquire High Technology Distribution Inc., a distributor of computer products, for stock valued at about $8.5 million.     * Burroughs Corp.  said the Federal Bureau of Investigation had awarded the company a $48.6 million contract to supply microcomputer workstations.     * CBT Corp., holding company of Connecticut Bank and Trust Co., said its shareholders, as well as the shareholders of the Bank of New England Corp., had approved the proposal to merge the companies, thus creating an institution with assets of more than $10 billion.

headline: Architectural Digest Appoints a Publisher
abstract: G. Robert Griswold, 54 years old and with 29 years at McGraw-Hill behind him, has been named publisher of Architectural Digest, which has one of the nation's most elite magazine audiences - and is $4.50 a copy.

headline: REPORTING THE NEWS IN A COMMUNIQUE WAR
abstract: Most of the news reports about last week's coup in Grenada and yesterday's invasion have relied on Government accounts from Washington and various diplomatic and intelligence sources, sporadic reports on the Grenadian radio station and telephone conversations with island residents.   Journalists, many sent recently to Bridgetown, Barbados, 150 miles from Grenada, have been unable to get firsthand confirmation of information on such matters as the extent of casualties in the invasion or the situation of United States students and tourists caught in the upheaval.   Virtually all Western reporters were expelled from Grenada more than a week ago, when the Government of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop was overthrown. No reporters were allowed to accompany the invasion force of United States Marines and troops from half a dozen other Caribbean countries - so the major stories were written by reporters in Washington, based on information given to them by State Department and other Government sources.

headline: French Court Releases Libyan Wanted in Italy
abstract: A French court ordered today that a jailed Libyan sought by Italy be released because Italy had not provided extradition papers.   The Libyan, Rashid Said Mohamed Abdullah, 34 years old, was arrested in Paris on Oct. 7 on a Milan warrant charging him with murder and illegal possession of arms.

headline: DWINDLING AMERICAN TOURISM
abstract: The joy of many American travelers at how much their dollars can buy abroad is not shared by much of the domestic travel industry, which, for obvious reasons, would rather see the money spent at home.    ''Total U.S. outbound travel increased by 7 percent this year, with Americans going abroad numbering 24.6 million,'' said Don Wynegar, director of the office of research of the United States Travel and Tourism Administration, a division of the Department of Commerce. Meanwhile, he said, ''Total foreign tourism to the United States declined by 2 percent, to an estimated 21.6 million arrivals. This was the second consecutive annual decline in inbound travelers.''

headline: PATENTS ; Taking Temperature Of Asphalt Pavement
abstract: A team of Soviet inventors received a patent this week for a method of measuring the temperature inside asphalt pavement.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The Politics of the English-Speaking Caribbean Nations Grenada Barbados Member of the British Commonwealth. Independent since 1966. Prime Minister: J. M. G. Adams, who belongs to Barbados Labor Party and was elected in 1976. Major opposition party is Democratic Labor Party.
