There is also a small black nationalist group called People's Progressive Movement.  Jamaica Member of the British Commonwealth. Independent since 1962. Prime Minister: Edward P. G. Seaga, who was elected in 1980, ending eight years of socialist rule under Government of Michael Manley. Mr. Manley, first elected in 1974, established close links with Cuba and Soviet Union, which were loosened with his defeat.  Dominica Member of the British Commonwealth. Independent since 1978. Prime Minister: Eugenia Charles, member of Dominica Labor Party, elected in 1980 after internal dissent led to resignation of Prime Minister Patrick John. Two attempted coups in 1981, both unsuccessful.  St.Kitts-Nevis Member of the British Commonwealth. Independent since September 1983. Prime Minister: Dr. Kennedy A. Simmonds, elected in 1980, is leader of People's Action Movement, in coalition with Nevis Reformation Party. One major opposition movement: the Labor Party.  St. Vincent and the Grenadines Member of the British Commonwealth. Independent since 1979, when current . Prime Minister,: Milton Cato, who had been serving as Premier, was elected. to current position in 1979. Frequent social strife since then, including general strike in 1981. Fragmented political opposition in the past but Progressive Democratic Party emerged as important opposition force to Mr. Cato's St. Vincent Labor Party.

headline: GEMAYAL ASSERTS DRUSE CHIEF SEEKS TO SPLIT LEBANON
abstract: President Amin Gemayel's Government accused the leader of the Druse today of trying to partition the country by setting up a local administration in Druse- controlled areas and by appealing to soldiers of the Lebanese Army not to carry out orders.   For his part, the Druse chieftain, Walid Jumblat, went out of his way to emphasize that his decision to set up a local administration, announced Saturday, was taken to provide basic public services to people living in the war- shattered areas under his control. He also emphasized he would welcome any help the central Government could provide. This move, he added, was not meant to be a prelude to the establishment of a Druse ''ministate.''   'Conscientious Objectors'    But Mr. Jumblat raised some suspicions about his ultimate intentions in the minds of senior Government officials today when he visited several hundred Druse soldiers who had gone to Hammana, a Syrian-occupied town some 18 miles east of Beirut. The soldiers there are acting as ''conscientious objectors,'' refusing to take part in any attempt by the Lebanese Army to use force to impose its authority over Druse-controlled areas.

headline: I.B.M.'S SPEEDY REDIRECTION
abstract: Industry experts and competitors of the International Business Machines Corporation agreed yesterday that the PCjr is the latest element of a fundamental change in marketing strategy and product design for the computer giant.   In two short years, they say, the company has created an entirely new line of compatible desktop computers - each able to transfer information freely with the other - that I.B.M. officials think will propel the company to $100 billion in sales annually by 1990.   The PCjr was the last link in the chain, bringing into the living room for under $700 a machine that can prepare data for further analysis on the rest of the company's more powerful line of office machines.   'Everyone's' Processor    ''The whole company has been fundamentally redirected,'' said Thomas J. Crotty, vice president of research for the Gartner Group, a Stamford, Conn., research firm that follows I.B.M. closely. ''It's not only that they want to be part of all markets, or be everyone's computer maker, it's that they want to be everyone's information processor,'' whether their customers are in the office or in the living room.

headline: MOSCOW ENVOY TO U.N. SAYS MISSILES INCREASE RISK OF WAR
abstract: The Soviet Union's deputy chief delegate to the United Nations said today that the decision to proceed with the deployment of new American missiles in Western Europe had greatly increased the risk of nuclear war.   The envoy, Richard S. Ovinnikov, said at a news conference that the imminent deployment of the missiles meant that ''irresponsibility and recklessness had prevailed over common sense.''   ''Detente,'' he said, ''has been deliberately murdered by the United States.''

headline: QUESTIONS RAISED AGAIN ON REAGAN'S LIMITS UNDER WAR POWERS ACT
abstract: With the ink barely dry on compromise legislation giving President Reagan carefully limited authority to keep marines in Lebanon for 18 months, today's bombings in Beirut raised anew the question of what military steps Mr. Reagan could legally take.    Congress asserted in the legislation, which Mr. Reagan signed Oct. 12, that any substantial expansion in the number or role of United States armed forces in Lebanon would require a new approval from Congress. Mr. Reagan had earlier said that ''it would be my intention'' to comply with the requirement.   Although the Administration said today that it had no plans to expand the marines' role or withdraw them, Mr. Reagan has in the past carefully hedged his commitment to abide by Congressional limitations on his use of armed forces abroad.   He insisted obliquely in his Oct. 12 statement that he had the power to keep the marines in Lebanon even without Congressional approval. He hinted that the central provision of the War Powers Act of 1973 - requiring the President to ''terminate'' the use of armed forces in ''hostilities'' abroad in 90 days unless Congress authorized longer involvement - was unconstitutional.

headline: Kohlberg Lawsuit
abstract: A class action suit was filed in state court in Delaware against Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company and the management of the Amstar Corporation in connection with their proposed leveraged buyout of the big sugar refiner. The deal calls for the buyers to purchase all of Amstar's common stock for $47 a share and all of its preferred stock for $8 a share. The plaintiff is demanding that the defendants pay Amstar stockholders the fair value of the company's $500 million in borrowing power that would allow the acquisition to occur.

headline: 680 Guerrillas Reported To Yield in Thailand
abstract: Some 680 anti-Government guerrillas abandoned their jungle bases and surrendered to the authorities today in a ceremony in southern Thailand.

headline: AMERICAN GROUP SAYS MANILA ABUSES RIGHTS
abstract: An American group that came here three weeks ago to investigate human rights conditions found a ''continuing pattern'' of abuse, much of it attributable to agents of President Ferdinand E. Marcos's Government, a member of the group says.     The three-member investigating team left for the United States today with notebooks that were said to be crammed with first-hand accounts of torture and other abuses in the detention camps, plus scores of unsolved murders also attributed to Government security forces.   The findings will be the basis of a report to the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the American College of Physicians, the American Public Health Association, the American Nurses Association and the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Science, which jointly sponsored the survey.

headline: Israeli Killed in Lebanon
abstract: An Israeli soldier was killed today by an explosive device as his patrol was moving through the southern approaches to Sidon in southern Lebanon, an army spokesman said. The death brought to 557 the Israeli losses in Lebanon since the invasion of June 1982.

headline: Baghdad Accepts Call By U.N. for Cease-Fire
abstract: Iraq today accepted a United Nations Security Council call for an immediate end to the Persian Gulf war, but warned it would take ''necessary measures'' if Iran rejected it.   Iran has already announced it will not accept the resolution, which was adopted Monday.

headline: Occidental Will Sell Permian to Wesray
abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to sell its Permian Corporation unit to Wesray Operations Inc., less than two weeks after a previous deal to sell Permian collapsed.    Under the agreement, the Wesray deal would be worth more than $375 million. Permian, which is based in Houston, purchases, transports and markets crude oil.

headline: DEBREU RECOGNIZED FOR PURE RESEARCH
abstract: When Gerard Debreu strolls with close friends and colleagues through a wildlife preserve above the shore of the Pacific Ocean north of San Francisco, the conversation often weaves through the work of Marcel Proust and the music of Saint-Saens.   ''Over the years, I have become more and more of a purist,'' he explained today, describing his taste in arts and letters.   That seems only fitting. The French-born economist, now in his 22d year at the University of California at Berkeley, made his mark on the profession 24 years ago in a 114- page monograph filled mostly with elaborate mathematical formulas.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: The 'Endless Summer'   The fuel industry is ruefully calling it ''an endless summer,'' but homeowners and other heating oil users who have been enjoying this fall's unseasonably warm weather may soon be paying more for the fuel they have not been buying in recent weeks.   One reason: Many oil refiners and the fuel distributors they sell to were hurt badly when they gambled on a normal winter last year. The winter proved to be the mildest in many years and they ended the heating season with too much unsold fuel.   ''Refiners won't raise their production this season until the price goes above their current break-even point of 79-80 cents a gallon,'' said Joel Faber, who heads an energy futures trading house bearing his name.

headline: ADDENDUM TO A 'DOOMSDAY' BOOK: THERE IS HOPE
abstract: ''They forget that Cassandra was right,'' said Aurelio Peccei, the amiable and optimistic man who founded and presides over the Club of Rome.    Eleven years ago, the club's study, ''The Limits to Growth,'' cast a chill over the buoyantly producing, reproducing and consuming world by predicting that mankind faced catastrophe within a century unless it acted quickly to establish an equilibrium in which population growth, industrialization and the depletion of resources were halted.   Since publication of the report, which was prepared by an international research team at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the club has sponsored a continuing series of more limited studies and international conferences that have elaborated on the same theme.   Mr. Peccei recently returned to his elegant Rome apartment from a conference in Budapest devoted to the discouraging question of how by the end of ths century the world will manage to feed six billion mouths. He heard some gloomy papers, bearing particularly on a likelihood that the capacity of the United States to make up much of the rest of the world's food deficit is diminishing.

headline: INTEREST RATES ARE STABILIZED
abstract: Interest rates stabilized yesterday, as government securities dealers, who make the markets in Treasury issues, estimated that the increases in rates last week were enough to attract investors for this week's heavy schedule of Treasury financings.    Though yields were higher than a week earlier, they were basically unchanged from Friday.   The average yield for $6.5 billion of 11 percent three-year notes that were auctioned at 12.30 P.M. was 11.11 percent, up from a 10.85 percent yield quoted for similar notes a week ago.   Three- and six-month Treasury bills totaling $12.4 billion were sold at average rates of 8.83 percent and 9.02 percent, respectively, up from 8.41 percent and 8.68 percent a week ago, when only $7 billion were auctioned.

headline: 2 Officials Under Carter Join Satellite-TV Unit
abstract: Two names from the Carter Administration are in the lineup of officers of a new company in the business of beaming television from satellites to rooftop receivers.   G. William Miller, a former Secretary of the Treasury, is chairman of the new company, called Private Satellite Network Inc. Richard M. Neustadt, a former White House adviser on communications, is senior vice president and general counsel.

headline: The U.N. Today; Dec. 7, 1983
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Pope Urges Guatemala To Return to Democracy
abstract: Pope John Paul II urged the Guatemalan Government today to restore democratic institutions, which he said would be a sure sign of lasting peace in the troubled Central American country.   The pope was speaking at a ceremony to receive the credentials of Jose Alejandro Deutschmann Miron, Guatemala's new Ambassador to the Vatican. The former envoy was dismissed after his Government accused him of delaying a papal message urging clemency for anti-Government rebels who were executed before the pope's visit to Guatemala in March, casting a shadow over the visit.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; WHY THE CONTINENT STILL SLUMBERS
abstract: EUROPE has been asleep for decades and shows few signs of   awakening. The modern economic world and its markets have passed it by. Though we still hear that the European Economic Community is an open and competitive market, the fact is that Europe is still strongly parochial and its presence in technological innovation, market clout and leadership has greatly diminished.  The slumber, though particularly manifest in recent years, has been present for decades, and a look back can prove instructive.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: American Water Works Co., Wilmington, Del., has named James V. LaFrankie president, succeeding John A. Gubanich, who is retiring.     *  Cybernex Corp., San Jose, Calif., has appointed Dan Klang vice president of Advanced Storage Technology for the corporation's future line of high-performance HDA components.

headline: COUNTERFEITING OF GOODS RISES
abstract: Earlier this year, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation obtained from the Philippines what appeared to be one of its circuit breakers, a widely used device that automatically cuts off electric power in case of overloading to prevent fire and shocks.    It bore the Westinghouse trademark, was the correct size and shape and carried the right serial number. But testing showed it to be a dangerous fake, incapable of doing what a genuine Westinghouse circuit breaker should do.   That is just one example of large- scale industrial counterfeiting that was presented at a meeting here last month of American and European manufacturers intent on bringing the phenomenon under control.

headline: U.S. AIDE BLAMES CHINA FOR DELAYING ARMS DEALS
abstract: A senior State Department official said today that there had been no sales of American military equipment so far to China because the Chinese had been seeking special treatment before they would agree to buy any arms.   In a briefing for reporters in advance of the arrival this afternoon of Foreign Minister Wu Xueqian, the official said that even though the Reagan Administration had told the Chinese it was willing on a case-by-case basis to consider the sale of certain arms, the Chinese were insisting on first being given an umbrella list of what arms they would be permitted to buy - something Washington as a rule does not do for any country, the official said.   Mr. Wu's long-planned three-day trip came as the Administration grew concerned about a possible rise in tension in northeastern Asia after the explosion in Rangoon on Sunday that killed some South Korean officials and that President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea said was meant for him.   The subject of possible arms sales was discussed at length during Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's recent visit to Peking. Washington is seeking a closer strategic relationship with China.

headline: Oil Surplus May Lower Fuel Costs
abstract: A large, unexpected surplus of crude oil and refined petroleum products has come onto the market during the past month. Barring an unusually cold winter, the excess supplies should mean lower prices for heating oil and gasoline.   The oil surplus, coming seven months after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries cut its crude prices to stimulate demand, has also led to mounting conjecture that OPEC may lower its prices again in December.   On Friday, in one of several indications of the excess of supplies worldwide, the Soviet Union said it was cutting the price of crude oil it exports by 50 cents a barrel, to $29. On the same day the Sun Company, a large United States producer, said it was lowering its wholesale price of heating oil by a cent a gallon, to 82.5 cents. Analysts said they expected other oil companies to reduce wholesale prices this week.

headline: China Ship Talks Fail PEKING, Dec. 18 (UPI) - Negotiations between the United States and China on renewing a shipping agreement have collapsed, industry sources said today. As a result, they said, Peking is expected to impose new restrictions on American vessels that use Chinese ports.
abstract: No formal announcement was made, but in Washington, Harold Shear of the Transportation Department, who headed the United States delegation, confirmed that the talks had broken down.

headline: Sea Galley Stores
abstract: Sea Galley Stores Inc. said it would probably not earn the 10 cents to 15 cents a share that analysts had projected for the fourth quarter and that it could report a loss.

headline: MARINES' ROLE IN BEIRUT HAS DRASTICALLY SHIFTED
abstract: In the aftermath of the attacks Sunday on the American and French contingents in the multinational force in Lebanon, many questions have been raised about their mission. This is an attempt to answer some of them.   Q. Why were the Marines sent to   Lebanon in the first place?    A. In August 1982, after Israel's invasion of Lebanon and encirclement of Beirut, the special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, worked out an arrangement to permit the Palestine Liberation Organization and Syrian forces in Beirut to be withdrawn. To insure their safety from Israeli attack, the United States, France and Italy sent detachments of about 800 men each to Beirut. The three-nation force remained in Beirut from Aug. 25 to Sept. 10.

headline: BRAZIL FEARFUL OF EXPLOSION OF DISCONTENT
abstract: Last week, in the midst of a debate over austerity measures that the International Monetary Fund has asked Brazil to adopt, Representative Mario Juruna leaped to his feet in frustration.    Facing a hushed chamber, he bitterly attacked the economic policies of President Joao Baptista Figueiredo and his principal adviser, Minister of Planning Ant^onio Delfim Netto. ''To me, every minister is a thief,'' he declared. ''Every minister is without shame, every minister is dishonest.''

headline: Soviet Accuses Sweden of Spying on Military
abstract: Tass, the official Soviet press agency, accused Sweden today of using reconnaissance planes to spy on Soviet military movements.

headline: OPPOSITION CANDIDATE IN VENEZUELA WINS EASILY
abstract: Jaime Lusinchi, the candidate of Venezuela's opposition Democratic Action Party, won an easy victory in today's presidential election.    His main competitor, Rafael Caldera of the governing Social Christian Party, conceded defeat.   As supporters filled the streets with honking cars and exploding firecrackers, Mr. Lusinchi said: ''In this moment, it is permissible to say I am really the President of the republic. This is a triumph for Venezuela, the people and Venezuelan democracy.''

headline: SOUTH AFRICANS MAKE OFFER TO ANGOLA
abstract: South Africa proposed a ''disengagement'' of hostile forces in Angola today as a first step toward solving the dispute over the granting of independence to South-West Africa, the territory administered by South Africa.   In a letter to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, the South African Foreign Minister, Roelof F. Botha, offered to begin the disengagement for a period of one month starting Jan. 31, 1984. Mr. Botha's letter said, ''The Government of South Africa is prepared to begin a disengagement of forces which from time to time conduct military operations against Swapo in Angola.''   Swapo is an acronym for the South West Africa People's Organization, the main guerrilla force fighting South African control of the territory, also known as Namibia.

headline: Tunisia Legalizes 2 Political Parties
abstract: President Habib Bourguiba legalized two opposition parties today and announced plans to establish a multiparty political system, the Tunisian press agency said.

headline: Black & Decker
abstract: The board chairman of the Black & Decker Manufacturing Company, Francis P. Lucier, reaffirmed today that he will not seek re-election. The board of directors said no replacement will be named for Mr. Lucier. Instead, the board said, the chairman's duties will be assumed by Laurence J. Farley, president.

headline: Germans Continue Protests Against Missile Deployment
abstract: Church organizations held nationwide services and marches for peace today as West Germany's 10-day campaign of mass protest against the planned deployment of new United States missiles in Europe moved into its fourth day.   The police said most of the meetings were small and peaceful with no repetition of Saturday night's violence in the northern port of Bremerhaven, where the police clashed with demonstrators.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: POWER OF VOODOO, PREACHED BY SORBONNE SCIENTIST
abstract: With a bachelor of science from Cornell and a master's in chemistry from the Sorbonne, Max Beauvoir never imagined he would succeed his grandfather as a voodoo priest.    But as the family gathered at his grandfather's deathbed, Mr. Beauvoir's life suddenly changed.   ''Just as a carnival band went by the house,'' Mr. Beauvoir recalled, ''grandfather turned to me and said, 'You will carry on the tradition.' It was not the sort of thing you could refuse.''

headline: Quanex Offering At $100 Million WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (Reuters) - The Quanex Corporation filed an offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of $100 million in senior mortgage bonds due 1999. The underwriter is Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.
abstract: Quanex, a producer of specialty steels, said it would use the proceeds of the offering to reduce debt in connection with a restructuring plan for its existing indebtedness. It said the restructuring plan is designed to permit completion of the company's Macsteel-Arkansas facility.

headline: Texas Instruments Soars 22 3/4;  Dow Closes 1.72 Higher
abstract: Stock prices ended with minor changes yesterday in slower trading after a midafternoon pullback erased many of the earlier gains.   The star performer was Texas Instruments, which soared 22 3/4 points, to 124 1/2, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The surge reflected reaction to the company's decision last Friday to withdraw from the home computer business, in which it lost $330 million before taxes in the third quarter.

headline: Reagan Says 1,000 Terrorists Are Being Trained in Lebanon
abstract: President Reagan said earlier this week that up to 1,000 terrorists in Lebanon are ''willing to sacrifice their lives in a kamikaze attack'' against American and Lebanese positions.   He made the remark Wednesday in a private comment to a Republican group, Citizens for America.

headline: Daisy Manufacturing Returns to the Family
abstract: The Daisy Manufacturing Company is back in the family - Cass S. Hough's family.   Mr. Hough, who is 79, worked for Daisy for 50 years and served as its president for 14 years. His grandfather was a founder of the maker of air guns.

headline: A SOWETO MILLIONAIRE SETS HIS SIGHTS ON CITY HALL
abstract: Ephraim Tshabalala is, by his own account, a man of ''background.'' And that, he said, is important in politics.    ''The Americans,'' he told a reporter, ''would never put a man without background into the White House, would they?'' By background, he said, he meant a certain degree of financial worth. Mr. Tshabalala certainly has that.   He is one of the most prominent, and wealthy, candidates seeking the post of Mayor of this huge and bleak black township from which Johannesburg appears as a crenellation of high-rise buildings on a distant skyline. The election, shunned by radical blacks and probably destined to be the target of a sizable boycott, is to be held Saturday.

headline: High-Tech Law
abstract: To the Business Editor:   Roy N. Freed's article ''The Demands of High-Tech Lawyering'' (Oct. 2) should be hailed as timely and accurate, as far as it goes. But high technology has come to many other areas and competent lawyering increasingly demands expertise in technology.

headline: U.S. ROLE IN THE U.N. IS DEBATED
abstract: Two Congressional hearings that were intended to examine whether the United Nations should stay in New York evolved instead into a forum on continued American involvement in the world organization.   The House Subcommittee on Human Rights and International Organizations heard testimony from three speakers on Sept. 27 and Oct. 3.   Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas; Elliot L. Richardson, chairman of the United Nations Association of the United States, and Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States representative at the United Nations, expressed wide-ranging concerns about the United States' role in the United Nations.

headline: EGYPT AGREES TO SEND AN AIDE TO ISRAEL FOR CONTINUED TALKS CAIRO, Nov. 10 (AP) - An Egyptian envoy will visit Israel to resume talks on issues that have strained relations since the Israeli invasion of Lebanon last year, it was announced here today.
abstract: The announcement came after David Kimche, director general of the Israeli Foreign Ministry, met with Foreign Minister, Kamal Hassan Ali.   Mr. Kimche and the Foreign Ministry said an Egyptian diplomat would visit Israel ''sometime in the future'' to continue the talks.   Egypt is the only Arab country to have signed a peace treaty with Israel. But no Egyptian delegations have visited Israel since the Israeli invasion of Lebanon last year.

headline: G.M. FACES A SNAG ON 'JAPAN STRATEGY'
abstract: Japanese auto makers will oppose allocating to the Isuzu Motor Company and the Suzuki Motor Company any shares in the quotas on imports to the United States, Takashi Ishihara, president of the Nissan Motor Company, said today.    This opposition, if successful, could jeopardize the General Motors Corporation's plans to satisfy the bulk of its small-car needs through links to Isuzu and Suzuki, among others.   At present, neither Isuzu nor Suzuki ships many cars into this country. But G.M. is planning to import about 200,000 cars from Isuzu and slightly under 100,000 from Suzuki next year. Thus, if Japan does not allocate a significant quota to the two companies, it could pose a problem for the American company. The quota system is to be revised next April.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  Brae Corp., San Francisco, has promoted Lawrence S. Hershfield to executive vice president of its American Sign and Indicator Corp. subsidiary.     *  Buckhorn Inc., Columbus, Ohio, has named Richard R. Halsor a group vice president.

headline: ISRAELI COALITION DEFEATS OPPOSITION CHALLENGE
abstract: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's nine-day-old coalition Government easily defeated three opposition motions of no confidence today on its ability to manage Israel's economy.   The single vote on the three no-confidence motions, in Parliament in Jerusalem, was 61 to 54. It came at the close of a debate in which the new Finance Minister, Yigal Cohen-Orgad, said his immediate target was to slash the $5 billion annual deficit in the country's balance of payments. The deficit has doubled this year.

headline: Duke Power
abstract: The Duke Power Company said it had filed for an electric rate increase of $213 million, or 13.6 percent, with the North Carolina Utilities Commission.

headline: Dorchester Gas Buyout Cleared
abstract: The Dorchester Gas Corporation, a diversified oil and gas production company that has been the subject of repeated takeover rumors, said its board had approved a leveraged buyout of the company for $22.50 a share, or $396 million. The company said the buyout, which would transform it into a privately held concern, was proposed by a group of investors including George S. Rooker, its 64-year-old chairman, and other members of its senior management.

headline: EVICTION AWAITED BY SOUTH AFRICANS
abstract: Several hundred black villagers refused today to heed an edict ordering them off lands that they have owned for 70 years and that are now termed a ''black spot'' to be excised from the surrounding white area.   The action appeared to reflect a sense of resignation tinged with apprehension that families resisting the order would be forcibly removed once civil rights workers and foreign television crews have left this wind-swept village, near Ventersdorp, some 80 miles west of Johannesburg.   Some families, seeking to avoid official action, tore the window frames and tin roofs off their houses and loaded them on chartered trucks to leave for an uncertain future.   Lawyer Seeks Further Extension    A lawyer representing the villagers, Nicholas Haysom, said he had received assurances from the authorities that the villagers would be given at least one more day before being forced off their land. He said he planned to seek a further extension of the deadline.

headline: GEMAYEL TERMS FACTIONAL TALKS 'A CAMOUFLAGE'
abstract: President Amin Gemayel said today that Lebanon's main problem was to get foreign troops out of the country. He said the reconciliation conference between Lebanese factions, which he has called at American urging, was ''a camouflage, a distraction.''    The Lebanese leader expressed some irritation and doubt over the usefulness of the current American-backed approach to his country's problems in a 90-minute interview in his office in the presidential palace at suburban Baabda.   Mr. Gemayel's Government, meanwhile, pressed ahead with efforts to convene the conference, announcing that it had formally invited the leaders of Lebanon's warring factions to meet on Oct. 20. It said the place would not be made known until Oct. 19 for security reasons. But there was still no agreement on where it should be held.

headline: Judge Rules Against Dirks
abstract: Raymond L. Dirks, a   securities analyst who headed   the now-defunct firm of John   Muir & Company, was found in   an initial decision of an administrative law judge to have   aided violations of the net capital rule of the Securities and   Exchange Commission.

headline: Soviet Calls for Warmth In Relations With China
abstract: The Soviet Union, a week before its next round of talks with China, has called for improved relations between the two countries and congratulated the Chinese people on the 34th anniversary of Communist rule.   The Soviet press agency Tass carried a telegram to the Chinese Government from the Soviet Parliament and Council of Ministers that said, ''Positive development of Soviet-Chinese relations would be in the interests of the two countries, would promote a solution to long-term economic tasks facing them, and would be of benefit to the entire international situation as well.''

headline: Ameritech Sets 2 Ventures
abstract: Ameritech, the Middle Western regional holding company that will be created by the breakup of the Bell System, today will announce an agreement with Aetna Telecommunications Laboratories to develop an optical fiber local communications network. The company will also announce the start of business of the nation's first cellular mobile telephone service, which will serve the Chicago area.

headline: EMBASSY GUARDS KEEP REVOLVERS
abstract: The United States marines who guard American diplomatic buildings around the world are usually armed with .38- caliber revolvers that have a round in the chamber, a State Department spokesman said today.   Under rules agreed upon by State Department and Marine Corps officials, the spokesman said, the guards may use the weapons whenever they judge that their lives or the lives of other American diplomatic personnel are endangered.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Monthly Set To Be Dropped The Goldhirsh Group, which   publishes Inc. and High Technology, has announced it will   suspend publication, with the   November issue, of its third   magazine, Technology Illustrated. According to Bernard A.   Goldhirsh, chairman of the   group, Technology Illustrated   was unable to attract sufficient   advertising to sustain publication.

headline: G.I.'S ON ISLAND SETTLING DOWN TO POLICE DUTY
abstract: With hostilities on this Caribbean island apparently at an end, United States military officials made it clear today that the army's key role now was guarding checkpoints, patrolling the capital and making house-to-house and car checks for weapons.   The officials said 2,300 paratroopers would leave shortly. They added that for the time being, the remaining 2,500 paratroopers of the 82d Airborne Division on Grenada would be deployed around the capital of St. George's as well as in northern parts of the island where snipers remain.   ''There's still small, individual bands and elements there,'' Maj. Douglas Frey, public affairs officer for the Airborne Division, said at the Grenada Beach Hotel, a bomb-damaged resort where the military has set up headquarters.

headline: Laos Turns Over Bodies Of U.S. Servicemen
abstract: Laos has handed over to a United States team the bodies of some American soldiers who were reported missing in action in the Vietnam War, the Laotian press agency said today.

headline: Kenya-Tanzania Agreements
abstract: Kenya and Tanzania have signed agreements on trade, transportation, tourism and telecommunications, the official Tanzania radio said today. The agreements followed the Nov. 17 treaty the two East African countries signed to reopen their common border, which had been closed since 1977.

headline: Aid for Brazil Sought
abstract: The League of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies opened an appeal today for $3.6 million for Brazil's drought- stricken northeastern region.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The U.N. Today Oct. 19, 1983 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10 A.M, 3 P.M. and 6 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 3 P.M.   Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M.

headline: DISRUPTION OF PEACE PARLEY IS TERMED TERRORISTS' GOAL
abstract: Some Lebanese officials asserted today that the terrorist explosions here that killed scores of United States marines and French paratroopers this morning were aimed at undermining the planned peace conference of the country's religious and political factions.    ''Every time we make some headway, evil elements act to set us back by killing and destruction,'' Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan told reporters as he joined President Amin Gemayel and other officials in an emergency Cabinet session.   Others, such as former Prime Minister Saeb Salam, a key figure in the peace conference, said the attacks appeared primarily to be an effort to compel the withdrawal of the international force of United States, French, Italian and British troops.   Butros Harb, a member of Parliament and former Cabinet minister, said the deaths of the American and French soldiers had poisoned the political atmosphere and overshadowed the reconciliation process.

headline: CAMBODIA'S REBELS GROW CONFIDENT
abstract: Sometimes it is easy to walk into Cambodia to visit an encampment of guerrillas loyal to Pol Pot, the Prime Minister who was deposed by Vietnamese troops five years ago.    At the Thai border village of Klong Nam Sai, eight miles south of here, a dirt road leads eastward into the woods. It is daybreak and the sound of Vietnamese artillery can be heard in the distance. A Thai policeman makes no move, as he usually does, to check on anyone heading for the border.

headline: Norwegian Prices Rise
abstract: The Norwegian consumer price index rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in September, after falling by two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the National Bureau of Statistics said today.

headline: DEATH SQUADS IN SALVADOR: CENTRISTS BECOME TARGETS
abstract: NewsAnalysis     Reagan Administration officials say they are now more alarmed by a recently stepped-up series of assassinations of Salvadoran democratic centrists than by more random killings of civilians suspected of sympathizing with left-wing rebels.  The importance of such selective assassinations has often been overlooked in the heated debate over human rights in El Salvador, which has concentrated on the rate of killing rather than the identities of those killed and the political motivation of the killers.   But as one United States official said of the death-squad assassinations, ''This is an effort to destroy the political center in El Salvador that United States policy has sought to nurture and protect for the last four years.''   In recent weeks, United States officials in El Salvador and Washington have issued statements deploring the death squads' activities and warning that failure by the Government to curb them could lead to a Congressional cutoff of American aid. They also assailed what they said were links between the death squads and the Salvadoran military. The statements appeared to represent a shift from an earlier, stated Reagan Administration policy of dealing with human rights abuses through what was called called quiet, behind- the-scenes diplomacy rather than publicly applied pressure.

headline: MORE STEEL CLOSINGS EXPECTED
abstract: The production capacity of the nation's steel industry is likely to shrink at least 10 percent over the next two or three years, analysts say. The first of a new wave of plant closings and write-offs, they predict, will be announced by the United States Steel Corporation later this month.   In addition, the company resulting from the proposed merger of the Republic Steel Corporation and the LTV Corporation, the parent of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, is expected to close several major facilities early next year.   Industry analysts, steel company executives and even union officials say the industry will cut back to reduce costs and make domestic steel more competitive with lower-cost imports. The domestic industry is still operating at less than 60 percent of capacity, even though the economic recovery is a year old.

headline: Nuclear Plant Delay Urged
abstract: An Energy Department agency recommended today a delay in construction until July 1985 as the cheapest option for the uncompleted No. 3 nuclear reactor of the Washington Public Power Supply System.   Peter Johnson, administrator of the Bonneville Power Administration, said a study by the agency had found that restarting the project then and at a moderate pace would be most economical.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: Puerto Rico Bank Issue Is Offered to Yield 10%    A $450 million bond issue of the Government Development Bank of Puerto Rico was offered yesterday with 10 percent bonds due in 2013 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.   The bonds, rated triple-A, are backed by the full faith and credit of the bank, which acts as financial adviser to public authorities in Puerto Rico and makes loans to public authorities and private businesses. By selling long-term bonds, the bank will lengthen the average maturitiy of its debt to match more closely the maturity of the loans it makes.

headline: Europe Seeking Technology
abstract: Western European governments, troubled by the losing battle Europe's computer companies are waging against United States and Japanese competitors, are enacting measures aimed at lessening Europe's dependence on high- technology imports.    To seasoned industry analysts, the plans may seem like the latest chapter in a chronicle of similar, largely futile efforts over recent years.   But the need to combat record unemployment has lent an unaccustomed sense of urgency to the plans. And past mistakes are leading governments to try novel tactics some analysts and industry officials say could effectively strengthen the industry.

headline: Death Toll Rises to 300 In Guinea Earthquake
abstract: The death toll from an earthquake that hit Guinea has risen to 300 and tremors continued to shake parts of the country today, the Conakry radio reported.

headline: INVESTING; INVESTING IN WHAT YOU KNOW BEST
abstract: THE president of Remington Products, clad in a   bathrobe, holds up an electric shaver and looks  straight into the camera. ''I liked this Remington Micro Screen Rechargeable Shaver so much,'' Victor Kiam says, ''I bought the company.''  Few investors, even those with the wherewithal, would go quite as far as Mr. Kiam with his purchase of Remington in 1979. But the notion presented in his already-classic television commercial that one can use first-hand knowledge of a product to invest successfully is seductive. There are individuals whose personal knowledge of detergents, automobiles and home funishings is as good as any Wall Street analyst's. Still others become, through their work, experts on photocopiers, securities services, computers and their own lines of business. And hobbyists can become authorities on paintings, stamps or Chinese ceramics. Can they turn that to profit?

headline: OPEC to Hold Line In Tentative Pact
abstract: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries tentatively agreed today to maintain the group's prices and production quotas at current levels.    Indonesia's oil minister, Subroto, told reporters at the conclusion of a three-hour meeting this evening that ''everybody will adhere to the production ceiling, the national quotas and the price as it was stated last March in London.''   But other delegation members said potentially divisive issues remain to be discussed. They caution that the agreement to maintain OPEC's 17.5- million-barrel-a-day production ceiling and $29-a-barrel benchmark price could unravel before final acceptance by the 13-member group.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Shale-Oil Group Abandons Efforts
abstract: A group of large oil companies has disbanded an organization it created last spring to produce oil from shale, according to the Mobil Corporation, the main sponsor.   The membership, which consisted of Amoco, Chevron, Marathon, Phillips, Sohio and Texaco as well as Mobil, formed the Shale Oil Development Group last March. But some members, including Chevron, have dropped out for various reasons and the decision has been made to abandon the effort.

headline: West German Orders
abstract: The index of orders at West German manufacturing plants rose 1 percent in September, seasonally adjusted, after a 3.2 percent gain in August, the Economics Ministry said today.

headline: West German Prices
abstract: Producer prices in West Germany rose two-tenths of 1 percent in November from October, and 1.4 percent from November 1982, the Federal Statistics Office said today. The year-to-year increase compared with a 1.2 percent rise in October and 1.5 percent in September.

headline: ADVERTISING ; Van Lines Unit Goes To Doremus Chicago
abstract: North American Van Lines has switched the consumer advertising assignment for its Household Goods division to Doremus & Company in Chicago.

headline: INVESTORS ADVANCE OFFER FOR AMSTAR
abstract: The Amstar Corporation, the nation's largest refiner of cane sugar, said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to be acquired by an investor group for $47 a share, or a total of about $430 million.   The investor group is led by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, a privately owned merchant banking firm with offices in New York and San Francisco.

headline: F.C.C. RULE CHALLENGED IN SENATE
abstract: The Senate Appropriations Committee approved an amendment today that would delay for six months a proposed Federal Communications Commission order permitting television networks to own programs and control their syndication.    The networks favor the proposed rule change, which was tentatively approved by the F.C.C. on Aug. 4, because it would permit them to enter a new segment of the broadcasting industry. If allowed to do so, however, they would emerge as major competitors to the investors and producers who now sell programs to the networks and control their future use.   Today's committee action came one day before President Reagan and a Cabinet council are scheduled to review the F.C.C. decision, in which the Justice and Commerce Departments have concurred.

headline: Turks Bar Cyprus Statement
abstract: A meeting of foreign ministers of the Council of Europe ended in uproar today after Turkey vetoed publication of a final communique condemning the declaration of independence by the Turks in Cyprus. For the first time in the 34-year history of the 21-member Council, the ministers failed to agree on a final joint communique. Turkey vetoed publication of the statement despite the fact a draft version had been issued to reporters.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: New San Antonio Issue Will Yield Up to 10.5%    A $115 million issue of San Antonio electric and gas revenue bonds was offered yesterday by a Merrill Lynch Capital Markets group with a maximum yield of 10.5 percent for bonds due in 2013 and 10.4 percent for bonds due in 2008. Among serial bonds, yields ranged from 8.5 percent for bonds due in 1990, to 9.8 percent in 1998 and 10.25 percent in 2003.

headline: Rightist Death Squad Kills 4 in El Salvador
abstract: Three men and a woman, including a top leftist, were found strangled near a market in San Salvador today.   In a message tied to the arm of each victim, a right-wing death squad called the Maximiliano Hernandez Martinez Anti-Communist Brigade took responsibility for the killings.

headline: 1,200 MARINES TO QUIT ISLAND FOR BEIRUT DUTY
abstract: Defense Department officials said today that most of the 1,200 United States marines in the 6,000-member Grenada invasion force had been replaced by Army troops and would head for Lebanon in the ''next few days'' to relieve the Marine force stationed there.    Marines made up the major part of the force in the early hours of the operation. As soon as initial objectives had been achieved, 5,000 Army paratroopers from the 82d Airborne Division began moving in to relieve them.   Most of the 700 Army Rangers who participated in the initial assault also have been relieved, the Pentagon officials reported.

headline: ISRAELI OFFICIALS IN U.S. FOR TALKS ON JOINT ACTIONS
abstract: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria met with party leaders in his first publicized appearance since he was reported ill two weeks ago. Page A10.        WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 - Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Defense Minister Moshe Arens arrived in the United States tonight for talks that are expected to center on Israeli-American cooperation in the Middle East and Israeli requests for more aid.   The Prime Minister said in a brief statement on his arrival in the capital that the ''situation in Lebanon and the Syrian threat to peace'' were the most urgent issues on the agenda.

headline: Rodale Press Halts Its Spring Magazine
abstract: Rodale Press, the health-oriented Pennsylvania publishing company, will discontinue Spring, the magazine of High Energy Living, with its November/December issue, Robert J. Teufel, Rodale president, confirmed last Friday.   The magazine, whose first issue was out in April 1982, has been just missing goals set for it in both advertising and circulation so it was decided to stop it, Mr. Teufel said, at the same time giving the assurance that there will be no layoffs.   Spring had a circulation of 400,000, and its subscribers will be given the opportunity to switch to other Rodale magazines.

headline: ASSASSIN RE-ENACTS HIS STEPS BEFORE '81 SHOOTING OF POPE ROME, Oct. 18 (AP) - Mehmet Ali Agca re-enacted for Bulgarian prosecutors today his movements before he shot and wounded Pope John Paul II in St. Peter's Square on May 13, 1981.
abstract: The reconstruction was directed by an Italian judge, Ilario Martella, who has been investigating Mr. Agca and a Bulgarian, Sergei Ivanov Antontov, who is charged with complicity in the shooting.   Judge Martella and his aides did not speak with reporters at the scene. He told Mr. Agca, who is serving a life sentence for the attempted assassination of the Pope, to keep silent.

headline: Australian Jobless Rate
abstract: Australia's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose to 10.4 percent in September from 10.2 percent in August and 7.5 percent a year earlier, the Statistics Bureau reported today. Its preliminary figures showed that the number of unemployed rose to 730,400 in September from 713,100 in August and 514,800 in September 1982.

headline: ALTERNATIVE MINIMUM TAX BITES
abstract: UNLIKE 1981 and 1982, when the Reagan Administration and Congress approved major tax bills, this has not been a year for widespread tax changes. Even so, a lot of wealthy taxpayers may be unhappy when they finish their returns.    There is one major new wrinkle: the revised alternative minimum tax, which was approved in 1982 and is effective this year. And it will bite, raising an additional $700 million in the fiscal year 1984, which began Oct. 1.   ''The A.M.T. is going to catch a lot of people unaware,'' said Stanley H. Breitbard, national director of executive financial services for Price Waterhouse.

headline: Another Marine Dies, Blast's 240th Victim
abstract: A United States marine has died from injuries suffered in the Beirut bomb blast, becoming the 240th serviceman to die from the terrorist explosion, officials said today.   Lance Cpl.

headline: CPC International To Shut 2 Plants CPC International said it would phase out two of its largest plants, resulting in an after-tax charge against 1983 earnings of about $55 million. The company, based in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., is closing the plants, which will be rebuilt ahead of schedule, to accelerate a previously announced investment program.
abstract: James W. McKee Jr., the chairman and chief executive, said the move ''is prompted by our determination to speed the multiyear expansion and productivity improvement program, to pay more of its costs now rather than later, and to receive the benefits earlier.''

headline: Members End Boycott Of Parliament in Japan
abstract: Opposition politicians ended a 37-day boycott of Parliament on Friday after a compromise was reached in a dispute over the bribery conviction of former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka.   The boycott ended when the governing Liberal-Democratic Party agreed to set up a 20-member ''political ethics council'' to review measures to guard against corruption.

headline: BLACK CHALLENGE TO PRETORIA: REBELLION,STILL PUNY, IS SHOWING MORE MUSCLE
abstract: The South African authorities seem constantly torn between an urge to magnify the threat posed to the white Government by the underground African National Congress and a desire to belittle it.    At home, the white minority is warned it is facing an ''onslaught'' that is likely to make urban terrorism and rural insurgency a permanent part of its experience.   Abroad, South Africa writes off the Congress movement - which was banned 23 years ago, after nearly half a century of futile nonviolent protest - as ''a small clique of blacks and whites,'' as Prime Minister P. W. Botha put it in an interview, that is ''controlled by the Kremlin.''  A Contradictory Reality    The contradictory perceptions distort a contradictory reality. From a military standpoint, the African National Congress has been one of the world's least successful ''liberation movements.'' After more than two decades of armed struggle, it is still restricted to infiltrating across South Africa's borders in tiny bands - two, threes and fives - and recruiting on a small scale, to limit the number of police spies it takes into its ranks.  But its desultory bombing campaign, which averages one incident every two weeks, has as much to do with its pre- eminent status among black nationalist movements in the country as a history that goes back 71 years - two years before the founding of the National Party, which now governs South Africa, and five years before the Bolshevik Revolution.

headline: Philippine Riot Police Block Teachers' March
abstract: Riot policemen prevented 1,500 striking school teachers from marching down a street leading to the Presidential Palace during a protest over wages and the killing of the opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

headline: Shultz Plans Visit to Brazil
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will go to Brazil on Oct. 25 to discuss cooperation between the United States and Brazil on economics, space, science and industrial, military and nuclear affairs, a State Department spokesman said today. The spokesman, John Hughes, said he did not know how long Mr. Shultz would stay in Brazil or whether he would stop in other South American countries.

headline: E.E.C.'s Steel Price Floor BRUSSELS, Dec. 23 (AP) - The European Economic Community set minimum prices today for steel in an attempt to end damaging price competition in the trade bloc's steel industry.
abstract: The price floors were set under an emergency plan adopted Thursday evening in Brussels by the industry ministers of the community's 10 member nations.   The minimum prices ordered by the community's commission are reductions from the ''guidance'' prices for steel products decided on in April.

headline: THE END OF ONE-STOP SHOPPING FOR TELEPHONES AND SERVICES Making Some Sense of the Divestiture
abstract: Q. Much of the discussion of the    A.T.& T. divestiture suggests   that it will create many problems. Does breaking up the company really make sense?     A. It is probably fair to say that none of the parties to the antitrust suit envisioned the outcome quite the way that it has turned out.    The divestiture plan that finally resulted has been criticized on many counts. Some other plan could undoubtedly have been devised, but no plan would have pleased everyone. To some, no change would seem a more attractive alternative than the current plan. But it is unlikely that the Bell System would have remained in place forever. Increased competition and other changes were beginning to occur even before the breakup was agreed upon.

headline: U.S. AND SOVIET DISCUSS WHETHER MOSCOW VIOLATED TERMS OF 2 ARMS PACTS
abstract: United States and Soviet officials in Geneva have started discussing American suggestions that the Soviet Union may have violated the terms of two arms control treaties.   The United States believes the Soviet Union may have violated provisions of the 1972 treaty limiting antiballistic missile defenses by building a huge new radar installation in Siberia and the 1979 treaty limiting strategic nuclear arms by testing more than one new intercontinental missile. The 1979 treaty has not been ratified but both sides have agreed to abide by its terms.   American officials are also concerned about encryption of electronic data broadcast from Soviet missiles during test flights. Such coding is forbidden if it would impede treaty verification.

headline: Zimbabwe Said to Arrest Son of Jailed Bishop
abstract: Philemon Muzorewa, a son of the detained former Zimbabwean Prime Minister, Bishop Abel Muzorewa, was reportedly arrested today, a spokesman for the bishop's United African National Council party said.   The spokesman said Philemon Muzorewa, 26 years old, who is not politically active, was forced into a car and driven away from his Harare home at 10 A.M. The party checked the number of the car with police and was told it belonged to Zimbabwe's secret service, the spokesman said, adding, ''We assume he has been arrested.''

headline: ALLIES BACK STAND ON GENEVA TALKS
abstract: The NATO allies said today that they would stand firm in their negotiating positions at the two sets of arms talks in Geneva and in their deployment of new American missiles in Europe.   The vows were made in the face of the Soviet Union's decision last month to suspend medium-range missile talks and its refusal today to set a new date for the resumption of negotiations on limiting strategic nuclear weapons.   Foreign ministers from the 16 North Atlantic Treaty Organization member nations met in closed session today. Spokesmen for several delegations said they stood by the communique, issued on Wednesday by the allied defense ministers, that said they ''reemphasized their support for the United States position in the talks, on which they have been kept fully informed,'' and welcomed the ''American initiatives to move the talks forward.''

headline: HRT Favors McCrory Offer LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13 (Reuters) - HRT Industries said it had decided that a stock purchase and funding offer from the McCrory Corporation is better than an earlier offer made by the Schottenstein Stores Corporation. HRT, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, said the McCrory offer is more likely to be approved by creditors, shareholders and the court.
abstract: HRT said McCrory had amended its plan to include a cash tender offer for the shares to be issued to creditors and shareholders under the reorganization plan. McCrory, a unit of the Rapid-American Corporation that operates variety and clothing stores, offered to pay the same per-share price that it would pay for the 55 percent it plans to purchase outright, HRT said. McCrory has offered $18 million for 55 percent of the issued stock, while Schottenstein, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, has offered $12 million.

headline: Some Students Decide To Remain in Grenada
abstract: Medical school students evacuated to the United States from Grenada reported tonight that although fighting continued on the island, some of their classmates have decided to stay.   ''My feeling is things have calmed down a lot,'' said Carey Gross, a Vassar graduate from Manhattan.

headline: African Leaders Seek End to War in Chad
abstract: President Ahmed Sekou Toure of Guinea began another attempt to negotiate an end to the civil war in Chad today as leaders of 38 African states began a two-day conference here with President Francois Mitterrand.

headline: Major Insurer Drops Lobby
abstract: The American Express Company has withdrawn from a lobbying group opposing unisex insurance legislation.

headline: TURNER BUYS SOLE RIVAL IN CABLE NEWS MARKET
abstract: Ted Turner, the Atlanta-based cable entrepreneur, announced yesterday that he had bought out his only challenger in the cable news business, The Satellite News Channels. The 24-hour headline service will shut down on Oct. 27 after little more than a year in operation and an estimated loss of more than $40 million.    The two owners of Satellite News, the American Broadcasting Companies and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, will receive $25 million for the venture.   ''It's a tremendous coup,'' said Paul Kagan, a cable analyst. ''Ted Turner has become the leader of cable news, so that when two companies with even greater resources came along they couldn't beat him.''

headline: ENVOYS MEET BRIEFLY ON LONG RANGE MISSILES
abstract: American and Soviet negotiators met today to discuss long-range nuclear weapons, but Western officials said Moscow might break off parallel talks on European missiles after the vote in the West German Parliament to accept the deployment of new United States nuclear forces.   Delegates to the negotiations on reducing strategic nuclear weapons met for just one hour before adjourning for a joint luncheon given by the United States negotiating team. The two sides agreed to meet again next Tuesday.

headline: $500 Million Issue By Salomon Unit
abstract: A $500 million issue of bonds collateralized by Government National Mortgage Association pass-through securities is offered through Salomon Brothers. The securities are issued by Salomon Brothers Mortgage Securities.   The $52.9 million of 10 7/8 percent bonds with an estimated average life of 1.8 years were offered at 99 7/8 to yield 10.96 percent; the $163.5 million of 11 3/4 percent bonds with a 5.4 year average life were offered at 99.31 to yield 11.93 percent; the $233.5 million of 12 percent bonds with a 10.8 year average were offered at 97 3/8 to yield 12.45 percent, and the $50 million of 12 percent bonds with a 22.3 year average were offered at 86 to yield 12.866 percent.   The bonds were rated AAA by Moody's and S.& P.

headline: CITY RETAIL SALES UP 6%
abstract: Retail sales in New York City by seven major department stores increased 6 percent in October from the year before, a spot-check found yesterday. Sales in the general metropolitan area, which includes results from the retailers' stores in the city and the suburbs, rose 7 percent.    Unseasonally warm weather hurt a major division of store business - cold-weather apparel. That was borne out by a generally spotty Columbus Day performance, retailers said. The holiday is usually one in which stores promote outerwear heavily, hoping to capitalize on the public's seasonal needs. But the relatively warm weather has not yet created the proper environment for such buying, retailers said.

headline: ARGENTINE REPORT URGES TRIAL OF EX-LEADERS
abstract: An Argentine military board has recommended that former President Leopoldo F. Galtieri, former Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez and 15 senior officers be tried for their role in last year's war against Britain for the Falkland Islands, according to a copy of the board's report published today.   The official board of six retired genrals and admirals recommended that General Galtieri, who was also Commander in Chief of the army, and Adm. Jorge Isaac Anaya, the former head of the navy, be court-martialed for crimes that carry sentences up to death, according to the report published in Siete Dias, a leading weekly, and confirmed today by a board member.   The report, which was harshest in dealing with the two commanders, said they failed to properly supply and assist the more than 9,000 servicemen on the island who were cut off by a British blockade and forced to surrender after the 11-week war in which more than 600 Argentines died.

headline: MCDONNEL TO PURCHASE HUGHES HELICOPTER UNIT
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, one of the nation's largest manufacturers of military equipment, said today that it would acquire Hughes Helicopters Inc. for about $470 million in cash.   The takeover will represent a substantial expansion of McDonnell's military contracts.   Hughes Helicopters, which is owned by the estate of the late Howard R. Hughes, is the principal supplier under a $7 billion contract to build 515 AH-64 Apache helicopters for the Army over the next six years.

headline: U.S. Surgical Auditor Resigns The United States Surgical Corporation said Ernst & Whinney had resigned as the company's independent auditor and was withdrawing its opinions from U.S. Surgical's 1981 and 1982 financial statements.
abstract: Ernst & Whinney, in its letter of resignation, said that records and statements furnished to it in a 1981 audit relating to tooling - molds and dies - were not reliable and that disclosures made to it following the audit were either late or incomplete, U.S. Surgical said in a statement.   During a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation, questions arose over whether tooling purchases were properly classified as capital expenditures.    U.S. Surgical's presdient, Leon C. Hirsch, said that the company had appointed Touche Ross & Company as its new independent auditor and that an investigation of the tooling purchases is under way. U.S. Surgical, which is based in Norwalk, Conn., and makes surgical stapling instruments, was the second-biggest percentage loser yesterday in over-the-counter trading, plunging $5.625, to $14.375.

headline: Finding on Brazil Steel
abstract: Carbon steel from Brazil is causing material injuries to American steel producers, the United States International Trade Commission said today in a preliminary finding. The finding sets off a Commerce Department investigation to determine the extent of underpricing and Brazilian Government subsidies for the steel exports.

headline: E.E.C. Backs Steel Link
abstract: The commission of the European Economic Community said today that it had authorized the British Steel Corporation and the TI Group P.L.C. to merge part of their seamless steel tube activities into a joint company. The British steel concerns will form Seamless Tubes Ltd. in a bid to remain internationally competitive for smaller-diameter hot-finished seamless tubes.

headline: Foreign Slabs Gain Hold in U.S. Market
abstract: American steel buyers are turning increasingly to foreign markets for their products and even the major domestic manufacturers, long opposed to such imports, are joining the trend.   The Kaiser Steel Corporation and the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, for example, are already significant importers. And the United States Steel Corporation, the country's largest steelmaker, has sparked a running controversy with its plan to import three million tons a year of semifinished slabs from Scotland. At the same time, the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation is bargaining for 300,000 tons from Brazil.

headline: DURABLES ORDERS UP LAST MONTH
abstract: Orders placed with factories for durable goods rose 4 percent last month, but the overall showing masked a disappointing drop for capital goods used by businesses, the Commerce Department reported today.   The report said the value of new orders rose $3.7 billion in November, to $97.1 billion.

headline: Bristol-Myers Up 17%
abstract: The Bristol-Myers Company said yesterday that its profits rose 17 percent in the third quarter, to $116.9 million, or 86 cents a share, from $99.6 million, or 74 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales increased 9 percent, to $1.03 billion, from $946.4 million.

headline: Boy Guilty in Bomb Case
abstract: A 14-year- old boy pleaded guilty today to sending Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher a letter bomb, which was defused by the police at a postal sorting office. The judge, Sir John Lloyd, accepted the plea and postponed sentencing until after Christmas so that a probation report could be prepared.

headline: Northeast Savings Stake Is Sold HARTFORD, Dec. 29 (AP) - A group of 16 investors has purchased a 5.24 percent interest in Northeast Savings. Northeast's chairman, Kent Dixon, called it the largest equity position held by individual investors. They now hold 265,200 shares of Northeast's more than 5 million shares outstanding.
abstract: According to a notice filed with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the three principals in the investment group are Alexander M. Vagliano of Norfolk, former executive vice president in charge of international banking at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York; Robert G. Wilmers, chairman and chief executive of the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo, and Brent D. Baird, general partner, Trubee Collins & Company, also of Buffalo.

headline: U.S. OFFICERS GIVE INVASION DETAILS
abstract: United States officers who served in Grenada described the invasion today as an operation mounted by a larger force than was eventually needed. They also provided new details on how news of the inadvertent bombing of a mental hospital reached the command.   Maj. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, who gave a two-hour briefing here with another army commander, said the 82d Airborne Division was originally scheduled to send in only 1,600 men, who were to relieve the initial invasion force of 1,900 marines and rangers. He said it was expected that the airborne troops would see only occupational duty because the invasion, which began on Oct. 25, would be ''a piece of cake.''

headline: POLISH DISSIDENT CHOOSES A TRIAL
abstract: Jacek Kuron, a Polish dissident, has decided to face trial on charges of plotting to overthrow Communist rule rather than accept a Government offer to emigrate, his son said today.   The son, Maciek Kuron, said after visiting his father in an Interior Ministry clinic that he had not been informed of suggestions that he should emigrate, but would refuse to do so.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Grenada Seeks Peace Corps
abstract: Grenada has asked the Peace Corps to send volunteers ''as soon as possible'' to help rebuild agricultural, health and education services, the agency said today. It is asking volunteers in the Caribbean area whether they would be willing to sign up to work in Grenada for one year so the program can start quickly, a spokesman said.

headline: UNUSUAL REHABILITATION IN THE SOUTH BRONX
abstract: If there is cheap long-term money available, people will have housing,'' said David Scharf, an experienced real estate man who is president of the Interstate Capital Company, which makes loans to small business. ''It's as simple as that.''    That belief has brought him to participate in an unusual housing venture in the South Bronx. While the project receives certain tax and mortgage relief, it is almost surely the only entrepreneurial housing venture using neither Federal subsidies nor city capital grants under way in the South Bronx. It is probably the first since the 1960's.

headline: ITALY HINTS AT PULLOUT OF ITS CONTINGENT
abstract: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of Italy indicated today that Italy may withdraw its troops from the international force in Lebanon because of the increased fighting there.    Mr. Craxi issued his statement in a meeting of European leaders here and after talks with President Francois Mitterrand.   In a brief statement, the Italian Prime Minister said: ''It is evident that if a situation based only on armed conflict prevails, our stand would need to be more clearly defined. We do not have military deterrence.''

headline: Bayer A.G. Sales Up 6%
abstract: Sales at the Bayer A.G. group rose about 6 percent in the first nine months of 1983, from $3.84 billion in the period a year earlier, a company spokesman said today.

headline: EAST GERMANY SEEKING $371 MILLION BONN LOAN
abstract: The East German Government, faced with a severe shortage of cash for its year-end debt payments to Western countries, is seeking hard-currency loans totaling the equivalent of $371.7 million from West Germany, banking sources said Thursday.    If the loans are approved, it would be the second time in six months that Bonn has stepped in with large loans to ease an acute liquidity squeeze on East Germany.   In June, Bonn agreed to guarantee the same amount of bank loans to East Germany, in what was the largest sum ever lent to the East Germans by West German banks and the first time that loans had been made without linking them to specific business deals.

headline: PATENTS
abstract: Multi-Purpose Suitcase  Three inventors have patented a multi-purpose suitcase. The invention, covered by this week's patent 4,412,604, is a composite, rectangular, molded suitcase, a table and a V-shaped ironing board.

headline: Security Link Is Denied In the Death of Briton
abstract: The Foreign Office indicated today that the death of a British banker in Moscow last June had no national security implications.   Friends of the banker, Dennis Skinner of the Midland Bank, said in Moscow on Sunday that two days before his death he gave them a note saying he knew of a Soviet agent inside the British Embassy.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN CORPORATE PERKS
abstract: For many employees, stretching a paycheck becomes more of a challenge every day. So a company compensation gimmick that amounts to a savings-such as a vacation home at discount rentals-is like money in the bank.

headline: NICARAGUA SAYS BISHOP WAS HELD AND APPARENTLY SLAIN BY REBELS
abstract: The Government said today that an American-born bishop had been kidnapped by rebels along with nearly 500 residents of a northern village. Later the Government radio said ''it appears'' that the bishop was killed by his captors.   The broadcast, by the press office of the ruling Sandinista junta, said the Government had a report that the cleric, Msgr. Salvador Schlaefer, Bishop in the Caribbean port of Bluefields, was slain early in the morning when he tried to resist his captors in the village of Wisconsin. It gave no further details but said an army detachment was being sent to investigate.

headline: COMMONWEALTH NATIONS NEAR ACCORD ON GRENADA
abstract: The Commonwealth nations were reported today to be close to a compromise agreement on what to do about the situation in Grenada, the Caribbean island invaded last month by United States-led forces.   The Commonwealth leaders, particularly those from the Caribbean nations, have been split over the Grenadian issue.   According to an official close to the discussions, a draft document on Grenada calls for withdrawal of all foreign troops from Grenada and offers to replace them with a peacekeeping force drawn from among the 12 Commonwealth countries in the Caribbean. Under the proposal, other Commonwealth countries would support the force with both money and technical help.

headline: TURKISH MILITARY LOSES IN ELECTION
abstract: In a setback for Turkey's military rulers, an independent conservative party led by an economist won a comfortable Parliamentary majority Sunday in the first elections since the generals seized power more than three years ago.    The party the military backed came in third, and three of the Cabinet ministers who ran on its ticket were defeated. Prime Minister Bulent Ulusu won a seat in Parliament by a narrow margin in Istanbul.   Turgut Ozal, the leader of the victorious Motherland Party, kept his post- election comments in a low key in a clear effort to avoid antagonizing the military rulers, who had opposed his candidacy.

headline: PRETORIA ISSUES NEW POLICY ON BLACK SCHOOLS
abstract: The South African Government pledged this week that it would move to improve educational standards for the country's black majority.    However, the policy statement in which the undertaking was announced would not dismantle racial segregation in schools, its critics said, or ease a protracted crisis over the disparities between black and white educational standards.   The crisis in South Africa's black schools has been simmering since the 1976 riots in Soweto, Johannesburg's sprawling black ghetto. Schools for blacks are generally held to be overcrowded, teachers are often poorly trained and there is a high dropout rate. There are also far fewer educational aids in schools for blacks than there are in schools for whites.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Issues    * Canada's $500 million issue of 10 7/8 percent bonds due in 1988 was priced at par, through Deutsche Bank A. G.     * Paine Webber Inc.'s Programmed Amortization Term Securities Inc. subsidiary filed for an offering of $500 million of G.N.M.A.-collateralized bonds series, 1983-1, through Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc.  Debt Ratings   * Public Service of New Mexico's ratings on its first mortgage bonds and collateralized industrial revenue bonds were lowered to A-, from A, by the Standard & Poor's Corp., which also lowered the company's ratings on its preferred stock and uncollateralized pollution control bonds to BBBx, from A-, and its commercial paper to A-2, from A-1.     * Uniroyal's rating on its Ardmore, Okla., industrial revenue bonds was raised to Ba-2, from B-1, by Moody's Investors Service, which also raised Uniroyal's rating on its 5 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures to B-1, from B-3. Moody's said the change affects about $124 million in debt.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Inflation Storm Warnings   Most economists are confident that no new outbreak of high inflation lies ahead, the consensus predicting only a modest acceleration of prices by 5 percent or so for 1984. But a significant minority rejects such optimism for the year ahead.   One of these is Milton Friedman, the monetarist, who has argued for some time that strong money-supply growth during the first half of this year has already made a new surge of inflation inevitable.  Now he's joined by Geoffrey H. Moore, director of the Columbia Business School's Center for International Business Cycle Research. Mr.  Moore's new index designed to foretell inflation is flashing a warning.  The index consists of only three components: the annual rate of change in prices of industrial materials, the change in total outstanding debt and the ratio of employed workers to the working-age population.

headline: AFTER THE SLAUGHTER, A MARINE SENTRY RECALLS SMILING FACE OF THE KILLER
abstract: As the suicide truck burst through the iron gate protecting the Marine headquarters here on Sunday, one of the Marine guards caught a fleeting glimpse of the terrorist behind the wheel. Afterward he could remember only one thing about him: He had a big smile on his face.   Lance Cpl. Robert Calhoun was in an observation post on the roof of the four- story Marine headquarters when the Mercedes truck came rumbling through. The building was blown out from under him, and he rode the roof right down to the ground in a landslide of sandbags and concrete.

headline: G.M.'S NEW ANSWER TO JAPAN
abstract: The General Motors Corporation today displayed the prototype of a small car intended to someday match similar Japanese cars in cost and match or exceed them in quality.    G.M.'s slickly packaged glimpse of its so-called Saturn Project - a subcompact to be manufactured late in the 1980's - was evidently intended to refute charges by competitors and the United Automobile Workers union that the company was planning to stop making small cars altogether in the United States because it couldn't develop a subcompact competitive with Japanese cars.   G.M. officials said they anticipate that a new manufacturing system they have designed to produce the Saturn car will cut production costs sufficiently to bring them close to those of the Japanese. One executive noted that because it costs $500 to ship a car from Japan, G.M. needs only to trim $1,500 from its current costs to match the Japanese.

headline: CURRENCY INTEREST RATES
abstract: rates Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.79    An index of yields for long-term   A-rated general obligation bonds   compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds*13.13    Salomon Brothers' estimate for new   long-term issues.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Lehman Loses Merger Officer    Eric J. Gleacher, who helped found the mergers and acquisitions department at Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. in 1978, has gone over to the competition at Morgan Stanley & Company.

headline: STATE DEPT. CITES CONFUSION FOR FALSE REPORT ON MASS GRAVE
abstract: The assertion that more than 100 bodies had been discovered on Grenada, and the denial a day later, were the result of confusion and a lack of communication among officials in Washington and others on the Caribbean island, State Department officials said today.    ''The communications between here and there aren't always great,'' a department spokesman said. ''Apparently there was some lack of communication between here and there.''   The initial report came from Grenada and said that the bodies may have included that of former Prime Minister Maurice Bishop.
