Later a reporter was told by a high-ranking United States official that the report was correct.

headline: DOUBTS IN MOSCOW ON BRITON'S DEATH
abstract: Shortly before 9 A.M. on June 17, Dennis G. Skinner, a 54-year-old British banker, was found dead after a fall to the sidewalk from his 12th-story apartment on Moscow's Leninsky Prospekt.    Accounts of the incident that circulated in the British community here at the time suggested it was a suicide, possibly related to loneliness and depression brought on by 15 years' work in Moscow.   But today a British couple living here disclosed to reporters that two days before his death Mr. Skinner approached them with a note that said he knew of a spy for the Soviet Union in the British Embassy and that his life was in danger. The existence of the note was then confirmed by sources at the British Embassy, who said it had been forwarded to authorities in England for presentation at the inquest into Mr. Skinner's death.

headline: U.S. AIDES, PLEASED BY RAID, DENY JOINT PLANNING
abstract: Reagan Administration officials expressed satisfaction today with the Israeli bombing attack on a pro-Iranian group in Lebanon. The group is believed to have been involved in the terrorist attacks on American, French and Israeli forces in Lebanon.   But the State Department insisted that there had been no coordination by Israel and the United States in carrying out the raid. They said the Israelis had not informed Washington ahead of time about the attack and had not been asked by the United States to do it.

headline: 7 BRITISH PAPERS BACK ON STREETS
abstract: Seven of Britain's nine major national newspapers were back on the streets tonight after a three-day printers' dispute. But the two others - The Sun and The Times - said they would not resume publication until the printers promised to work normally.   The printers went out Friday in a dispute that began over the hiring of nonunion labor at a small plant in northwestern England five months ago and that has become a test of the Conservative Government's new laws to curb union power.

headline: AROUND THE WORLD
abstract: Pakistanis Charge 22 Were Slain by Army    ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Oct. 20 (Reuters) - An opposition spokesman said today that Government troops backed by helicopter gunships had killed 22 people in Pakistan's troubled Sind Province, but the Government said the report was not true. (A Government spokesman at the Pakistan Embassy in Washington said the Pakistanis did not have helicopter gunships.)

headline: IVORY COAST HAILS THE CHIEF BUT ASKS: WHAT'S NEXT?
abstract: One day late last month, a gleaming white Concorde suddenly appeared in the skies over this West African capital.    When it landed at Port-Bouet Airport a few minutes later, a small man in a buff-colored three-piece suit emerged and descended the steps to a long red carpet.   Columns of soldiers and sailors froze to attention. A military band began to play, a cheering crowd waved small orange, white and green flags - the same flags that had been draped from every streetlight in town - and a television announcer, his voice trembling, proclaimed: ''The President is here! The President has arrived!''

headline: Jersey Bank Link
abstract: Midlantic Banks Inc. said the board of First Peoples Bank of New Jersey had approved a definitive agreement for its acquisition by Midlantic for about $43 million.

headline: Bomb Kills 2 Lebanese
abstract: Two Lebanese were killed when a bomb they were making went off by the coast road near the Lebanese port of Tyre, the military command said today. The Israeli radio quoted Lebanese radio reports as saying Israeli troops had made several arrests after the bomb blew up Friday night.

headline: SOVIET OIL TOOL CURBS RULED OUT
abstract: The Reagan Administration, ignoring the recommendation of an interagency advisory group made shortly after the Sept. 1 destruction of a South Korean airliner, has decided against tightening controls over exports of oil and gas equipment to the Soviet Union, Administration officials said today.   The decision signals a reluctance to put further bars on trade with the Russians, and helps the United States avoid new trade frictions, such as those arising from last year's sanctions against selling equipment for construction of the natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe.   Currently, the Administration restricts the sale of most high-technology equipment to the Soviet Union. But the Administration has permitted the sale of some pipeline construction equipment, such as conventional drilling rigs, that involve less advanced technology. Most recently, equipment to help lay pipelines has been removed from the restricted list.

headline: Omnimedical President
abstract: The Omnimedical Corporation, a medical scanner maker, said it had retained a management consulting firm to help improve financial performance, and had appointed a new president to replace Ronald L. Stoddart, who resigned. Gary R. Mounts, chairman, replaced him.

headline: CRUISE LINE EXECUTIVE MOVES TO COSTA AS CHIEF
abstract: Howard A. Fine, who until last week was president of New York- based Norwegian American Cruises, has been named president and chief executive officer of Miami-based Costa Cruises Inc.   Mr. Fine, who steps into a newly created post at Costa, had his former responsibilities sold out from under him.

headline: BRITISH PRESS DISPUTE: MORE THAN FLEET STREET AT STAKE
abstract: New talks are to begin Monday in the industrial dispute that led last weekend to the temporary closing of all of Britain's national newspapers and this week to the worst outbreak of picket-line violence in the country since 1979.  The labor unrest, it is widely agreed, has its roots in one of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's most important initiatives: her effort to limit trade-union power. It has therefore become a legal, industrial and political test case, with implications extending far beyond Fleet Street.    One of the biggest factors in Mrs. Thatcher's victory in May 1979 was popular resentment over strikes by public employees in the preceding months - strikes that led to crises in some hospitals and to the appearance of mounds of uncollected trash and garbage in the streets. The failure of the Labor Party under James Callaghan, who was then Prime Minister, to avoid what was called the winter of discontent gave Mrs. Thatcher's promises of changes in the trade-union movement wide appeal.

headline: CONGRESS APPROVES I.M.F. AID
abstract: Ending months of uncertainty and partisan bickering, Congress today gave final approval to an increase of $8.4 billion in American support for the International Monetary Fund.   The approval, awaited eagerly abroad, will permit additional lending to economically troubled third world countries. It virtually assures that an agreement of last February to increase the resources of the 146-nation lending agency by more than $40 billion will be put into effect on Nov. 30.   Eighty-three other countries had already ratified the accord. Others were waiting for the United States and are now expected to move swiftly through their own parliamentary procedures.

headline: LEADER'S BROTHER FREED IN COLOMBIA
abstract: The brother of President Belisario Betancur of Colombia was freed early today, 15 days after being kidnapped by leftist guerrillas.   The guerrillas of the National Liberation Army released Jaime Betancur after pleas from world leaders, including Pope John Paul II; Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader; Javier Perez de Cuellar, the Secretary General of the United Nations, and the ruling junta of Nicaragua.   Mr. Castro said in a letter that the kidnapping was ''against revolutionary ethics'' and he rejected the rebel group's claim to follow Cuban revolutionary ideals.

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: Telesphere's Staff Is Cut After Loss    Telesphere International Inc. said yesterday that it was reducing its payroll by 120 employees, or 28 percent, and that it lost $6.9 million in the fiscal third quarter. Telesphere, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill., also said high-level managers had voluntarily accepted substantial salary reductions.

headline: ADVERTISING ; Grey Net Up by 23.1%; Doyle Dane Posts Loss
abstract: Grey Advertising and Doyle Dane Bernbach announced third-quarter earnings yesterday. Grey was up 23.1 percent, while D.D.B. showed a net loss, as it did in the same period a year ago.

headline: SPLIT IS REPORTED IN KISSINGER PANEL OVER SALVADOR AID
abstract: Henry A. Kissinger, chairman of the Presidential commission on Central America, has clashed with some Democrats on the panel who favor making new American aid to El Salvador conditional on an end to right-wing death- squad violence, commission officials said today.    A commission spokesman, Herbert Hetu, said that while no final recommendations had been drafted, the group was expected to propose a large new aid program for Central America in its report to President Reagan early in January. Other commission officials said the aid package could total several billion dollars over 5 to 10 years.   These officials, speaking on condition that they not be identified, said several Democrats on the 12-member commission had asserted that American aid to El Salvador should be linked to a halt in right-wing death squads. But they said that former Secretary of State Kissinger, among others, had argued that since El Salvador was of vital interest to the United States, aid should not be made conditional.

headline: THE NEW ALLURE OF MANUFACTURING
abstract: WATERLOO, Iowa    WHEN Deere & Company decided in 1974 to build a new tractor assembly plant in the rolling farm country of northeast Iowa, the mandate from top management was to build one at the leading edge of manufacturing technology.   That leading edge turned out to be ''flexible manufacturing,'' a technology born a decade ago that is finally beginning to transform the factory floors of some of the nation's largest companies. It's a marriage of robots and computers that might have allowed Henry Ford to turn out Model T's and Model A's almost simultaneously on the same assembly line.   At Deere, the mix includes 10 different models of tractor transmissions and 5,000 configurations of tractors. ''We ended up with features in there we never even dreamed of at the start,'' said Robert W. Boeke, a senior vice president at Deere. ''We didn't realize then that you could tie the different computers in the plant together and drive the whole thing.''

headline: Whose Deficit?
abstract: To the Business Editor:   Robert Eisner makes some commendable points in his article, ''Will the Real Deficit Please Stand Up?'' (Sept. 25), but one he missed should be brought to your readers' attention.   He cites the oft-made argument that Government debt may be construed as an asset since, ''the more we all own in Government bonds, other things being equal, the wealthier we are likely to feel.''

headline: TURMOIL CAPSIZES ISRAEL'S ECONOMY
abstract: No sooner had Israel's new Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, been sworn into office than the nation's worst economic crisis in years hit like a storm. Widespread fear that the Government would institute a 50 percent devaluation of the Israeli shekel had created panic buying of dollars and dumping of the usually stable bank stocks on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange. The Government reacted swiftly. It shut down the exchange, halted all foreign currency trading and a day later devalued the shekel by 23 percent. It also cut subsidies on basic foodstuffs in half and promised to support the value of the bank shares. Such austerity measures were cheered by some and scorned by others. Israelis flooded stores, buying up goods before the devaluation took effect, and many called for the resignation of Finance Minister Yoram Aridor, whose economic policies have been under attack for months. Late in the week, Mr. Aridor did indeed resign after the Shamir Cabinet rejected his plan to replace the shekel with the dollar as the currency for salaries, budgets and prices.

headline: MOSCOW PREPARES A-ARMS IN EUROPE
abstract: The Soviet Union said today that preparations were under way in East Germany and Czechoslovakia for the stationing of tactical nuclear weapons there if the United States and its allies deploy new missiles in Western Europe.   ''These steps are of the nature of one of the planned response measures in case the American missiles are sited in Europe,'' said the Soviet announcement, which was was issued by the Defense Ministry and was made public by the official press agency Tass.   The Soviet announcement said the new missiles ''are directed at maintaining the equilibrium in the nuclear systems between the Warsaw Pact and NATO in Europe.'' Similar statements were published by Tass from the East German National Defense Council and the Czechoslovak Government.

headline: $65.2 Million Issue For Mobile, Ala. A $65.2 million Mobile, Ala., general obligation refunding warrant issue was tenatively priced with yields ranging from 5.75 percent to 11 percent yesterday by E. F. Hutton.
abstract: The issue was rated A by Moody's and triple-A by S.& P. The issue is insured by the Municipal Bond Insurance Association on all maturities except for the term warrants due in 2007.   The serial bond warrants mature from 1984 through 1993.

headline: Peugeot Plans Plant Closing
abstract: Peugeot,   the financially troubled French   auto maker, said it would proceed with a plan to shut its Talbot car plant in France, and   terminate 7,000 jobs.

headline: U.S Says Soviet Ship Menaced Search Boat
abstract: A Soviet intelligence ship menaced a Japanese ship participating in the search for the remains of a downed South Korean airliner, Pentagon officials said today.   Three days ago the Japanese ship, Kaiko Maru 3, was held at bay for 20 minutes in international waters until a United States warship appeared and sent radio messages warning the Soviet ship to retreat, the officials said.

headline: Marine Casualties In Beirut Attack
abstract: The Defense Department today identified these casualties of the artillery attack on marines Sunday in Lebanon, completing the identification:      Killed BIDDLE, Cpl.

headline: Washington State Mortgage Bonds
abstract: The Washington State Housing Fi=?nance Corporation entered the credit markets with a $193.5 million issue of mortgage-revenue bonds sold through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

headline: New Option Expirations
abstract: Beginning today, the three exchanges that trade stock index options will expand the series of expiration months.

headline: Market Place; Strong Revival For Car Parts
abstract: WHEN the nation's Big Three automobile makers report their third-quarter earnings later this month, Wall Street expects comparisons with last year's period to be quite spectacular. Meanwhile, profits are climbing for those companies that supply automotive replacement parts, as well as original equipment.   Last week, for example, Echlin Inc. announced earnings of 52 cents a share for its fourth quarter ended Aug. 31, against 35 cents a share in the same period last year.   Echlin produces replacement parts for electrical, brake and fuel systems. With investors apparently anticipating heftier profits, Echlin's shares recently traded at a record price of 24 7/8 on the New York Stock Exchange, up from a low of 10 1/2 early last year. Yesterday, Echlin closed at 22 7/8, unchanged.

headline: SANTA FE CLIMBS 2.9%
abstract: Two major railroads planning to merge reported higher income yesterday for their third quarters.    The Southern Pacific Company reported a 73.4 percent increase in third-quarter net income. Santa Fe Industries, which intends to merge with Southern Pacific in a $5.2 billion stock swap, reported a 2.9 percent increase in profit for the quarter.

headline: PatentsStacy V. Jones Improving Production Of DNA
abstract: WASHINGTON CHEMICAL reagents invented by two scientists at the University of Colorado in Boulder are described as accelerating the production and increasing the purity of DNA, the basic raw material of genetic engineering.   Marvin H. Caruthers and Serge L. Beaucage were granted patent 4,415,732 and assigned it to University Patents Inc. of Norwalk, Conn.

headline: BACHE AGAIN CENSURED FOR BROKER MISDEEDS
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today censured Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. for violating the agency's margin rules and failing to properly supervise a stockbroker who, the agency charged, was involved in multimillion-dollar stock frauds.   The agency's action was the third time in the past 18 months that it has accused Prudential-Bache of failing to properly supervise its employees. Bache settled today's case by consenting to the agency's censure and agreeing to tighten supervision of its brokers. It neither admitted nor denied the charges.

headline: Mesa's Gulf Fee
abstract: T. Boone Pickens Jr., chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, has agreed to pay Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb a $1 million fee - and possibly as much as $7.5 million - for advice in a proxy fight against the Gulf Oil Corporation, filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission showed. A 15-page agreement disclosed that Mesa would pay the first $1 million as a retainer by next July. The rest would become due, among other reasons, if a group headed by Mr. Pickens makes a profit on a nearly 18-million-share block of Gulf stock it owns or if Mesa is taken over.

headline: U.S. GETS REPORTS OF DEATH THREATS FROM CUBA AGAINST AMERICANS
abstract: The United States said today that it had received intelligence reports of death threats emanating from Cuba against Americans in Latin America and elsewhere in retaliation for the invasion of Grenada.   State Department officials said they had warned Cuba that they viewed such reports with ''the gravest concern.''

headline: U.S. Team to Study 'Yellow Rain' Reports
abstract: The United States has formed a team to investigate the reported use of chemical weapons in Southeast Asia and Afghanistan by the Soviet Union and its allies, a United States Embassy spokesman said Saturday.   The three-man team, based in the embassy here, will evaluate reports of the use of chemical and biological weapons and interview reputed victims of such attacks, the spokesman said.

headline: Rain Kills 26 in India
abstract: Heavy rain in the southern state of Tamil Nadu, over 15 inches in some areas, killed at least 26 people today and left thousands homeless, the Press Trust of India news agency said. Most of the deaths occurred when rain- soaked mud walls of houses and huts collapsed on their inhabitants, it said. The state capital, Madras, received 6.8 inches of rain, but that area is recovering from a drought and the water was welcome.

headline: DICKEY-JOHN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
abstract: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **

headline: SWEDES SIEZE 2D SHIPMENT OF EQUIPMENT
abstract: Swedish customs officials have found a second consignment of goods believed to be part of a highly advanced American-made computer system that the Reagan Administration says was being smuggled to the Soviet Union.   Bjorn Eriksson, general director of the Customs Authority, said three cases of equipment that arrived in the port of Malmo in the last few days were being investigated by his officers.   Government computer experts today bagn examining four containers of equipment that arrived in the neighboring port of Helsingborg two weeks ago from South Africa to determine whether it included war materials.   Another part of the same shipment consisting of three comtainers was seized Nov. 11 on a Swedish vessel in Hamburg, West Germany, at the behest of United States officials who said they were being sumggled to the Soviet Union in violation of the Export Control Act, which bans shipments of munitions, armaments and critical technology to Moscow.

headline: G.M. Model Delay
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said a shortage of parts from suppliers would delay the start-up of production and sales of 1984 model A-body cars for one to three months. The company's new front-wheel-drive station wagon model was due to go on sale Sept. 22, but the shortage will cause a delay until the first week of November. Low dealer inventories are expected until late January.

headline: Profits Scoreboard

Chrysler to Buy Preferred Back DETROIT, Dec. 8 (Reuters) - The Chrysler Corporation said today that it plans to repurchase an unspecified number of its $2.75 cumulative preferred shares through Salomon Brothers Inc. if they become available at prices Chrysler considers attractive.
abstract: Chrysler, which has about 10 million shares of the preferred outstanding, said no purchases will be made before it pays a dividend to holders of the stock by Dec. 15.   The company is required to redeem 300,000 of the shares each year, starting June 15, 1984, pursuant to a mandatory sinking fund. Chrysler said it might use some of the repurchased stock to satisfy 1984 and future sinking fund requirements.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: People     *  Michael D. Donahue has been promoted to executive vice president at Dancer Fitzgerald Sample Inc.     *  David H. Wolf has been named a senior vice president at Henderson & Friedlich.

headline: Texaco North Sea
abstract: Texaco Inc. said its Texaco North Sea U.K. subsidiary will acquire a 1 percent stake in the Forties field in the North Sea from the British Petroleum Company. The cost was not disclosed.

headline: Argentine Designs On Gibraltar Reported
abstract: The Spanish Foreign Minister today confirmed a British newspaper report that a group of Argentines had been caught in Spain while apparently planning an attack on the British colony of Gibraltar during the 1982 war between Britain and Argentina in the Falkland Islands.   The minister, Fernando Moran, said in an interview that ''a group of Argentines attempted to cross into Gibraltar presumably with the intention of carrying out some acts of war.''

headline: HUMAN RIGHTS ORGANIZATION SAYS ABUSES ARE USED FOR PROPAGANDA
abstract: Amnesty International charged today that some governments use human rights as a propaganda ploy while covering up abuses in their own countries or in allied nations.   The United States and the Soviet Union were among countries criticized for such reputed manipulations of public opinion in the London-based group's annual report, made public today.   Amnesty International, which won a Nobel Peace Prize in 1977 for its human rights work, outlined the charges in the introduction to its 351-page ''Amnesty International Report 1983,'' which covers thousands of reports of rights abuses in 1982.   The report said, ''Governments, news media and other institutions have used human rights issues in polemical attacks on other nations while deliberately giving inaccurate public assessments of progress on human rights by their allies.''

headline: BILL HELPS CANADA'S RAILROADS
abstract: Canada's Parliament on Monday is scheduled to replace an 87-year-old law that has generated billions of dollars in operating losses for the nation's railroads by restricting what they can charge to haul grain.   Over the objections of opposition parties, the governing Liberal Party of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau will give final reading to a bill raising the current average rate that the nation's railroads may charge to ship a ton of grain to market to $25, from the current $4.89.   Under the current rate schedule, CP Rail, a unit of Canadian Pacific Ltd. and the nation's biggest railroad, has lost more than $1.2 billion (Canadian) on grain hauling since 1970 alone - $200 million of which came last year. The Government-owned Canadian National Railway Company, the country's other transcontinental railway, has also been losing money on grain shipments.

headline: JAPAN POLITICS IN A QUANDRY OVER MORALITY
abstract: He will probably never make it into Bartlett's ''Familiar Quotations,'' but Akira Hatano may have earned himself a niche in Japanese political lore with a recent comment on political morality.    ''To ask a politician for classic virtue such as honesty and purity,'' he said, ''is like asking for fish at the vegetable store.''   In some places, that sort of observation would have been dismissed as nothing more than the obvious. But this country has been preoccupied - almost obsessed, some feel - with political ethics since mid-October, when former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka was convicted of taking bribes.

headline: GRENADIANS' TOLL PUTS BY U.S. AT 21
abstract: American officials here said today that a total of 21 Grenadians had been killed in the United States-led invasion of this Caribbean island. But they left open the possibility that the toll might be higher because some of 42 unidentified bodies now presumed to be those of Cubans might actually be Grenadians.   The figure of 21 Grenadians was announced hours after it was announced that a military transport plane had flown the 42 bodies to Barbados, where they were to be shipped to Cuba for forensic examination.   Maj. Gen. Jack B. Farris, commander of American forces here, said today of the 42 bodies that ''some number of that number may also be Grenadians.''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Chilean-Argentine Quake
abstract: An earthquake measuring 5.8 on the Richter scale struck the Chilean-Argentine border area on Wednesday, a National Earthquake Information Service spokesman said today. The spokesman, Russ Needham, said the quake struck at 9:22 P.M. mountain standard time. It was centered 120 miles north of Santiago.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: Left Holding the Bonds   Holders of Washington Public Power Supply System bonds - particularly those who own defaulted bonds of the system's Projects 4 and 5 - are getting increasingly restless. Bondholder groups are springing up across the country to push for some means of making good on the $2.25 billion debt on the two plants, the largest municipal bond default in history. And their voices are beginning to be heard - along with others, like that of a special Washington-Oregon commission, which on Thursday recommended a surcharge on electric power in the Northwest.   In New York, there is the Ad Hoc WPPSS 4 & 5 Bondholders Protective Committee. In Chicago, there is the Washington Public Power Supply System Bondholders Association. And on Wednesday Chemical Bank, trustee for the bondholders, held the first meeting of its newly appointed Bondholders' Advisory Committee.

headline: I.B.M. Cuts Back Josephson Project
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation said it significantly reduced its Josephson technology research program and is reassigning most of those workers involved to other high-speed computer technology projects.   The decision was the result of progress in other high-speed technologies, which has narrowed the performance advantage offered by the Josephson technology, I.B.M, said.   I.B.M. will continue to do research in super-conductivity and super-conducting devices, of which the Josephson device is one example.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: American Express Adds to IDS Bid By Reuters
abstract: The American Express Company will add a 10-year, $40 million note to the price for the proposed purchase of the Alleghany Corporation's Investors Diversified Services unit, the companies said. They said that the note would be added to the previously announced cash and stock transaction to offset the impact of the decline of about 15 percent in the price of American Express stock since the deal was announced in September. Yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, American Express rose 75 cents, to $32.375.

headline: Talking Businesswith Terrier of General Electric 5% Dollar Drop Is Forecast
abstract: In recent weeks, the value of the dollar on foreign exchange markets has receded from its record high levels against major foreign currencies. The dollar has experienced declines in the last year, only to rebound. But a growing number of foreign exchange managers and currency forecasters expect the current trend to continue.   Among those who are looking for a further downward correction in the value of the dollar in the next year to 18 months is J. Robert Terrier, manager of foreign affiliate financing at the General Electric Company. Mr. Terrier's group oversees foreign exchange transactions amounting to about $1 billion annually.

headline: Unions Challenge Continental Filing
abstract: The Airline Pilots Association, along with the two other unions on strike against Continental Air Lines, filed court papers seeking to dismiss the company's Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition, a pilots' union official said.   The official, Martin Martinez, said the unions' filing charged that Continental's action was made in bad faith and seeks to abrogate existing contract agreements.   A Continental spokesman, Bruce Hicks, said the company was confident of its legal position.

headline: WOOING THE CORPORATE TRAVELER
abstract: The nation's major airlines have discovered that most business travelers - or at least the companies that pay their expenses - like discount fares as much as vacation travelers who pay their own way. An estimated 85 percent of all domestic air travel this year was at a discount, and carrier executives are determined to reduce this as sharply as competition will allow.   ''The business traveler is the heaviest user of airline transportation,'' said Thomas J. Kiernan, vice president, marketing administration, for American Airlines. He said that the business traveler is a repeat customer. ''While the leisure and business markets are roughly equal at 49 percent and 51 percent of the total airline traffic respectively, only 36 percent of passengers account for that 51 percent of business travel. So whatever happens to the airline industry in total will be magnified in its effects on the business traveler in 1984.''

headline: Haig to Advise Amway On Foreign Operations
abstract: Alexander M. Haig Jr., former Secretary of State, has added the Amway Corporation to the list of companies for which he is a consultant.   Mr. Haig, who also used to be the commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as a four-star general, will advise Amway on entering possible new international markets and will help to study factors involved in possible manufacturing activity outside the United States and Canada, the company said.

headline: EX-AFGHAN ENVOY RELAYS REPORT OF MASSACRE OF 126 BY RUSSIANS
abstract: A former Afghan diplomat asserted today that Soviet troops massacred 126 villagers in southeastern Afghanistan last week.   The former diplomat, quoting survivors of the attack, said women and children were bayoneted. The account could not be independently confirmed.

headline: CHASE, FOR $308 MILLION TO BUY ROCHESTER BANK
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase Lincoln First Banks Inc., a large Rochester-based bank holding company, for $308 million.     The deal would represent the biggest acquisition in the history of Chase, the nation's third-largest bank holding company, with assets of $80 billion. It would also give Chase the biggest branch network in the state, edging out Citibank. The 135 branches of Lincoln First, which has total assets of $4 billion, would increase Chase's total to 328, compared with Citibank's 315.

headline: Vietnam Moves Troops Into Thai Border Area
abstract: Vietnam has moved troops, tanks and armored personnel carriers into an area near the eastern border of Thailand and is apparently preparing to attack Cambodian guerrillas, Thai military officials said today.

headline: Zimbabwe Threatens To Seize Whites' Land
abstract: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe has threatened to confiscate white-owned land for the resettlement of peasants if Britain refuses to give promised compensation.

headline: 21 Killed in Thai Bus Crash
abstract: A total of 21 people were killed and 40 were injured today when a bus collided with a motorcycle and then struck another bus. The police in Yasothon, 370 miles northeast of Bangkok, said the bus was headed for Ubon when it hit the motorcycle, killing the rider. The bus then tried to speed from the scene of the accident and hit another bus.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: ADT has named Anthony J. Grosso vice president of national accounts.     *  American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., has appointed Kim F. Wilson president of its newly established Davis & Geck ivision.

headline: South Africa Price Data
abstract: Consumer prices in South Africa rose by five-tenths of 1 percent in November from October and 10.6 percent from November 1982, according to the Government's Central Statistics Services. November's figures indicated a slight downward trend in South Africa's inflation rate. Consumer prices moved up by 10.7 percent in the year to October 1983 and by 1 percent in October from September.

headline: Kodak to Lay Off 400 Employees
abstract: The Eastman Kodak Company will lay off 200 workers in Rochester and 200 more in Windsor, Colo., because fewer employees than expected took advantage of a voluntary retirement and separation incentive plan, the company said.

headline: INDIA'S TRAINING PROGRAMS SEEK TO WIN INFLUENCE
abstract: India, despite its own problems of poverty and underdevelopment, is becoming an important donor of economic and technical assistance to other developing nations.    Although India's development assistance may not seem large in financial terms when compared with Western contributions, the programs that India sponsors are far-reaching, according to aid experts here.   These projects are intended to increase the influence of New Delhi among third world nations. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is now chairman of the group of nations calling themselves the nonaligned movement.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: *  Broadchild Securities Corp., an affiliate of D. H. Blair & Co., has appointed John T. Moran president.     *  Corroon & Black of New York Inc.  has promoted Anthony J. Romano to senior vice president.

headline: More Than 600 Vietnamese Reach Indonesia on Freighter
abstract: More than 600 Vietnamese have arrived in Indonesia aboard one of the biggest refugee vessels to leave Vietnam since the exodus of 1979, a United Nations official said today.   Philippe Labreveux, head of the Jakarta office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said 605 refugees landed Oct. 17 at Galang Island near Singapore aboard a 500-ton freighter.

headline: Addendum
abstract: * Newsweek magazine increasing its advertising rates 5.5 percent, starting with the Jan. 2 issue.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Accounts     * Addressograph Farrington Inc., Randolph, Mass., to Provandie & Chirurg Inc., Boston.

headline: Mitterrand in Yugoslavia
abstract: President Francois Mitterrand of France began a three-day visit to Yugoslavia today. He was met at Belgrade airport by President Mika Spiljak and Prime Minister Milka Planinc.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Stock Move Profitable For Value Line's Chief    Arnold Bernhard's decision to take his investment advisory service public last May has paid off so far. The stock price of Value Line Inc. has doubled since then, and Mr. Bernhard finds himself a much wealthier man on paper.   Mr. Bernhard and his family own 8.1 million shares of Value Line. The stock was first sold to the public at $17, and is now trading in the over- the-counter market at $34.50. That gives the Bernhards' holdings a value of close to $280 million.

headline: Hughes Satellite
abstract: Hughes Communications Galaxy Inc. asked the Government for permission to build and operate a new type of communications satellite with several times the data capacity of those now in use.

headline: LABOR ORGANIZER WITH A TALL DREAM
abstract: For Lech Walesa, this has been a difficult year.    The one-time unemployed electrician who rose to become an international figure, the embodiment of the dreams of millions of Poles for a better life, emerged from 11 months of solitary confinement last fall to find his Solidarity union crushed by martial law. He had thrilled crowds and negotiated with the Government; he had even met, virtually as an equal, with the heads of the two institutions that dominate Poland - the Communist Party and the Roman Catholic Church. Now, the Government said, he was a has-been, the ''former head of a former union.''

headline: THINKING BIG AT QUALITY INNS
abstract: Robert C. Hazard Jr. enjoys telling folks here about the party he threw last fall in New Orleans. He filled a fleet of silver limousines with 996 formally attired guests, threw in a motorcycle escort and drove the whole show into the Superdome. He rolled out a real red carpet. Champagne flowed. Henry Mancini led the orchestra.    Mr. Hazard says the bash cost almost $350,000, but his guests, most of them franchisees of Quality Inn hotels and motels, had a ball. ''For a day,'' he says, ''we made them feel like kings.''

headline: Metromedia's Founder Begins New Challenge At the age of 68, John W. Kluge is taking Metromedia Inc. on yet another financial adventure.
abstract: Mr. Kluge and four of Metromedia's top executives, along with the investment firm of Boston Ventures Ltd. Partnership, plan to take the big communications company private by purchasing it for $1.6 billion.   Metromedia is Mr. Kluge's creation. He was born in Germany and worked his way through Columbia University before starting out on his business career, first in the paper business and then in radio station management.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM; FOREIGN SECRECY: A KEY TO THE LOCK
abstract: IN 1981, the Securities and Exchange Commission sued ''unknown purchasers'' who bought Santa Fe International securities just before the announcement of its merger with Kuwait Petroleum. The unknown investors, purchasing through Swiss banks, made over $6 million in a few days. Insider trading was charged, but for two years this litigation has stalled while the S.E.C. attempts to identify the purchasers whose names are shielded by Swiss secrecy laws.   This is but one example where foreign secrecy and blocking laws have impeded the S.E.C.'s efforts to police the internationalized United States securities markets. And the problem is not unique to the S.E.C. It affects a host of Federal agencies and occurs in cases involving antitrust violations, tax fraud - such as is alleged in the Marc Rich case - and private civil litigation.  This is no small problem. The dollar and the integrity of our capital markets stand at the center of world economic order. Stock and bond purchases in the United States by foreign persons or institutions have more than doubled in four years, to $53 billion in 1982. Our markets also are an important source of capital for foreigners. About 250 foreign issuers and 25 foreign governments have securities registered with the S.E.C.

headline: Bank Inquiry
abstract: First National Bank of Midland has disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Comptroller of the Currency are investigating the bank to determine whether it adequately disclosed its deteriorating financial condition. First National has also told its stockholders that unless it can sell from $40 million to $60 million in new stock to replace dwindling equity, the $1.5 billion institution will have to be sold.

headline: 2 Time Bombs in Jordan
abstract: Jordanian security authorities in Amman have defused another time bomb, the second in 24 hours. The Interior Ministry said today that a suitcase packed with 25 pounds of explosives was spotted in a vacant lot near the Chinese Embassy. On Wednesday authorities defused a 12.5-pound bomb near the Saudi Arabian Airlines office in Amman.

headline: IRAQ REPORTS MINING LANES TO AN IRANIAN PORT
abstract: Iraq said today that its gunboats had mined the approaches to an Iranian oil port in the western Persian Gulf and it warned petroleum tankers to avoid the area.   The Iraqis also said their helicopter gunships bombed and strafed Iranian positions along the northern front and ''transformed the battlefield into a huge graveyard swallowing up the enemy and damaging his equipment and weapons.''

headline: RATE FEARS PERSIST DESPITE RECOVERY
abstract: Interest rates and Federal budget deficits are at levels that were unthinkable during the 1970's, yet the nation's economy is growing at a healthy pace and confounding forecasts of an anemic recovery from the 1981-82 recession.    ''The most suprising thing about this recovery is its normalcy,'' said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon Nation Bank in Pittsburgh. From his vantage point in the heart of the steel industry, Mr. Robertson added, ''smokestack America is still hurting.'' But the overall economy is doing nicely, as measured by improvement in broad measures such as nonfarm employment and industrial production.

headline: New Control Of GAF Near By The Associated Press
abstract: Barring a further court fight, a dissident group of the GAF Corporation stockholders is expected to get control of the company on Tuesday, a GAF spokesman said. GAF, a chemical and roofing-materials company, plans to reconvene a shareholders meeting on that day to officially announce results of the vote on an attempt by a group led by Samuel J. Heyman, a Connecticut real estate developer, to unseat GAF's management, said Robert Button, the GAF spokesman.

headline: Stocks Drop; Dow Off 11.89
abstract: Stock prices dropped sharply yesterday in continued heavy trading as rising interest rates weakened most of the list.    At the conclusion of the session, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 11.89 points, to 1,261.89. The decline was broadly based, with losing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbering those that rose by a 3-to-2 ratio.

headline: O'NEILL TO OPPOSE NEW AID TO FIGHT NICARAGUA REGIME
abstract: Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., who backed President Reagan's use of American Marines in Lebanon, said today that he would oppose the Administration's continuing aid to Nicaraguan rebels in a crucial vote scheduled for the House of Representatives on Thursday.   ''I believe that the United States should not be engaged militarily in trying to overthrow other governments,'' Mr. O'Neill said. ''I believe there is a sharp difference between what the Administration is doing in Lebanon and what it is trying to do in Nicaragua. In Lebanon, it is supporting a government. In Nicaragua, it is trying to overthrow one.''

headline: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES REPORTS 6.9% INCREASE
abstract: The United Technologies Corporation reported yesterday that its net income in the third quarter rose 6.9 percent, to $121 million, reflecting strength in its helicopter and air- conditioning businesses.    ''Despite lower aircraft engine shipments and unfavorable foreign exchange rates experienced in the third quarter, our future looks promising,'' said Harry J. Gray, chairman and chief executive of United Technologies.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: A.T.& T. President To Retire April 1    William M. Ellinghaus, president and chief operating officer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, announced yesterday that he would retire April 1.    Mr. Ellinghaus, 61 years old, thus will become the last chief operating officer of the Bell Telephone System, which ends its existence on Jan. 1 as A.T.& T. divests itself of its operating companies.    The divestiture delayed Mr. Ellinghaus's retirement, he said yesterday.

headline: FRANCE REPORTED TO SEND FIGHTERS TO IRAQ AIR FORCE
abstract: France was reported today to have started delivery to Iraq of jet fighters that the United States and other Western countries believe may increase the dangers of the Iran-Iraq war.    The planes, when armed with previously delivered Exocet air-to-surface missiles, would give the Government of President Saddam Hussein the capacity to block Iranian oil ports.   Iran has said it would close the entrance to the gulf in the Strait of Hormuz if its oil installations are threatened. This would endanger the supply of oil to most of the world.

headline: Car Sales Up in E.E.C.
abstract: Sales of passenger cars in the European Economic Community rose by more than 3 percent in 1983, and sales of commercial vehicles increased by 1.5 percent, according to industry figures released today.

headline: BEIRUT SCHEDULES ITS TALKS ON UINTY
abstract: President Amin Gemayel's Government announced today that a long-delayed national reconciliation conference of Lebanon's Moslem and Christian leaders would begin Thursday at Beirut International Airport, which is protected by the American Marine contingent.   But whether the meeting will take place on schedule, if at all, remained in doubt.   Several of the 10 politicians scheduled to attend have been involved in assassination attempts against one another in the last eight years, and all of them are worried about their safety.

headline: President Is Appointed At Burgess & Leith Inc.
abstract: James M. Oates, a 37-year-old bank president in St. Louis, has been named president and chief operating officer of Burgess & Leith Inc., a New England investment bank bent on expansion.   Burgess & Leith, 51 percent owned by Phoenix Mutual Life, a $3 billion Hartford insurance company, has 22 offices in New England and New York.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: G.E. Names Head Of Ceramics Unit    The General Electric Company yesterday announced the formation of a new subsidiary, General Electric Ceramics Inc., and the appointment of Dr. H. Gary Carlson as its president.   G.E. Ceramics will manufacture technical ceramics - products such as carriers for integrated-circuit chips and substitutes for metals in mechanical and structural applications. Dr. Carlson said that while Kyoto Ceramics in Japan dominated the field and ''the United States is badly behind,'' he expected substantial growth and redistribution.   Dr. Carlson estimated that the world market for technical ceramics is worth $1.7 billion and that Kyoto commands a 20 to 25 percent market share. But he predicted that worldwide sales would reach $14 billion in 1990 and $28 billion in 2000, and that the influence of G.E. Ceramics would grow from ''very small'' to first or second position in the field, with a 30 to 50 percent market share.

headline: Tandy TV Deal
abstract: The Tandy Corporation's Radio Shack chain will market the direct satellite-to-home television service started recently by United Satellite Communications, the two companies said.

headline: A Stable Day For Eurobonds
abstract: Eurobond trading was quiet with prices stable, following a lower opening in government bonds in the United States, dealers said today.

headline: F.C.C. SAYS SENATE BILL ON PHONES ISN'T NEEDED
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission charged today that telephone legislation approved by the Senate Commerce Committee was unnecessary and would prompt large companies to build private communications systems outside the national network.    The allegations by the F.C.C., made in a letter to Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, concern a bill approved by the Senate committee last week that would impose a two-year moratorium on a commission decision on telephone ''access fees.'' The F.C.C. decision would require all residential and business customers to start paying to their local phone companies a new monthly fee in 1984 to gain access to long-distance networks. Mr. Goldwater is chairman of the subcommittee on communications.

headline: BUDGET DEFICITS EFFECTS DEBATE IS INTENSIFYING
abstract: As the 1983 fiscal year comes to an end with the biggest Federal budget deficit ever, the Reagan Administration is intensifying the debate about how harmful or benign deficits may be.   Having promised as a candidate to balance the budget by 1983, President Reagan has gone over onto the defensive of late and has been playing down the economic significance of the budget deficit.   At the end of the fiscal year at the close of business today, spending exceeded revenues by nearly $200 billion, nearly twice the 1982 deficit of $110.7 billion, the previous high.   The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office has estimated that, without new spending cuts and tax rises, the deficit could stay up around $200 billion for years to come, a prospect widely regarded as dangerous to the country's economic well-being.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: * A. H. Belo Corp.  said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell two television stations - KFDM in Beaumont-Port Arthur, Tex., and WTVC in Chattanooga, Tenn. - to Freedom Newspapers for $49 million.

headline: Money Fund Assets Sag
abstract: Assets of money market mutual funds fell sharply in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.   It said total assets dropped $581 million, to $165.75 billion.

headline: Two Soviet Diplomats Are Expelled by Belgium
abstract: The Belgian Government said today that it had expelled two Soviet diplomats for spying, the second Eastern-bloc espionage scandal in Belgium in recent months.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: Advertising; Grey's Corporate Survey
abstract: EVEN though advocacy advertising has become a bit of a buzzword of late, the vast majority of corporate leaders in a recent survey strongly rejected the concept.   They agreed with the statement, ''Corporate advocacy advertising is a blatant misuse of stockholder money,'' one of a number of statements in a true-or-false questionnaire circulated by Grey Matter, the marketing newsletter of Grey Advertising.   But as for corporate advertising in general, they were all big supporters. And that was why Grey contacted the group - chief executives of 50 of the country's biggest users of corporate advertising - in the first place. Twenty-five responded, and of them, 22 were opposed to advocacy advertising.

headline: SOVIET SEEKS TO LAY BLAME FOR ICE CRISIS
abstract: With a two-week struggle to save more than 40 Soviet ships trapped in Arctic ice nearing an end, the Communist Party daily Pravda has set aside the drama and heroics of earlier accounts and turned to apportioning blame for the crisis among Government bureaucracies.   ''Ships of the Far Eastern Shipping Line are now emerging one after another from the armor of ice and making their way to home ports,'' a Pravda correspondent, N. Bratchikov, wrote. ''Some will pass through the Bering Strait, others across four oceans, around Europe. Unwillingly the question arises: Is the Arctic alone to blame for what happened?''

headline: 100 Seized in Uruguay After Soldiers Charge
abstract: Riot troops and mounted policemen charged into a crowd demonstrating against Uruguay's 10- year-old military Government on Thursday night and arrested about 100 people, witnesses said.   Several demonstrators were kicked, punched and hit with riot sticks, they said.

headline: Salvadoran Military Shakes Up Command
abstract: Defense Minister Eugenio Vides Casanova has ordered a sweeping shake-up of the military command.

headline: Riggs Plans Acquisition
abstract: Riggs National Bank has signed a letter of intent to buy the ownership stock of A.P. Bank of London for $37.5 million, Riggs and the Norwich Life Insurance Society of Norwich, England, announced today. Riggs, which reported assets of $4.2 billion as of Sept. 30, has a branch in London.

headline: Mozambican Sees Ties With U.S. Improving
abstract: President Samora M. Machel of Mozambique, who is here on a European tour, said in an interview today that Mozambique's relationship with the United States was improving.   In the interview, published in the Lisbon daily Diario de Noticias, Mr. Machel said:   ''The American Administration now has without doubt a more lucid attitude to cooperation with Mozambique. They discuss things with us very frankly and we appreciate this.''

headline: No Headline
abstract: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be reported this week.  Monday   NoneTuesday   Merchandise Trade BalanceOct.Wednesday   Leading IndicatorsOct.

headline: STATE-SPONSORED TERROR CALLED A THREAT TO U.S.
abstract: In recent months the United States and its allies have become the targets of what Arab and Israeli security experts describe as terrorism sponsored by sovereign nations.  State-sponsored terrorism, they say, is exploiting an anti-American atmosphere in the Middle East and the willingness of some activists to commit suicide for a cause, and has become a potent form of political violence that is extraordinarily difficult to prevent or root out.  Although the hard evidence is fragmentary - because of the professionalism of the operations and the ease with which plotters can disappear across Lebanon's open borders - the overwhelming opinion among diplomatic and security sources in the Middle East is that the Governments of Syria and Iran are ultimately involved in some way. They said both Syria and Iran had the resources and ample political motives for supporting these attacks as an adjunct to their foreign policies in the region.  Bombing of Marine Compound   When Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger declared that the bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut on Oct. 23 was carried out with the ''sponsorship, knowledge and authority of the Syrian Government,'' he was only giving public voice to what Western diplomats and Arab officials had been saying privately.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Britoil Inc.  announced that it would offer $150 million of commercial paper notes guaranteed by Britoil P.L.C., through Lehman Commercial Paper Inc.     *  Dresdner Finance B.V., the finance arm of Dresdner Bank A.G., is issuing $400 million of floating rate notes due in 1993, with attached warrants, at a price of 105. The notes pay interest at 0.25 percentage point above the mean of the bid and ask London interbank interest rates for six-month dollar deposits.      Common Stock     *  Biomatic Inc.  filed an initial public offering of 200 million common shares, through Southeast Securities of Florida Inc.     *  Cherokee Group, which produces a line of women's footwear and ready- to-wear apparel, filed for an initial public offering of one million shares, through Blyth Eastman Paine Webber.

headline: An Attempted Coup Is Reported in Grenada
abstract: An attempted coup against the Cuban-backed Government of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop in Grenada was reported yesterday, but there were conflicting accounts about the outcome.

headline: ISRAELI POLICEMEN KILL 2 PALESTINIAN YOUTHS AFTER ROCK-THROWING
abstract: Israeli border policemen shot and killed two Palestinian youths today after a rock- throwing incident in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.   The shootings were the first such violent Palestinian deaths in the West Bank since the killing of three students at the Islamic College in Hebron last July by unknown masked assailants.   Four other youths were wounded in the shooting today, which occurred near the city of Tulkarm, 21 miles northeast of Tel Aviv, according to the city's Mayor.

headline: Equitable Files Realty Bonds
abstract: The Equitable Realty Assets   Corporation, a subsidiary of   the Equitable Life Assurance   Society of the United States,   filed a registration statement   with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday   for the sale of $195 million of   mortgage-backed bonds   through underwriters led by   Salomon Brothers Inc.  The issue consists of interest-   bearing installment bonds due   in 1989 and 1994 and zero-coupon bonds due in 1996, the company said. Principal payments   will begin next July 1 for the   bonds due in 1989 and on July 1,   1989, for the bonds due in 1994.  Payments on the bonds will   be made solely from the cash   flow from a pool of home mortgage loans and other assets.

headline: Kaiser Realty Sale
abstract: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had sold a 28- story office tower, the Ordway Building, in Oakland, Calif., to an affiliate of the JMB Realty Corporation for $76.6 million.

headline: DISILLUSION WITH NICARAGUA GROWS IN EUROPE
abstract: The Sandinista Government is losing political support in Western Europe because of its close ties to Cuba and its attitude toward its domestic critics, according to diplomats and foreign policy analysts here.    ''We were very enthusiastic about the Sandinista revolution because we thought it would be truly nonaligned,'' said a European diplomat. ''But it seems clear by now that the Sandinista political project is to radicalize the regime and lean more heavily each day on the Communist bloc. Europeans are only now beginning to realize this.''

headline: Talking Businesswith James of Raymond, James Diversification At Regionals
abstract: BOCA RATON, Fla.   Many large national brokerage firms have been building up their networks of branch offices by buying regional firms, which often have strong ties with local customers.   Other regionals, however, have remained independent, and several have gone public to raise the money needed for expansion. One that did so in July is the RJ Financial Corporation, based in St. Petersburg, Fla. It is the parent of Raymond, James & Associates, the largest Florida-based regional, with 27 branch offices in the state, plus one in Puerto Rico, and with plans for offices in Atlanta and Memphis.

headline: MISSILE LAUNCHERS EXPECTED AT U.S. BASE IN BRITAIN SOON
abstract: Britain's Defense Minister told the House of Commons today that mobile launchers for cruise missiles would arrive soon at a United States air base in England but the missiles themselves would not come into the country until later.    The Minister, Michael Heseltine, made the announcement during a debate in Parliament on deployment of the new nuclear weapons.   (Reuters reported that the House of Commons passed a motion by a vote of 362-218 reaffirming support for NATO's decision to deploy medium-range nuclear missiles in Western Europe. The vote, at the end of the debate in Parliament, came as an estimated 1,000 demonstrators staged a torchlight procession in London.)

headline: FOR THE JAPANESE, A PEEK BEHIND THE PALACE WALLS
abstract: For Japanese, one of the special bonuses of a visit by an American President is that they get a rare glimpse behind the weathered walls of the Imperial Palace.    It happened when President Ford came in 1974 and again with President Carter five years later. Thursday night the Japanese people were able to witness, through live television coverage, a state banquet for President Reagan at which Emperor Hirohito was the host.   The Emperor has made a graceful transition from a figure once thought to possess divine qualities to a more prosaic ''symbol of the state.'' Still, he retains a certain aura and leads a life largely sheathed in secrecy. A look at him, however brief, is enough to make many people here pay attention.

headline: PUTTING MINORITY GRADUATES ON CORPORATE CAREER
abstract: When Randy C. Sanderson graduated from Belmont High School in St. Louis in 1973, his main goal was not much different from other inner-city high school graduates - to find a decent-paying job. Going to college was not on his mind, nor was becoming a business leader someday.   Later that spring, however, things changed when Mr. Sanderson was introduced to Inroads Inc. The 14-year-old nonprofit organization, which has its headquarters in St. Louis, is the only agency in the country that prepares minorities for the corporate mainstream on a year-round basis.   ''Inroads convinced me that I would be better equipped for the corporate world if I went to college,'' Mr. Sanderson said in a recent interview. ''Although I had my doubts at first, I took their advice, and today my company and I have a perfect marriage.''

headline: SALVADOR SAYS REPORTED MASSACARE VICTIMS WERE SUBVERSIVES
abstract: Salvadoran Army officials, reacting to reports that soldiers had massacred large numbers of civilians, said today that 20 ''subversives'' had been killed in a recent army sweep northeast of here.   The statement followed accusations by relatives of the victims that troops of the United States-trained Atlacatl Battalion herded 20 women and children into a house in San Nicolas village on Nov. 4 and shot them the next day.   There were also unconfirmed reports on guerrilla radio stations that as many as 100 civilians had been slain.

headline: No Headline
abstract: DYR's U.S. Head   DYR, the recently renamed joint venture of Young & Rubicam of New York and Dentsu of Tokyo, will have a new president in its United States operation on Jan. 20 - Takashi Michioka, a 20-year Dentsu man who had worked in its New York office in the 1960's and in London during the 1970's. As head of DYR (USA), he will be in charge of the New York and Los Angeles offices. He is replacing Akio Minamoto, who is going back to Dentsu in Osaka.

headline: NOVEMBER INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT UP
abstract: Domestic industrial output rose a modest but encouraging eight-tenths of 1 percent in November for the second consecutive month, but a separate Government report shows that the deficit in foreign trade set a record last summer.   The Federal Reserve Board reported today that last month's advance in production by the nation's factories, mines and utilities was the 12th in a row and brought output 15.9 percent above the level of a year ago, when the recession was at its worst.    The production gain matched October's growth, which was also eight- tenths of 1 percent, the report noted. Although that was the slowest pace reached this year, it was regarded as a normal showing for this stage of an economic recovery.

headline: Your Money; Overambitious Tax Shelters
abstract: DESPITE the flurry of year-end tax shelters being advertised these days, or perhaps because of it, investors should be particularly careful of these investments.   This is the traditional time of the year when such offerings are heavily promoted, especially to individuals anxious to generate more deductions before 1983 comes to an end. And because of the rush, many buyers may succumb to the purchase of illegal, dubious or uneconomic shelters this year that they will deeply regret in the future.    ''A good number of the public deals that come out late in the year are lousy,'' said Donald Ercole, a partner of the certified public accounting firm of Arthur Young & Company. ''The shelter industry knows that people who examine shelters do it earlier in the year.''

headline: LAMSTON STILL SMALL AND LOCAL
abstract: While the fadeout of the neighborhood variety store has been predicted for years, M. H. Lamston evidently hasn't been listening. In 1984, the 32- store chain will celebrate 50 years in the metropolitan New York area, a period in which it has witnessed the rise and fall of many larger and smaller retailers.    Lamston has prospered at the upscale end of the variety store business. But it has done so without a heavy push into smart new shopping malls and without resorting to extensive discounting of its wide range of merchandise.

headline: REAGAN DISMAYED AT MOSCOW'S MOVE
abstract: President Reagan said today that Yuri V. Andropov's announcement of plans to counter NATO missile deployment with new Soviet weapons was at ''sharp variance'' with previous Russian calls for arms agreement.    ''While we are dismayed,'' the President said in a four-sentence statement, ''we are determined to renew our efforts to entirely do away with the land- based intermediate-range nuclear missile systems.''   The President, seeking holiday quiet at his mountain ranch near here, was briefed this morning by his national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, after Moscow's announcement that it planned to increase its nuclear weapons in Eastern Europe, within the Soviet Union and in unspecified ocean areas.   Walkout Was Expected    The announcement came a day after the Soviet Union broke off the Geneva talks on medium-range nuclear missiles, in what it said was retaliation for the start of deployment of new American missiles in Western Europe.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Bozell Wins Account    Bozell & Jacobs has won the Satellite Television Corporation account that could grow to $25 million in billings, even though when it starts in the fourth quarter of next year it will only be about $6 million.

headline: Trader Wins Potato Case
abstract: As a result of the potato-futures default in 1976, a Federal District Court jury in New York has awarded Joseph Strobl $460,000, which under antitrust law is tripled, to $1.38 million.   Mr. Strobl, now 67 years old, is a Detroit investor and former operator of amusement facilities.

headline: New Finance Minister Gets Approval in Israel
abstract: The Israeli Parliament approved the nomination of Yigal Cohen-Orgad as Finance Minister today in a vote of 60 to 48. He succeeds Yoram Aridor, who resigned last week.

headline: Sun Set to Close Lubricant Facility
abstract: The Sun Company said it will close the lubricant-aking facilities at its Marcus Hook, Pa., refinery.

headline: ISRAEL SHUTS WEST BANK UNIVERSITY FOR 2 MONTHS BECAUSE OF PROTESTS
abstract: The Israeli Army shut down Bethlehem University for two months today following violent clashes with students over the last two days.   The army also closed two schools under the aegis of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency in the Kalandia refugee camp near here for a month because, the army spokesman said, their students threw stones and disturbed traffic on the road to Jerusalem.   Sporadic incidents of stone-throwing occurred across the West Bank and East Jerusalem today, which is the anniversary of the signing of the Balfour Declaration in 1917 in which Britain expressed its support for the establishemnt of a Jewish homeland in Palestine. The day is considered one of national mourning for Palestinians. In East Jerusalem, local merchants marked the day with a partial strike.

headline: IRAQ REPEATS WARNINGABOUT IRAN'S SHELLING
abstract: Iraq, accusing Iran of continued attacks on civilian areas, has repeated a warning that it will again strike targets inside Iran if the shelling continues.

headline: U.S. OUTPUT JUMPS 5% IN QUARTER
abstract: Paced by the strongest factory performance in nearly three years, the productivity of workers in nonfarm private businesses grew at an annual rate of 5 percent in the third quarter, the Government said today.   The Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics said the most recent figures on employee output continued a trend in which productivity has grown more in the past four quarters than at any time since 1976.   As calculated by the bureau, productivity measures changes in the amount of goods and services turned out in an hour's paid working time.

headline: Fannie Mae Issue
abstract: The Federal National Mortgage Association's $1 billion of 11.2 percent debentures due June 10, 1987, were offered at a price of 100 through various securities dealers. When the interest rate was announced, the issue yielded about 20 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than recently issued four-year notes of the United States Treasury.

headline: Rumsfeld Visits Israel; No Promise on Arafat
abstract: Donald Rumsfeld, the United States special envoy to the Middle East, conferred with Israeli leaders today, but Israel made no commitment on allowing the evacuation of Yasir Arafat and his guerrillas from Lebanon.   Mr. Rumsfeld, who arrived Thursday night from talks in Damascus with Syrian leaders, met alone with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir for 70 minutes. Mr. Rumsfeld said later, ''Any comment might harm my mission.''

headline: AMID THE DESERT OF DISTRUST, AN ARAB AND A JEW TEAM UP
abstract: More than four years ago Lucien Ben-Shoshan, a 37-year-old Jew, and Khalil Atamna, a 33-year-old Arab, became partners in a small enterprise making concrete building blocks. Their company thus became one of a scattering of Arab-Jewish businesses in Israel, blooming like little wildflowers in a landscape of distrust.   Now their machinery clatters profitably on a site down a narrow road in this small Jewish town between Haifa and Tel Aviv.

headline: Wolverine Sale
abstract: A management group of the Wolverine Aluminum Corporation, led by the company's president, Gregory Smith, said it had agreed to acquire the company for $26 a share. Based on about 1.3 million shares outstanding, the transaction has an indicated value of about $34 million. Mr. Smith said he had reached an agreement with the Synalloy Corporation, a metal fabricator; the Worldmark Corporation, and Barry Cohen, a New York investor, to merge Wolverine with a new company to be owned by the four parties.

headline: Zimbabwean Air Officer Says He Was Tortured
abstract: Three white Zimbabwean Air Force officers released from detention in Harare a week ago flew into Britain today, and one said he had been tortured.   The three were the last of seven officers who were cleared of sabotage charges in August but immediately redetained under Zimbabwe's emergency laws.

headline: U.S. PANEL AND NICARAGUA MEET AT CLOSE OF LATIN TOUR
abstract: Henry A. Kissinger, closing a week- long visit of President Reagan's commission on Central America to the region, said tonight that ''we should not have to choose between peace and democracy'' in Nicaragua.   The coordinator of Nicaragua's Sandinista junta, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, responded that the United States would ''have to decide if they want to continue on a line toward war, a war of open aggression on the part of the United States which we are already living here in Nicaragua, or if they're looking for the path of reduction of tension and political solution.''   The remarks by the two men came at the end of a day of meetings between the commission and Government, business and religious leaders here. It was the last stop on a weeklong tour that included the five Central American countries and Panama.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Atari Assigns More to D.D.B.  Atari Inc., the troubled division of Warner Communications, announced yesterday    that it had consolidated its advertising assignments on the   international scene just as it   did domestically early last   month. The beneficiary is, once   again, Doyle Dane Bernbach.

headline: Philips Net Rises 28%
abstract: N.V. Philips' Gloeilampenfabrieken said today that its third-quarter profits rose 28.8 percent, to 103 million guilders, or $34.2 million, from 80 million a year earlier.

headline: G. & W. Forecast
abstract: Martin S. Davis, chief executive of Gulf and Western Industries, predicted yesterday that the recently slimmed-down conglomerate would earn $3 a share in the fiscal year ending July 31. In the 1983 fiscal year, the company earned $1.70 a share on continuing operations excluding special charges and write-offs. G. & W. had $260 million in after-tax earnings in 1983, but a one-time $472 million charge, which was part of its divestiture program, resulted in a $212 million net loss.

headline: KING'S HARASSERS FREED IN SPAIN
abstract: At a time of rising tensions in the northern Basque region, the Supreme Court handed down milder sentences than expected today in a case of 19 Basque nationalists charged with insulting King Juan Carlos during a royal visit to Guernica two years ago.    The verdict was still condemned by the defendants.

headline: Nicaraguan Rejects an Offer Conveyed by Rebels to U.S.
abstract: An offer by Nicaraguan rebels to end their guerrilla attacks in return for democratic concessions was immediately rejected by Nicaragua's Foreign Minister.

headline: TRANSCRIPT OF THE PRESIDENT'S NEWS SESSION;
abstract: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news session on the South Lawn of the White House this afternoon concerning the events in Lebanon, as recorded by the White House: OPENING STATEMENT    For some time now we have been flying regular and routine reconnaissance flights with unarmed planes in Lebanon as a part of the protection and defense of our forces there. We notified the Syrians of this some time ago, assuring the planes were unarmed; this was purely for reconnaissance. There have been some instances of firing at those planes now and then from unknown sources. But early yesterday, two such reconnaissance missions were fired upon by literally hundreds of antiaircraft and a combination of surface to air missiles which were coordinated in several sites by the Syrians. Early today we responded to this unprovoked attack by striking back at those sites from whence had come the attack.

headline: Nissan's British Plans Said to Gain
abstract: Senior executives of the Nissan Motor Company, ending more than a year of internal disagreement, have agreed on a plan to produce cars in Britain, a company official confirmed here today.   According to the executive, who asked to remain unidentified, only the head of the company's labor union, Ichiro Shioji, now stands in the way of Nissan setting up a plant in Britain.   ''There is a consensus within our top management in favor of this project,'' the senior nissan executive said. ''But as a Japanese company, we cannot go ahead without the union's approval. We still need to talk more with Mr. Shioji.''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: JORDANIANS MAY REACH OUT TO ARAFAT AGAIN
abstract: Jordan is prepared to hold new discussions with Yasir Arafat to work out a common approach to efforts toward a Middle East settlement, but only under certain conditions, according to Arab and Western diplomats.    The diplomats, who were interviewed in recent days, said they were giving their version of views held by the Jordanians on the basis of their embassy's repeated contacts with Government officials here.   They said Jordan's most detailed condition was that any approaches pick up essentially where they were interrupted in April, when, they said, Mr. Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, broke off contacts that were being held on a common Jordan-P.L.O. approach toward Arab-Israeli negotiations.   The Government here has made no formal statement on the matter and has been reticent to discuss it in recent months. Official Jordanian sources said last week that they discerned no movement anywhere toward a resolution of the overall Palestinian problem.

headline: CURBS ON GRENADA NEWS COVERAGE CRITICIZED IN HOUSE HEARING
abstract: Three television figures and a lawyer specializing in freedom of the press joined today before a House subcommittee in criticizing the Government for barring news coverage in the early days of the invasion of Grenada.    David Brinkley, senior correspondent for ABC News; John Chancellor, a commentator for NBC News, and Edward M. Joyce, president of CBS News, said they did not recall another major landing operation by the United States that was not covered by reporters.   The lawyer, Floyd Abrams, said the decision to exclude the press was consistent with other information-control actions such as making more Government documents secret.   ''I know of no other recent Administration that has acted so consistently against the right of the public to obtain information,'' Mr. Abrams testified.

headline: GTE Settles Iran Contract Dispute
abstract: The GTE Corporation said it had settled a contract dispute with Iran stemming from the taking of American hostages in November 1979 and the resulting breakoff of diplomatic relations.   The company said the settlement essentially calls for GTE to complete the shipment of some telephone equipment for which Iran had previously paid. The settlement also reduces from $95 million to $18 million a line of credit posted by GTE as a guarantee for completing work on a telephone communications system for Iran.

headline: Technology Sales to China
abstract: The United States has removed restrictions on the export to China of many high-technology goods, Commerce Department officials said today.

headline: ECONOMIC INDICATORS DOWN 0.4%
abstract: The Government's index of leading economic indicators fell four-tenths of 1 percent in November, the first decline in 15 months, the Commerce Department reported today.    But the Administration and independent economists expressed little concern about the dip in the index, which is intended to forecast future swings in economic activity.    Some analysts said they expected the figure to be revised to a small gain when more complete data are available, while others said that the decline was a positive development.

headline: VLI Halts Filing Of Stock Offering IRVINE, Calif., Dec. 15 (Reuters) - The VLI Corporation said it would not file a registration statement for a secondary offering of common stock because the firm has not been able to find enough selling stockholders.
abstract: Late last month, VLI said it planned an offering of two million shares, all to come from selling stockholders who are primarily early investors in the company.

headline: New Chief Named By Household Unit
abstract: Bernard F. Brennan, Montgomery Ward's executive vice president, retail, resigned yesterday to become president and chief executive officer of the Household Merchandising Corporation, a subsidiary of Household International.    Mr. Brennan, 44 years old, joined Montgomery Ward, a subsidiary of the Mobil Corporation, in September 1982 as executive vice president for stores.

headline: Spinoff Approved At Trans World Shareholders of the Trans World Corporation voted overwhelmingly in favor of proposals that will spin off Trans World Airlines from the company. Under one proposal, the 81 percent holding of the parent company in the airline will be distributed to Trans World stockholders at the rate of about 0.93 share of T.W.A. stock for each Trans World share. Under a second proposal, the incentive compensation plans of the two companies were separated.
abstract: After the spinoff, which is expected to become effective Feb. 1, Trans World will be left with four major subsidiaries that have been consistently profitable. The airline's earnings have fluctuated widely, showing heavy losses for the last two years. The four units are Spartan Food Systems Inc., which owns and operates 423 restaurants; the Canteen Corporation, a vending and direct food service business; Hilton International, which operates 90 hotels, and the Century 21 Real Estate Corporation.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: Bear Creek Corp., a producer of fruit, gourmet foods and garden plants, said its shareholders had approved the acquisition of the company by a unit of R.J. Reynolds Industries for $39 a share, or about $74.1 million.     *  Columbia Gas System Inc., Wilmington, Del., said it had approved a 29 percent increase in its capital expenditure program for 1984, to $312 million, from $241 million in 1983.     *  Denny's Inc., an operator of restaurants based in La Mirada, Calif., said it had agreed to acquire 78 Colony Kitchen restaurants from Trust Houses Forte Ltd.'s Travelodge International Inc. unit for $13.6 million.

headline: Debt Issues
