abstract: *  Beverly Enterprises, a Pasadena, Calif., health care company, announced that it had entered into an unsecured $100 million revolving credit agreement with First Interstate Bank of California, Morgan Guaranty Trust and Manufacturers Hanover Trust.     *  First Jersey National Corp.'s $25 million issue of notes due in 1993 was priced at 99.75, to yield 12.92 percent, through Goldman, Sachs & Co.     *  Paccar Inc.  said its Paccar Financial Corp. unit had filed a shelf registration for $100 million aggregate principal amount of senior debt securities, to be issued from time to time with terms set at the time of sale.

headline: LONDON EXCHANGE ENTERING NEW ERA
abstract: The stocks and bonds that are traded on the London Stock Exchange have been less interesting lately than the brokerage houses themselves.   Last week, Vickers da Costa, a medium-sized broker with a strong international trading department, agreed to sell 29.9 percent of its British operations and 80 percent of its overseas units to Citicorp for about $30 million.    This week, Akroyd & Smithers, one of the Exchange's largest stock wholesalers, became the investment target of Mercury Securities, the holding company for one of Britain's top merchant banks, S. G. Warburg.   Mercury said it intended to link Akroyd with that bank. Terms of the acquisition are expected to be announced on Thursday, but, as in the case of Citicorp, Mercury, as a non-exchange member, cannot buy more than 29.9 percent.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Swift's Chief Quits; Esmark Realigns      Esmark Inc. announced yesterday what it termed a major management realignment, including the resignation of Joseph P. Sullivan, president and chief executive of its Swift & Company unit.    Mr. Sullivan, 50 years old, was one of three executives often mentioned as the future Esmark chief executive. He said yesterday, however, that it had been a long-term goal of his to enter some kind of public service. ''The good Lord has been good to me,'' he said. ''It's time I gave some of it back.''

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: COMPUTER INDUSTRY: MORE JOBS DESPITE LAYOFFS
abstract: WHEN the Osborne Computer Corporation, in Hayward, Calif., laid off David Berg along with more than 300 other people as it filed for bankruptcy last month, he didn't spend much time unemployed. One week later, Mr. Berg, a software engineer, had accepted a job for higher pay at a new company in nearby San Jose that designs computer systems for hotels.   Nine days after Osborne let go Peter Brown, a support-staff member who dealt with questions from dealers about the Osborne computer, he was working for Onyx Systems Inc., a computer manufacturer in San Jose.  And Brad Berkey, an assembly-line troubleshooter at Osborne before being laid off, got a job at nearby Vicom Systems; his new employer pays for his schooling toward a college degree.

headline: 'Telephone' Helps Lift Dow 1.83
abstract: Prices of American Telephone and Telegraph stock, old and new, advanced smartly yesterday and accounted for nearly 17 percent of all the shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange.   The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.83 points, to 1,277.44, in very light trading. Stocks that rose in price outnumbered those that fell by 841 to 601. Turnover fell to 57.8 million shares, from 108.1 million Wednesday.

headline: LOWER MANHATTAN DRAWS NEW BACK OFFICE MARKET
abstract: Officially, it is called the Lower Manhattan Mixed Use District. But more commonly, the elongated triangle below Canal Street, west of West Broadway and north of the World Trade Center, is known as TriBeCa, Lower Hudson or, on occasion, Washington Market.   This section of lower Manhattan is an old industrial neighborhood of printers and food packagers that has undergone a substantial transformation since a zoning change in 1976 permitted residential loft conversions?    The influx of new inhabitants, and the shops, restaurants and boutiques that followed, has revived the area by attracting people to it throughout the day. That activity has, in turn, helped make the rehabilitated neighborhood an attractive place for lower-priced commercial office space.

headline: PUZZLING MOVE AT SUPERIOR OIL
abstract: Howard B. Keck's unexpected resignation from his remaining posts on the board of the Superior Oil Company prompted speculation today that he is preparing to sell the large block of Superior stock that he controls.   Mr. Keck, the 70-year-old son of Superior's founder, resigned from his posts as a director, chairman of the board's nominating committee and a consultant, Superior announced Thursday night.   The resignation came several months after Mr. Keck lost a proxy fight in which his sister, Willemetta Keck Day, won shareholder support for a resolution that changed the bylaws to make it easier for another company to acquire Superior.

headline: Advertising; CBS Unit's Publishers Lead Shifts
abstract: PETER G. DIAMANDIS, president since Sept. 27 of CBS Consumer Publications, announced several key executive appointments over the weekend, including the naming of four publishers. He said the changes were in line with his desire to streamline the company and make it into a fast-paced consumer-oriented organization.   Francis X. Dealy Jr., 45 years old and a former publisher of Tennis magazine, has been named publisher of World Tennis, and William Curtis, 26, has been named ad director.

headline: NEW SUIT QUESTIONS MANVILLE TACTICS
abstract: A recent court filing in the Manville Corporation's bankruptcy proceeding charges that the company has tried for years to avoid its liability for the asbestos injuries that its workers developed. In the process, the filing says, Manville used tactics of questionable legality and morality.    According to the papers filed by George Rosenberg, a Los Angeles lawyer who represents asbestos victims, Manville's efforts to limit its liability have included everything from shopping for a favorable accounting opinion to lying that its former general counsel was dead when in fact he was alive.   Manville officials deny any wrongdoing. ''This is a pack of scurrilous lies,'' said G. Earl Parker, the vice president-counsel of Manville.

headline: RETALIATION MOVE BY U.S. IS POSSIBLE
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, angered by the seeming impunity of those responsible for recent explosions like those in Kuwait on Monday. said today that, if the attackers could be identified, ''there will be ways of getting at them.''   ''It is a great tragedy,'' he said of the attacks against the American and French embassies as well as other installations in Kuwait.   The attacks, he said, were not aimed only at governments, but also at ''the general concept of law and order.''   Mr. Shultz spoke at a news conference here before leaving for Washington, where plans on how to react to the bombings, believed carried out by pro- Iranian groups, are to be discussed within the Government.

headline: END OF THE LINE FOR A FAMILY BUSINESS
abstract: ANDREW ROSEN is a personable    27-year-old - tall, dark and   handsome, as they used to say, with a ready smile and personable manner. He dresses in business suits, sits comfortably at a director's table and earns $299,000 a year.   Last week, during an interview, he was philosophical and at ease about the imminent loss of his lofty position as president and chief executive of the Puritan Fashions Corporation. He was equally calm, at least outwardly, about the Rosen family's loss of Puritan, which his grandfather founded in 1907 and which Rosens have run ever since.   Calvin Klein, the designer, and Barry Schwartz, his business partner, succeeded last Tuesday in a takover bid for Puritan, which makes most of its $250 million in annual revenue from selling Calvin Klein jeans.

headline: 2 Beirut Dead Identified
abstract: The last two bodies from the Oct. 23 Marine headquarters bombing in Beirut, Lebanon, have been identified.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;  CPC International Sets Division Realignment
abstract: CPC International is not a very descriptive name. Nor is it a household word, but many of its products are - Skippy peanut butter, Hellman's mayonnaise and Thomas' English muffins.   CPC used to be a sleepy company called Corn Products Refining, until the 1950's, when it bought Knorr, a West German soupmaker, and Best Foods. Since then it has grown not only as a corn refiner but also as a grocery producer. Yesterday, CPC, which posted sales of $4.1 billion last year, announced an organizational realignment and the appointment of eight presidents to new divisions.

headline: Interest Rates Down Slightly
abstract: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday in extremely light post-holiday trading. By late in the day, rates for outstanding Treasury bills had declined about two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, with three-month and six-month issues bid at rates of 8.80 percent and 8.95 percent, respectively.   Overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market averaged about 9.2 percent during the day, a level that did not provide any clues about Federal Reserve monetary policy, dealers said. In the week ended Nov. 23, the overnight Federal funds rate averaged 9.26 percent, down from the 9.39 percent average of the previous four weeks, but analysts are not sure if the decline was significant.

headline: JETS FOR IRAQ: FRANCE PLAYS DOWN EFFECT
abstract: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson declined to confirm today that France had delivered advanced jetfighters to Iraq, but spoke as though the planes' arrival in Iraq was a foregone conclusion.   ''Five more planes, what does that change?'' he asked. ''Very little.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1983
abstract: The Economy  The jobless rate fell in October , to 8.7 percent, from 9.1 percent, the Labor Department reported. While the seasonally adjusted number of people employed was slightly lower, officials said, payroll jobs were strongly higher in durable goods manufacturing and construction, the two sectors hit hard by the recession, suggesting that employers were turning from longer work hours to larger work forces. The figures indicated the rapid recovery is continuing, and analysts said the jobless rate would drop below 8 percent next year. (Page 1.) In New York City, the jobless rate fell to 9.2 percent. (16.)  Companies will file data with the S.E.C. electronically under a new pilot program, and the agency will make the data public almost instantaneously. Officials said the program will enable investors at home computers to go directly to S.E.C. files for the latest information on companies they are interested in. (35.)

headline: President Quits At Carnation
abstract: The Carnation Company of Los Angeles said yesterday that Dwight Stuart, 59 years old, had resigned as president ''to devote full time to personal interests.'' Timm F. Crull, 52, executive vice president, was named to succeed him. Mr. Stuart is the son of the late Elbridge Hadley Stuart, former chairman of Carnation, and the grandson of Elbridge Amos Stuart, the company's founder. Mr. Crull joined Carnation in 1955. He left in 1977 to become president of Norton Simon Inc. and returned to Carnation in 1980.

headline: Massey-Vickers Talks
abstract: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. said today that it was negotiating with Vickers P.L.C. to buy a British plant of the Vickers Rolls-Royce division, which makes diesel engines of about 1,000 horsepower, mostly for trucks, tanks and small locomotives. Massey said the price probably would be about $29 million.

headline: Defecting Chinese Pilot Flies MIG-19 to Taiwan
abstract: A Chinese Air Force pilot flew a MIG-19 jet fighter to Taiwan today and asked for political asylum, the Defense Ministry reported.

headline: SINCE '45 UNESCO HAS BEEN A POLTICAL BATTLEFIELD
abstract: Unesco, the Paris- based organization that the United States promised today that it would quit next year, is a senior member of what officials call the United Nations ''family,'' a collection of independent world bodies with differing tasks that are loosely grouped under the United Nations in New York.    Other ''family'' members include such relatively well-known organizations as the World Bank and the World Health Organization. There are also more obscure ones, like the International Telegraphic Union and the World Intellectual Property Rights Organization.   Together, this United Nations ''family'' represents an attempt to address problems at the world level, whether these are political problems, such as resolving conflicts, or more technical ones, such as promoting economic development, fighting contagious disease or sharing radio frequencies.   Created After World War II    Considerable idealism lay behind the creation of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization in 1945. Throughout World War II, the Allies had discussed education's role in safeguarding peace when the fighting ended. When Unesco was founded, it was with in the belief that education and knowledge would in themselves help combat Nazi ideology and promote international understanding.

headline: Soviet Honors Geologist
abstract: The title of Hero of Socialist Labor, a high honor, was given today to a geologist, Vasily Podshibyakin, for prospecting oil and gas fields in Siberia's Yamal Peninsula. The fields, extending from northwest to southeast across the peninsula, are expected to become major producers, especially for gas. Production drilling at Novy Port, at the southern end, is already under way.

headline: Eurobonds Steady In Quiet Trading LONDON, Dec. 14 (Reuters) - Eurobonds were steady today in quiet trading, dealers said.
abstract: American convertibles traded in a narrow range after slight declines early on.

headline: Military Official in Bahrain
abstract: Richard L. Armitage, Assistant Defense Secretary for international security affairs, met the Emir of Bahrain, Sheik Isa bin Salman al-Khalifa, here today.

headline: PRICES RISE FOR A THIRD DAY
abstract: Prices of debt securities rose for the third consecutive day as traders were encouraged by a drop in overnight interest rates and by active investor demand at the Treasury auction of two-year notes.    By late in the day, rates for short- term securities due in less than a year had fallen as much as one-tenth of a percentage point, although Treasury bill rates were little changed. In the long bond market, the 12 percent Treasury issue due in 2013 was offered at 102 31/32, up 1/2 point, to yield 11.63 percent. The bellwether Treasury bond is down from 105 5/8 on Oct. 6, but is above the average of about 101 18/32 set at the Nov. 10 auction.

headline: American Treasury Secretary Vows Firmness on Lebanon
abstract: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that American troops would remain in Lebanon until peace was restored there.

headline: Beatrice Sale; Ralston-Vicorp
abstract: The Beatrice Foods Company said it had signed a definitive agreement for the sale of its confections operations in the United States as part of its realignment plan. The operations were sold to the Hutamaki Group of Finland.

headline: SOVIET FOOD STORE OFFICIAL SENTTENCED TO DEATH
abstract: The former director of Moscow's best food store, once purveyor of delicacies to the Soviet elite, has been sentenced to death for corruption.   The unusual announcement from the Soviet press agency Tass of the extreme measure taken against Yuri K. Sokolov, and of long prison terms handed down to four of his associates, was viewed as a strong signal that Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, intends to pursue his year-old crackdown on corruption in high places.   Mr. Sokolov had been director of Gastronom No. 1, an ornately decorated store on Gorky Street that is popularly known as Yeliseyevsky's because it occupies the premises of a celebrated prerevolutionary delicatessen of that name.   Mr. Sokolov was famed in Moscow as supplier of scarce delicacies to well- placed and well-heeled Muscovites, and his regular customers reportedly included Galina Churbanov, the daughter of the late Leonid I. Brezhnev and wife of Yuri M. Churbanov, a former First Deputy Minister of Internal Affairs, who has reportedly been demoted to a relatively minor post in Murmansk.

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: McCann Loses Times Account The New York Times announced yesterday that its relationship with its advertising   agency, McCann-Erickson   Worldwide, would end Jan. 15.

headline: Broken Hill, G.E. Talks
abstract: The General Electric Company said yesterday that negotiations on the sale of its Utah International division to the Broken Hill Propietary Company of Australia for $2.4 billion were still active despite the expected failure to close the deal by Monday.   The companies had signed a memorandum of intent in January and a definitive agreement in April specifying that either company could withdraw if the sale had not been concluded by the end of October.

headline: Dutch Police Have Half Of Heineken Ransom
abstract: The police said today that they had found more than half of the $11 million ransom paid for Alfred H. Heineken, the brewery chairman.

headline: 1980'S GRADS: BABY BOOM TO JOB BUST
abstract: WHEN David Rivers graduated from the University of Massachusetts at Amherst nine months ago, he moved to New York City full of enthusiasm and optimism about starting a career in advertising. But despite a model job campaign and impressive credentials, including a high grade-point average and summer and part-time work experience, Mr. Rivers has been unable to break into advertising or even land an entry-level job in a related field.   He is not alone among recent college graduates. More than 900,000 of them in the 1980's have discovered they must put aside college-days dreams and settle for jobs that do not require a degree if they want to work at all.

headline: Eastern's Losses
abstract: Eastern Airlines lost $62.1 million in October and November when it raised the possibility of filing under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code and was urging its unions to make concessions. The loss put the carrier's total loss for 1983 so far at $191 million, compared with a loss of $117.9 million in the period a year earlier. The figures were in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission submitted as part of a $367 million rescue plan agreed to by Eastern's three major unions.

headline: LABORITE LEADER DEPLORES 'EXCESSIVE' TIES TO U.S.
abstract: Neil Kinnock, the newly elected leader of the Labor Party, said today that the British ''are not masters of our own foreign policies because of our excessive state of obligation to the American Government.''    Mr. Kinnock, who would become Prime Minister in the event of a Labor victory in the next general election, asserted that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher ''enjoys far more than she should the borrowed splendor'' of intimate relations with Washington and especially with President Reagan. The price she pays, he continued, ''is that the primary criterion for every British action, with the sole exception of the Falklands war, is whether it will be acceptable to the Americans.''   ''I think the primary criterion should be the best interests of Britain,'' the 41- year-old leader said in a long interview.

headline: CONSOLIDATED GAS NAMES A PRESIDENT
abstract: Ralbern H. Murray, who helped the Consolidated Natural Gas Company build sales in its hour of need, has been named president and chief operating officer, effective March 1. Mr. Murray, 54 years old, succeeds G. J. Tankersley, 62, as president. Mr. Tankersley will continue as chairman and chief executive.   Consolidated, based in Pittsburgh, serves customers in New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania and West Virginia. A fully integrated company, it explores for gas, produces it, transports it, stores it and sells it at wholesale and retail.

headline: Treasury List Is Small; Tax-Exempts Heavy
abstract: Investors and traders in the Treasury market will enjoy a brief hiatus in note and bond financings this week, after absorbing $16 billion of new three-, 10- and 30-year issues last week.   The only auctions scheduled are the regular Monday sale of three- and six-month bills. Last Thursday, the outstanding three-month issue was bid at a rate of 8.75 percent, while the six-month issue was 8.91 percent.

headline: Advertising; Financial Magazine's New Era
abstract: SINCE 1970, Mark J. Meagher has been very high up in corporations involved with advertising media. But he never seriously sold advertising until this year. The change came after he led a group of 14 limited partners that bought the venerable Financial World magazine last May and set himself, the only general partner, up as publisher. Now he has revamped the ad sales force and established a network of advertising representative firms and placed himself at their head.    And the former inside man, strictly a bottom-line kind of chap, now finds he really enjoys the coast-to-coast presentations. He blames it on his Irish blood.

headline: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1983
abstract: The Economy   Industrial production surged 1.5 percent in September, indicating that the economy was growing vigorously despite high interest rates, the Federal Reserve Board reported. Officials now expect next week's estimate of the gross national product for the period to exceed a 7 percent projection issued a month ago. (Page 1.)    Producer prices rose a modest 0.2 percent in September despite a surge in food prices, the Labor Department reported. It said declines in the cost of new cars and gasoline helped restrain inflation. The annual rate for the first nine months was just 0.2 percent; if that rate holds, 1983 would have the best record since 1963. (35.)

headline: THE 'HOLIDAY BLUES' ARE OVERSTATED ILL, HEALTH EXPERTS FIND
abstract: After years of hand-wringing over the ''holiday blues,'' a form of depression once thought to afflict vast numbers of Americans, mental health experts now stress that Christmas actually intensifies most major emotions of everyday life, joyous or sad.    Christmas is a time, they say, when lovers rejoice more than ever while the lonely may sink into despair; when close-knit families bind together while warring households shatter; when most workers relax and enjoy themselves while workaholics fret and feel guilty, and when the mentally well may feel better while the mentally ill may feel worse.   Christmas is also a time, they say, when dimly remembered roles are resumed with new intensity as far-flung families reunite. Sibling rivals who live a continent apart may return home to compete again for a favorable nod from their parents, and powerful professionals who command respect and awe in the community may find themselves reduced to whining children under the disapproving glance of a dictatorial mother.   For Most, No Despair    But for most people Christmas is not a time of depression and despair, according to the handful of researchers who have studied the psychological impact of the season.

headline: Kero-Sun Put In Bankruptcy
abstract: A Federal judge today declared Kero-Sun Inc. bankrupt. The company is the nation's largest distributor of portable kerosene heaters. Judge Robert Krechevsky issued the order after a hearing in which Kero-Sun tried to get a seven-week-old bankruptcy petition against it dismissed.

headline: ARABS ASSAIL U.S. POLICIES
abstract: News  Analysis    RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 11 - Two weeks after beginning a major effort to strengthen its political and military ties with Israel, the United States is finding itself under increasing attack from Arab countries unhappy over the arrangement.  Indeed, the Arab Governments seem to have little else to agree upon these days, given the sharp rifts over the situation in Lebanon and the Iranian-Iraqi war.   Even Washington's closest friends in this part of the world, Jordan, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, the Sudan, Tunisia and Morocco, have been expressing their discontent over the enhanced ''strategic cooperation'' between the United States and Israel.   According to American diplomats here, the message from Washington's friends is similar in the various capitals: by dramatizing the connection with Israel, the United States is distracting attention from the flow of Soviet arms to Syria and from the Syrian-backed disruption in Lebanon, including the effort to crush Yasir Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization.

headline: MOSLEM WORLD IS UNSETTLED BY SURGE IN FUNDAMENTALISM
abstract: Almost five years after an Islamic revolution toppled the Shah of Iran, a resurgence of religious fundamentalism is unsettling the Moslem world from Africa through the Middle East and into Asia, according to scholars and government officials.    Teheran has played a major role, directly and indirectly, in encouraging Islamic fundamentalist forces in the region, Arab officials and Western diplomats say. Iranian militants have trained thousands of Shiite Moslems from Arab countries at a center near Qum and at other camps. Diatribes against Western nations and what Iranians call corrupt Arab governments are beamed daily to the Arab world by the Iran radio and distributed throughout the region on cassettes.   The example set by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's revolution and his rejection of non-Moslem ideologies have inspired not only Shiite Moslems but many Sunnis as well.

headline: A Version in English Of French Magazine
abstract: George Green, president of The New Yorker magazine, and Daniel Filipacchi, head of Hachette, the major French publishing company, agreed last Thursday to work together to bring out and sell a one-shot English-language version of Elle, the French fashion magazine. The French will be in charge of the editorial content and production, and the Americans will be in charge of advertising sales and promotion.

headline: New Bombings in Corsica
abstract: Bombs exploded in law courts and 15 other buildings, including homes and shops, in Corsica early today on the eve of a visit by Interior Minister Gaston Defferre. The police said no one was injured but damage was severe. No one took responsibility for the explosions.

headline: ISRAELIS FRET IN SHEKELS AND DO BUSINESS IN DOLLARS
abstract: If you can say the English word ''over'' with a heavy Hebrew accent, you're on your way to gaining fluency in the Israeli lexicon of economic survival.    ''Over'' is becoming Hebrew slang for ''overdraft,'' the means by which Israelis make it through the month after their checking accounts run dry. These days, in the midst of new price rises, devaluations and general investor unease, all of Israel seems to be living on one big overdraft, deepening anxiety and challenging the ingenuity of both buyer and selller.   The South African immigrant who runs the Deli Nepi just off Jaffa Road lists the prices of his pastrami, pickles and corned beef on rye in Israeli shekels, but he thinks in dollars. ''I know what I pay for my meat in dollars,'' he said, ''and so I know what I have to charge in dollars.''

headline: EXILED EMPEROR WILL FIGHT TO STAY IN FRANCE
abstract: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, the army captain who became Emperor Bokassa I of the Central African Republic and who was later sentenced to death in that country for murder, said today that he would resist all attempts by the French Government to force him out of France.    The French Government indicated that it had other plans. ''It is not desireable that he remain,'' said Claude Cheysson, the Minister for External Affairs. ''We therefore are looking for another foreign country which will receive him.'' Mr. Cheysson spoke in Athens where he is attending the European Economic Community meeting.

headline: SALVADOR CLERIC SAYS 6,096 DIED
abstract: The Roman Catholic Auxiliary Bishop of San Salvador said today that 6,096 people had died in El Salvador's political conflict this year, most of them killed by the armed forces and right- wing death squads.   ''It is almost a rare thing to die a natural death in this country,'' Msgr.

headline: Money Fund Assets Rise
abstract: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose by $847 million, to $166.85 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. It was the sixth weekly increase in a row.

headline: U.S. Urges Rules for Air Tickets
abstract: The Justice Department's antitrust division said today that the airlines that run computerized reservation systems have been using them to punish competitors, and it called on the Civil Aeronautics Board to regulate the systems.   The division has conducted a two- year investigation into the systems, through which well over half the nation's airline tickets are sold.   ''The department has concluded that certain practices in the industry have harmed competition, and that some government intervention is necessary in order to alter those practices,'' the division said of the booking systems.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: Moody's Lowers Rating On U.S. Steel Issues    Moody's Investors Service yesterday reduced its ratings on $5.5 billion of debt and preferred stock of the United States Steel Corporation and its Marathon Oil subsidiary.    The long-term debt rating of the two companies was cut to Baa-2 from A-3, while subordinated debt of U.S. Steel was cut to Baa-3 from Baa-1.

headline: EFFORT TO LIFT DEBT LIMIT BOGGED DOWN IN SENATE
abstract: A Senate effort to raise the ceiling on the national debt by Monday was bogged down today as the Senators used the debt bill as a vehicle for a series of unrelated amendments ranging from Grenada and Lebanon to budget cuts.    Because several of these amendments were approved today, it is now expected that the House of Representatives may have to vote on the ceiling again, which could delay action into next week and force the postponement of several scheduled sales of Treasury securities totaling $16 billion.   But there is no immediate threat of shutting down the Government or not paying bills - as there has been in the past when the debt outstanding reached the ceiling - because the Treasury has an unusually large cash balance of $36 billion, enough to pay the bills through mid-November, officials said. The Social Security Administration said its November checks would be sent next week.

headline: Advertising; Henderson, Graf, Doyle In Merger
abstract: A RARE three-way ad agency merger was accomplished in the wee hours Friday morning, creating a $28 million shop named Henderson Friedlich Graf & Doyle. The new combination has particular strengths in the financial, high-technology and travel advertising fields.

headline: 3 Latin Nations Agree To Revive Defense Pact
abstract: The Defense Ministers of Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador, who met here over the weekend along with the chief of the United States Southern Command, have agreed to revive an anti-Communist military pact, the Guatemalan Army said.

headline: U.S. ARMS OFFICIAL OFFERS VIEW ON TALKS
abstract: The Reagan Administration's top arms control official said today that the Russians have given no formal message of plans to break off strategic arms talks in Geneva despite public hints that these talks were in jeopardy.    After today's one-hour negotiating session in Geneva, the Soviet delegate, Viktor P. Karpov, cast some doubt over the future of the talks by telling reporters that he did not know whether the Soviet Union would continue them next year after a scheduled recess. The current round of talks, which began on Oct. 8, is scheduled to end after one more session on Thursday.   Kenneth L. Adelman, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, said in a telephone interview late today, ''We have no indication they are going to break off'' the strategic arms reduction talks, known by their acronym Start.

headline: DRUSE SAY SHELLING WAS NOT RETALIATORY
abstract: The leaders of the Druse militiamen who killed eight United States marines on Sunday said today that the shelling had not been in retaliation for the United States' air raids in central Lebanon hours earlier.    The marines, they said, were not the main target of the shelling.   The leaders said that after a day of being shelled and sniped at by Lebanese Army units close to the Marine encampment at the Beirut Airport, Druse militiamen began returning the fire in early evening and that it spilled over onto the marines.   Officers of the Marine contingent said, however, they did not believe the shells that hit their positions had been ''spillover.''

headline: SPAIN GROWS LESS PRUDISH, BUT NOT YET LIBERTINE
abstract: A bent, elderly woman dressed entirely in black, from her stockings to her head scarf, was moving slowly down the street when she came upon a piece of paper on the sidewalk. It was a page from a popular magazine, a photo of a naked couple in amorous embrace.    The woman looked around slowly, stooped to pick it up and stared at it. Then she marched to a wastebasket, ripped the picture about eight times and dropped it in.

headline: A RICH PRESENT FOR RETAILERS
abstract: A higher-than-expected swell of Christmas buying across the country is expected to present the nation's retailers with their own holiday gift - their best profits in recent years.    The sales surge means that retailers' pretax earnings in December and the fourth quarter should be the highest since 1978. The season is expected to produce between 50 and 65 percent of the year's profits, instead of the normal 40 to 50 percent.    Stronger sales alone do not necessarily produce such healthy profits. But combined with inventory controls that are apparently tighter than usual this season, and operating expenses that do not increase through the holidays, the result is stronger-than-expected earnings, according to industry analysts and store executives.

headline: C.D. Rates Decline
abstract: Interest rates on certificates of deposit dropped sharply in New York and around the country last week, an indication that competition for the newly deregulated instruments was continuing to lessen, the Bank Rate Monitor said yesterday.   The Monitor's average of rates offered on six-month certificates by 10 major New York banks and thrift institutions dropped to 9.65 percent last week, from 9.84 percent.

headline: SPAIN'S FEMALE BULLFIGHTERS FIGHT MEN, TOO
abstract: The bullring was built in the traditional country way, with wood, scrap metal and old carriage wheels to protect the 6,000 spectators crammed together on wooden benches as the procession of bullfighters and horsemen entered the ring. It was as it has always been, but this time something was different - two of the three bullfighters were women.   One was Joachina Ariza, a 29-year- old Andalusian with short black hair known simply as ''La Alcabena'' - the woman from Alcalba. By choosing to enter the bullring she was fighting more than the bulls. She was battling centuries of tradition, symbolism and legend that add up to discrimination against women in Spain's most manly art.

headline: MARINE CHIEF DISAVOWS REMARK ABOUT WITHDRAWAL FROM BEIRUT
abstract: The Commandant of the Marine Corps, Gen. Paul X. Kelley, has disavowed a remark attributed to him on Thursday in which he said he was ''optimistic'' that the Marine Amphibious Unit in Lebanon could be withdrawn early next year.   General Kelley, contending that his Thursday statement had been misunderstood, said in a statement Saturday that ''our marines are fully prepared to remain in Lebanon until ordered to leave by competent authority.'' That authority would be President Reagan or Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger.

headline: MARKETING SPRINT: FIRST, LOWER FEES
abstract: The GTE Corporation announced yesterday that it would drop the monthly service fee it charges users of its long-distance Sprint service on Jan. 1 and replace it with a minimum monthly charge of $5.     Sprint currently charges residential customers a flat fee of $5 a month in addition to their calling charges. The monthly fee for business customers is $25. But beginning Jan. 1, GTE said, customers will not be charged the fee if they make more than $5 worth of long-distance calls during the month.

headline: MEXICO'S BORROWING MAY DROP
abstract: Mexico's net borrowing abroad in 1984 should be less than the $5 billion raised in 1983, Commerce Minister Hector Hernandez said here today.   He also indicated in an interview that lower interest rates on a package of credits being arranged for Brazil might lead to better conditions for Mexico's borrowing.   Mr. Hernandez declined to comment specifically on the Brazilian loan, but said that industrial nations benefited from lower terms on such loans because they enabled developing countries to increase imports.

headline: JERSEY FINDS CHARTER SOUND
abstract: The New Jersey Insurance Department, which supervises the sale of Charter Company annuities in every state except New York, said yesterday that Charter's New Jersey operation was ''financially sound and able to meet all its contractual obligations.''    The department also said in a statement that the Charter Security Life Insurance Company, the Charter Company subsidiary based in Chatham, N.J., was ''undergoing its routinely scheduled examination by our department, with the states of Georgia, Texas, Louisiana and New York participating.''   Asked about Charter's New York subsidiary, which handles the sale of annuities specially licensed for sale in that state, Salvatore R. Curiale, New York's deputy insurance superintendent, said, ''The New York Charter company is also O.K., and they're certainly able to meet their obligations.''

headline: HAITI IS ALIVE WITH RUMORS OF SUCCESSION
abstract: -AU-PRINCE, Haiti - When a new Constitution was rushed through Congress in a just a matter of hours recently, two tiny sections in all the small print seemed to open a crack in Haiti's hermetic palace politics.    One amendment gave President Jean-Claude Duvalier the right to choose his own successor; another authorized him to name a substitute should he travel abroad.   To members of the local elite, who have long studied the mysterious ways of the dynastic first family, the constitutional changes seemed to support persistent rumors here that President Duvalier is chronically ill and may have to leave Haiti for treatment.   Many questioned why Mr. Duvalier, who is President-for-Life and is only 32 years old, would be thinking about succession. They also said it was interesting that the President should want to travel now, although his father and he have never interrupted 25 combined years of rule with a trip abroad.

headline: DAYS OF CRISIS FOR PRESIDENT: GOLF, A TRAGEDY AND SECRETS
abstract: At midday Saturday, as President Reagan was in the midst of a round of golf at the Augusta National Golf Course in Georgia, he had under active consideration a secret request from Caribbean nations to join in the invasion of Grenada.   The President, already a legend in the Administration for keeping his own counsel, had begun the most secretive and momentous week of his incumbency with a golf club in his hands.   One of his golfing partners, Secretary of State George P. Shultz, was receiving the latest details of Grenada plans going on back in Washington, and discussing them with the President on the golf course, according to White House officials.   At the same time, the President's national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, was monitoring the situation nearby as the President stroked away.

headline: Technology; Home Barriers Against Theft
abstract: SALES of burglar alarms for the home are growing rapidly. A 1980 report by Frost & Sullivan, a market research firm, estimated that in 1978 only 1.9 percent of the approximately 75 million private homes in the United States had antitheft protection. This year, a survey by National Family Opinion and the trade magazine SDM (for security distributing and marketing) found that the share had grown to 8.6 percent.   Use of security systems in homes is still quite modest in comparison with virtual saturation in the commercial sector, says Joseph P. Freeman, an industry analyst and project director of an updated report to be published soon for Frost & Sullivan. But if the recovery continues, he predicts, another 1.5 percent of homeowners each year will have security systems installed, and the number could thus more than double in the next six years.

headline: Galaxy Oil Debt
abstract: The Galaxy Oil Company of Wichita Falls, Tex., said it had amended its agreements with its bank lenders, restructuring some $31 million in loans, and that it was no longer under default on the debt. Under the agreement, the company's existing $31 million debt to the banks was restructured into three credits, and a new $3.5 million line of credit was made available. A minimum of $3 million in additional funds was made available for development drilling on the San Pedro Ranch, which is Galaxy's principal oil and gas property in southwest Texas.

headline: THE PUBLICITY EFFECT OF I.B.M. 'STING'
abstract: It began with a dramatic ''sting'' that made headlines 17 months ago. Now the case against two Japanese companies accused of trying to steal secrets from I.B.M. is drawing to a quick, quiet and anticlimactic close.    Hitachi Ltd. and the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation have both been fined $10,000, a limited punishment that tends to make the initial uproar appear overblown. But industry analysts and attorneys see the lasting significance of the case in its public relations effects.

headline: EVER-FLEXIBLE OPTIONS
abstract: OPTIONS are sometimes compared to fire insurance: They can provide investors with coverage if a stock they own goes down, and they can allow investors to share in the increases on stocks they would like to purchase.  Options trading is both for the investor who ''looks to make a lot of money on a small investment, at the risk of losing it all'' and for the investor who is ''supplementing income or hedging an investment,'' said Gerald Kuschuk, manager of the options department at Prudential- Bache Securities.  One of the most versatile forms of investments, options can be bought or sold - on a particular stock, a small group of stocks, a group of stocks in one industry or the entire market.

headline: ADVERTISING ;  Addendum
abstract: * Modern Maturity magazine increasing its circulation rate base 5.9 percent, to 9 million from 8.5 million; its four-color advertising rates 10 percent, and its black-and-white 20 percent, with the April/May issue.

headline: REAGAN AIDES SAY C.I.A. BULLETIN WARNED OF LIKELY BEIRUT ATTACK
abstract: The Senate Appropriations Committee deleted $220 million in secret financing for a Jordanian strike force in the Middle East. Page A11.           WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 - Three days before a bomb blast killed United States marines, soldiers and sailors in Beirut, intelligence agencies warned that American forces in Lebanon would probably be the target of a terrorist attack, Reagan Administration officials said today.   The intelligence report, the officials said, specified that the group that appeared to be planning such an attack was a militant pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem group in Lebanon known as the Islamic Amal and the Party of God.

headline: 13 English Soccer Fans Jailed For a Luxembourg Rampage
abstract: Thirteen English soccer fans were jailed and fined today on charges of theft, looting and assault in a violent rampage after an international match.   The fans, aged 18 to 24, some strongly protesting their innocence, were sentenced in Luxembourg court as their mothers and girlfriends wept and protested.

headline: EXECUTIVES BACK TAX INCREASES
abstract: Although they insist on spending reductions, some of the nation's leading business executives are saying that substantial tax increases are inevitable and even a good idea if they reduce the Federal Government's budget deficits.   Several current and former chief executives of major American corporations, who concluded a three-day conference here on Saturday, said increased taxes would be preferable to budget deficits, which they believe are keeping interest rates unusually high given the drop in inflation.   Irwin Miller, chairman of the executive and finance committee of the Cummins Engine Company said he has always been ready to support a tax increase. ''We need more revenue, enough to get the budget deficit down substantially,'' Mr. Miller said.

headline: British Indexes Fall and Rise
abstract: The British economy's long- term leading indicators continued to decline in October, while the shorter leading indicators rose again, according to the Government's central statistical office. The longer leading index, which indicates turning points in economic activity about one year in advance, fell to 108.9 in October, from 110.2 in September.

headline: GRENADA NEIGHBOR IS SEARCHED BY U.S.
abstract: Three hundred United States marines looking for Cubans landed today on a tiny island 20 miles north of Grenada, but they returned to their ships several hours later without having found any, United States military officials said.   The marines reportedly detained 17 men believed to be members of the Grenadian People's Revolutionary Army and uncovered a cache of weapons and ammunition.     The Cuban Government said tonight that American troops had surrounded its embassy in Grenada. Havana also said its diplomatic personnel had been ordered out of the island. (Page A18.)

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: Bank Certificates Sold Through Bahamas Unit    The Union Bank of Los Angeles announced yesterday that it was selling $200 million of negotiable certificates of deposit through its branch in Nassau, the Bahamas.    According to an official at Merrill Lynch Money Markets Inc., which acts as dealer for the bank's certificates, the only other domestic banks to actively issue certificates in Nassau are Citibank and Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

headline: Rebels Attack in Salvador
abstract: About 300 rebels armed with automatic weapons attacked a town in the center of a Government reconstruction area, but pulled back today after 12 hours of combat. A Defense Ministry spokesman said one soldier was wounded in the attack on San Lorenzo, 37 miles east of the capital. San Lorenzo is at the center of a United States-financed reconstruction project designed to attract refugees back to their homes.

headline: Wisconsin Notes Offered at 5.75%
abstract: A $700 million issue of Wisconsin notes due June 15, 1984, is offered with a yield of 5.75 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

headline: G.M. RAISES DIVIDEND 40 CENTS, TO $1 A SHARE
abstract: The General Motors Corporation yesterday raised its quarterly dividend to $1 dollar a share, up from the 60 cents a share it has been paying since the second quarter of 1980.    The dividend is payable on Dec. 10 to those who are stockholders of record as of Nov. 17. With the higher quarterly payment, the total 1983 dividend will be $2.80 a share, up from $2.40 a share in 1982 and also in 1981. Before the second quarter of 1980, General Motors was paying quarterly dividends of $1.15 a share.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Kodak Layoff Hint    ROCHESTER, Oct. 19 (AP) - The president of the Eastman Kodak Company, Kay Whitmore, said selective layoffs might become necessary ''when a division or a department can find no other way to operate effectively.'' Mr. Whitmore was quoted in an employee magazine to be published Thursday. About 2,700 Kodak workers have already been laid off.

headline: WORKER INSURANCE EVOLUTION
abstract: Almost 75 years after it began in the United States, workers' compensation insurance is at a crossroads. Employers who pay for it, workers who receive it and insurance companies that handle it are all concerned whether the system, as currently structured, is equipped to handle its new financial burdens.   The payment of benefits to workers who suffer injury or death on the job has traditionally been the principal function of this state- regulated insurance system. But recently, regulators, insurance companies and others involved with workers' compensation have been focusing more intently on the increase in the value of claims for job-related diseases.

headline: Republic Airlines
abstract: The financially pressed Republic Airlines said it welcomed a proposal by leaders of its six unions to create a new employee stock-ownership plan that could buy up to 25 percent of the company's shares. The union leaders endorsed such a proposal at a meeting on Wednesday and intend to submit a plan to the master executive councils of the unions on Nov. 3. A. L. Maxson, senior vice president-finance, said that of the company's 13,300 employees, about 8,300 are already shareholders and own about 15 percent of the carrier's shares outstanding.

headline: DELOITTE BUYS JAPAN SPECIALIST
abstract: Deloitte Haskins & Sells, one of the Big Eight accounting firms, has acquired Sho Iino Accountants, an accounting firm that serves Japanese companies, Deloitte announced yesterday. Company officials would not disclose the purchase price or the financial terms of the agreement.   The acquisition is a part of the Deloitte program to expand into the growing market for accounting services to American branches of Japanese companies.

headline: PERSONAL INCOME RISES 1.2%, BUT SPENDING LAGS
abstract: Americans increased their personal income by 1.2 percent last month, the biggest rise in more than two years, but raised their spending by only about half that much, the Commerce Department reported today.   The report said part of the income gain came from the adjustment of wages following a strike by telephone workers. But even without that factor, the gain would have been 1.1 percent, the same as September's revised advance and still sizable.

headline: 2,100 Given Amnesty By Uganda's President
abstract: President Milton Obote granted full amnesty to 2,100 prisoners today to mark the 21st anniversary of Uganda's independence from Britain, the state-run Uganda radio reported.   It said the prisoners who were given amnesty were mostly first offenders and others who had been serving prison terms of three years or less for petty crimes.

headline: Colombia Bars Extradition
abstract: The Colombian Government has rejected a United States request for the extradition of a Colombian citizen charged with drug trafficking. A decree signed by President Belisario Betancur and published Saturday night said Jesus Mejia Romero, sought by the United States along with 22 other Colombians for his supposed involvement in drug trafficking to Florida, would be tried by local courts instead. The crime in which he was supposedly taking part had taken place in Colombia also, the decree said.

headline: NO U.S. BAR SEEN TO LTV STEEL PLAN
abstract: Economic  Analysis        Years ago, if the No. 4 and No. 3 steel companies had combined to form No. 2, the merger would have been the No. 1 target of trustbusters.  However, the proposed merger of the Republic Steel Corporation with the LTV Corporation, the parent company of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, is not expected to face an antitrust challenge from the Department of Justice or the Federal Trade Commission.   Republic, which is No. 4, and LTV, No. 3, submitted papers to Washington last Friday explaining the merger's effects, according to company spokesmen. One LTV official said the companies' main argument is that the combined entity's market share will not be so great as to have anticompetitive and therefore illegal effects. He noted that the ''failing company'' defense - which succeeded when the Lykes Corporation, parent of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, merged with LTV in 1978 - is a secondary argument.

headline: U.S. WAS WARNED BY MRS. THATCHER
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that the British Government had urged President Reagan to reconsider his plans to launch an invasion of Grenada after learning of them Monday, and that no British ships or forces had taken part.    The announcement in the House of Commons that Grenada, a member of the Commonwealth, had been invaded by an ally despite the Government's expressed misgivings led to harsh criticism of both the British Government and President Reagan by opposition parties and some of Mrs. Thatcher's own Conservatives.  France described the invasion as ''a surprising action in relation to international law'' and said it had not been informed of the action. (Page A19.)    The Soviet press called the invasion an ''act of undisguised banditry.'' Havana said Cuban workers in Grenada were ''heroically'' resisting American troops. Page A17.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Lilco Earnings Climb by 24.2%    The Long Island Lighting Company reported yesterday that it had earned $110.9 million, or 89 cents a share, in the third quarter, up 24.2 percent, from $89.3 million, or 81 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 16 percent, to $479 million, from $412.8 million.

headline: RETALIATORY MOVE BEING MENTIONED
abstract: A senior American official said today that if an investigation proved that a pro-Iranian group was responsible for the bombing of the United States Embassy in Kuwait this morning, the United States would probably consider retaliation, perhaps in coordination with France.   The official, traveling with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, said the United States was aware that the Islamic Holy War, a pro-Iranian group, had said it was responsibile for the attacks on five installations in Kuwait, including the American and French Embassies.   He said: ''We're conducting an investigation, both on the scene and in terms of intelligence collation, to see how this event relates to earlier bombings in the Middle East.''   The pro-Iranian group has said it was responsibile for the bombing of the American Embassy in Beirut last April and is believed to have been involved in bombings of American, French and Israeli military installations in Lebanon in the last two months. President Reagan vowed that the culprits would be punished for the attack on Oct. 23 that killed 240 marines, sailors and soldiers, but only French and Israeli planes made retaliatory raids. The United States bombed Syrian positions in Lebanon eight days ago in retaliation for an attack on United States Navy reconnaissance planes.

headline: REAGAN'S TRIP TO JAPAN: TIES REMAIN STRONG
abstract: News   Analysis    TOKYO, Nov. 6 - President Reagan's scheduled arrival here Wednesday for a three-day visit comes at a time when Japanese seem uncertain whether they are on good or bad terms with the United States.  If they wished, Mr. Reagan and Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone could find plenty to talk about to make them mutually unhappy. Japan still does not spend enough on defense to satisfy many Americans, two-way trade is likely to produce a $23 billion deficit for the United States this year and continued high unemployment has left some Americans with the notion that the Japanese are responsible for many of their troubles.   There is grousing, too, on this side of the Pacific, mostly out of conviction that every time something goes wrong in the United States, Japan is made a scapegoat. The sense that this country tends to be picked on unfairly is sufficiently engrained for a new word to have cropped up in some circles here: ''goatability.'' It is used only partly in jest.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
abstract: 30-Year Bonds By Fannie Mae    The Federal National Mortgage Association announced plans yesterday to sell $700 million of debentures tomorrow, including the first 30-year issue ever by a Federal agency.   Interest rates will be announced today for $250 million of debentures due Dec. 10, 1986, $200 million due Dec. 10, 1990, and $250 million due Dec. 10, 2013.

headline: 30 Groups Ask Marcos To Resolve Succession
abstract: Thirty business, professional and labor organizations appealed today to President Ferdinand E. Marcos to help head off national financial disaster by resolving questions of succession should he die or become incapacitated.   Their full-page advertisement in The Bulletin Today, the country's most widely circulated newspaper, read less like a criticism of the President than a plea for his help.

headline: TREASURY ISSUES TO DOMINATE WEEK
abstract: The Treasury sector will be the focus of attention in the credit markets this holiday-shortened week. Besides the regular weekly auction of bills totaling $12.8 billion, the Treasury plans to sell $6 billion of four-year notes, $5.25 billion of seven-year notes and $3.75 billion of bonds due in about 20 years.    Only about $250 million of tax-exempt bonds are scheduled for sale this week, the largest being a $170 million issue of Chicago special facilities revenue bonds for O'Hare International Airport. Although the volume of new issues is down sharply from the $2 billion or more sold in recent weeks, securities dealers will still be busy distributing the earlier offerings.

headline: LOSS SEEN IN WESTERN UNION MOVE
abstract: In two moves to prepare for a great intensification of competition next year, the Western Union Corporation said yesterday that it would take a one-time $125 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings and reduce its staff 5 percent.    Analysts said the charge, involving a reduction in its valuation of assets, would result in a loss of about $102 million in the fourth quarter and $35 million for the full year. But a spokesman for Western Union said that the company's cash flow would not be seriously affected and that it did not expect the action to have any impact on dividends.   The company also announced a new marketing emphasis on Easylink, an electronic mail service and successor to its telex service that allows communication between computer terminals, using telephones. Western Union named John F. Naughton, a senior marketing executive, as vice president and product line manager for Easylink.

headline: ADVERTISING ; 3 of 9 Investigations Result in Ad Changes
abstract: Only three of the nine investigations of national advertising claims were resolved in November when the advertisers in question either changed or dropped the advertising.    In the other six, the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus found the claims supportable.

headline: U.S. PROPOSES TO DROP OIL PAYMENT PROGRAM
abstract: With $426 million in claims at stake, the Energy Department proposed today to abandon the program under which the nation's oil refiners were required to make cost-equalization payments to each other while prices were under Federal control.   This means that some companies with below-average crude oil costs would be relieved of paying tens of millions of dollars in liabilities that were on the Energy Department's books when President Reagan lifted the remaining price controls in January 1981. By the same token, other, high-cost refiners would not receive similar payments to which the department reckoned they had been entitled.   The department invited comments on the proposal during the next 30 days. But however Secretary Donald P. Hodel rules on the matter after receiving the comments, his decision is sure to touch off a new burst of lawsuits, either from those who will receive no money or from those required to pay.

headline: TURKISH ALLY OF CAPITALISM
abstract: Turkey's champion of free enterprise, whose party won the parliamentary elections on Sunday, irritated the ruling generals during the campaign with what they viewed as his brash promises. He said that as Prime Minister he could even sell shares in the bridge over the Bosporus to citizens to raise money for development projects.    To the military, such campaigning by Turgut Ozal, the 56-year-old economist who leads the conservative Motherland Party, was the hallmark of a man given to what President Kenan Evren derided as untruths and sweet promises. But the voters, apparently impressed by his aggressively positive approach, gave the Motherland Party 212 of the 400 seats in Parliament.  The President congratulated him today and is expected to name him Prime Minister later in the month.

headline: Washington Post Gains
abstract: The Washington Post Company said today that its net income for the third quarter rose 44.7 percent, to $12.3 million, or 86 cents a share, from $8.5 million, or 60 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 9.3 percent, to $202.9 million, from $185.7 million.

headline: A TEXAS BANK'S TIES TO OIL
abstract: The search for a buyer of the Midland bank is narrowing. Page D4.             MIDLAND, Tex., Oct. 13 - The First National Bank here took pride in being an Oil Patch bank, an institution that loaned money to the industry on a handshake. And now that it is failing, there is an outpouring of emotional support from those it has helped over the years.

headline: Searchers Off China Spot Life Jacket From Ship
abstract: Searchers spotted a life jacket from a missing United States oil-drilling ship in the South China Sea, a rescue official said today, but there were no signs that any of the 81 crew members had survived after a typhoon hit the vessel.   Chinese ships, meanwhile, were measuring what might be the wreck of the ship on the sea floor, the official New China News Agency reported.

headline: CONTINENTAL REAFFIRMS PLANS TO FLY
abstract: Executives of Continental Air Lines said here today that passenger response remained strong in the face of a strike called for Saturday by pilots and flight attendants and that more than enough air crews would be on hand to fly the carrier's new schedules.   Frank Lorenzo, Continental's chairman, said at a news conference that demand for the airline's new cut-rate, $75 fare had been ''unusually overwhelming'' despite the threat of a pilots' strike. Mr. Lorenzo said an estimated 1.4 million calls had been made to the airline's reservation system on Thursday, more than 10 times the previous record of 120,000 calls in one day.    The Air Line Pilots Association voted on Thursday to strike Continental at 3 A.M., Eastern daylight time, on Saturday.

headline: SICILIANS PROTEST AT MISSILE BASE
abstract: Antimissile demonstrators formed a six- mile human chain today in an attempt to link Catania with a United States naval base where NATO nuclear missiles are stored, witnesses said.   But a spokesman for the Italian Ecumenical Center said the human chain missed its mark by about two and a half miles.

headline: Greek Panel Approves Accord on U.S. Bases
abstract: The Greek Parliament's Foreign Affairs Committee has approved an agreement reached with Washington on the future of United States bases, it was announced here today.

headline: TWO PLANS OFFERED FOR KAISER ASSETS
abstract: The Kaiser Steel Corporation's assets may be divided between an Oklahoma-based investor group and a Colorado coal-mining company. a Kaiser spokesman said today.   Kaiser earlier filed a document with the Securities and Exchange Commission that said the investor group, led by J. A. Frates of Tulsa, Okla., and the Perma Resources Corporation, of Colorado Springs, are considering two possible transactions for a Kaiser acquisition.

headline: BRITONS SHYING AWAY FROM MISSILES
abstract: On the eve of a scheduled parliamentary debate on the stationing of cruise missiles, there are signs that the Government's plans for deploying some of the American missiles have become extremely unpopular after the invasion of Grenada.    The Government is certain to win the vote in Parliament on the deployment of the 160 missiles at two American bases. But public-opinion polls released this weekend suggest that the political cost may be higher than Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had thought before American troops invaded the tiny Commonwealth island.

headline: BRITAIN IS OFFERING TO SERVE IN PEACEKEEPING FORCE
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told the House of Commons today that Britain would look sympathetically on any request to join other Commonwealth nations in a peacekeeping force for Grenada.    She also said Britain would abstain from a United Nations resolution deploring the American invasion.   She spoke on a day of embarrassment for her Government, whose advice against the invasion was ignored by the United States, and for Queen Elizabeth, whose representative in Grenada, Sir Paul Scoon, the Governor General, was reported on Wednesday to have requested the invasion.   The Queen is the head of state of both Britain and other Commonwealth countries.  Grenada has belonged to the Commonwealth since gaining independence in 1974. A governor general is the Queen's titular representative in a Commonwealth country, carrying out largely ceremonial functions.

headline: President Resigns At Centerre Bank
abstract: A prominent St. Louis banker, Richard F. Ford, announced his resignation yesterday as president, chief operating officer and a director of the Centerre Bank and its parent, the Centerre Bancorporation.   A spokesman said that Mr. Ford, who is 47 years old, and the bank's chairman and chief executive, Clarence C. Barksadle, were out of the office for the afternoon.   In a statement, Mr. Barksdale said: ''For some time, Dick has entertained the idea of pursuing other business interests. However, we both agreed that it was in the best interest of the company that he remain until the bank had an opportunity to restructure its loan operations. Now that this has been accomplished, Dick has chosen to leave.''

headline: Security Council to Convene To Discuss Iran-Iraq Conflict
abstract: The Security Council will meet at 11 A.M. on Monday to consider new proposals to end the war between Iran and Iraq, the United Nations announced today.   Members agreed to the session in private consultations late Friday night after examining a draft resolution that would call for the ''immediate cessation of all hostilities in the region of the Persian Gulf,'' an official said.   France, which has been supplying arms to Iraq, is understood to be behind the new peace effort, although the resolution's listed sponsors are Guyana, Togo and Zaire.

headline: 2 GUNMEN SHOOT JORDAN'S AMBASSADOR TO ROME
abstract: Two gunmen shot and seriously wounded Jordan's Ambassador to Italy and his driver today as they left the Jordanian Embassy, the police said.   The attack came a day after Jordan's Ambassador to India was shot six times in New Delhi.

headline: WEINBERGER TIED TO CURB ON PRESS
abstract: A Pentagon spokesman said this week that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger approved in advance the restrictions imposed on reporters in the first days of the invasion of Grenada.   Mr. Weinberger himself said at a news conference on the second day of the invasion Oct. 26 that the policy had been made by commanders in the field and that he would not overrule them.   The Pentagon spokesman, Michael I. Burch, said in an interview that Mr. Weinberger had discussed the issue of news coverage before the troops landed and had decided to keep the press away.   On the same issue, the White House chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d, said he had not known about the restrictions in advance but did approve of them and would use them again in a similar situation, which he characterized as ''a commando raid.''

headline: Austrians Seize False Gold Tied to London Bullion Theft
abstract: The Austrian police announced the arrest today of 5 men and the discovery of 10 counterfeit gold bars stamped with numbers and refiner's name to match 6,000 real bars stolen in Britain last month.   The police said the five arrested in Vienna on Tuesday night apparently planned to sell the counterfeit gold, passing it off as part of the haul of three tons of bullion stolen by masked gunmen from a warehouse near London's Heathrow Airport on Nov. 26.

headline: PROBLEMS OF THE YEN'S VALUE
abstract: The interrelated problems of trade and the value of the yen relative to the dollar are expected to be two of the dominant topics during President Reagan's discussions this week in Japan with Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone.    No solutions are expected as a result of these talks, but the fact that they are on the agenda is viewed as a positive sign by business executives and economists in the United States.   The following questions and answers explain the problems, how they arose and what, if anything, can be done about them.   Q. Why are trade with Japan and the value of the yen so important to the United States?

headline: A LOVE-HATE AFFAIR ON LAKE ONTARIO
abstract: You can still go to the old places here - those saloons with their separate gentlemen's and ladies' entrances, where the endless glasses of draft beer come in even numbers.  ''Each drinker is an island unto himself,'' said a patron of the Wheatsheaf, founded in 1849 and Toronto's oldest bar. ''Ontario may be the Scotland that was.''   There is also the Elm Grove Tavern, where the locals remember a man walking in six or seven years ago, shooting a customer and then strolling to another bar across the street to order a beer and wait for the police. Or the Edgewater, which a regular calls ''the last bastion of the bouffant'' and where old men in tuques timelessly chew on tobacco and the world's problems. Or the Winchester, where a makeshift country band sometimes forgets the words.

headline: Coast Thrift Unit Fights Takeover BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP) - The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association said it had obtained a temporary restraining order preventing Paul Amir, a dissident shareholder and real estate developer, from buying more of its stock.
abstract: David I. McDougall, the association's corporate secretary, said that the association is trying to prevent Mr. Amir from taking over the association, which has assets of $1.6 billion.   Mr. Amir received clearance Friday from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to acquire more than 10 percent of the association's stock, according to his attorney, Terry Christensen. Mr. Amir then demanded a Jan. 27 shareholders meeting to vote on removing the association's board of directors and electing a new slate.

headline: U.S. SEVENTH ARMY UNDERGOES A RENOVATION
abstract: Military   Analysis        HEIDELBERG, West Germany - The United States Seventh Army, after years of operating with older equipment, is now being heavily refurbished.  The Seventh Army, which has its headquarters here, is getting more than 400 new weapons and support systems, ranging from M-1 Abrams tanks to high technology communications networks.   Expenditures for modernizing the forces in 1984 will be $239 million more than in 1982, and spending for maintenance and repair will increase by $91 million over the same period.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The U.N. Today Oct. 31, 1983 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 11:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 11 A.M., 3 P.M. and 6 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Moscow Police Stop A John Lennon Rally
abstract: The police seized at least three young people who had gathered in a small, quiet rally today to remember John Lennon, who was killed three years ago in New York.

headline: Economic Scene; Large Deficits: Pressure Rises
abstract: SENIOR advisers in the Reagan Administration are drafting a forecast for economic growth of 4.5 percent next year, as measured from the fourth quarter of this year to the fourth quarter of next year. Beyond 1984, the Administration is assuming that the economy will grow by an average of 4 percent a year through 1989 as a basis for its long-term budget planning. But even with such optimistic assumptions, huge budget deficits loom.    Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers and still champion of the probable necessity of future tax increases despite the efforts of at least some members of the White House staff to dump him, is feeling no pain these days. Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and President Reagan acknowledge that there may have to be tax increases after the election, but they want bigger spending cuts first - that is, cuts in nonmilitary spending.

headline: IN TEXTBOOKS, STEREOTYPES OF ARABS
abstract: Some Israeli experts say they have found that Hebrew textbooks are replete with negative stereotypes of Arabs and that the curriculums in Israeli Jewish schools have done little or nothing to eradicate prejudice.   ''What the kids are getting is a lot of stuff on Arab-Jewish wars and standard red-neck bigotry in order to prepare them for age 18 to go out and kill,'' said Benyamin Chetkow-Yanoov, who teaches social work at Bar-Ilan University in Tel Aviv.   The dominant theme of reading books in the lower grades is war and patriotism, according to Daniel Bar- Tal, a professor of psychology at Tel Aviv University's school of education. He is conducting a research project on the matter.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS; RATES UP AMID DEBT ANXIETY
abstract: Continued anxiety over the impact of the Treasury's cancellation of its debt package pushed interest rates higher yesterday.   While traders believe Congress will eventually raise the national debt ceiling and free the Treasury to reschedule the $16 billion in notes and bonds, they fear that the market will have difficulty absorbing the securities. With the Treasury already scheduled to hold further auctions beginning Nov. 22, dealers are concerned that rates will have to climb higher to attract buyers.  ''The bottom line is the closer you get to year-end the less time you have to distribute a huge amount of supply,'' said Maria Ramirez, money market economist at Merrill Lynch Economics Inc, ''and since eventually the debt ceiling will be raised, the Treasury will have to auction the same anount of securities in a smaller time span.''

headline: ADVERTISING
abstract: Radio Bureau's Chief    The executive committee of the Radio Advertising Bureau on Friday gave the chief executive's title to William Stakelin, 41, who joined the bureau in July as president and chief operating officer. Miles David, vice chairman who was president from 1965 to 1982, will serve as a consultant.

headline: OFFICIALS RAISE POSSIBILITY OF A LONG GUERILLA WAR
abstract: Military   Analysis    American military sources said yesterday that serious consideration must be given to the possibility that some Cuban troops in Grenada might fight a protracted guerrilla war against the United States invasion forces.   United States officers on the island have revised their estimates of the number of Cubans in Grenada, where earlier this week the total had been estimated at 1,000, including workers who before the invasion had been building an airstrip at Point Salines.  Yesterday the figure was put at 1,100, with more than 600 being held prisoner.    Three hundred or more were said to be in the hills near Pearls, the commercial port on the northeastern coast, and the rest in hills near the Point Salines airfield at the southwestern tip of the island.   A War of Harassment    Given adequate weapons and ammunition, the American military sources said, the Cubans could carry on a war of harassment based on the positions they are believed to hold in the hills that run from near the capital, St. George's, northeast of Point Salines to well beyond Pearls Airport.

headline: AIRLINES SEE OLYMPIC GOLD
abstract: A lot of ticket holders to the Olympic Games in Los Angeles next summer seem likely to get a shock from the price of their airline seats.   Like the hotel and car rental industries, the airlines are looking to reap a windfall from the stampede of spectators at the summer Olympic Games, the first to be held in the United States in 52 years. About 500,000 extra passengers are expected to fly into the Los Angeles area during the Games.   The top six carriers serving Los Angeles have rescinded their normal discount fare during a four-week period. This may force some transcontinental passengers to pay more than twice the usual bargain rate on nonstop flights.

headline: INVASION TROOPS TRAINED TO MAKE SURPRISE RAIDS
abstract: The United States troops who invaded Grenada early this morning consisted of marines and Army Rangers, units trained for such operations. Rangers are soldiers specially trained to fight in small groups and to undertake surprise raids in any terrain or weather.   Government officials said in press briefings today that about 700 Rangers and 1,200 marines of a Marine amphibious unit landed in the island. The officials said some of the Rangers parachuted into the Point Salines area near the southern end of the island. If so, this would be the first combat jump by United States airborne troops since the Vietnam War, when such jumps were a sparingly used tactic.

headline: SAUDIS REASSESS THE GAINS BOUGHT WITH OIL
abstract: A cascade of petrodollars over the last 10 years has dramatically transformed the contours of life in the Persian Gulf.    But it has also brought economic and social problems that remain unresolved.   And the decade of apparently limitless wealth is ending with the clear realization that oil revenues, although huge, are indeed finite. Oil production has slowed, and the global recession has shrunk the markets that the region's shiny new industrial installations were designed to serve.   This is raising serious questions about whether the OPEC members along the Gulf have spent their billions wisely, and whether they have acquired the political leverage that these billions should have brought them.

headline: THE THICKET OF LEBANON
abstract: Four United States marines were slightly wounded when a car bomb exploded near refugee camps on the southern edge of Beirut. Page A13.           NewsAnalysis    BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 19 - The prospects for a genuine settlement of grievances by Lebanon's feuding religious and political factions seemed more remote than ever today as the Government put off Thursday's opening of a national reconciliation conference.  The principals had objected to the Government's choice of a site, the Beirut International Airport, which is guarded by the United States Marines.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM EDITORIALS ON THE BOMBING OF MARINE HEADQUARTERS IN ; BEIRUT
abstract: The Philadelphia Inquirer    Tragically it is time to recognize that there are honorable tasks on this earth that cannot be completed. That if there were 16,000 U.S. Marines committed to peacekeeping in Lebanon - instead of the 1,600 who were there before 6:20 Sunday morning and those who now remain alive - they could not impose order, political stability, on the warring, hating, barbarous factions that are there. Nor, finally, could 160,000.    The Boston Globe    Whatever comes of investigations, grieving American families know only that their loved ones died in a helpless way in a seemingly hopeless cause.

headline: Canadian Denies U.S. Barred A Rescue Plan for Grenada
abstract: Allan J. MacEachen, the Canadian Minister of External Affairs, said at a news conference on Monday that he had ''absolutely no evidence'' to show that the United States or its Caribbean allies in the invasion of Grenada had blocked Canadian rescue plans so that these would not interfere with the military landings then being prepared.
