Mr. MacEachen said he had accepted the explanations offered by the Caribbean nations that the plane, chartered from Leeward Islands Air Transport, had been denied permission to leave Barbados for Grenada as part of the Caricom nations' decision to impose a commercial and economic boycott on Grenada after Maurice Bishop, its Prime Minister, had been killed.

headline: CAPITAL SPENDING LAGGING
abstract: Two weeks ago at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, painted a rosy picture of the nation's economic prospects. With lots of hard work and a bit of luck, he told the annual Business Outlook Conference, there was a good chance for five years of solid expansion in the nation's economy.   But even as Mr. Smith was speaking, the director of corporate planning for a major capital goods company based in the Middle West could be seen shaking his head in disbelief.  This vignette tells a lot about what has been going on in the American economy this year. Consumer spending - especially for autos and housing - has come roaring back to life. But expenditures on new plant and equipment, which represent the business investment side of the economy, have barely started to recover.

headline: BELGIAN EX-NAZI ADMITS WORKING FOR U.S. INTELLIGENCE AFTER 1945
abstract: Robert Jan Verbelen, a former Belgian Nazi leader, admitted today that he was a spy for the United States in Vienna for eight years after World War II, heading a network of 100 agents.   His statement in an interview followed an accusation Wednesday by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith in New York that he was employed by United States Army counterintelligence in Austria from 1947 to 1955. The League made the accusation after getting access to United States Government documents under the Freedom of Information Act.

headline: Advertising; Magazine Publishing Hazards
abstract: People who follow the magazine business are often struck by the frequent failure of many new magazines put out by giant, experienced publishing companies - especially since many new publications put out by novices have made it.   James B. Kobak, a well-known consultant in the magazine field, describing the ''fun but dangerous'' game of starting a magazine to members of both the Magazine Publishers Association and the American Society of Magazine Editors, recited a litany of losers: Cable TV Week, from Time Inc.; Families, from Reader's Digest; Inside Sports, from Newsweek; The National Observer, from Dow Jones. Mr. Kobak's presentation was made at the Southampton Princess for the three-day, 64th annual American Magazine Conference.   Although publishers must constantly be planning for new publications, Mr. Kobak said, statistically the prospects for them are rather bleak. His research shows that of the consumer magazines of more than 100,000 circulation brought out since 1965, two-thirds were put out by newcomers to magazine publishing.

headline: LENT SAYS PANEL ALLOWS HIM TO VOTE ON NYNEX
abstract: Representative Norman F. Lent said today that as a result of an opinion by the House Committee on Standards of Ethical Conduct, he intended to continue voting on legislation concerning the reorganization of the nation's telephone system.    Mr. Lent, a Republican who represents Nassau County, requested the ruling after it became known that his wife, Barbara Morris Lent, had been hired as a lobbyist for the Nynex Corporation. After the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company on Jan. 1, Nynex will operate the local telephone systems of New York and parts of New England.

headline: Business and the Law; Unitary Tax Scope Widens
abstract: AS states find themselves increasingly hard- pressed for revenues, more and more are converting to the so-called unitary worldwide method of figuring corporate income taxes.   The unitary worldwide tax, which was upheld by the Supreme Court in June, allows states to take into account the worldwide profits of large corporations. Under California's law, the specific statute upheld by the Court, the state determines what percentage of a multinational concern's payroll, property and sales are within the state - and then taxes that percentage of the company's worldwide profits. California gets some $500 million in extra revenues because of the unitary tax method. Currently, a dozen states have a unitary worldwide tax system, and several others are considering one.

headline: NAVY SAYS ACCIDENT IS MINOR
abstract: A Soviet guided-missile frigate that was apparently shadowing the United States aircraft carrier Ranger had a ''minor collision'' with an American destroyer today in the northern Arabian Sea, the Defense Department reported tonight.    There were no American casualties and the collision was so slight that it appeared there were no Soviet injuries either.   It occurred at about 3:30 P.M. New York time, a spokesman for the Defense Department said. The vessels involved were the Fife, a destroyer with the United States Seventh Fleet, and the Soviet guided-missile frigate Razyashchy.

headline: NICARAGUA FACES A NEW SHORTAGE: TOYS
abstract: Managua has been hit by an acute shortage of toys.    Parents wait hours in line at Government-run stores for a chance to buy dolls and toy trucks. Meanwhile, in other parts of the city, private vendors peddle water pistols and talking robots at inflated prices.   Press reports have laid much of the blame on the Minister of Internal Commerce, Dionisio Marenco, charging his agency with inefficiency, and accusing his employees of helping themselves to the best toys before they are put on public sale.

headline: A TEST FOR DIPLOMACY: BROOKLYN VISITORS AT THE U.N.
abstract: The question was direct, a bit angry: ''Why do the African countries always vote with the Arabs against Israel?''   The question was asked by a visitor from Brooklyn, one of 150 people here at the United Nations today for a special tour that included frank and even at times confrontational talks with diplomats.   An answer came from a man who sat across the table from them, Joseph Legwaila, the permanent representative of Botswana at the United Nations.   ''We think the attitude of the African countries will change as soon as the attitude of Israel changes,'' he said. ''My country believes that the Arabs are wrong.

headline: Jordanian King in Baghdad
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan arrived in Baghdad today accompanied by his Prime Minister, Modar Badran, and other senior aides, the official Iraqi press agency said.

headline: BONN DISCLOSES SOVIET MOVES ON NEW MISSILE OFFER
abstract: West German officials provided some details today of what they called an attempt by the Soviet Union to present a new arms reduction proposal as though it had originated with the United States.   The West German officials said the Soviet Ambassador to Bonn, Vladimir S. Semyonov, delivered a three-page letter to Chancellor Helmut Kohl's office on Thursday night.   The Soviet letter asserted that Paul H. Nitze, the United States negotiator at the talks in Geneva, had presented a new proposal that called for reducing the number of Soviet SS-20's targeted on Western Europe from 243 to 120 in exchange for NATO forgoing deployment of new American Pershing 2 and cruise missiles.   Similar Soviet assertions were made in London, Brussels, Rome and The Hague, all Western European capitals that are scheduled to deploy the new American medium-range missiles, one source said.

headline: Data Bank; November 13, 1983
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: BRAZIL PACT OUTLINED TO BANKS
abstract: A delegation of Brazilian officials and international bankers set out yesterday on a round-the-world trip to sell a tentative $11.8 billion credit agreement to the 800 commercial banks that have lent money to Brazil. The agreement postpones for five years payment of debt principal owed in 1984 by Brazil.    Affonso Celso Pastore, president of the central bank of Brazil; William R. Rhodes, a senior vice president of Citibank who is the chairman of a 14- bank advisory group for Brazil, and William B. Dale, deputy managing director of the International Monetary Fund, flew first to Toronto for a meeting with Canadian creditors at the Bank of Montreal.   Meanwhile, technical experts from the advisory committee were meeting in New York to iron out details of the agreement the delegation is promoting, an agreement reached in Washington Thursday between Brazilian officials and a coordinating committee of 60 commercial banks. The package consists principally of $6.5 billion in new loans to be used to cover interest payments due this year and next and $5.3 billion in rescheduling of principal due in 1984. The principal payments were rescheduled to start in 1988 and to last four years. Repayment of the principal of the new $6.5 billion loan also will start in 1988.

headline: INTEREST RATES RISE MODESTLY
abstract: Short- and long-term interest rates rose modestly yesterday in uneventful trading.    On the eve of today's meeting of Federal Reserve monetary policy makers on the Federal Open Market Committee, analysts said that a move to reduced short-term interest rates might not come until market participants have better knowledge about the extent of any decline in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market. Yesterday, the closely watched overnight rate averaged an estimated 9.55 percent after opening at 9 3/8 percent and rising to 10 percent late in the day.   ''The funds rate will have to subside closer to the 9 percent level or even below it in order for any improvmeent to be visible in the short end of the markets,'' analysts at Merrill Lynch Economics Inc. said in the Daily Credit Market Comment.   During yesterday's trading Treasury bills fluctuated in a narrow range with the three-month rate rising one basis point to 8.74 percent. Rates for other money market instruments due in less than a year were little changed.

headline: U.S. EASES RESTRICTIONS ON COVERAGE
abstract: The Defense Department eased restrictions on news coverage in Grenada today by increasing the number of reporters and camera crews allowed there and permitting them overnight or even indefinite stays.    ''We've virtually opened it up all the way,'' said Michael I. Burch, a retired Air Force officer who is the Pentagon's Assistant Secretary-designate for Public Affairs.   Mr. Burch said that the 168 reporters and photographers flown to Grenada today from Barbados were told they were free to remain as long as they wished but with the understanding that they would not receive any military support services, such as land transportation, housing, food and water and facilities for transmitting their reports and pictures.   Mr. Burch said he made the decision to allow greater access to news reporters after conferring with aides to Adm.  Wesley L. McDonald, commanding officer of United States forces in the Atlantic, and Vice Adm. Joseph Metcalf 3d, who is commander of the task force that invaded Grenada.

headline: MERCK'S BIG VENTURE IN JAPAN
abstract: Perhaps the most striking sign of the changes that are reshaping the Japanese pharmaceutical industry came in August when Merck & Company bought a controlling interest in the Banyu Pharmaceutical Company, a major drug maker in Tokyo.   Merck's $314 million purchase is being hailed here as a sign of the growing importance of the lucrative Japanese drug market to foreign companies, and also as an indication of a new receptivity in Government and business circles to sizable acquisitions by overseas concerns.    Through its control of prices, the Government is forcing a consolidation among the roughly 400 domestic producers that supply the $12 billion- a-year market in Japan for prescription drugs. In the last year, the Government has stiffened its system of making annual price reductions on old drugs, while speeding the approval of new and relatively high- priced drugs. The purpose is to reward innovative companies and make the country's fragmented industry internationally competitive.

headline: SALVADORAN TROOPS RETAKE TOWN
abstract: Government troops fanned out into the mountains in search of guerrillas today after retaking this town from an estimated 1,500 rebels reportedly commanded by a Roman Catholic priest.   At least seven soldiers and one civilian were killed in heavy fighting Sunday when the rebels captured the town and then lost it, military officers said.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE
abstract: Schering-Plough Head Wears Yet Another Hat     Robert P. Luciano has added still another title at the Schering-Plough Corporation.   Mr. Luciano, 50, was recruited five years ago as senior vice president for administration of the Kenilworth, N.J., company.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: *  Advest Inc., Hartford, Conn., has named Robert L. Thomas executive vice president.     *  Business Men's Assurance Co., Kansas City, Mo., announced that Kenneth Higdon, president and chief operating officer, was taking early retirement.

headline: GRENADA SNIPERS WOUND 2 G.I.'S
abstract: Snipers wounded two United States paratroopers today, military spokesmen said. Their wounds were said to be slight.   The incident raised to 115 the number of Americans wounded since the invasion of Grenada more than three weeks ago. Eighteen American servicemen have been reported killed.

headline: 2 Afghans Executed For '82 Murder
abstract: Two Islamic rebels who were convicted of killing a senior Afghan official a year ago have been executed in Kabul, the Afghan capital, the Kabul radio said today.

headline: ISRAELI BIDS ARABS 'OPEN A DIALOGUE'
abstract: President Chaim Herzog of Israel, in a speech that was applauded by some delegates and boycotted by many others, appealed today to Arab countries to negotiate their differences with his Government.   Mr. Herzog, speaking in a half empty General Assembly Hall, said:   ''For years, we maintained that dialogue is the only road to peace and that negotiations, however protracted and difficult, must lead to positive results. Let us begin to talk. Let us open a dialogue. Let us forget the bitterness of the past.''

headline: STRIFE HURTS SALVADOR NEWS OUTLETS
abstract: When a radio station here did not broadcast a statement issued recently by a right- wing paramilitary group, bombs were planted in the building. As a result, the owner has decided to stop all news broadcasts.    El Mundo, San Salvador's only evening newspaper, which is financially pressed, and three other radio stations were warned by the same paramilitary organization, the Secret Anti-Communist Army, that they should stop running paid political advertisements by unions or what it described as ''other Communist groups'' such as Mothers of the Disappeared.   According to editors who did not want to be identified, news considered controversial is rarely reported in the press here, in the words of one, ''because of the situation.''

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 21, 1983: MONDAY Bank Amer Rlty InvGenuine PartsBaxter Travenol LabsGopodrich (B F) CoCentury Tel EnterpInterlake IncCigna CorpJohnson ControlsDisney (Walt) PrdtnsNafco Finl GroupDu Pont (E I) CoRepublic CorpFirst Interstate BncrpSan Diego G & E

headline: New Zealander to Visit U.S.
abstract: President Reagan will meet Prime Minister Robert D. Muldoon of New Zealand in Washington early next year, the White House announced today. The two will confer on Feb. 24.

headline: 'WE WILL NOT RENEGE,' AIDE SAYS
abstract: The Government of Prime Minister Bettino Craxi reaffirmed Italy's determination tonight to keep its military contingent in Beirut.    ''Italy intends to continue its commitment to the multinational force,'' Mr. Craxi said on television after a meeting of his Cabinet Council, a select group within the Cabinet, that concentrated on the bomb attacks on the American and French military headquarters.   In a fuller statement, Defense Minister Giovanni Spadolini said: ''Italy reaffirms its commitment for peace in Lebanon. The mourning of the Americans and French is also our mourning. We will not renege on our role in the Mediterranean, a role dedicated to preserving the conditions for dialogue and coexistence among the peoples.''

headline: Advertising; New Name And Plan At Agency
abstract: EURO CENTER COMMUNICATIONS opened its office in New York in the fall of 1980 as an agency with a difference. It planned to attract smaller international marketers who wanted more control over their advertising abroad.    As with many plans, this one did not work out. Now the owners will be taking a more conventional name to reflect that they have unintentionally become a conventional agency.

headline: U.S. FORCES: NEED ARISING FOR MORE TROOPS, SHIPS AND PLANES
abstract: Military   Analysis    The strain on United States military resources is growing, and Defense Department officials say they believe that if it continues, as appears likely, more men, ships and aircraft will be needed.   They said present military commitments and operational plans for future contingencies had stretched available forces thin in this country and abroad. The demands responsible for the strain include the landing yesterday of about 2,000 troops in Grenada, the replacement of marines lost in Sunday's bomb attack on the Marine contingent's base in Lebanon, the probable reinforcement of that force and the deployment of Army and Navy forces in Central America.   The armed forces of the United States total 2,136,400, including 198,700 women.   194,600 in the Marines    The Marine Corps, which has been called on to plug strategic holes in the Middle East and Central America, is 194,600 strong, including 8,100 women. It is organized in three divisions from which the Marine Amphibious Units that have been used in Lebanon and Grenada are drawn.

headline: 12 Writers Arrested in Oslo
abstract: Twelve writers were arrested Thursday night after the police raided the homes of the editorial staff of Ikkevold, a leftist magazine accused of publishing military secrets that included the location of a United States submarine listening post in Norway, the authorities said today. The police said they confiscated printed material relevant to the case.

headline: ARAFAT AIDE ASKS PERSIAN GULF STATES FOR HELP
abstract: A high-ranking Palestinian official met tonight with leaders of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council to plead for support for Yasir Arafat, the chief of the Palestine Liberation Organization.    The Palestinian, Khalid al-Hassan, who is a businessman and member of the Central Committee of Al Fatah, conferred with Persian Gulf leaders as they assembled for a summit meeting.   Officials said a delegation would go to Syria on Tuesday to urge President Hafez al-Assad to stop the fighting between Syrian-backed Palestinian forces and those loyal to Mr. Arafat.

headline: U.S. Says Salvador Suspect Did Not Kill Military Adviser
abstract: The United States Embassy said today that a student arrested for the murder of an American military adviser is innocent and his confession was obtained by the Salvadoran authorities ''under duress.''

headline: MONDALE ASSAILS GRENADA MOVE AND A LACK OF SECURITY IN BEIRUT
abstract: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale charged today that the United States invasion of Grenada undermined ''our ability to effectively criticize'' Soviet suppression of liberty in Afghanistan, Poland and elsewhere.   Mr. Mondale said he was withholding final judgment on the military action until President Reagan provided a further explanation. ''They may have an argument, but if they do, we haven't heard it,'' Mr. Mondale said at a news conference called to announce that the American Federation of Teachers had endorsed him for the Democratic nomination for President.

headline: UNDER 1983 CHRISTMAS TREE, EXPECT THE HOME COMPUTER
abstract: This is the year in which the home computer will join the sled and the bicycle under the Christmas tree.    In numbers that outstrip even the most optimistic predictions, Commodores, Ataris and Colecos are being snapped up from the shelves. Americans have embraced the home computer as their favorite gadget for a Christmas present, replacing the food processors and video games of Christmases past.    ''Last year, computers were new, unique and expensive,'' said Egil Juliussen, president of Future Computing Inc., a market forecasting concern that expects 2.5 million home computers to be sold this Christmas, twice as many as last year. ''This year, they're cheap, and they have become    the    gift.''

headline: A ROSY OUTLOOK FOR ELECTION '84
abstract: -year-old Wall Street economist, was calculating the Misery Index last week, examining movements in the economic barometer used occasionally by Presidential challengers to embarrass White House incumbents. Adding the level of unemployment to the inflation rate, the director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company figured the index stood at 20.5 percent just before the 1980 elections that brought Ronald Reagan to Washington. Currently the index is hovering at 13.6 percent, and based on Mr. Wenglowski's forecast, it will creep up to only 14.5 percent by Election Day 1984 as inflation rises faster than unemployment drops.  ''These numbers say that Reagan makes it - things will be looking good for him on the economic front by Election Day,'' he said.    Such is the prevailing sentiment among a number of the nation's prominent economists, who were asked recently to gaze into their crystal balls for the 12 months until the Presidential election. Based on their current forecasts, the economy will treat Ronald Reagan well if he decides - as most observers think he will - to make a second run for the White House. Inflation, though moving up, will remain relatively subdued, they say, unemployment will continue its slow descent, the economy will continue to move ahead buoyantly and interest rates will trend downward.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The U.N. Today Nov. 3, 1983 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Political and Security Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Decolonization Committee - 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: West German G.N.P.
abstract: The real growth in West Germany's gross national product will be well over 1 percent in 1983 and at least 2.5 percent in 1984, the Finance Minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, said in a statement today. The economy shrank by 1.1 percent in 1982.

headline: Washington WatchClyde H. Farnsworth Ex-Im Bank's Planes for Sale
abstract: -10's are in mothballs in desert hangars at Yuma, Ariz., the unwanted property of the Export-Import Bank, which is still trying to sell them. The bank, a Federal agency that finances exports, provided $150 million of credit when Laker Airways bought the planes from McDonnell Douglas. When the airline collapsed last year, the Ex-Im Bank, as holder of the first mortgage, seized the planes.   Defense committees in Congress have been keenly interested in the affair. They have just been able to get some unsought advice to the bank written into the new military appropriations bill that cleared before Friday's adjournment.

headline: SOME IN CONGRESS QUESTION IF SECURITY WAS ADEQUATE
abstract: Members of Congress questioned the adequacy of security measures to protect American marines in Beirut today as the toll from Sunday's terrorist bombing rose to 216 dead.   The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, John Tower, told reporters after questioning Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger in a closed meeting that ''the consensus of the committee is that the security was not adequate.''   ''It is difficult to defend against terrorist attacks of that kind,'' said Senator Tower, Republican of Texas, ''but that threat could have been minimized, in my judgment.''   Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts and a member of the committee, asserted that ''quite clearly every security measure was not taken.'' He said Mr. Weinberger had tried to answer questions from the committee but ''not to my satisfaction.''

headline: SALVADORAN SAYS U.S. IS GIVING MIXED SIGNALS
abstract: President Reagan's decision to kill a bill that tied future military aid to El Salvador to an improvement in the country's human rights record has weakened the Salvadoran Government's resolve to confront the problem, according to Salvadoran politicians and political analysts here.   The officials said Mr. Reagan's decision on Wednesday was only one of a number of mixed signals from the United States that have undercut the Reagan Administration's strong statements against right-wing terror here.   ''Your Government never seems to have a clear policy,'' said one Salvadoran politician. ''Everyone here, the left and the extreme right, can read what they want to from the signals.''

headline: 40 Percent of Venice Flooded As High Tides Sweep the City
abstract: High tides washed over Venice today, and city officials said 40 percent of the city was flooded.

headline: BUSH GROUP'S PROPOSALS ON BANKING REGULATION
abstract: An Administration working group has agreed on a long list of changes meant to simplify Federal regulation of financial institutions, according to a statement from Vice President Bush's office.    The group, which Mr. Bush heads, is striving to send recommendations for legislative proposals to President Reagan within weeks. The President could modify the proposals before sending them to Congress.    Mr. Bush, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, Federal Reserve Board Chairman Paul A. Volcker and other members of the Task Group on Regulation of Financial Services met for three hours Thursday at the Vice President's home and reached agreement on some 30 proposals from the Bush staff.

headline: POPE BIDS WORLD FIGHT HUNGER NOT WAR
abstract: Pope John Paul II urged world leaders today to spend less on arms and to turn their attention to the ''unspeakable sorrow'' of starving children.   The Pope made the appeal in his annual Urbi et Orbi Christmas message to the city of Rome and the world, and afterward gave Christmas greetings in 43 different languages.   In his third such appeal in four days, John Paul urged world leaders to work out ''equitable and honorable'' solutions to global crises, ''which make ever more threatening the clouds gathering on the horizon of humanity.

headline: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 13, 1983
abstract: Companies   Federal bank regulators lent $100 million to First National of Midland, Tex., to keep it from failing before they can arrange a rescue by a stronger bank. The loan to the big bank, which has been hurt by losses on loans to energy companies, was one of the largest ever by the F.D.I.C. (Page A1.)    Ted Turner said he has bought The Satellite News Channels, the only challenger to his Cable News Network, from ABC and Westinghouse for $25 million. In two weeks, the Atlanta entrepreneur will shut down the rival operation, which has lost more than $40 million. Analysts saw the deal as a triumph for Mr. Turner. (D1.)

headline: CURRENCY AND STOCK SALES HALTED
abstract: Banks in Israel halted sales of foreign currency Monday and the stock exchange was shut for the second day as Government and banking officials tried to stem heavy sales of shekels.   The commercial banks closed their foreign currency counters at 11:15 A.M. until further notice on the instructions of the Bank of Israel, the nation's central bank. The unusual move came as the race to convert shekels into dollars, now in its second week, accelerated, even though a major source of shekels - the sale of companies' shares - was eliminated by the closing of the stock exchange.

headline: U.S. and Rumania Sign Pact
abstract: The United States and Rumania signed an agreement on cooperation in science, education, television and other fields, the United States Information Agency announced today. The two countries have had such agreements for 10 years.

headline: A DISABLED SOVIET SUB SURFACES OFF ATLANTIC COAST
abstract: United States Navy officials reported today that a nuclear-powered Soviet attack submarine had surfaced 470 miles off the South Carolina coast, apparently because of mechanical problems.    ''The sub seems to be experiencing some sort of mechanical problem,'' a Navy official said. ''But we don't know what the nature of the problem is. They aren't talking to us.''

headline: WHAT'S HAPPENING IN CANADIAN BUSINESS ; OIL SANDS WEALTH--A DREAM LIVES ON
abstract: OTTAWA Canada's oil sands have long been the stuff of extravagant dreams. In the mid-1970's, the futurist Herman Kahn vainly urged Canada to import 50,000 Koreans to build a new oil sands plant every three or four years. Three years ago, the corporate dream-makers were flying high with multibillion-dollar schemes to unlock the sticky black gold from the deep deposits in northern Alberta.

headline: Iran Reported to Execute 9
abstract: Iran has executed nine people convicted by a revolutionary court of trafficking in opium and heroin, Iran's state- run radio reported today. In a broadcast monitored by the British Broadcasting Corporation in London, Iran said all nine were put to death Saturday night and this morning.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Paradyne Cites S.E.C. Tactics     WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -   The Paradyne Corporation   today accused the Securities   and Exchange Commission of   using ''trickery and deceit'' in   investigating charges that   Paradyne violated securities   laws to obtain a $100 million   computer contract. Last March, the S.E.C. accused Paradyne, of Largo,   Fla., of violating securities   laws in fulfilling a contract   with the Social Security Administration. In its countercomplaint,   Paradyne charged that S.E.C.   staff attorneys engaged in   ''illegal action.''

headline: INDIAN POLICE RAIDTEMPLE AFTER SIKH CLASHES
abstract: Policemen firing tear gas broke up warring factions of Sikhs, then stormed the Sikhs' historic temple in Old Delhi today.   More than 20 people were injured in the clash between a group of New Delhi-based Sikhs supporting the policies of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and another group supporting a militant call for autonomy in northern Punjab state.   Plainclothes Sikh police officers then entered the Sisganj Sikh temple and arrested about a dozen members of the militant group, officials said. Steel-helmeted policemen fired 70 tear-gas canisters to stop the fighting between the rival groups before plainclothes officers stormed the temple, officials said.

headline: HARTFORD INSURANCE IN MCKINNON LINK
abstract: The Hartford Insurance Group said yesterday that it would buy a 23 percent interest in Thomson McKinnon Inc. and that it had arranged for the securities firm to market the Hartford's life insurance products.    The Hartford, a subsidiary of the ITT Corporation, will buy $75 million of newly issued shares in Thomson McKinnon. The insurance group said it had no plans to seek a controlling interest in the securities firm, which will continue to be independently managed.

headline: CREDIT RATES; Interest Rates Rise Again
abstract: Prices of Government securities slid and interest rates rose slightly for the second day this week in quiet credit market trading yesterday. Analysts said fears that the renewed strength of the economy might spark a less accommodative Federal Reserve policy had caused investors to retreat from the market.  Adding to market concern was the 9.50 to 9.38 percent Federal funds rate, which is the cost of overnight loans among banks. Analyst said the rate is firmer than it would be if the Federal Reserve were easing monetary policy. This rate prompted speculation that the Fed did not ease in September as many analysts thought. As a result of the uncertainty, dealers sold Government securities to bring prices down to attract buyers.

headline: Dow Rises by 3.46; Trading Slows
abstract: The stock market registered a modest advance in slower trading yesterday, despite growing apprehension over the turmoil in Grenada and Lebanon.    At the conclusion of trading, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 3.46 points, to 1,252.44. In the general market, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that declined by 896 to 692.

headline: A Return to the Wars From a Publishing Stint
abstract: Eric Weber, who dropped out of the agency business in order to run a book publishing company he formed, is returning with a vengeance - as executive vice president and head of one of the three creative divisions of Dancer Fitzgerald Sample.    The publishing company, which he built around his best-selling book, ''How to Pick Up Girls,'' will continue to operate.    Mr. Weber started in the advertising business in 1965 as a copywriter at Benton & Bowles, and later worked at Papert, Koenig, Lois and Young & Rubicam.

headline: ANTITRUST FIGHT ON FILM SHOWS
abstract: What Bernard Goldberg and Jeffrey Deneroff want to know is why ''Return of the Jedi,'' ''Octopussy,'' ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' and ''Superman II'' opened in more than 1,000 movie theaters around the country - but not in Greenwich Village.    For Mr. Goldberg and Mr. Deneroff, who own the 580-seat, four-screen Quad Cinema in the Village, the question is more than academic. They say the exclusion of their theater from hundreds of first-run movies has cost them $4 million since they opened in 1972.   In an antitrust suit that could go to trial before United States District Judge Leonard Sand as soon as Nov. 7, Mr. Goldberg and Mr. Deneroff are charging that the best movies are being kept away from the Quad by a conspiracy involving both the major movie distributors, such as Paramount, 20th Century-Fox and Warner Bros., and the major New York-area movie exhibitors, such as Walter Reade, Cinema 5 and Loews.   Triple Damages of $12 Million    If they can prove their case, they could not only shake up this city's movie theaters, but also win triple damages of $12 million.

headline: ARAFAT EMBRACES MUBARAK IN CAIRO IN RECONCILIATION
abstract: Yasir Arafat, who was evacuated from northern Lebanon Tuesday with 4,000 of his followers, met in Cairo today with President Hosni Mubarak.    It was Mr. Arafat's first visit to Cairo in six years. The Palestine Liberation Organization, which he heads, and 17 other members of the Arab League broke relations with Egypt because Egypt signed peace agreements with Israel.    The two men embraced on the steps of the presidential palace, then met in private for nearly two hours.

headline: GRENADIAN SAYS ISLAND WOULD PROBABLY RE-ELECT MAN OUSTED IN '79
abstract: Alister Hughes, a Grenadian journalist, said last week that if the Caribbean island's voters had to choose now, they would probably re-elect former Prime Minister Eric M. Gairy, whose regime in Grenada was overthrown in 1979. .   ''It wasn't pleasant under Gairy,'' Mr. Hughes said at a news conference in New York Tuesday, ''but he would be selected as the least undesirable.''   The journalist said the interim Government now in place was ''well- equipped to do the job'' and added that he hoped elections would be postponed for 18 or 24 months to allow new political parties time to develop.   Mr. Hughes made the comments before it was announced that Alister McIntyre, who was appointed to head the interim government, would not be able to take the post because of illness. The nature of his illness was not specified, but he is known to suffer from diabetes.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Associates Corp. of North America's $100 million issue of 11.85 percent senior notes due in 1989 was priced at par, through Salomon Brothers Inc. The issue is rated A1 by Moody's Investors Service and Ax by Standard & Poor's.     *  Crystal Oil Co.  filed an offering of $100 million of senior subordinated debentures due in 1998, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.     *  DWG Corp.  said its National Propane Corp. subsidiary filed an offering of $40 million of senior subordinated debentures due in 1998, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.     *  European Investment Bank's 250 million-mark issue of 8 percent bonds due in 1991 was priced at 99.75, to yield 8.04 percent, through Deutsche Bank.     *  First Texas Savings Association's $50 million issue of 11.55 percent certificates of deposit due in 1987 was priced at par, through Goldman, Sachs & Co.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Clevepak Corp.  said it had signed a five-year, $100 million revolving credit agreement with a group of four banks led by Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co.     *  Computer Products Inc.  announced that it would postpone its offering of $20 million of convertible Eurobonds due in 1998 until next year because of weak market demand. Underwriters were led by Shearson/American Express International Ltd.

headline: Medtronics Aide Indicted MIAMI, Dec. 11 (AP) - An executive for the world's largest producer of heart pacemakers was indicted by a Federal grand jury on Friday in connection with a plan to sell trade secrets to a rival company.
abstract: James J. Krieger, an international marketing director for the Medtronics Corporation in Minneapolis, was arrested in Miami last month while delivering 19 confidential documents to an undercover agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to the indictment.   The indictment said the agent posed as an official of the Miami- based Cordis Laboratories, the nation's second-largest producer of pacemakers.

headline: SmithKline
abstract: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation said it could have flat earnings in the fourth quarter, but it does not expect them to fall below those of the year earlier.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1983
abstract: The Economy Factory output rose 0.8 percent in October, the 11th consecutive monthly gain, the Federal Reserve reported. The increase was the smallest since the recession ended last November, reflecting a normal slowing of growth. Economists hailed new evidence of rising outlays for expansion and modernization. (Page D1.)  President Reagan urged Congress to raise the national debt limit to $1,600 billion. Otherwise, he warned, the Government will run out of cash Dec. 1. (A26.)

headline: Italian Prices Increase
abstract: Italian consumer prices rose 1.3 percent in September from August and were up 13.6 percent from September 1982, the State Statistical Institute reported today. The rise compares with a four-tenths of 1 percent monthly increase in August, when the year-to-year rise in the cost of living registered 13.7 percent.

headline: PENNZOIL SETS TALKS ON GETTY
abstract: J. Hugh Liedtke, chairman of the Pennzoil Company, said yesterday that Gordon P. Getty, head of a trust that controls 40 percent of the Getty Oil Company's stock, had agreed to meet with him soon to discuss a ''restructuring'' of Getty Oil.     Such a meeting, implying at least a willingness by Mr. Getty to listen, would come on the heels of Pennzoil's surprise offer Tuesday evening to pay $100 a share in cash for 16 million Getty shares, enough to give the big natural resources company 20 percent of Getty at a cost of $1.6 billion.    The offer put Pennzoil in the middle of a legal dispute between the management of Getty Oil on one side and the Sarah C. Getty Trust and the J. Paul Getty Museum that together control 52 percent of the stock on the other.    Moses Lasky, Mr. Getty's lawyer, said he had received a ''courtesy call'' from Pennzoil telling him Mr. Liedtke would call his client. ''Mr. Getty,'' he said, ''is conscious of his fiduciary obligation as a Getty director and a trustee to keep his eyes and ears open to anything that's for the benefit of the stockholders and the beneficiaries.'' He declined to comment further.

headline: DELAYS EXPECTED IN NOTIFYING KIN
abstract: Defense Department officials said today that identification of the military personnel killed in yesterday's terrorist bombing in Beirut has been slowed because some of the victims had not been wearing their combat identification tags and because records of many had been destroyed in the blast.   The loss of the records, some of which can eventually be duplicated from documents stored in the United States, has complicated the process of notifying the relatives of those dead who have been identified.   Although the toll of dead marines and sailors now stands at 192, Pentagon officials said that only about 20 families had been notified by late this afternoon.

headline: Chemical Workers in Austria Clash With Conservationists
abstract: Fights broke out between supporters of the international conservation group Greenpeace and workers at an Austrian chemical plant during a protest today against the deadly chemical dioxin, the police said.

headline: Chad's Leader Said to Agree In Principle to Talk to Rebel
abstract: At a French-African conference that ended today, the President of Chad was reported to have agreed in principle to talk with the leader of the forces battling his Government.   The 10th annual conference, which was attended by President Francois Mitterrand and representatives of 38 African countries with which France once had colonial ties, agreed unanimously that any solution to the war in Chad would have to preserve the unity and territorial integrity of Chad.

headline: No Headline
abstract: The U.N. Today Oct. 28, 1983 GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Special Political Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Economic and Financial Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Decolonization Committee - 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Williams Changes
abstract: The Williams Companies, which has acquired about 71 percent of of the Northwest Energy Company's shares outstanding, announced that five Northwest directors - including the chairman and chief executive officer, John G. McMillian - had resigned and been replaced by Williams nominees. Williams also said that Northwest's president, Thomas W. Dizerega, had resigned, and that Joseph H. Williams, chairman and chief executive officer of Williams, would become chairman of Northwest. Williams, an energy concern based in Tulsa, Okla., is offering $39 a share for Northwest's 29.8 milllion shares.

headline: KEY VICTIMS OF BOMB BLAST IN RANGOON
abstract: Suh Suk Joon    Appointed Deputy Prime Minister and Economic Planning Minister three months ago . . . At age of 45 the youngest Cabinet official in South Korea's history . . . A graduate of Vanderbilt University in Nashville, Tenn.  . . . Entered Government service in 1962 and served as Deputy Minister of Economic Planning before being appointed chief economic adviser to President Park Chung Hee in 1979 . . . Was Minister of Commerce and Industry before being named to his last post in July as part of a Government shift toward a more open economic policy favoring rapid turnover of types of industries.   Lee Bum Suk    Foreign Minister since June 1982 . . . 58 years old . . . A graduate of Korea University who also studied at the University of Maryland and George Washington University and spoke fluent English and Japanese . . . Made his reputation as a tough but tactful negotiator in 1972 and 1973 as leader of his country's Red Cross delegation at talks with North Korea on reunification of separated families . . . A career diplomat who served as chief protocol officer of the Foreign Ministry, Ambassador to India, Minister of National Unification and chief secretary to President Chun Doo Hwan . . . As Foreign Minister, led South Korea's negotiations for a $4 billion loan from Japan . . . Described by colleagues as ''gutsy'' in advocating his policies.   Kim Jae Ik    The President's chief economic adviser and Seoul's primary economic spokesman . . . 44 years old . . .  Considered along with Suh Suk Joon to have been a chief architect of South Korea's move toward more liberal economic policies . . . Holder of a Ph.D. from Stanford University who joined the Government in 1974 with the Economic Planning Board . . .  Joined the President's office three years ago and was instrumental in lowering the country's inflation rate.

headline: SOVIET CALLS U.S. AIR RAIDS IN LEBANON A 'SERIOUS THREAT TO PEACE'
abstract: The Soviet Union today ''resolutely condemned'' the American air raids against Syrian positions in Lebanon on Sunday, calling them ''a serious threat to peace in the Middle East, and not only in that region.''   A ''Tass statement'' - a format that represents an official Government position - said the ''unprovoked raid of the U.S. air force was perpetrated obviously to deliberately aggravate the situation in Lebanon and around it, and to create a pretext for further escalation of the U.S. acts of aggression against Syria.''   The statement by Tass, the official Soviet press agency, came after a press conference at which Soviet political and military spokesmen similarly condemned the American raids.

headline: U.S. IS QUITTING UNESCO, AFFIRMS BACKING FOR U.N.
abstract: The United States formally announced today that it intended to withdraw from Unesco in a year's time. But at the same time, it said that it would strengthen its participation in the United Nations and other international agencies.   In a letter to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said, ''We wish you to understand that our withdrawal from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization does not presage any wider disengagement from the United Nations or its other specialized agencies.''   Gregory J. Newell, the Assistant Secretary of State for International Organizations, said at a news conference this afternoon that the United States ''not only remained committed but would redouble its efforts'' in the other organizations. The decision to withdraw from Unesco, he said, was made only after the group refused to adjust its policies to meet American and other Western complaints.

headline: TAXING PERKS
abstract: To the Business Editor:     In enumerating examples of perks that would be affected, Representative Stark does not mention anything about perks enjoyed by Congressmen. Expense monies, allowances for staff (with employment of relatives), postal fees, subsidized dining facilities, no-charge health care, junkets to far-off places - would Congressmen pay taxes on any of these?   JOHN CLIFFORD Bayside, N.Y., Sept. 19

headline: SALVADOR REBELS SEIZE TOWN
abstract: Leftist guerrillas have seized Ciudad Barrios, the second city in eastern El Salvador they have attacked this week, and heavy fighting was reported in the area today.   A Defense Ministry spokesman confirmed that the rebels attacked and seized control of Ciudad Barrios on Monday, a day after they pulled out of the nearby town of Tejutepeque.

headline: Playboy Loss Is Narrowed
abstract: Playboy Enterprises yesterday reported a loss for the fiscal first quarter, ended Sept. 30, of $1.4 million - less than the $2.4 million loss of a year earlier.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Michigan General Corp.  has extended its exchange offer to holders of its 10 7/8 percent senior sinking fund debentures due 1992 and its 14 percent senior sinking fund debentures due 1992.      Common Stock     *  Advanced Computer Communications amended a registration statement for a proposed initial public offering of 1.2 million shares; 1 million will be sold by the company and the rest by shareholders, through Wertheim & Co.     *  Bell Industries announced an initial public offering of 650,000 common shares at $32 each, through Goldman Sachs.

headline: F.C.C. Levies A.T.&T. Fine
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission voted today to fine the American Telephone and Telegraph Company $80,000 for its failure, along with one of its Bell System companies, to abide by rules governing the deregulation of telephone equipment.   The fine was levied for violations of the agency's Computer II decision, which, among other things, specified that after Jan. 1, 1983, neither A.T.&T. nor the Bell companies could engage in the sale or lease of newly made telephones unless they established a separate subsidiary. The Northwestern Bell Telephone Company was in violation of the rules in Iowa, the F.C.C. said.

headline: PATENTS; Building Blocks Made From Soil
abstract: Harry C. Sangree, now a graduate student at the Columbia University Business School, realized some years ago, while on volunteer work in Zaire, that there was a need for cheap building materials in such countries. This week he was granted patent 4,406,606 for apparatus to make building blocks from soil.

headline: Need in U.S. For Arab Oil
abstract: The Reagan Administration formally abandoned today the national goal of energy independence, saying that the United States would rely ''to some extent'' on Arab oil imports for at least the next 20 years.   But the Administration, introducing its latest National Energy Policy Plan, said Americans should enjoy relatively stable gasoline prices for the rest of this decade.

headline: CHICAGO'S MERCANTILE EXCHANGE MAKES ITS MOVE
abstract: Amid the usual fanfare and the ordinary vexations, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange today moved back across the Chicago River to a new 40-story headquarters - its third trading floor in the past 12 years.   After a round of speeches by such dignitaries as M. Susan Phillips, the new chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, Mayor Harold Washington rang the opening bell at 7:30 A.M. In the excitement that followed, exchange officials forgot to cut the chocolate-frosted cake shaped like the new skyscraper.   There were other incidents, too. Clerks complained that telephone cords were not long enough. Computer terminal operators, accustomed to transcribing hand-written data, strained to hear the squeaky voices on the new walkie-talkies in the pits.

headline: BUILDING OF 2 SHIPS LIFTS HOPES IN U.S.
abstract: In a move that may point to a revival of the dormant American passenger cruise industry, a $230 million contract has been signed by the Marine Power and Equipment Company of Seattle for construction of the first luxury liners to be built in the United States in more than two decades.    The contract, for two 800-passenger vessels to be completed within the next four years, may also establish a heartening precedent for passenger shipbuilding in this country, an industry that has been all but strangled in recent years by low-cost, often-subsidized foreign competition.    ''This will be a boon to American shipyards, which today have very little backlog and are kept alive by Government contracts,'' said Lesa Sroufe, an analyst with Foster & Marshall/American Express in Seattle who follows the shipbuilding industry. ''It will also mean jobs for repair yards. A lot of shipyards have added drydocks to make up for the lack of shipbuilding work.''

headline: Data Bank; November 27, 1983
abstract: THE ECONOMY

headline: BOARD CHAIRMAN RESIGNS AT GHH
abstract: Manfred Lennings, the management board chairman of Gutehoffnungsh"utte, or GHH, Europe's biggest machine-building group, will step down next month, company officials said yesterday.    The officials said the group's supervisory board is expected to accept the resignation of Mr. Lennings, 49 years old, at a meeting in Frankfurt Nov. 8, because of disagreement over how to turn around the group's troubled machine-building unit, Maschinenfabrik Augsburg-N"urnberg A.G., or M.A.N.   They said the board would likely appoint Klaus G"otte, 51, a former executive of the Flick group who is now a member of M.A.N.'s supervisory board, to succeed Mr. Lennings.

headline: Computer Snag Halts Trading
abstract: Futures trading at the New York Commodity Exchange Center was interrupted yesterday afternoon - and halted for some commodities - because of a computer failure, the exchange announced. Officials said the problem occurred at about 2:30 P.M., just before the final bell in silver and gold trading, and that those contracts were settled.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Previous   Year

headline: ISRAEL IS A TOPIC AT LEBANON UNITY TALKS
abstract: The first substantive round in the Lebanese unity conference began today with Syria and its anti-Government Lebanese allies asking that the American-sponsored Israeli-Lebanese withdrawal accord be scrapped, conference sources said.  Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam of Syria, nominally an observer at the conference, was said to have taken an active role in the five hours of talks in the Carnival restaurant atop the Intercontinental Hotel.  According to one conferences source, he behaved as if he had Soviet backing to press for the abrogation of the Israeli-Lebanese accord worked out in May.  The Christian Lebanese Front, a pro- Israeli group led by Camille Chamoun, asked that critics of the accord put forward their own alternative for insuring an Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon, the conference sources said. No alternative was offered.

headline: NEW INQUIRY TEAM NAMED BY MARCOS
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos named a new panel today to investigate the assassination of his chief political rival, Benigno S. Aquino Jr.   The new commission consists of a retired judge, a corporate lawyer, a pro- Government union official, a university vice president and an appliance manufacturer.   Mr. Marcos pledged on Friday to name a panel of private citizens after Arturo Tolentino, a member of the National Assembly, declined for the second time to head the inquiry. Mr. Tolentino said he and the Assembly would lose credibility. He had advocated an investigation carried out entirely by private citizes.

headline: ;  Many Facets
abstract: To the Business Editor:   -Studded Losses,'' should have mentioned several points.     * The item concerned itself exclusively with investment-grade diamonds. But most consumers buy jewelry-grade diamonds and not investment diamonds.

headline: Debt Issues
abstract: *  Buttes Gas & Oil Co.  announced that its offshore contract drilling subsidiary had concluded a $113 million financing agreement with a group of banks led by Security Pacific National Bank.     *  Chase Manhattan Corp.  filed for an offering of $300 million of floating rate extendable notes due in 1992, through Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. Chase said the interest rate for the first three years would be adjusted weekly for an undetermined spread above the bond-equivalant of the three-month treasury bill auction rate.     *  Commonwealth Edison Co.'s two- part bond offering totaling $200 million was offered through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Co. The $100 million of 12 1/4 percent bonds due in 1991 and the $100 million of 13 3/8 percent bonds due in 2013 were both offered at a price of 100. Both issues were rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBBx by Standard & Poor's.

headline: Law Firm Embraces Bankruptcy Business
abstract: A newly formed and little known law firm, McCabe/Gordon of Boston, has been finding its share of business in the growing field of bankruptcy proceedings and company reorganization.    The firm, formed just seven months ago by Edmond McCabe and Steve Gordon, has been involved in three of the major bankruptcy proceedings in the United States.

headline: CHILEAN LAND AGAIN SEIZED BY HOMELESS
abstract: For the last three years, Carlos Rodriguez and his young wife had been sleeping on the floor of a friend's kitchen. So when they heard several weeks ago that a group of homeless families was planning to take over a plot of public land and set up homesteads there, Mr. and Mrs. Rodriguez eagerly joined them.    Standing in front of the tiny tent he has built from cardboard and plastic, Mr. Rodriguez said that although his new home was far from ideal, it was an improvement over what he had before.   ''The way I was living was no good,'' he told a visitor to the makeshift camp on the south side of Santiago where 20,000 homeless Chileans are now living.

headline: ISLAMIC AIDES MEETING TO DISCUSS P.L.O. RIFT
abstract: Islamic foreign ministers will discuss ways to end the conflict between rival factions in the Palestine Liberation Organization at a five-day conference of Moslem nations scheduled to open here on Tuesday, conference sources said today.   Officials from the Islamic Conference Organization are scheduled to meet in Dhaka Sunday to draw up an agenda for the meeting.

headline: Spain's Parliament Votes To Ease Abortion Law
abstract: The Socialist majority in Parliament voted today to legalize abortion in certain cases. It would be the first such legalization in nearly a half century.

headline: LEBANESE ADJOURN PARLEY IN GENEVA
abstract: Representatives of Lebanon's warring factions adjourned today after a week of meetings that produced proposals for legal, political and electoral changes.   The delegates said they would take the proposals to the leaders of the factions for discussion before a second round of the national reconciliation conference, which is expected to start here within a week.

headline: STATUS OF ARMS NEGOTIATIONS These are the arms control negotiations that are now under way:
abstract: Strategic Arms Talks - The United States and the Soviet Union are discussing limitation of long-range nuclear delivery systems. The talks, which are a continuation of negotiations that go back to 1969, resumed in June 1982 and after a recess are to resume Thursday in Geneva.

headline: U.S. AIDES PESSIMISTIC ON SOVIET TIES
abstract: In the aftermath of the Soviet downing of a South Korean airliner, some officials in the Reagan Administration say that American and Soviet officials may have lost their ability to hold serious discussions.    Several senior officials and Soviet affairs experts in the Government said in recent interviews they were worried that the coincidence of the attack on the plane and the expected start of NATO's deployment of new American missiles in Western Europe in December might produce the most dramatic confrontation between Moscow and Washington since the Berlin and Cuban crises of the early 1960's.   Soviet Intentions Uncertain    However, the officials say they can only guess what the Soviet Union will do if, as expected, the negotiations in Geneva fail to produce an accord on limiting missiles and if the deployment of the 572 new missiles in West Germany, Britain and Italy begins on schedule.   Some senior officials, including President Reagan, seem persuaded that despite repeated Soviet threats of some kind of retaliation for the missile deployment, there will be no serious crisis.

headline: U.S. ENVOY CASTIGATES SALVADORANS ON TERRORISM
abstract: The United States Ambassador to El Salvador said tonight that the unwillingness of the Salvadoran Government to take action against the right-wing death squads ''runs an extremely serious risk'' of provoking a cutoff of aid.  The Ambassador, Thomas R. Pickering, added that such intransigence could call into question the capacity of the United States to support democracy in El Salvador.  The Ambassador made his remarks in a question and answer period after delivering a speech in which he said that ''extremist terror'' is the ''essential stumbling block to democracy in El Salvador.'' He called the work of the death squads ''another case of fascists serving the Communist cause.''    ''There is information available to many of us about some of the personalities involved,'' Mr. Pickering said. ''My deep concern is that no one seems to be trying to develop evidence which would stand up in court.''

headline: THE CORPORATE ASSAULT ON WAGES
abstract: TROUBLED American corporations, beset by deregulation and imports, are stepping up their campaign for labor concessions and their efforts are paying off.     By threatening plant closings and insolvency and by using new weapons such as going into bankruptcy court to reorganize, management has succeeded in driving union wage increases to their lowest level in years. Even the mightiest unions such as the steelworkers and auto workers have been put on the defensive by management's demands for concessions.    But labor, still reeling from large- scale layoffs, is starting to regroup and is increasing its resistance to givebacks.   ''Concessions used to be a rare and isolated event,'' said George M. Perry, an economist at the Brookings Institution. ''If you asked what portion of settlements in any past year contained concessions, the answer would be zero or 3 percent. Last year and this year, however, about half the major contracts have contained concessions.''

headline: Alcoa Project
abstract: The Aluminum Company of America announced a $250 million factory modernization that officials said would save the jobs of 4,100 people in this town named for the company.

headline: Allis to Reset Aswan Blades
abstract: American engineers from the Allis-Chalmers Company of Wisconsin will start work on replacing the turbine blades of Egypt's Aswan Dam in January 1985, a United States official said today.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Officers Picked For I.D.S. Unit The American Express Company announced yesterday that   it planned to name Walter D.   Scott chairman of Investors Diversified Services when its recent merger with the insurance   and investment management   company is completed in early   1984. Mr. Scott is currently   president and chief executive   officer of I.D.S. American Express also said   Harvey Golub would take Mr.   Scott's current positions. Mr.   Golub is a partner in McKinsey   & Company. Also, Michael B.   Panitch, currently vice chairman of Shearson/American   Express Inc., is to become vice   chairman of I.D.S.

headline: Uniguard Mutual Gets New Chief Executive
abstract: Richard S. L. Roddis says he will miss teaching tort and insurance law at the University of Washington in Seattle because ''I love law and my students are very bright.''   He has been named chairman and chief executive of the Uniguard Mutual Insurance Company, effective Feb. 1, replacing Jay D. Porter, who retires in January at age 65. The company, based in Seattle, wrote $220 million in earned premiums in 1982, with the bulk of business focused in Western states. Mr. Roddis has served as a director of the company and its subsidiary, the Olympic Life Insurance Company, since 1971.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1983    International The House voted to require foreign cars sold in the U.S.  to be built in large part with American parts and labor. The measure is aimed chiefly at the Japanese, whose cars now hold nearly 20 percent of the U.S. market. It has little support in the Senate, however, and is strongly opposed by the Administration. (Page A1.)  As Bonn tried to unravel the tangled bank deals of Schr"oder M"unchmeyer, Hengst & Company, West German banks installed a management team to run the private firm. The bank's problems, apparently stemming from liabilities incurred by its Luxembourg subsidiary, could be the worst shock to Luxembourg's lending market since the collapse of Banco Ambrosiano. (D1.)

headline: Niger Arrests 26
abstract: Twenty-six people have been arrested in Niger in connection with a plot to overthrow the Government on Oct. 5, the Niger radio quoted President Seyni Kountche as saying today. They were not identified.

headline: ;  Invisible Hand
abstract: To the Business Editor:   Prof. Robert Dorfman (''A Nobel Quest for the Invisible Hand,'' Oct. 23) observes that it is not easy for a noneconomist to appreciate the fundamental and enduring problems of the foundations of the science of economics. Maybe, but maybe not.    The invisible hand is thought ''powerful'' and ''subtle'' (Professor Dorfman's labels) because it promises to convert individualistic anarchy (''each to his/her own'') into equilibrium and social stability. Those who seek ''scientific proof'' that the achievement is possible are bound to reap such rewards as Nobels, and so they do. Professor Dorfman, however, would have done better to deal with the question he posed but then ignored: ''Where is the assurance . . . that a host of businessmen flocking to an industry that promises high profits will not so flood the market that their products sell for less than they cost?''

headline: MARCOS SAYS REVIVAL OF THE SUCCESSION ISSUE IS PART OF A CONSPIRACY
abstract: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, under growing pressure from Philippine businessmen to allow election of a vice president, said revival of the issue is a conspiracy that could weaken his power, according to a statement issued today by the presidential palace.   ''That will make me a lame-duck president because the Vice President is elected while the President is not,'' Mr. Marcos was quoted as saying in Baguio on his first visit outside the capital in four months. ''That's ridiculous.''

headline: GRENADIANS ARE SEARCHING THROUGH RUBBLE OF ASYLUM
abstract: Custodians wearing face masks dug through the rubble today at the Grenada Mental Hospital where at least 17 people were said to have been killed Oct. 25 by American bombs.   As some of the inmates bellowed from locked and undamaged cells, Lennox Hotteley, a 28-year-old guard who was assisting in the clean-up operations, described how American planes flew over a nearby army headquarters as an antiaircraft gun 75 yards from the asylum kept firing away.   The hospital is one of several institutions atop a high ridge overlooking the harbor. To the south, about 100 yards away is Fort Frederick, where the command of the Grenadian Army had been gathered. Nearby is an old-age home, a home for brain-damaged boys and a tuberculosis sanitarium.

headline: James River Says Debt Is Revamped
abstract: The James River Corporation announced that it had completed the restructuring of its $525 million of debt and credit lines.   The company said the restructuring included the exchange of $39 million of preferred stock in a subsidiary for James River preferred stock, the conversion of $11.1 million of James River preferred stock, and the redemption of $5 million of convertible preferred stock.

headline: Begin Is Absent From Rites At Wife's Grave in Jerusalem
abstract: A memorial stone was laid at the grave of the wife of former Prime Minister Menachem Begin on the Mount of Olives overlooking the Old City today, but Mr. Begin did not attend the ceremony.

headline: The U.N. Today; Oct. 10, 1983
abstract: GENERAL ASSEMBLY   Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.   Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 3 P.M.   Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10:30 A.M.   Legal Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: ARMS AID TO NICARAGUA STILL RISING, U.S. SAYS
abstract: In the face of American Navy exercises off the coast of Nicaragua since late July, the flow of military supplies from the Soviet Union, Cuba and Eastern Europe continues to increase, State Department officials said today.    But officials specializing in Central America contend that since the Reagan Administration stepped up pressure against Nicaragua last summer, the Nicaraguan Government has agreed to a draft regional declaration of objectives to foster elections and democratic institutions, to remove outside military advisers and to halt outside military aid to the region.   Representatives of nine Latin American countries, meeting in Panama from Sept. 7 to 10, reached general agreement on a 21-point declaration embracing those objectives, but the declaration has not been released pending final approval by the nine governments. Administration officials said they would regard it as a major diplomatic gain for Nicaragua to commit itself formally to such objectives.

headline: A 3d U.S.-Employed Linguist Seized at Guatemalan Home
abstract: Kidnappers seized a Guatemalan linguist working for the Agency for International Development last week, the third A.I.D. teacher abducted in about a month, officials said today.

headline: Turkish Newspapers Banned
abstract: Turkey's martial law authorities banned the daily newspapers Gunaydin and Tan today for an indefinite period, newspaper officials said. No reason was given for the ban, but newspaper sources said they believed it was imposed because the papers did not carry a portrait of the founder of the Turkish republic, Kemal Ataturk, on their front pages Saturday, the 60th anniversary of the republic.

headline: Japan's Sales Of VTR's Up
abstract: Japan's exports of videotape recorders rose to a record monthly high of 1.47 million units in September, the Electronics Industries Association of Japan said today.

headline: SHAMIR AND EGYPTIAN HOLD TALKS
abstract: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir met with a ranking Egyptian official today and voiced confidence that the two nations could ''reach a good agreement'' if talks resumed on Palestinian self- rule, an Israeli spokesman said.   The Egyptian, Shafei Abdel Hamid, who is an Assistant Foreign Minister, is the first high-ranking Egyptian to come here since Israel invaded Lebanon 18 months ago.

headline: U.S. CONCERNED BY DELIVERY OF FRENCH WARPLANES TO IRAQ
abstract: Reagan Administration officials said today that they were increasingly concerned that shipments of oil from the Persian Gulf might be disrupted by Iran now that five French Super Etendard jet fighters have been delivered to Iraq.   The officials said, however, that they saw no immediate crisis since it would take Iraqi pilots four to six weeks before they could fly the French jets in combat. The Administration's concern is that the Iraqis might attack Iranian oil installations and possibly incite the Iranians to retaliate by stopping oil shipments through the Persian Gulf.

headline: No Headline
abstract: Radio Grand Forks GRAND FORKS, N.D., Nov. 3 (AP) - Radio Grand Forks Associates said it had sold radio stations KNOX-AM and KYTN-FM for $3 million to Red River Associates, a group of businessmen in Ithaca, N.Y. Radio Grand Forks Associates, based in Peoria, Ill., is owned by The Peoria Journal Star newspaper. The transfer is subject to regulatory approval.

headline: Waldheim Seeks Discretion
abstract: Kurt Waldheim, former Secretary General of the United Nations, called on the United States and the Soviet Union today to return to quiet diplomacy.

headline: WEST GERMANS START MISSILE PROTESTS
abstract: Several thousand demonstrators tried to blockade a United States Army barracks in Bremerhaven today. It was the first major action of a planned 10 days of protests against the deployment of American medium-range nuclear weapons in West Germany.   Early this morning, riot policemen laid down huge coils of barbed wire and cordoned off the Carl Schurz barracks in Bremerhaven, preventing demonstrators from getting near the base's perimeter a mile away. Police armored cars patrolled the streets of the northern German port city, and water cannon stood by.

headline: SHULTZ-GROMYKO MEETING POSSIBLE AT ARMS CONFERENCE IN JANUARY
abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz indicated today that he might meet with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, at an East-West conference on disarmament in Stockholm Jan. 17.    Several Western European nations, especially West Germany, have been urging that the 35-nation conference on developing safeguards against surprise attacks be begin with foreign ministers present.  Mr. Shultz, at a breakfast meeting with reporters, indicated he would not oppose that effort, although he declined to say specifically that he would meet with his Soviet counterpart.   ''It seems to be shaping up as a meeting to which foreign ministers will go,'' he said. ''If that's the way it emerges, then the United States will be represented.''

headline: White House Urges M-1 Rise
abstract: The White House would like the M-1 money supply to grow somewhat faster and return to the target range set by the Federal Reserve, Larry Speakes, the chief White House spokesman, said today. ''We would like to see M-1 money growth get back within its target range in order to reflect a slow steady growth in the money supply,'' he told reporters.

headline: Nissan Net Down 27%
abstract: The Nissan Motor Company, the maker of Datsun autos and trucks, said today that its net income fell 27 percent in the six months ended Sept. 30, despite a 3 percent rise in sales. The company said it earned $153 million in the latest six months on sales of $7.20 billion, compared with $211 million on sales of $6.99 billion in the comparable period last year.

headline: ADVERTISING ;  Addendum
abstract: * McCall's magazine increasing its advertising rates 8 percent with the February issue.

headline: Suriname Reports Sabotage By Striking Bauxite Workers
abstract: The Government said today that striking bauxite workers had damaged transmission lines and tried to drain oil from an electric transformer.   It said the sabotage Tuesday came as the bauxite workers and striking bank employees renewed their protest against higher income taxes scheduled to go into effect Jan. 1.

headline: Canadian Steel Decline
abstract: Canadian steel ingot production in the week ended Nov. 25 declined 2.5 percent from a week earlier, to 308,281 tons, Statistics Canada said today.

headline: Kissinger Panel Arrives In Panama for Talks
abstract: A United States commission headed by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger arrived here late tonight to begin a weeklong, six-nation tour of Central America.

headline: Steel Accord At E.E.C.;  E.E.C. Reaches Steel Accord BRUSSELS, Dec. 22 (AP) - Industry ministers from the 10 nations in the European Economic Community reached agreement today on an emergency program to stop cutthroat competition that they say is destroying their steel industry.
abstract: The program sets minimum prices for products that make up 40 percent of the steel output in the Common Market. The goal is to prevent price wars that have broken out in recent years among producers trying to sell excess production on markets already burdened by a steel glut.

headline: ARGENTINE DEBT REQUEST
abstract: Officials at Argentina's major creditor banks in the United States sought yesterday to clarify a request by Argentina that it be allowed to delay for six months payment of interest and principal due on its foreign debt.     Many of the banks apparently had not yet received copies of a telex message that the Argentine Economics Minister, Bernardo Grinspun, sent late Thursday to William R. Rhodes, a senior vice president at Citibank and chairman of the 12-bank advisory committee.   In that message, Mr. Grinspun said Argentina ''does not intend to request any moratorium or repudiate any executed agreements.'' He also asked Mr. Rhodes to inform creditors that Argentina would complete the refinancing of billions of dollars of overdue public-sector debt by the end of June or earlier.

headline: French Output Up
abstract: France's gross domestic product rose five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, revised from a gain of two- tenths of 1 percent, the Government's statistics institute said today. This compared with a decline of two- tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter and a gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent a year earlier.

headline: Advertising; Cable's Traveling Teacher
abstract: NOW that he has steeped himself in the mysteries of the new electronic media, Richard L. Gilbert, an ad agency president for 25 years, is preparing to take to the road to spread his knowledge.   Starting next Friday in Detroit and then moving during January from St. Louis to Kansas City, and then to Philadelphia, Dick Gilbert will share with the advertising practitioners his belief that on its first time around, at least, cable TV has been a flop.   ''There has been so much hype and hoopla that someone should go out and give the agencies an overview,'' he said with himself obviously in mind for the job.

headline: U.S. CASUALTIES IN GRENADA
abstract: The Army has identified these additional United States servicemen killed or wounded in the fighting in Grenada: Killed LUCAS, Capt. Keith Joseph, Fort Campbell,   Ky.

headline: NICARAGUAN PRESENTS STATE DEPT. WITH 4 TREATIES ON LATIN AMERICA
abstract: Nicaragua's Foreign Minister presented the Reagan Administration today with four draft agreements that he said were ''concrete and detailed proposals for the guaranteeing of the international peace and security of all the Central American states.''   The official, Miguel d'Escoto Brockman, met for an hour with Langhorne A. Motley, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affiars, returning a visit by Mr. Motley to Nicaragua 10 days ago.   Mr. Brockman described the exchange of visits as ''an indication that perhaps there's an interest in pursuing the situation along diplomatic lines and perhaps the possibility of rejecting the military way.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST TUESDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1983
abstract: Companies    Kirk Kerkorian wants to take MGM/UA private in a deal valued at $452.2 million. The reclusive Las Vegas financier already controls 50.1 percent of the entertainment company's shares. As a result, analysts said, it was unclear how much of a voice other shareholders would have in assessing the bid. (Page D1.)    Greyhound strikers voted overwhelmingly to accept a three- year contract and end their seven-week strike. The bus company hoped to have full service restored by tomorrow. (A1.)

headline: Filipino Rebels Kill 8
abstract: Gunmen believed to be Moslem separatist rebels ambushed an army truck on Mindanao Island, killing six soldiers and two civilians, including a 2-year- old boy, the Philippine News Agency reported today. One of those wounded in the attack, in Lanao del Sur Province, 500 miles southeast of Manila, was the father of the boy who was killed, the report said.

headline: TRADE DATA SOUGHT ON BULLION DEALER
abstract: New York State officials said yesterday that they were investigating whether a West Coast gold dealer who committed suicide a week ago might have suffered multimillion-dollar losses in the gold and silver market.    David Fishlow, spokesman for Attorney General Robert Abrams, said that Wall Street commodities dealers were being canvassed about any business they might have transacted with Alan David Saxon, or the precious metals company of which he was chairman, Bullion Reserve of North America.   In Los Angeles, meanwhile, District Attorney Robert Philibosian said that Mr. Saxon, his company and ''people associated with the company'' were under investigation for possible grand theft.   Mr. Philibosian added that, even though the Los Angeles coroner's office had called Mr. Saxon's death a suicide by carbon monoxide poisosing, he was not fully convinced that Mr. Saxon had killed himself. Mr. Saxon's body was found in his ground- floor sauna bath with a hose running to a motorcycle outside.
